Jan 4, 2025 A Talking points Comprehensive policy document dated January 4, 2025 (Don's final education thinking), presenting mature formulations of… ▸ more
Comprehensive policy document dated January 4, 2025 (Don's final education thinking), presenting mature formulations of his education reform vision. Reiterates the six life roles framework and emphasizes education as a service system. Provides detailed definitions of key terms and discusses anticipated changes including increased independent learners, adult in-service education, professional autonomy, service expansion beyond schools, government service identification, student choice, accountability, and private sector involvement. Lists priority issues: terminology shift, purpose, services, structure, autonomy, accountability, in-service training, grading, and establishing a PEI Education Association. Includes specific observations about PEI education system deficiencies and recommendations for improvement.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL

2025 Definitions (2) Guardian letter advocating for common definitions in education discourse. Don proposes the definition "any experience… ▸ more
Guardian letter advocating for common definitions in education discourse. Don proposes the definition "any experience that has a formative effect on the way a person thinks, feels or acts" and calls on PEI's Department of Education to develop and publish clear definitions of key terms to improve institutional clarity and communication.

2025 structuring Letter titled "Restructuring Needed" outlining five structural issues: purpose (need to define life roles better),… ▸ more
Letter titled "Restructuring Needed" outlining five structural issues: purpose (need to define life roles better), services (information, counselling, instruction, products, technology, quality assurance, governance, funding, HR), structure (organize by function not clients), autonomy (teacher freedom to respond to learner needs), and accountability (autonomy with accountability jointly applied). Emphasizes these are not new issues but require public dialogue and action.

2025 structurer Extended letter based on PEI school trustee's comments years ago about need for structural reform. Addresses vision… ▸ more
Extended letter based on PEI school trustee's comments years ago about need for structural reform. Addresses vision (public statement of goals/ideals/values—PEI philosophy statement lacks detail), conceptual clarity (distinguishing education from schooling), structure (services vs. clients served), accountability, and collaboration. Concludes these issues, while not unique or new, collectively hobble education's ability to serve and should be modified or discarded.

2025 structure Editor Comprehensive letter on structural impediments to education improvement. Traces concerns from PEI school trustee and… ▸ more
Comprehensive letter on structural impediments to education improvement. Traces concerns from PEI school trustee and Education 2020 Inc. (2015). Critiques confusion of "education" with "going to school." Emphasizes "form follows function" principle and OECD/World Bank research on school autonomy and PISA results. Notes Mathew Bedard's finding that "autonomy and accountability jointly applied" costs nothing. Advocates functional restructuring highlighting instruction, counselling, information rather than school administration.

Letter showing government departments typically organize by function/service (Agriculture by crops/livestock/policy; Health by care/children/drugs; Transportation by drivers/roads). Observes PEI Education appears organized around clients served rather than services offered. Advocates restructuring around essential skills, life roles, or service functions to refocus on education service provision.

Supports his clarity/terminology work by organizing structural hierarchy. Supports broader argument for precise organizational and definitional clarity.

2025 framework Comprehensive educational framework document articulating education as a service, economic sector, and performance… ▸ more
Comprehensive educational framework document articulating education as a service, economic sector, and performance standard. Contextualizes education within community (PEI population 160,000), individual life roles (individual, family member, citizen, consumer, producer), and essential learning domains (math, science, communication, soft skills, self-care). Emphasizes that community futures depend on educational quality and that education must serve multiple life roles, not just academic preparation.

Letter critiquing PEI education terminology and organizational structure. Points out that Department of Education describes role narrowly as "developing and delivering curriculum" rather than helping people gain skills. Notes that PEI replaced "education" with "school" in legislation, limiting systemic scope. Urges Department to clarify and republish its mission.

2025 Structure Comprehensive letter calling for clarity and structural change. Don identifies six issues: (1) purpose is unclear; (2)… ▸ more
Comprehensive letter calling for clarity and structural change. Don identifies six issues: (1) purpose is unclear; (2) vision is too narrow (youth-focused); (3) education and schooling are conflated; (4) organizational structure ignores functions; (5) teachers/principals lack operational freedom despite OECD/World Bank recommendations; (6) collaboration literature conflicts with actual silos. He advocates for refocusing from schools to education, from standardized metrics to improvement measures, from credentials to competencies.

2025 Social Capital Letter exploring social capital in education systems. Don defines it as relationships arising from "knowing,… ▸ more
Letter exploring social capital in education systems. Don defines it as relationships arising from "knowing, collaborating and socializing" with others. He cites examples: sharing classes, "Ag for Life Day" at Bluefield High School, team teaching, parent-teacher collaboration, and community projects. Reflects personally that he benefited greatly from social capital-building opportunities created by mentors and colleagues throughout his career. Incomplete draft noting research supports the importance of interpersonal relationships and networks.

2025 Services.3 Letter identifying nine typical education services drawn from literature: Information, Counselling,… ▸ more
Letter identifying nine typical education services drawn from literature: Information, Counselling, Governance/Leadership, Instruction, Quality Assurance, Learning Products/Technology, Funding, Human Resources, and Data tracking. Don argues these services are currently available in schools but mostly to youth, and should also serve independent learners without requiring school enrollment. He reflects that pandemic response would have been easier with a comprehensive education system in place.

2025 Roleof Dept Letter noting that Islanders expect a broader Department role than "curriculum development." Don cites comparisons: New… ▸ more
Letter noting that Islanders expect a broader Department role than "curriculum development." Don cites comparisons: New Brunswick (helping citizens gain lifelong learner attributes), Alberta (economy-focused skills), and anonymous sources (helping people navigate life and contribute to society). He emphasizes the vast difference between delivering curriculum and developing people, recommending an update to the Department's stated role.

2025 Role of Depaetment Letter dated May 23, 2025, arguing that the Department of Education's defined role is too narrow. Rather than… ▸ more
Letter dated May 23, 2025, arguing that the Department of Education's defined role is too narrow. Rather than "developing and delivering curriculum," Don proposes the role should be "creating experiences that cause others to learn" regardless of age. He calls for the role to be reviewed, revised if necessary, and widely circulated throughout the education system.

2025 Role 1 Letter proposing that the Department of Education's role should be updated from "developing and delivering curriculum"… ▸ more
Letter proposing that the Department of Education's role should be updated from "developing and delivering curriculum" to "promoting, encouraging and regulating" education. Don advocates separating oversight from operations—as the Department of Health does with Health PEI—allowing departments to focus on regulation while delegating operations to schools, colleges, and universities. He sees this as essential to shifting focus from schools to education broadly.
BIOGRAPHICAL

 Read · Download
2025 Restructuring Called For Letter documenting multiple structural confusions in PEI education. Don notes: (1) the Department claims to offer… ▸ more
Letter documenting multiple structural confusions in PEI education. Don notes: (1) the Department claims to offer "schooling" only, despite "education" being in its title; (2) the Department is organized by schooling levels rather than functions; (3) the Department's stated role omits "helping learners"; (4) common terminology is lacking; (5) PEI has a "school system" rather than an "education system." He calls for review and upgrade based on education literature.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2025 Purposer Concise letter emphasizing that "everything flows from purpose." Don contrasts PEI's vague purpose statements with New… ▸ more
Concise letter emphasizing that "everything flows from purpose." Don contrasts PEI's vague purpose statements with New Brunswick's clearer formulation: "to help each student develop the attributes needed to be a lifelong learner, to achieve personal fulfilment, and to contribute to a productive, just and democratic society." He advocates for a comprehensive review and restatement of PEI's educational purpose.

Brief letter to editor questioning the closure of Prince County Vocational School and Provincial Vocational Institute. Don notes that employers report former graduates started businesses based on training received, and asks whether equivalent vocational training is available today and where to find it. Reflects concern about loss of practical skills training infrastructure.

2025 Overhaul Letter to editor arguing for structural review of PEI's education system, distinguishing between a "school system"… ▸ more
Letter to editor arguing for structural review of PEI's education system, distinguishing between a "school system" (youth-focused) and an "education system" (lifelong learning). Don cites the World Bank's warning about conflating schooling with education, and advocates for service-based organization addressing Islanders of all ages. Proposes that clarity on education purpose and service offerings is essential staff development and policy communication.

2025 Op-ed Framework document outlining a comprehensive approach to organizing education services on PEI. Don articulates… ▸ more
Framework document outlining a comprehensive approach to organizing education services on PEI. Don articulates education as a lifelong, multi-role process spanning individual, family, citizen, student, consumer, and producer roles. Identifies eight core education functions (Information, Instruction, Feedback, Counselling, Funding, Products/Technology, Leadership/Governance) and critiques the current focus on age-based institutional delivery rather than service-based organization. References "Education 2020" initiative and the "Road of Life" framework.

2025 Missionr A welcome letter to PEI's new Minister of Education emphasizing the role's importance in shaping Islanders' futures and… ▸ more
A welcome letter to PEI's new Minister of Education emphasizing the role's importance in shaping Islanders' futures and society. Don critiques the Department's self-described role as "developing and delivering curriculum" to youth as far too narrow. He argues Islanders expect the Department to help people of all ages develop knowledge, skills, attitudes, and attributes needed to thrive—a distinction between school-focused versus education-focused governance that should guide the minister's priorities.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2025 Focus Don clarifies the World Bank's distinction: education is a lifelong process occurring anywhere, anytime; learning… ▸ more
Don clarifies the World Bank's distinction: education is a lifelong process occurring anywhere, anytime; learning experiences cause change through accumulated experiences, not through meeting places. Schooling is one pattern of help, but technology expands education-on-demand possibilities. He defines government's role as "encourage, promote and regulate education" (the "architects of education"), continuously scanning research to help Islanders obtain needed education. He argues oversight and operations should be separated, citing PISA and Montreal Economic Institute support for increased school autonomy and models like "Health PEI" for health service delivery.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2025 Dear Editor Don recounts a formative 1969 visit to PEI as newly appointed Holland College president. Meeting with Dr. Edward… ▸ more
Don recounts a formative 1969 visit to PEI as newly appointed Holland College president. Meeting with Dr. Edward Sheffield, an education adviser, Don noticed Sheffield's constant response to questions was "that is another thing that must be done first." Don found inspiration in Alan Paton's "Cry the Beloved Country," adopting the principle "do the next right thing" as his problem-solving approach. He applies this philosophy to education reform, advocating for clarity of purpose first and departmental role clarification as essential starting points.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2025 D_A Educ system Don argues that PEI has a "school system" rather than an "education system," focused only on young people. Drawing… ▸ more
Don argues that PEI has a "school system" rather than an "education system," focused only on young people. Drawing analogies to health systems (where hospitals are part of broader services) and legal systems, he contends that education services should extend beyond schools to serve the total community. A true education system would expand the Department's role, improve standards, increase community involvement, and better utilize technology.
BIOGRAPHICAL

 Read · Download
2025 D- Services Brief letter to editor (D-22-03) on "Typical Education Services." Don defines education as a set of services helping… ▸ more
Brief letter to editor (D-22-03) on "Typical Education Services." Don defines education as a set of services helping people learn, including information, counselling, instruction, feedback, learning guides, learning products, technology, funding, and human resources. Notes services are seldom mentioned in education literature. Critiques Department lumping all services under "schools" and argues services should be available to homeschooled, part-time, and independent learners—distinguishing an education system from a school system.

2025 D- Role Letter to editor (dated 7/23/role) titled "The key to education reform." Don cites Conversation article on reforming… ▸ more
Letter to editor (dated 7/23/role) titled "The key to education reform." Don cites Conversation article on reforming public education. Critiques PEI's "clarity problem" in education policy, noting Administrative Handbook definition only addresses "children" despite Department serving all ages, and "meaningful place" is too vague for program design. Critiques Department's role statement as understatement, proposing it should be "encourage, support and regulate" education services. Argues clear purpose and structure should arise from public discussion, possibly Cabinet or Legislative Assembly debate.

2025 D clarity Editor Letter to editor on "A clarity problem." Don notes World Bank and Canadian educators confuse "going to school" with… ▸ more
Letter to editor on "A clarity problem." Don notes World Bank and Canadian educators confuse "going to school" with "getting an education." Presents his view of education as experiences that changed him over years, demonstrated by what he knows, believes, feels, values, and can do. Critiques PEI Department's narrow definition as "develop and deliver curriculum" and proposes broader role as "encouraging, supporting and regulating" education. Notes Department definitions are not readily available to public.

2025 D Clarity-2 Draft (Doc5/Hand2, labeled "Guardian-clarity") on education complexity and missing public conversation. Don documents… ▸ more
Draft (Doc5/Hand2, labeled "Guardian-clarity") on education complexity and missing public conversation. Don documents disconnects between education literature and practice: learners learn at own pace but assigned same time; literature emphasizes soft skills but curriculum lacks them; essential skills lists differ between education literature and Department graduation requirements; curriculum excludes everyday competencies; Department limits itself to youth education. Lists role uncertainties and structural issues. Calls for purpose clarity and discussion about education structure versus school facilities.

2025 D Clarity-1- docx Letter to editor (Doc5/Hand, labeled D-22) on education complexity. Don discusses learners' different interests,… ▸ more
Letter to editor (Doc5/Hand, labeled D-22) on education complexity. Don discusses learners' different interests, capabilities, experiences, and needs; notes they fill six life roles. Defines education system as programs and services supporting learners, with tools including information, instruction, diagnosis, counselling, quality control, products, and technology. Emphasizes schools as important but not the whole system. Proposes each child should leave school "having mastered the tools to (continue to) learn."

Lists educational practices that upgrade schooling: student self-evaluation, choice in project assignments, student-designed learning plans. Marked "Interesting!" Appears to be brief reference note or draft fragment.

2025 D -System Lengthy letter to editor (D-22--4) on "EDUCATION FUNCTIONS." Don outlines typical education system functions:… ▸ more
Lengthy letter to editor (D-22--4) on "EDUCATION FUNCTIONS." Don outlines typical education system functions: information and counselling, governance and leadership, instruction, quality assurance, products and technology, funding, and human resources. Critiques PEI's confusion of education with schooling, notes lack of benchmarks, and discusses structural issues. References OECD, UNESCO, World Bank on education structure. Proposes education should serve all ages and offer separate services (not just schools). Compares education system to health system model. Represents his most systematic articulation of education system design.

2025 D -Purpose Letter to editor (reference 902-892-5859, labeled 332) on "Our educational purpose." Don argues PEI lacks clear… ▸ more
Letter to editor (reference 902-892-5859, labeled 332) on "Our educational purpose." Don argues PEI lacks clear educational purpose and cites vague departmental language ("creating opportunities for student success," "helping students secure a place in society"). Proposes education should support life roles (citizen, family member, individual, student, consumer, producer). References New Brunswick's clear goal for Grade 5 mastery of reading, writing, numeracy. Argues clear purpose is urgent and should involve community input.

2025 D - Series About Highlight Compilation of draft letters titled "D-23 Series" on education reform. Don argues education has been "overpowered by… ▸ more
Compilation of draft letters titled "D-23 Series" on education reform. Don argues education has been "overpowered by the influence of schools" and defines education as experiences changing what people know, feel, believe, value, and can do. Emphasizes education's role in six life roles. Critiques website focus on schooling rather than education. Uses analogy: improving the rink won't improve your grandson's hockey. Includes multiple draft variations and represents his core messaging on education versus schooling distinction.

2025 Conversation Substantial draft on "CONVERSATION NEEDED" about education. Don surveys Islanders' concerns about education versus… ▸ more
Substantial draft on "CONVERSATION NEEDED" about education. Don surveys Islanders' concerns about education versus schools, notes World Bank warning about confusing the two, and discusses removal of "education" from PEI's Education Act. Provides definitions of education, school, college, and university. Proposes "life roles" framework (individual, family member, citizen, student, producer, consumer) and discusses education's role in each. Extensive notes on education system structure, focusing on education delivery versus school operations—reflects his major policy interests.

2025 Converation Lengthy draft on education services and teaching philosophy. Don categorizes typical education services (information,… ▸ more
Lengthy draft on education services and teaching philosophy. Don categorizes typical education services (information, counselling, management, quality assurance, learning, technology, funding, human resources, data) and argues departments don't make them separately available. Proposes shifting from school-based to learner-based education, especially in senior grades. Discusses the need for public conversation and community education forums.

2025 Clarity 1 PEI 8 Draft notes titled "Glendenning Notes" and "Clarity PEI -1" exploring education terminology. Don discusses the World… ▸ more
Draft notes titled "Glendenning Notes" and "Clarity PEI -1" exploring education terminology. Don discusses the World Bank's warning about confusing schooling with education, critiques lack of transparency in public education discourse, and notes departmental focus on running schools rather than providing education services. Suggests establishment of a PEI Education Association. Contains references to World Bank, OECD Education 2030, and Montreal Economic Institute materials.

2025 Brraches of educationDear Editor Returning to a core concern, Don revisits departmental structure, organizing his critique around the concept of… ▸ more
Returning to a core concern, Don revisits departmental structure, organizing his critique around the concept of "branches" or divisions. Comparing PEI to other departments: Agriculture structures around crops, animals, potatoes; Health around COVID, drugs, e-health, hospitals; Fisheries around angling, hunting, wildlife, trapping. PEI Education, however, organizes by levels (elementary, secondary, postsecondary) rather than branches of educational endeavor. Education creates experiences through which people develop knowledge, skills, attitudes, attributes—enabling language learning, road building, community thriving, health services, artistic creation. Schools should organize education; so should the Department leading them. The letter, despite a typo in the filename ("Brraches"), represents mature expression of Don's consistent message: departmental structure must reflect educational services and human development outcomes rather than institutional hierarchy. This final letter synthesizes his multi-year advocacy into a clear organizational principle.
BIOGRAPHICAL

 Read · Download
2025 Benchmark Supporting "elected trustees" returning to public education agenda, Don first reviewed the Schools Act and Department… ▸ more
Supporting "elected trustees" returning to public education agenda, Don first reviewed the Schools Act and Department documents. He identified concerns: (1) Department describes role narrowly as "developing and delivering programs" to youth; he argues it should be "encouraging and supporting Islanders to gain skills, knowledge and attitudes to thrive in democracy"; (2) World Bank notes ministries confuse schooling with education. Don concludes boards' usefulness depends on decisions allowed/encouraged. Based on experience and research from Montreal Economic Institute, OECD, and World Bank, he recommends the province first update its education vision statement. Clear vision makes appropriate structure evident, enabling better decisions about school roles and trustee necessity. He cites Education 2020 Inc.'s 2015 recommendation for "a clear and compelling vision of education for all Islanders"—still valid a decade later. This letter connects governance structure to vision, treating boards as secondary to foundational policy clarity.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2025 Assessment results Pleased by PEI's improved Pan-Canadian test rankings, Don analyzes three assessment purposes: (1) design learning… ▸ more
Pleased by PEI's improved Pan-Canadian test rankings, Don analyzes three assessment purposes: (1) design learning strategies (professional information shared only with client/teacher, not graded); (2) establish achievement levels (what developed countries increasingly use, replacing credentials with qualifications); (3) compare individuals (for program improvement planning). Islanders most often discuss achievement levels. Don observes confusion between achievement and grade levels, with grade levels disappearing. He proposes two system changes: (1) replace outcomes with competencies as instructional basis; (2) convert credentials to qualifications. The letter emphasizes alignment with education literature and his experience, positioning assessment reform as integral to larger system transformation. Signed as "a long-time student of education."
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2025 A Dear Editor Don contends that PEI's education system is "really only a school system" requiring structural overhaul. The World… ▸ more
Don contends that PEI's education system is "really only a school system" requiring structural overhaul. The World Bank, largest public education contributor, cautions countries against confusing schooling with education. PEI does conflate them, focusing on serving youth in schools rather than all Islanders across ages, interests, and capabilities. Education is a service to help people gain/develop knowledge, skills, attitudes, values, and attributes; collaboration between educators and community is essential. Standard education services include information, counseling, learning products, technology, analysis, instruction, human resources, and tracking. Services should be clearly identified and promoted, with help tailored to individual learner needs. Restructuring should begin with: (1) common understanding of education; (2) clear purpose; (3) identified services. Don concludes by asserting PEI has internal expertise; it needs only to act on it rather than hiring external consultants. This letter synthesizes his reform vision into actionable steps.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2025 -educ vs school Drawing on a 2018 World Bank report, Don emphasizes the distinction between "going to school" and "gaining an… ▸ more
Drawing on a 2018 World Bank report, Don emphasizes the distinction between "going to school" and "gaining an education." He provides three evidence-based reasons: (1) Time in school is unreliable as a learning measure; better to set standards and allow time to meet them; (2) Education comprises multiple services—information, instruction, counseling, assessment, learning products, technology—most offered anywhere, while "going to school" is not itself an educational service (analogous to hospital or shopping plaza); (3) PEI's department title "Education and Lifelong Learning" seems redundant since education includes lifelong learning. Don notes that instructional services benefit from centralized locations, while non-instructional services (information, counseling) may serve better if decentralized. He proposes a lexicon of common educational terms, supporting his broader call for definitional clarity.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2025 -Meaning-3 A comprehensive essay examining education's definition, Don argues PEI needs to articulate how the education system… ▸ more
A comprehensive essay examining education's definition, Don argues PEI needs to articulate how the education system defines education. His literature review found no published PEI definition. He presents examples from authoritative sources: Good's Dictionary (education as social process for competence); OECD (organic, sustained communication for learning); Anonymous (experience with formative effect); Ontario (act of teaching and receiving knowledge). Don emphasizes that education is complex; learners have varied interests, experiences, capabilities, needs, and life roles. Teachers/educators must communicate clearly. Conceptual clarity heightens understanding of key concepts; lack of clarity must be directly addressed. He notes the absence of definitions may signal disagreement about education's meaning and mission, suggesting some resist definition due to lack self-confidence. This essay synthesizes Don's extended analysis into a substantial policy statement.
BIOGRAPHICAL

Nov 23, 2024 Booklet 2 Comprehensive 2024 document (November 23, 2024 - possibly Don's final year of active work) presenting Don's framework… ▸ more
Comprehensive 2024 document (November 23, 2024 - possibly Don's final year of active work) presenting Don's framework for PEI education system design. Emphasizes conceptual clarity as fundamental to education planning and policy. Defines learners as individuals with diverse interests, experiences, and aspirations. Outlines typical education services (information, counselling, instruction, quality assurance, products/technology, funding, human resources), system standards (public administration, comprehensive, universal, portable, accessible), and organizational structure. Includes learning levels (Bloom's taxonomy), emerging changes (autonomy, profiles, tutors, detailed tracking), and recommended reading from OECD and World Bank. Documents organizational structures and extensive notes reflecting his continued intellectual engagement with education policy into his mid-90s.

Nov 21, 2024 Finding 2 Summary Second findings iteration (November 21, 2024) reinforcing and refining conclusions from Finding 1. Reiterates lack of… ▸ more
Second findings iteration (November 21, 2024) reinforcing and refining conclusions from Finding 1. Reiterates lack of clarity, departmental structure misalignment, documentation deficiencies, transparency failures, and lack of professional education organizations. Emphasizes distinction between education and schooling as central problem. Focuses on teaching function documentation needs (learning models, assessment frameworks, curriculum clarity). Slightly more condensed than Finding 1 but maintains core themes.

Nov 17, 2024 Finding 1 Summary First comprehensive findings document (November 17, 2024) synthesizing major systemic deficiencies in PEI's education… ▸ more
First comprehensive findings document (November 17, 2024) synthesizing major systemic deficiencies in PEI's education system. Identifies lack of clarity in purpose and roles, fear inhibiting honest discourse, departmental structure focused on school operations rather than education delivery, insufficient documentation, limited school autonomy, poor transparency, lack of education organizations and professional communities, and absence of self-correcting mechanisms. Notes OECD/PISA research showing autonomy improves outcomes. Recommends independent national oversight body and comprehensive documentation improvements.

Oct 22, 2024 Talking points Discussion guide distilling Don's education reform arguments into concise talking points. Covers… ▸ more
Discussion guide distilling Don's education reform arguments into concise talking points. Covers education/learning/schooling definitions, learner characteristics and life roles, community capacity, education services (information, counselling, instruction, assessment, progress reporting), system components (visibility, definitions, beliefs, standards, collaboration, structure), modern system characteristics, and current issues (purpose/vision, education vs. schooling confusion, departmental role, structural focus, accountability, transparency). Dated October 22, 2024, this represents Don's refined messaging for public discourse.

Sep 18, 2024 Issues 100 . Comprehensive examination of education system complexity arising from individual uniqueness in physical, mental,… ▸ more
Comprehensive examination of education system complexity arising from individual uniqueness in physical, mental, emotional makeup, prior experience, learning pace and style. Addresses nine key issues: terminology confusion, unclear purpose, unidentified services, structural misalignment, insufficient autonomy, weak accountability, inadequate collaboration, missing education system (only school systems exist), and lack of transparency. Emphasizes that these issues are not new and require public engagement. (Dated September 18, 2024)

May 24, 2024 Documentation Brief outline document dated May 24, 2024, establishing foundational categories for educational analysis. Lists key… ▸ more
Brief outline document dated May 24, 2024, establishing foundational categories for educational analysis. Lists key documentation elements including definitions, purpose, desired learner outcomes, departmental focus, standards clarity, school autonomy, and three core models (learning, assessment, curriculum). This appears to be a framework document establishing the structure for more detailed analysis to follow.

Apr 3, 2024 Finding 3 Education Third findings document (April 3, 2024) consolidating conclusions from research, conversations, and experience.… ▸ more
Third findings document (April 3, 2024) consolidating conclusions from research, conversations, and experience. Explicitly states PEI has a school system rather than education system. Documents that the Department of Education lacks a definition of education, confuses educational branches with levels, and has inappropriately narrowed its role to curriculum delivery. Identifies knowledge and definitional gaps, recommends external standards body, calls for public dialogue on education purpose, emphasizes need for transparency, collaboration, and documentation. Suggests restructuring government involvement to promotion and regulation rather than operation.
EDUCATION

Feb 3, 2024 Finding 2 and Conclusions-20-PEI Extensive findings and conclusions document (February 3, 2024) providing comprehensive system critique with detailed… ▸ more
Extensive findings and conclusions document (February 3, 2024) providing comprehensive system critique with detailed categorization. Documents widespread public concern about education quality, particularly regarding basic communication and math skills. Identifies structural rather than resource problems as urgent. Notes the system's inability to self-correct without external intervention but also recognizes broad support for change. Lists specific systemic characteristics (monopoly, institution-centered, obscured accountability, time-based, lacking innovation encouragement, insufficient collegiality) and crucial gaps (early childhood education, independent learner support, prior learning certification, entrepreneurship development). Concludes with recommendations for restructuring.

2024 Tracking Titled "Making Learning Visible," this August 2024 letter addresses learner progress tracking. Don identifies best… ▸ more
Titled "Making Learning Visible," this August 2024 letter addresses learner progress tracking. Don identifies best practices from education literature: report progress on each outcome/competency, engage learners in the rating process, discuss results with learners, and post results. He acknowledges this approach is time-consuming but argues it's valuable for the learning process. The letter reflects Don's advocacy for transparent, learner-engaged assessment systems that prioritize feedback and visible progress, aligning with his broader vision of learner-centered education reform.

2024 Role of Dept ito1 Dated March 9, 2025, Don expands on role definition, arguing many Islanders (including educators) confuse education… ▸ more
Dated March 9, 2025, Don expands on role definition, arguing many Islanders (including educators) confuse education with schooling. World Bank research cautions against this conflation. Education encompasses all learning—at home, school, church, play, work—developing knowledge, skills, attitudes, and values. Oregon's Department of Public Instruction identifies six life roles: individual, family member, student, worker, and citizen (five of six listed). Don critiques PEI's narrow departmental self-description: "developing and delivering curriculum" to young Islanders. He proposes the government's role is better described as "encouraging, supporting and regulating" education for all Islanders across all contexts—home, school, work, community—not just youth in schools. This represents a comprehensive reconceptualization of government's educational mandate.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2024 Role of Department Don critiques the PEI Department of Education's self-description as "developing and delivering curriculum." He presents… ▸ more
Don critiques the PEI Department of Education's self-description as "developing and delivering curriculum." He presents broader formulations from other Canadian provinces: New Brunswick emphasizes "helping citizens gain attributes needed to be lifelong learners"; Alberta focuses on "skills needed for success in rapidly changing economy and society"; and an anonymous source describes helping "people navigate life and contribute to society." The difference between "delivering curriculum" and "helping people develop" is substantial, Don argues. His conversations with Islanders reveal expectations far exceeding curriculum delivery. He recommends the PEI Department review and expand its role statement to better align with citizens' educational expectations and international best practices.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2024 Learning to learners In this October 2024 letter, Don reconceptualizes education as a service supporting the learning process through… ▸ more
In this October 2024 letter, Don reconceptualizes education as a service supporting the learning process through information, encouragement, funding, instruction, assessment, assignments, materials, and technology. He notes learners study at their own pace, anywhere and anytime—schools, home, work, transit, day or night. Independent learners are increasing. Traditional education has brought "learners to learning" through schools; Don advocates developing the reverse approach: bringing "learning to learners" wherever they are. This service-oriented perspective represents a fundamental reframing of education from institutional (school-based) to learner-centered (learning-based), reflecting his broader vision of systemic reform.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2024 Definition Drawing on World Bank guidance, Don explains the education-vs.-schooling distinction. Education is an umbrella concept… ▸ more
Drawing on World Bank guidance, Don explains the education-vs.-schooling distinction. Education is an umbrella concept encompassing all learning—at home, in school, through travel, self-exploration. School/schooling refers to physical facilities and institutional settings. COVID accelerated this distinction by expanding home-based and independent learning. Don again notes his unsuccessful search for the Department of Education's definition of education in official documents. Upon inquiry, he learned the definition was replaced with "school" in the Education Act. He questions whether this applies to all schools or only public ones, and argues such a significant change deserves public discussion. The letter emphasizes that clear definitions enhance communication and mutual understanding.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2024 Definition neded August 23 Don reiterates his core argument in September 2024: definitions are critical to clarity of communication, enabling… ▸ more
Don reiterates his core argument in September 2024: definitions are critical to clarity of communication, enabling clearer thinking, better understanding, and mistake-prevention. He was surprised to learn the Department of Education no longer defines "education"—the word was replaced with "school" during an Education Act amendment. This change may explain the narrowing of educational services offered by government. Don distinguishes clearly: education and school are different words with different meanings. He calls for a taxonomy of key terms to be created and widely circulated, emphasizing the importance of shared conceptual frameworks in policy discourse.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2024 Definition 1 A concise early letter establishing Don's core concern: the Department of Education no longer has a published… ▸ more
A concise early letter establishing Don's core concern: the Department of Education no longer has a published definition of "education." The term was removed from the Education Act and replaced with "school." Don notes this linguistic shift appears strange and counterintuitive, particularly given education's importance to personal and community futures. He questions whether this change applies to all schools or only public schools, highlighting ambiguity in government communication. The letter succinctly frames definitional clarity as foundational to effective policy discussion and accountability.

2024 D-Clarity D - This is an extended draft/revision containing multiple versions of Don's call for conceptual clarity in education. The… ▸ more
This is an extended draft/revision containing multiple versions of Don's call for conceptual clarity in education. The core argument: education and schooling are fundamentally different concepts (education is a service; school is a place). World Bank guidance supports this distinction. Don critiques the Education Act's elimination of an education definition in favor of a schooling definition, signaling institutional narrowing. He analyzes departmental literature, organizational structures, and terminology choices. The document includes repeated sections addressing departmental reorganization, the misalignment between government structure and educational services, and specific recommendations for defining key terms (education, school, student). His recommendation: the department should reestablish itself as "Department of Education" and publish clear definitions as "Step One" in education improvement.

2024 Coming to a School near you Dated August 3, 2024, this letter documents emerging trends in education literature that Don anticipates will influence… ▸ more
Dated August 3, 2024, this letter documents emerging trends in education literature that Don anticipates will influence PEI's education system. He identifies 29 anticipated changes and highlights five key items: personal learning profiles, increased learner choice, greater student tracking detail, more documentation of activities and processes, and availability of separate learning services beyond traditional school. This proactive commentary shows Don monitoring international education trends and positioning PEI to be prepared for systemic changes. His prescient identification of these shifts suggests advanced knowledge of education evolution and forward-thinking policy engagement.

2024 Clarity - Don questions the contradictions in the Department of Education's terminology and mandate. He notes that the department… ▸ more
Don questions the contradictions in the Department of Education's terminology and mandate. He notes that the department includes "Lifelong Learning" and "Early Childhood Development" in its title despite education already encompassing both. More critically, he discovered that the official Education Act no longer contains a definition of "education," replacing it instead with "school." This shift reflects a narrowing of the department's conceptual scope from education (a broad service) to schooling (institutional focus). Don advocates for the department to document and share its current taxonomy of key terms, arguing that clarity in language is essential to understanding government's educational mission and public accountability.

2024 Anticipated changes Don summarizes anticipated changes in education from reviewing eight literature lists (ranging 5-10 points each). His… ▸ more
Don summarizes anticipated changes in education from reviewing eight literature lists (ranging 5-10 points each). His synthesis identifies six key anticipated changes: personalized learning, competencies (shift from traditional knowledge transmission), increased school autonomy, schools as learning hubs (community centers), more relevant content, and greater student and teacher agency. He suggests it would be valuable to develop a PEI-specific list of anticipated changes to guide local education reform.

2024 Adding visibility Don discusses the concept of "Making Learning Visible" and the shift from lesson plans to learning maps. Learning maps… ▸ more
Don discusses the concept of "Making Learning Visible" and the shift from lesson plans to learning maps. Learning maps shift focus from what teachers teach to what learners learn, tracking progress by topic, outcomes, or competency. Maps provide each learner with a planned learning journey map, a record of experiences, a discussion focus, and information for parents. The map with ratings becomes an achievement record and springboard for further study. Don presents this as a promising improvement approach for education systems.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2024 A Puzzler1 Don articulates the broader education clarity problem affecting not just PEI but internationally. He identifies… ▸ more
Don articulates the broader education clarity problem affecting not just PEI but internationally. He identifies multiple sources of confusion: rarity of definitions in government literature, lack of public discussion, unclear visibility, replacement of "education" with "school" in the Education Act, absence of education/school agendas, interchangeable terminology use, international research citations (World Bank, OECD, Montreal Economic Institute), absence of national standards, and lack of community information. He emphasizes education's importance and complexity, calling for a "taxonomy of key education terms" to provide helpful clarity for public understanding.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2024 -2 Don addresses PEI's need for a clear "definition of education." He notes that while a previous Education Act included a… ▸ more
Don addresses PEI's need for a clear "definition of education." He notes that while a previous Education Act included a definition, "education" was recently replaced with "school" in revision. He distinguishes between needing a school definition and maintaining education as a separate, broader concept, given their important differences. He observes that PEI now appears to have a "school system" rather than an "education system." He urgently recommends the Department develop an "education taxonomy" and circulate it widely throughout the education community for clarity and shared understanding.

Oct 13, 2023 Charateristics1 In contrast to File 10's critique, Don outlines what constitutes a quality education system: current terminology, clear… ▸ more
In contrast to File 10's critique, Don outlines what constitutes a quality education system: current terminology, clear publicly displayed purpose, discussion of services, service-based organization, transition from grades to profiles, shift to learning guides, evaluated outcomes, focus on education rather than schools, public engagement, school autonomy, collaborative (non-silo) structures, accessible system information, education vs. school systems distinction, clear accountabilities, education associations/advisory committees, and increased public promotion. Dated October 13, 2023, this represents his vision for positive transformation.

Jul 2, 2023 Fear . Analysis of fear as institutional dysfunction in education systems. Documents how contemporary students view college… ▸ more
Analysis of fear as institutional dysfunction in education systems. Documents how contemporary students view college instrumentally, and identifies faculty responsibilities to demonstrate credibility, clarify expectations, and promote self-efficacy. Critiques PEI's Toronto District School Board (TDSB) culture of fear trickling from administration to principals to teachers. Questions punitive grading systems and advocates for progress reporting instead. Dated July 2, 2023, representing Don's observation of systemic anxiety undermining educational effectiveness.

Feb 2, 2023 Definitions 4 Don's comprehensive "Key Definitions" document (February 2, 2023) providing his taxonomy of education concepts.… ▸ more
Don's comprehensive "Key Definitions" document (February 2, 2023) providing his taxonomy of education concepts. Includes detailed definitions of: learner (with three pieces of "luggage"—natural conditions, prior learning, aspirations), learning (multidimensional, experiential process), education (result of formative experiences), education system (community services supporting development), teaching (arranging experiences), schools (group-based facilities), school system (district reporting), educated (capability in everyday life), and life roles (individual, family member, student, citizen, consumer, producer). This represents the most complete expression of Don's educational philosophy.

2023 83 Night and Short Courses The Education 20/20 Souris continuing education survey revealed community interest in work-related, online, and… ▸ more
The Education 20/20 Souris continuing education survey revealed community interest in work-related, online, and practical courses supporting employment. Multiple providers (SKILLSPEI, post-secondary institutions, community schools, employers, professional groups, seniors colleges, private schools) expressed willingness to provide service. Problem: neither community nor education system is organized to respond. Don proposes creating a "College of Continuing Education" (without its own instructional staff) to promote and organize continuing education of all types where legal and funded. Final section features seasonal greetings. Includes Pot Pourri items: Ontario requiring two online credits for graduation in 2023-2024; Manitoba Registered Nurses College discovering graduates lacked adequate English skills; 80th anniversary of Miramichi Rural High School opening.

2023 Euturer Based on scanning multiple literature lists, Don identifies anticipated changes in public education: learning guides… ▸ more
Based on scanning multiple literature lists, Don identifies anticipated changes in public education: learning guides replacing lesson plans, learner profiles replacing grades, Bloom's taxonomy-based rating scales, increased school autonomy, better teacher access to education research, growing numbers of independent learners, and increased collaboration. He suggests these would be valuable agenda items for PEI education discussions. Labeled D-23.

2023 D-8 stuctue Don proposes structural changes for PEI education following leadership transitions (thanking Deputy Minister Bethany… ▸ more
Don proposes structural changes for PEI education following leadership transitions (thanking Deputy Minister Bethany MacLeod, welcoming Erin McGrath-Gaude). His "top five" priorities: (1) Terminology—distinguishing education from schooling; (2) Purpose—clarifying PEI's education purpose; (3) Roles—correcting the Department's role description from curriculum delivery to broader mandate; (4) Services—identifying education services; (5) Structure—organizing around branches/fields rather than schools. Additional recommendations include establishing accountabilities (helping change lives, not just running schools), increasing school autonomy (per OECD), documenting functions, providing benchmarks, encouraging engagement and collaboration, discontinuing student ranking (not an educational function), and maintaining an education focus. Conclusion: PEI should replace its school system with a full education system.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2023 D-7 Dear Editor A comprehensive synthesis of Don's education concerns, based on discussions with Islanders, personal experience, and… ▸ more
A comprehensive synthesis of Don's education concerns, based on discussions with Islanders, personal experience, and international research. He identifies three core problems: (1) Structural—confusing education with schooling, a problem the World Bank identified in developing countries but which applies to PEI; (2) Definitional—difficulty finding education definitions in Department literature or school websites; (3) Organizational—services organized by age rather than by educational functions (essential skills, citizenship values, employment skills, social graces). He argues the Department should lead public discussion on education's purpose, services, and standards through an "education plan." He contrasts having a "school system" with needing an "education system." Contact: 902-892-5859.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2023 D-1 Conversation This file contains two related pieces. First, Don proposes increased public conversation about education, noting that… ▸ more
This file contains two related pieces. First, Don proposes increased public conversation about education, noting that PEI's education definition has narrowed over 50 years. He offers his own definition: "any experience that changes what a person knows, feels, believes, values or is able to do." Second, he observes that the World Bank's concern about developing countries confusing schooling with education also applies to developed nations like Canada. Education is a process; school is a place. He proposes that PEI develop a "full scale education system" similar to a health system—comprehensive, serving all Islanders, with schools as one component. He lists key elements: learners, teachers, learning devices, research access, standards, delivery agency, assessment, tutoring, information and counselling. Such a system would organize around branches of education (essential skills, science, employment skills, technology) while schools organize by age.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2023 D story Don addresses PEI's "conceptual clarity problem" in education discourse. Despite searching the Department of Education,… ▸ more
Don addresses PEI's "conceptual clarity problem" in education discourse. Despite searching the Department of Education, school websites, CAMET, CMEC, and CEA, he finds only one definition (from Home and School Federation). He criticizes the interchangeable use of "education" and "schooling," citing World Bank research showing these are distinct concepts. Don argues that PEI operates a "school system," not an "education system," and that traditional school structures are inadequate given contemporary educational changes across Canada and globally. He advocates for a comprehensive definition encompassing education at all levels and kinds.

2023 D Nov 23 Education A concise May 4, 2023 letter offering Don's personal definition of education. He frames education as the process by… ▸ more
A concise May 4, 2023 letter offering Don's personal definition of education. He frames education as the process by which individuals close the knowledge gap between birth and adult life competence. Education is demonstrated through what people know, can do, and how they act. He distinguishes education from schooling, noting that good education enables people to handle daily life issues. This letter sets up his recurring theme—that education and schooling are fundamentally different concepts requiring separate discussion and institutional approaches.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2023 D Focus - Don's foundational letter examining the structural misalignment between public education's stated mission and actual… ▸ more
Don's foundational letter examining the structural misalignment between public education's stated mission and actual implementation in PEI. He argues that education is deeply complex, serving diverse learners with different needs, and that clear communication and shared definitions are essential. After reviewing PEI Department documents, school websites, and various educational bodies, Don finds no consistent definition of "education" and notes that the Department's official role—to "develop and deliver high quality programs and curriculum"—is too narrow. He references World Bank warnings against confusing "going to school" with "getting an education," observes that PEI's Department structure focuses on running schools rather than providing education services, and concludes the current system is misaligned with community needs and expectations. He recommends the three readings: World Bank's Crisis in Education (2019), Bedard's Pedagogical Autonomy (2015), and OECD Education 2030.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2023 D Clarrity D - A comprehensive letter calling for education sector clarity on four fronts. First, defining education itself: Don… ▸ more
A comprehensive letter calling for education sector clarity on four fronts. First, defining education itself: Don references the Education Act's definition ("imparting or acquiring knowledge") but expands to include skills, attitudes, and attributes for contemporary life. Second, identifying kinds of help learners need: counseling, instruction, learning products, technology, assessment, and others. Third, establishing organizational responsibility to "encourage, support and regulate services"—recognizing that provinces operate school systems rather than education systems. Fourth, making education system development a priority. Don references relevant literature (OECD, World Bank Report 2018, Montreal Economic Institute, OECD Education 2030) and notes recent senior Department management changes may enable desired restructuring. The letter synthesizes Don's year-long advocacy campaign, presenting his accumulated insights as urgent policy priorities requiring immediate attention.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2023 D 2 Puzzler A letter from 2018 (included in 2023 file collection, indicating Don's archival organization) framing education system… ▸ more
A letter from 2018 (included in 2023 file collection, indicating Don's archival organization) framing education system structure as a "puzzler" (things he doesn't understand). Don observes that most PEI government departments structure by field/branch: Agriculture (land, crops, potatoes), Health (COVID, drugs, e-health, hospitals), Fisheries (fishing, hunting, wildlife, trapping). Education, however, organizes by study levels (elementary, secondary, postsecondary), a notably different structural criterion. Don proposes alternative organizing principles: essential/occupational skills (welding, arts, science, technology), or life roles (citizen, individual, family member, student, producer, consumer). He uses a culinary metaphor—focus on the menu (educational services) rather than the dining room (schools)—suggesting that top leadership in Department and schools should focus on educational services, not school operation. This early articulation of structural critique demonstrates the consistency of Don's thinking over years.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2023 C System A substantial working paper comparing school systems with education systems and arguing PEI operates the former, not… ▸ more
A substantial working paper comparing school systems with education systems and arguing PEI operates the former, not the latter. Don establishes that education's future impact depends on citizen education quality, that education is an umbrella concept encompassing all impact-bearing experiences, and that early home/family experiences plus teacher influence are key. He notes education is constitutionally provincial responsibility but provinces should "promote, support and regulate" services—yet services are rarely identified separately or promoted, remaining embedded in schools/colleges/universities for enrolled students, creating a fragmented system. The paper includes British Columbia's education development goals (critical thinking, creativity, independence, skill, productivity, cooperation, civic awareness), defines education systems through multiple sources (Business Roundtable standards, components, Georgia Vision Project elements), and catalogs comprehensive services. Don identifies accountability types (compliance, professional norms, results), observes PEI lacks clear role descriptions for teachers/principals and performance reports, and recommends readings (OECD Education 2030, PISA, World Bank Education Crisis 2019, CMEC PCAP 2019). This paper represents Don's most comprehensive systematic analysis.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2023 C Services A brief letter proposing that education services be explicitly identified and promoted to both institutional and… ▸ more
A brief letter proposing that education services be explicitly identified and promoted to both institutional and independent learners. Don lists six core services from internet research: information, counseling, diagnosis, learning products and technology, instruction, and assessment. He observes these services are available to school-enrolled students but should be equally accessible to independent learners. The letter advocates expanding education service accessibility beyond traditional school settings, supporting his broader theme that education systems should serve all citizens, not only school-enrolled youth.

2023 A Education A foundational letter defining education as the lifelong learning process through which people close the gap between… ▸ more
A foundational letter defining education as the lifelong learning process through which people close the gap between limited birth knowledge and extensive survival/thriving knowledge. Don characterizes education as the culmination of learning-driven changes and adjustments, evident in what people know, can do, value, and how they act. He defines good education as enabling people to address issues encountered in daily life. The letter positions education as outcome (accumulated knowledge/capability) rather than process alone, distinct from schooling (which Don promises to address separately). This brief but philosophically grounded piece represents Don's foundational understanding of education's nature.

2023 3 Branches A letter proposing that PEI restructure education services along branches or types rather than age-levels. Don notes… ▸ more
A letter proposing that PEI restructure education services along branches or types rather than age-levels. Don notes that most government departments organize by field (Health: services, drugs, COVID, e-health; Agriculture: crops, livestock, land). He observes that Education is organized by level/age instead, and that while Early Childhood Development and student assessment are identified as services, most departmental focus centers on school operation. Don emphasizes that Islander conversations repeatedly highlight essential skills, personal skills, and employment, yet these are not prominent departmental services. He calls for discussion and restructuring to elevate literacy, numeracy, and employment training to parity with Early Childhood Development.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2023 2 Education or schooling A published letter (2023) expanding on the critical distinction between education and schooling, citing the World… ▸ more
A published letter (2023) expanding on the critical distinction between education and schooling, citing the World Bank's 2018 caution against treating these as equivalent. Don defines education as a broad, lifelong process of acquiring knowledge while developing thinking, creativity, problem-solving, comprehension, and learning capacity, encompassing values, habits, and character development. School, by contrast, is a specific location offering education services, comparable to a hospital as a resource-rich site where teachers and learners meet. Don emphasizes this distinction is not semantic but functional: education is a process; school is a place. This clarity is essential because conflating them limits perception of educational possibilities to institutional settings, constraining community understanding of how learning occurs.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2023 100 Services 2 A systematically organized document cataloging typical education services based on literature review. Don identifies… ▸ more
A systematically organized document cataloging typical education services based on literature review. Don identifies ten essential services: information (recent, accurate, independent), counseling (including diagnosis and assessment), organizational governance with vision, instruction (including diagnosis, counseling, presentations, practice, conversation, modeling), quality assurance, learning products, technology access, equitable funding, specialized personnel (teachers, administrators, counselors, advisors, technical specialists), and student progress reporting. Don observes that while these services are theoretically integrated into school systems, they are practically lost to most Islanders because school systems limit access to enrolled students. The document reflects Don's systematic approach to defining what an education system should comprehensively deliver.

Cover page for Don's 2023 manuscript "Education in Prince Edward Island." Represents major professional work synthesizing education policy research and recommendations based on decades of experience in educational leadership and reform.

Aug 23, 2022 14 Talking points This substantial policy document (dated August 23, 2022) presents a comprehensive framework for education system reform… ▸ more
This substantial policy document (dated August 23, 2022) presents a comprehensive framework for education system reform in PEI. Don develops detailed definitions of education, learners, learning, teaching, and schooling, emphasizing that education is a service distinct from schooling. He outlines six life roles (individual, family member, student, citizen, consumer, producer) that education should support. The document identifies structural issues including unclear purpose, inadequate services identification, misaligned organizational structure, insufficient teacher autonomy, and weak accountability mechanisms. It proposes OECD and World Bank research to support system redesign and addresses grading practices, noting that students should demonstrate competencies rather than receive grades based on effort or equity.

Jun 1, 2022 4 Clarity This policy document (dated June 1, 2022) argues that education reform should be reframed as a plea for clarity. Don… ▸ more
This policy document (dated June 1, 2022) argues that education reform should be reframed as a plea for clarity. Don proposes establishing a PEI lexicon to address terminology inconsistencies in education literature. He distinguishes between education (a service with multiple functions) and schooling (institutional delivery). Emphasizes that vision statements must move beyond general philosophy to provide specific direction and measurable goals. Notes that services should be available to all citizens, not just those in formal school settings. This document reflects Don's belief that clear definitions and communication are foundational to meaningful educational reform.

2022 Clarity 4 Multi-part essay on education clarity problems including missing definitions, unclear terminology, and confusion… ▸ more
Multi-part essay on education clarity problems including missing definitions, unclear terminology, and confusion between education and schooling. Don outlines structural and organizational issues requiring reform, with dates ranging from 2022-2023, showing sustained engagement with policy issues.

2022 Purpose A letter arguing that PEI lacks clarity about its educational purpose, a deficiency Don identifies as fundamental to… ▸ more
A letter arguing that PEI lacks clarity about its educational purpose, a deficiency Don identifies as fundamental to system design. He notes that departmental literature references "creating opportunities for student success," "securing a place in society," and "developing high quality programs," but argues these statements lack sufficient specificity for program design or results measurement. Don proposes that education's purpose is helping people gain knowledge, skills, attitudes, and attributes for various life roles (citizen, family member, individual, student, consumer, producer), with citizen and employment contexts most frequently mentioned by Islanders. A clear purpose, Don argues, would direct organizational structure and provide focus for instruction and assessment, shifting teacher work from subject/grade delivery to enabling students' life role competence. He calls this "purpose firm" (quoting a Sunday School teacher) and urgently needed.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2021 March 25 During the COVID-19 pandemic, Don challenges the term "remote learning," arguing that only learners can learn and… ▸ more
During the COVID-19 pandemic, Don challenges the term "remote learning," arguing that only learners can learn and learning happens where the learner is. Support for learning can be remote, but learning itself is not. He references the World Bank's observation that educators confuse "going to school" with "getting an education," and advocates for focusing on function rather than place. This piece reflects Don's philosophical precision and his effort to correct conceptual confusion even in common parlance.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2021 4-Trustees Don reiterates his support for elected trustees, now reviewing the Schools Act and internet resources. He identifies… ▸ more
Don reiterates his support for elected trustees, now reviewing the Schools Act and internet resources. He identifies two Department concerns: (1) the Department frames its role as "developing and delivering programs" rather than encouraging all Islanders to improve education, and (2) the Department conflates schooling and education. Drawing on Montreal Economic Institute, OECD, and World Bank sources, Don argues that trustee usefulness depends on permitted decision-making authority. He calls for updating PEI's education vision statement before deciding on board structure, citing Education 2020 Inc.'s 2015 recommendation for a clear vision as the foundation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2021 1-2021 Whither bound Don questions PEI's unclear education mission, comparing it unfavorably to Health's goal of "accessible quality health… ▸ more
Don questions PEI's unclear education mission, comparing it unfavorably to Health's goal of "accessible quality health services" and Agriculture's goal of innovation. He criticizes the Department's limitation to "children birth to Grade 12" as narrow, notes confusion between schooling and education (citing the World Bank), and observes that most developed nations have qualification authorities to rationalize credentials, while Canada and the USA lack these. Don calls for clear leadership that removes conceptual confusion about education's purpose and scope.

Dec 20, 2020 86 - C implied contract Open Education No. 86-C (December 20, 2020). Don analyzes unclear commitment of PEI government to education services… ▸ more
Open Education No. 86-C (December 20, 2020). Don analyzes unclear commitment of PEI government to education services for its 155,000 citizens. Questions whether education promises time-in-school versus achievement levels, and whether government should ensure basic citizenry skills, employment readiness, democracy participation, and lifelong learning capacity. Reflects his life-roles framework (individual, citizen, family member, learner, consumer, producer).
EDUCATION
Read · Download

Dec 10, 2020 15 umeracy Occasional paper No. 15 (December 10, 2020) by Don examining numeracy as an essential skill for citizens and workforce.… ▸ more
Occasional paper No. 15 (December 10, 2020) by Don examining numeracy as an essential skill for citizens and workforce. He synthesizes research from Conference Board of Canada, UK initiatives, and Australian programs, noting 45% of Canadian adults have inadequate numeracy skills. Don proposes 12 recommendations including offering numeracy as a separate subject on PEI, basing curriculum on everyday skills, establishing competency-based levels, creating advisory committees, and adopting community-based rating scales. This document shows his evidence-based advocacy approach and direct engagement with concrete educational reform proposals that influenced PEI policy discussions.

Duplicate or near-identical version of File 17 (Conclusions-1.doc), dated October 15, 2020. Contains the same comprehensive synthesis of conclusions about PEI's school system, systemic characteristics, identified gaps, and 2020 observations about narrow focus, internal resistance to change, fear-based culture, erosion of social capital, and lack of professional voice in PEI education.

October 2020 94 Board of Education In this October 2020 piece, Don proposes reimagining school governance on PEI through a "Board of Education" rather… ▸ more
In this October 2020 piece, Don proposes reimagining school governance on PEI through a "Board of Education" rather than traditional school trustees. His vision involves local residents ensuring community members access 21st-century educational services including online courses, counseling, and personal development. He draws on Washington DC's model where Board of Education members serve as visible education advocates. Don emphasizes collaboration between educators and community stakeholders, reflecting his belief that both professional voices and user perspectives are essential for improving education.

Sep 20, 2020 Report-7 Combined Final Citizens' Math report dated September 20, 2020 providing comprehensive analysis of everyday math skills for PEI… ▸ more
Final Citizens' Math report dated September 20, 2020 providing comprehensive analysis of everyday math skills for PEI citizens. Based on three-day citizen panel session (October 7-8, 2019) facilitated by Meg Savory. Don Glendenning listed as Education 20/20 Inc. project support. Includes employer profiles from Charlottetown and Alberton, rating scales, and detailed CoSolved curriculum analysis identifying 56 of 84 citizen skills matched to PEI math outcomes.

Aug 20, 2020 93 Beliefs Don articulates core beliefs shaping his education philosophy: all can learn, learning is individual, early childhood… ▸ more
Don articulates core beliefs shaping his education philosophy: all can learn, learning is individual, early childhood education is crucial, education develops lifelong competence, family responsibility is key, and government should encourage education, ensure equity, and support workforce development. This document represents his fundamental values and worldview. Published August 20, 2020 in Open Education No. 91-B.

Don proposes education outlets/centers (like pharmacies in health care) providing learning products, memberships, and flexible access. He recalls a North Island Community College model with mini accounting learning centers in Sears outlets. He suggests this decentralized model would simplify COVID-19 planning and expand educational access. Published August 20, 2020 in Open Education No. 92.

Don draws on World Bank research on successful education reforms, emphasizing need for multidisciplinary expertise at ministry level, capacity at district offices, and managerial expertise in schools. He references his own work on a World Bank project in Pakistan years ago, showing his international development experience. Published August 20, 2020 in Open Education No. 91-3.
