Aug 20, 2020 91-Mission Don calls for open dialogue about education's future in PEI, identifying structural gaps between services expected and… ▸ more
Don calls for open dialogue about education's future in PEI, identifying structural gaps between services expected and delivered. He cites OECD and World Bank findings on autonomy and accountability, criticizes Department oversight as limiting operational freedom, and advocates for engaging educators in collaborative planning. Published August 20, 2020 in Open Education No. 92.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Aug 20, 2020 200-5 School is where I work Newsletter 200-5 (August 20, 2020) critiquing the conflation of schooling with education. Don notes World Bank research… ▸ more
Newsletter 200-5 (August 20, 2020) critiquing the conflation of schooling with education. Don notes World Bank research showing this confusion affects developing countries and Canada alike—comparing it to "going to the supermarket" versus "shopping." He observes people speak of "Grade 9 or Grade 12 education" as if duration equals education, and they ask "where I got my education" meaning school location. This conceptual confusion extends to curriculum and grading. Don proposes granular grading—rather than overall subjects, grade components like "number," "shape," "statistics" separately. He notes some nations have established qualification authorities (Canada hasn't). This reflects his precision-oriented approach to educational language and structures.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Aug 20, 2020 200-3 Skill development Newsletter No. 200-3 (August 20, 2020) lamenting decline of vocational education in PEI. Don traces 100-year history of… ▸ more
Newsletter No. 200-3 (August 20, 2020) lamenting decline of vocational education in PEI. Don traces 100-year history of quality skill training through Agricultural Aid Act (1912) and replacement legislation with quality assurances (standards, staffing, curriculum, inspections, conferences). He notes federal leadership role ended; provinces now reimbursed for expenses, reducing emphasis on rigorous skill development. Don reflects on PVI and PCVHS supplying 50 years of work-entry personnel and small business entrepreneurs; the gap is now felt by business community. He concludes education has become product-focused (credentials) rather than service-focused, narrowing from comprehensive offerings to school-based instruction, losing autonomy and accountability in process.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Aug 20, 2020 200-2 Structural overhaul Newsletter (August 20, 2020) proposing specific structural overhauls following institutional structural analysis… ▸ more
Newsletter (August 20, 2020) proposing specific structural overhauls following institutional structural analysis framework. Don advocates: granting schools operational autonomy (per OECD PISA research showing better outcomes), organizing departments around functions (governance, instruction, information, counselling, products, human resources, quality assurance) rather than hierarchies, distinguishing education from schooling (World Bank perspective), applying Mathieu Bedard's "accountability and autonomy jointly applied" principle, and separating professional from administrative roles (hospital model). These targeted recommendations reflect his systematic, evidence-based reform approach grounded in international comparative research.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Aug 20, 2020 200-1 Structural Newsletter No. 95 (August 20, 2020) analyzing structural impediments to PEI education quality. Don defines structural… ▸ more
Newsletter No. 95 (August 20, 2020) analyzing structural impediments to PEI education quality. Don defines structural issues as policies, procedures, culture, teaching approaches, and physical dimensions interfering with quality. He identifies seven key impediments: political filtering through government departments, narrowed vision compared to 50 years prior, lack of professional autonomy (both principals and teachers "non-existent"), inadequate accountability focused on school operations rather than skill development outcomes, "fear factor" discouraging open discourse, product-oriented (credentials-focused) rather than service-oriented approaches, and undervalued vocational/technical education. Don cites OECD PISA research and proposes "clear, compelling" vision as starting point. This synthesizes his systemic critique.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Aug 20, 2020 200--9 j Courses Newsletter (August 20, 2020) proposing revival of WWII-era J-Courses (Job Instruction Training, Job Relations Training,… ▸ more
Newsletter (August 20, 2020) proposing revival of WWII-era J-Courses (Job Instruction Training, Job Relations Training, Job Methods Training) updated for 2020 (including Job Technology Training). Don describes these brief, sharply-focused skill courses created during Canada's agrarian-to-manufacturing transition, which provided workers with business-card-sized job reference cards. He draws parallels to modern challenges: construction trade shortages, employer complaints about graduates' work skills, and employment readiness gaps. Don sees these mini-credentials as models for modern community college offerings and cost-reduction for workforce entry. This demonstrates his appreciation for historical solutions to contemporary challenges.
EDUCATION

 Read · Download
August 2020 100-Don An August 2020 newsletter marking the end of Education 20/20's newsletter series (Newsletter #100). Don reflects on his… ▸ more
An August 2020 newsletter marking the end of Education 20/20's newsletter series (Newsletter #100). Don reflects on his writing as a learning tool and his use of flipcharts and typewriter for developing ideas. Recaps core definitions of learner, learning, instruction, and school. Emphasizes that learning is personal, grading is not a teaching function, and communities support learning because it benefits both individuals and the collective. Expresses gratitude and closes with holiday wishes.

August 2020 93 Recent reading This August 2020 newsletter curates international education news and trends Don found noteworthy. Topics include… ▸ more
This August 2020 newsletter curates international education news and trends Don found noteworthy. Topics include colleges' responsibility to prepare students for employment (Hechinger Report), Canadian school system priorities emphasizing student-centered governance (Paul Bennett's book), teacher literacy standards in Australia, partnerships between community colleges and employers (Paul Quinn College), COVID-19 adaptations in Canadian colleges, and EU vocational education frameworks emphasizing lifelong learning and competency development. Don presents himself as an intellectual collector and synthesizer of global education trends, sharing insights with Education 20/20 Inc. subscribers.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jun 4, 2020 88-5 Action Article No. 88 (June 4, 2020) on "Some Structural Issues" outlines four starting points for change: clear compelling… ▸ more
Article No. 88 (June 4, 2020) on "Some Structural Issues" outlines four starting points for change: clear compelling provincial education vision, functionally-based organization, learner-centered instructional model, and autonomy with accountability for professionals at delivery points. Don includes Epstein's Framework on Involvement, which details six dimensions of family and community engagement: parenting support, communication, volunteering, home-based learning, decision-making participation, and community collaboration. This framework emphasizes removing barriers to involvement and providing meaningful, flexible opportunities for families to engage with schools and support student learning.
EDUCATION
Read · Download

Jun 4, 2020 88-4-D Action Article No. 88 (June 4, 2020) titled "Signs of Change in Education" identifies indicators that suggest education reform… ▸ more
Article No. 88 (June 4, 2020) titled "Signs of Change in Education" identifies indicators that suggest education reform is occurring, including media commentary beyond official channels, changed enrollment patterns at Holland College, expanded adult education offerings (particularly in Souris), and increased community participation on curriculum committees. Don notes these signals appear in people's everyday conversations and coffee-club discussions, suggesting grassroots support for change. He maintains his core message that the education system needs overhaul due to narrow focus, bureaucracy, and lack of accountability, while emphasizing that PEI citizens desire students to be independent learners capable of working and playing together.
EDUCATION INSTITUTIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jun 4, 2020 88-12 learning and school Article No. 88 (June 4, 2020) clarifies the distinction between "going to school" and "getting an education," citing a… ▸ more
Article No. 88 (June 4, 2020) clarifies the distinction between "going to school" and "getting an education," citing a 2018 World Bank report. Don emphasizes that learning results in behavioral change and can occur anywhere, not just in schools, yet many Islanders (including educators) conflate education with schooling. He explains that communities encourage and fund learning they deem valuable (medicine, mechanics, policing) and that while schools are purpose-built facilities, attending school does not guarantee good education. The piece advocates for holistic rating scales, competency-based learning, self-paced programs, and democratic school governance while criticizing the current politically-filtered conversation focused on administrivia rather than meaningful educational change.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jun 4, 2020 88 -9 Overhaul Article No. 88-9 (June 4, 2020) examines foundational beliefs about learners and education systems, beginning with a… ▸ more
Article No. 88-9 (June 4, 2020) examines foundational beliefs about learners and education systems, beginning with a John Dewey quote about the importance of understanding what people believe. Don proposes key beliefs that should underpin PEI education: learners need individual advocacy, learning is personal and self-paced, education is central to community future, and change should be led by Islanders rather than outside experts. The piece contrasts beliefs about learners, education, and government responsibilities, emphasizing that improved education requires clarity about these fundamental principles before implementing systemic changes.

May 20, 2020 90-- Teaching Don synthesizes OECD research on teaching quality, emphasizing that teacher quality is the most important school… ▸ more
Don synthesizes OECD research on teaching quality, emphasizing that teacher quality is the most important school variable influencing student achievement. He presents expanded roles for teachers across individual, classroom, school, and community levels, including management of learning processes, multicultural teaching, and community partnerships. Published May 20, 2020 in Open Education No. 90.

Apr 26, 2020 8 Pay for Open Education No. 87 (April 26, 2020). Don discusses evolving performance-based rating systems that assess student… ▸ more
Open Education No. 87 (April 26, 2020). Don discusses evolving performance-based rating systems that assess student performance by accuracy, consistency, fluency, and self-confidence rather than traditional grades. Includes profile of Bishop Carroll High School's self-directed learning model as exemplar. Reflects his advocacy for competency-based assessment and student-centered learning approaches.

Apr 15, 2020 90 Restructure Article No. 90 (April 15, 2020) addresses post-COVID educational impacts, anticipating long-term changes rather than… ▸ more
Article No. 90 (April 15, 2020) addresses post-COVID educational impacts, anticipating long-term changes rather than "return to normal." Don notes Australian post-secondary institutions facing decimated budgets from lost regional students and uncertainty about their return, while endowments supporting disadvantaged students recover slowly. He predicts employers may shift from credentials to qualifications and from education products to services. The piece outlines seven structural systemic elements needed: overarching beliefs framework, service-based organization (listing leadership, information/counselling, funding, products, instruction, human resources, quality assurance), distinguishing education from schooling, service-industry culture, autonomy-accountability joint application, professional independence, and de-politicization. Don criticizes conflating education with schooling, noting this distorts schools' role, increases costs, and bureaucratizes services.

Open Education No. 87 (April 15, 2020), bilingual English/French. Don reports on novel initiative involving 10 Island citizens developing list of 72 practical math skills for daily living, never done before. Plans to post on education2020.ca for comparison with official curriculum. Includes COVID-19 impact analysis and World Bank leadership recommendations. Exemplifies his community-engaged, practical approach to curriculum development.

Notes weak management capacity and recommends autonomy/accountability integration. References COVID-19 impact on higher education. Reflects his long-term vision for culture change and leadership development.

Don explores whether education should be conceptualized as a product or service, drawing on his own experience becoming a teacher and his observations of education systems. He argues that schools often treat education as a factory producing standardized products, but suggests that character development differentiates learners. The piece reflects his lifelong commitment to reimagining education delivery. Published February 20, 2020 in Open Education No. 86.

Feb 12, 2020 D-2 Conversation A February 12, 2020 letter to the editor calling for public conversation about education. Don argues that… ▸ more
A February 12, 2020 letter to the editor calling for public conversation about education. Don argues that service-centered education became product-focused, with educators withdrawing from public discourse into professional silos. He quotes an Ontario education activist's five critical questions and advocates for an all-party panel to lead structured public discussion about education fundamentals. This piece reveals Don's concern about public disconnection from education policy.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
January 2020 12 Typical Education Services January 2020 paper defining ten typical education services provided by systems: governance, leadership, funding,… ▸ more
January 2020 paper defining ten typical education services provided by systems: governance, leadership, funding, regulation, information, counseling, instruction, quality assurance, learning products, and human resources. Don critiques PEI Department of Education's narrower role definition focusing only on children in schools, arguing it omits citizens and many service functions. He advocates for comprehensive education systems supporting all community members across life stages. The paper presents a functional framework for understanding education delivery, distinguishing between structural services (governance, leadership, funding) and operational services (instruction, assessment, counseling). Don argues the province's self-imposed limitations prevent meeting full community educational needs. This brief paper encapsulates his systematic thinking about educational organization.

Documents the organizational structure and mission of Education 20/20, a member-driven, independent organization Don founded to improve education across Canada. Describes the organization as learner-driven, accountable, and accessible, with focus on raising public awareness, supporting educators, promoting research, and advocating for educational improvements.

Advocates for functional organization with clear purpose, services represented at senior levels, defined autonomies and accountabilities, and notes Education 2020 Inc. made similar recommendations in 2015.

2020 A Purpose Published letter titled "Education's Purpose Not Clear" citing childhood Mission Band song inspiring his reform… ▸ more
Published letter titled "Education's Purpose Not Clear" citing childhood Mission Band song inspiring his reform advocacy. Argues PEI's education purpose is unclear and insufficiently detailed, limiting to "children" when Department serves all ages, and using vague "meaningful place" language. Proposes education's legitimate purpose involves preparing for six life roles: individual, family member, citizen, student, consumer, producer. References Education 2020 Inc.'s 2015 "Call for Action" recommending clear vision. Concludes clarifying education purpose should be government's highest education priority requiring public engagement. Signed Don Glendenning, undated (reference D-22-02).

2020 Education 2020 Invitation & Program - Oct. Event second draft Workshop invitation for "A Framework for Learning" event held October 21, 2013, at the Quality Inn in Charlottetown,… ▸ more
Workshop invitation for "A Framework for Learning" event held October 21, 2013, at the Quality Inn in Charlottetown, PEI. Don Glendenning is listed as opening and closing speaker. The program features presentations on teaching and learning from Alice Taylor, Brenda Goodine, and Eileen Conway-Martin. REFERENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2020 2020 educ vs schools Two-part letter presenting Don's central thesis: education encompasses all learning (home, travel, social occasions,… ▸ more
Two-part letter presenting Don's central thesis: education encompasses all learning (home, travel, social occasions, personal exploration) while schools are merely institutions delivering instruction. Educators conflate these concepts, hindering PEI educational quality. Don advocates Oregon's "life roles" framework (citizen, individual, student, family member, provider, consumer) as curriculum starting point with citizen advisory bodies. He argues the Department should either broaden its mission or revert to its former name, "Department of Public Instruction," as governments now frame their role narrowly as producing programs for schools rather than advancing comprehensive education.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2020 2020 Puzzled about math Incomplete working draft from Don's ongoing mathematics education investigation combining conversations, educator… ▸ more
Incomplete working draft from Don's ongoing mathematics education investigation combining conversations, educator discussions, instructional material examination, competency identification, and articles. Don reflects on education broadly and notes the World Bank's 2018 report suggesting Ministries of Education have become part of the education problem. He expresses suspicion about grade-organized math skills lists given classroom reality showing four- to six-level grade variation. Document cuts off but indicates concerns about lack of oversight, external expertise involvement, and citizen consultation in math curriculum.

 Read · Download
2020 2020 Math Letter from Don describing his investigation of PEI mathematics instruction, undertaken not as a math specialist but… ▸ more
Letter from Don describing his investigation of PEI mathematics instruction, undertaken not as a math specialist but from recognizing math as a frequently-cited community concern. Don details his research: interviews with math educators, curriculum examination, survey administration, and internet research. Key findings include citizens need math fluency not extensive knowledge, tutoring helps struggling students, good teaching overcomes home disadvantages, more practice time needed, teacher preparation requires strengthening, competencies better than outcomes for curriculum development, and emerging rating scales reflect real-life criteria with self-assessment components.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

Activity report from October 1, 2020, outlining Education 20/20 Inc.'s initiatives including monthly electronic newsletters (both official languages), website posting, annual education awards ($2,500 to Island institutions), twelve occasional papers, presentations promoting educational change, and survey of Souris residents. Lists ongoing "Citizen Mathematics" donor-funded project examining math competencies in Islanders' daily lives and labor market entrance requirements. Documents Don's organizational leadership and commitment to bridging theoretical education and practical community needs.

Introductory course descriptions for Education 2020's coding and robotics programs. Emphasizes that computer literacy and coding skills are essential for tomorrow's citizens, teaching mathematical thinking and problem-solving. Notes 25-hour introductory coding course and separate robotics program covering mechanisms, dynamics, intelligent controls, and practical applications. Demonstrates Don's forward-thinking approach to education reform and commitment to preparing students for technology-driven future.

Amended version of the math skills competency list identifying specific mathematical abilities needed for everyday citizen life. Compiled by the citizen panel with facilitator Meg Savory and recorder Marla Gidney. Lists 125+ competencies organized into categories: whole numbers, measurement, fractions/decimals/percentages, spatial reasoning, patterns/relationships, statistics, and financial literacy. Shows Don's innovative approach to curriculum development grounded in practical citizen needs rather than academic structure.

Press release announcing completion of Citizen Math competency analysis. Education 20/20 developed 72 competencies across seven fields using DACUM process (grounded in Canadian research innovation). The analysis identifies math skills people actually use rather than theoretical curricula. Demonstrates Glendenning's sophisticated understanding of pedagogical methodology and his preference for practitioner-grounded educational development. The DACUM methodology connection shows his awareness of Canada's educational innovations, particularly Holland College's pioneering work.

2020 2020-2-E Reform Planning document dated August 4, 2020, outlining strategic options for Education 20/20 Inc.'s future amid… ▸ more
Planning document dated August 4, 2020, outlining strategic options for Education 20/20 Inc.'s future amid organizational transition. Don addresses the organization's current activities (newsletter, occasional papers, awards programs) and financial status ($649 credit union balance, $2,500 restricted funds). The document presents six options: presidential resignation with new executive, restructuring to include apprenticeship and private school services, activity suspension, merger with another organization, charity-to-nonprofit conversion, or wind-down. Don arranged a Zoom meeting via CFPEI for August 19, 2020, requiring director feedback by August 17. This reflects his methodical approach to institutional governance during organizational strain.
REFERENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2020 2020-2-D Reform In this reflective working paper written while at his cottage, Don Glendenning shares his ongoing preoccupation with… ▸ more
In this reflective working paper written while at his cottage, Don Glendenning shares his ongoing preoccupation with Education 20/20's future despite being away. He acknowledges having numerous ideas for organizational initiatives but recognizes constraints of his advancing age and directors' busy schedules. Based on organizational discussions, recent planning, and Tim McRoberts's committee work, Don reaffirms that PEI's education system cannot independently institute needed 21st-century changes. He advocates for an active, broad-based, independent, member-driven organization of Islanders invested in education quality. Don identifies structural barriers to change: clarity of mission, structure, communication, autonomy, and accountability. He notes that bureaucracy and "the fear factor" hamper educational progress. Don outlines potential Education 20/20 roles (research, information, instruction, professional development) and indicates he will support whatever organizational direction the board chooses. This document captures Don's mature reflection on educational leadership and his adaptive, democratic approach to organizational governance.
REFERENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2020 2020-2 B Reform This working paper reflects Don Glendenning's analysis of education challenges on PEI based on organizational… ▸ more
This working paper reflects Don Glendenning's analysis of education challenges on PEI based on organizational activities, director discussions, committee work, and personal experience. He identifies that the system needs overhaul with major issues in clarity, structure, communication, autonomy, and accountability. Don critiques education being treated as a product rather than service, notes the gap between community needs and system delivery, and concludes the current system cannot support needed changes. For Education 20/20, he proposes establishing a broad-based, independent professional organization representing all education providers. He challenges current directors about leadership commitment and outlines options: elect new officers, suspend operations, or wind up. A reminder about PEI's "fear factor" affecting professional expression indicates Don's awareness of political and bureaucratic constraints on reform.
REFERENCE

This planning table outlines proposed public information sessions for parents and the general public, indicating Education 20/20's commitment to community engagement and public education. Suggested topics include emerging occupations (with interest level of 1), helping with math (level 4), and educating grandchildren (level 4), with identified presenters from education institutions and the private sector. The document reflects Don's understanding that education improvement requires public understanding and participation. The selection of panelists including UPEI faculty and Holland College staff indicates his collaborative approach to drawing expertise from PEI's educational institutions.

His investigation of numeracy, employer profiles, and innovative school models reveals a comprehensive methodology for developing evidence-based educational frameworks grounded in community needs.

2020 2020 Description Math Award description for the 2020 Excellence in Education Award focused on numeracy. Defines numeracy as "having the… ▸ more
Award description for the 2020 Excellence in Education Award focused on numeracy. Defines numeracy as "having the confidence and skill to use numbers and mathematical approaches in all aspects of life—at work, at home and beyond, as consumers, in managing finances." Cites PEI Department of Education's Early Numeracy Intervention Program and Conference Board of Canada findings indicating Canada's "C" grade on numeracy skills. The award ($2,500) supports innovative approaches to improving numeracy in PEI. Application deadline was February 28, 2020, with final reports due December 31, 2020. This represents the outcome of Don's strategic planning process initiated after the unsuccessful 2019 cycle.

This appears to be a revised or edited version of File 4, containing largely identical content about public conversation on education, governmental confusion between education and schooling, and proposals for systemic dialogue. The document reiterates concerns about the multiple conflicting agendas in education and emphasizes that communities deserve to be consulted about education's fundamental purposes and funding.

2020 1 Conversation Don calls for democratic public dialogue about fundamental education questions: Why should the state educate citizens?… ▸ more
Don calls for democratic public dialogue about fundamental education questions: Why should the state educate citizens? How? Who decides when education is complete? This lengthy piece, structured around an Ontario educator's framework, emphasizes that education policy should be citizens' responsibility, not isolated to government. He critiques Department confusion between "education" and "schooling," notes community concerns about literacy, numeracy, and practical skills, and proposes structural solutions including a Board of Education to provide ongoing advice. Don argues that current education dysfunction stems from multiple players with conflicting agendas.

2020 205 2020 info services August 29, 2015 Education 20/20 Inc. document outlining organization's mission and information service strategy.… ▸ more
August 29, 2015 Education 20/20 Inc. document outlining organization's mission and information service strategy. Mission emphasizes ensuring quality education through twin pillars of information and engagement, with website as communication hub. Services include "Open Education" monthly bilingual newsletter, website, blog/Twitter development, and surveys of parents, students, employers, and teachers. Guiding principles emphasize writing for public audiences, gathering local information, publishing in both official languages, and promoting best practices. Document establishes Education 20/20's role as an independent educational advocacy organization focused on public engagement in education reform.

2020 D-1 Expectations A 2020 blog post criticizing PEI education structure (not people) as the barrier to improvement. Don references… ▸ more
A 2020 blog post criticizing PEI education structure (not people) as the barrier to improvement. Don references Education 2020 Inc.'s call for action and argues that the World Bank is correct—Islanders confuse schooling with education. He advocates shifting conversation from operational matters (buses, storm days, technology, grades) to learners, programs, and services. He questions what the Department of Education actually aims to accomplish and critiques unclear accountability structures.

Occasional Paper No. 9 from December 22, 2019, defining key education concepts: Education as any experience with formative effect, Education System as community services for citizen education, Education Services as task performance for others' benefit. The paper documents typical provincial education services including information/counselling/advice, funding, instruction (with reference to Education 20/20 panel findings on youth support needs), leadership/governance, human resources, learning products/technology, and quality assurance. Includes contact information for Education 20/20 Inc. in Charlottetown.

December 2019 101 Broader definition A December 2019 letter to the Charlottetown Guardian referencing the Premier's mandate letter to the Education… ▸ more
A December 2019 letter to the Charlottetown Guardian referencing the Premier's mandate letter to the Education Minister. Don notes that while the mandate lists good intentions, the underlying institutional soil needs improvement first. He laments that PEI's education vision has narrowed over his 50 years on the island and references Education 20/20's 2016 "Call for Action" requesting a "clear and compelling vision." Advocates for all-party collaboration to develop forward-looking education guidance.

References Souris study showing community education services are geared to program delivery rather than community needs. Don outlines his philosophy: education as experiences with formative effect, references OECD and Good's Dictionary definitions, and criticizes the current Department structure for not reflecting functions performed. Calls for overarching principles in education policy and notes the gap between community expectations and educational services delivered. October 20, 2019.

October 2019 100 confusing An October 2019 letter to the Charlottetown Guardian editor expressing concern about inconsistent use of education… ▸ more
An October 2019 letter to the Charlottetown Guardian editor expressing concern about inconsistent use of education terminology. Don distinguishes education (formative personal experience) from schooling (institutional provision), noting this confusion undermines policy coherence. He criticizes graded structures that assume uniform learner development and urges employers/institutions to recognize the distinction between credentials and qualifications. A concise statement of semantic confusion as a root cause of systemic problems.

Dated September 28, 2019.

Open Education No. 79 (August 25, 2019), bilingual English/French. Don questions whether early-years education should prioritize literacy, numeracy, self-care, community care, interpersonal relations, creativity, and lifelong learning as report-card subjects, with traditional subjects as medium. Cites evidence that boutique schools (music, sports, environment) contribute to student education. Reflects his holistic approach to learning beyond cognitive development.

August 20, 2019 letter to Charlottetown Guardian advocate for standard educational definitions. Criticizes confusion between education and schooling, notes inconsistent use of "learner/learning excellence," and points out that school grades provide administrative convenience rather than reliable indicators of learning. Argues employers are often disappointed by grade-credential mismatch.

Open Education No. 78 (July 20, 2019). Don examines the teacher's role in assessment and critiques the current system where government determines what's taught, employs teachers, and sets achievement standards. He questions this "incestuous" arrangement and advocates for clearer role definition. Article exemplifies his systems-level thinking about education governance and accountability.

Jul 4, 2019 106 math July 4, 2019 letter proposing a math skills mapping initiative for everyday Islander living. Don identifies three… ▸ more
July 4, 2019 letter proposing a math skills mapping initiative for everyday Islander living. Don identifies three reasons for the focus: importance for individuals/community, frequency of math concerns in public conversation, and disconnect between standardized testing results and workforce/further study outcomes. Advocates for citizen-based math mapping, restructured rating scales, and common analysis across math instruction on PEI.

Jun 3, 2019 Minister-Souris Dated June 3, 2019, this letter addresses Hon. Brad Trevors, newly appointed Minister of Education and Life Long… ▸ more
Dated June 3, 2019, this letter addresses Hon. Brad Trevors, newly appointed Minister of Education and Life Long Learning. Don congratulates him on his appointment and calls it "the most important portfolio in the Province." The letter updates the Minister on Education 20/20's activities in Souris, including community consultations on continuing education and a research study funded through the Labour Market Development Agreement. Don advocates strongly for continuing education, referencing Holland College's success in 1986-87 when it served over 3,000 night school students. He proposes that institutions encourage part-time education, suggests merging Senior's College and Community Schools into an island-wide continuing education service, and requests a meeting to explore the issue further.

EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jan 15, 2019 9 Right Thing This letter to editors (January 15, 2019, draft) reveals Don's leadership philosophy, connecting his experience… ▸ more
This letter to editors (January 15, 2019, draft) reveals Don's leadership philosophy, connecting his experience founding Holland College (50 years prior) with his current advocacy. He recounts adopting "do the next right thing"—a strategy he learned from a book (Cry the Beloved Country) while observing apartheid struggles in South Africa. Applied to PEI, he identifies the next right priority as developing "a clear and compelling vision of education for Islanders of all interests, all ages, all communities and all life roles—not just school-age Islanders." He urges establishing a vision-setting committee whose members are chosen for their views rather than constituent representation, and emphasizes that the Department must own the vision, not just adopt it. This piece provides valuable insight into Don's philosophy and his belief that Islanders have lost hope in educational improvement.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jan 15, 2019 9 Community Voice This letter to the Charlottetown Guardian and Journal Pioneer (January 15, 2019, draft version) argues that Souris—or… ▸ more
This letter to the Charlottetown Guardian and Journal Pioneer (January 15, 2019, draft version) argues that Souris—or any community—should have a standing committee to ensure its residents receive needed educational services, without necessarily operating schools municipally. Don emphasizes that meeting community needs is foundational to education's purpose and that modern technology enables this without silos. He directs readers to a Souris report on the Education 20/20 website, positioning Souris as a natural experimental site for community-based education planning, reflecting his ongoing engagement with local educational advocacy.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

Jan 15, 2019 8 Souris 1 Education - A Community resource Letter dated January 15, 2019, to Charlottetown Guardian and Journal Pioneer. Don discusses Education 20/20's community… ▸ more
Letter dated January 15, 2019, to Charlottetown Guardian and Journal Pioneer. Don discusses Education 20/20's community survey in Souris revealing employer struggles to find skilled workers and learner demand for practical, part-time, hands-on training. He argues education is "bundled" bureaucratically and proposes "unbundling" services (grading, qualifications, quality assurance) separate from school functions. References OECD recommendations on school autonomy and accountability.

CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jan 10, 2019 5 Self correcting Letter dated January 10, 2019, from Don to Charlottetown Guardian criticizing public education's lack of… ▸ more
Letter dated January 10, 2019, from Don to Charlottetown Guardian criticizing public education's lack of self-correcting mechanisms and responsiveness to user needs. He argues that unlike market-driven sectors, education faces no natural pressure for change because school attendance is mandatory and alternatives are scarce. He advocates for OECD models combining school autonomy with teacher accountability, and notes emerging alternatives in curriculum development, educational products, technology delivery, and qualification awarding.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
January 2019 10 Coninuing education in Souris January 2019 paper documenting Education 20/20's needs assessment for continuing education and workforce development in… ▸ more
January 2019 paper documenting Education 20/20's needs assessment for continuing education and workforce development in Souris, PEI (population 3,798 in surrounding area). Commissioned with Canada-PEI Labour Market agreement funding, the survey identified training needs and barriers including lack of local opportunities, commuting difficulties, internet access limitations, and awareness gaps. Employer challenges included shallow labor pools, specialized equipment training gaps, and IT skills shortages. Don recommends bridge-building measures: online access, classroom-and-hands-on programming, area-specific skills training, and barrier removal. The paper identifies systemic issues: lack of integrated planning, siloed educators, delivery gaps, and limited community voice in decision-making. This work exemplifies Don's commitment to rural community development and responsive education.
EDUCATION
Read · Download

Don Glendenning authored an opinion piece for The Guardian newspaper advocating for numeracy as a foundational skill in PEI's education system. He argues for curriculum reform to address gaps between school mathematics instruction and real-world competency needs identified by employers.

c. 2019 PEI Math Platform Project proposal document for the PEI Math Platform initiative by Education 20/20 Inc., with Don Glendenning listed as… ▸ more
Project proposal document for the PEI Math Platform initiative by Education 20/20 Inc., with Don Glendenning listed as primary contact (pei@education2020.ca, phone 902-892-5859). Proposal identifies a "math gap" in PEI education and proposes developing a competency-based curriculum master list reflecting math skills used by citizens in everyday life. Project objectives include creating a standard competencies list, developing elaboration packages, establishing common rating scales and benchmarks. Target audience: Islanders transitioning from public education to work or further studies. Estimated budget: $15,000. Addresses diverse stakeholders (teachers, employers, certification bodies, counselors). Published circa 2019.

2019 fundraising poster proposal for "Math for Every-Day Living" identifying Education 20/20 Inc.'s mission ("A quality education for every Canadian") and Don as primary contact. Articulates the challenge of fragmented math instruction across PEI providers and proposes identifying community-based competency maps through stakeholder convening. Reflects Don's ability to synthesize complex educational issues into compelling donor communications.

2019 00 Cover 2019 Cover page for December 2019 compilation of Education 20/20's "Open Education" newsletter series, featuring the first… ▸ more
Cover page for December 2019 compilation of Education 20/20's "Open Education" newsletter series, featuring the first 10 issues. Includes holiday greeting from Editor, Board, and Staff of Education 20/20. Expresses philosophy that writing is learning activity and creative outlet; newsletters provide information, raise questions, express opinions, generate ideas, and spark thinking. Explains initiative rationale: education is important issue, information drives change, education under-represented in public media. Reflects Don's commitment to public engagement and idea dissemination.

2019 2019-2 AGM Press release covering Education 20/20 annual meeting where Glendenning reported on organization activities including… ▸ more
Press release covering Education 20/20 annual meeting where Glendenning reported on organization activities including Souris continuing education survey. Glendenning highlighted community requests for online courses and hands-on training while noting poor course advertising and insufficient priority for continuing education. New officers elected with Glendenning serving as Treasurer. The organization thanked him for services during founding years, signifying his foundational role in establishing Education 20/20. Shows his transition to supporting rather than leading role while maintaining involvement.

2019 2019-1 Math map Press release for Education 20/20's innovative math skills mapping initiative, proposing to survey Islanders on… ▸ more
Press release for Education 20/20's innovative math skills mapping initiative, proposing to survey Islanders on mathematics used in daily life. Project estimated at $15,000, with fundraising underway through Community Foundation accounts. This novel approach addresses concerns about basic math skills among young Islanders by documenting practical applications. The creative methodology reflects Glendenning's willingness to challenge conventional educational thinking and his commitment to grounding curriculum in real-world competencies.

2019 2019- Poverty Press release connecting Nobel Economics Prize research on poverty to PEI education. The award recognized… ▸ more
Press release connecting Nobel Economics Prize research on poverty to PEI education. The award recognized ground-breaking work on health and education in developing countries, concluding that better instruction (rather than more teachers or resources) is key to improving outcomes. References PISA research findings and Montreal Economic Institute study on Quebec's accountability-driven success. Positions Don Glendenning as thoughtful analyst connecting global research to local policy. Shows his intellectual engagement with evidence-based education reform.

2019 2019 Probus Clean version of PROBUS Club briefing release. Education 20/20 survey in Souris revealed interest in online courses,… ▸ more
Clean version of PROBUS Club briefing release. Education 20/20 survey in Souris revealed interest in online courses, concerns about rural internet infrastructure, and workforce training needs in agriculture, fisheries, and tourism. Local businesses sought both advanced and practical training with better course information and career planning support. Glendenning's presentation stimulated robust discussion on education systems. This demonstrates his credibility with business leadership and his attention to rural PEI education and economic development concerns.

2019 2019 5-Seaward Media April 2019 press release announcing Education 20/20's math skills mapping initiative. Organization proposes surveying… ▸ more
April 2019 press release announcing Education 20/20's math skills mapping initiative. Organization proposes surveying everyday math skills used by Island residents, noting that despite math's frequency as a complaint topic, no empirical study of practical math skill use exists. Results will inform teachers, curriculum developers, standard-setting, counseling, career planning, and skill documentation. As part of annual meeting, Dr. Glendenning reviewed year's activities, particularly Souris continuing education survey revealing demand for online courses and hands-on training. Glendenning noted continuing education's importance but insufficient advertising and planning priority. Officers: Bill Whelan (Vice President), Ross Reid (Secretary); fundraising for math skills mapping underway.

2019 2019-Future of 2020 - 1 Highlight In this reflective planning document, Don Glendenning shares his personal journey founding Education 20/20 about a… ▸ more
In this reflective planning document, Don Glendenning shares his personal journey founding Education 20/20 about a decade prior, driven by concerns about public education turmoil. He describes his vision for a broad-based organization supporting quality education for Islanders of all ages. Don candidly discusses his underestimation of educational cloistering and his evolving concern about provincial educational quality despite organizational growth in his knowledge. He acknowledges his advancing age and suggests the need for organizational changes while reaffirming commitment to current projects. The document addresses foundational questions about Education 20/20's future direction, potential restructuring, and leadership succession.

Agenda for Education 20/20's sixth annual meeting for the year ending December 31, 2019. Standard business items included approval of previous minutes, president's report, financial statements and budgets, elections of directors and committee members. Following the formal meeting, community discussion on education needs of island communities was planned. The agenda reflects systematic governance structure and commitment to community dialogue.

2019 2019-Education Service-1 Early proposal for an education network model in Souris. Describes network functions paralleling the agency model but… ▸ more
Early proposal for an education network model in Souris. Describes network functions paralleling the agency model but emphasizing flexibility: not-for-profit, independent, granting transcripts but not credentials, cooperating with all providers, serving any subjects and fields. Explores multiple potential host organizations including Town of Souris, Education 20/20, schools, charitable organizations, and provincial bodies. Documents alternative institutional approaches to achieving community education goals.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2019 2019 B Continuing Educ This comprehensive needs assessment report outlines Education 20/20's findings from a formal survey conducted in late… ▸ more
This comprehensive needs assessment report outlines Education 20/20's findings from a formal survey conducted in late 2018 in Souris (population 3,798). The document identifies critical barriers to continuing education including lack of local training opportunities, inability to commute to distant programs, limited internet access, and low awareness of available services. Employers face a shallow labour pool and lack of specialized training. The report recommends establishing a local agency to coordinate and support continuing education services, offering skill training modules, online courses, and counselling. Potential funders include SkillsPEI, the Department of Education, and private donors. The document demonstrates systematic needs analysis and comprehensive recommendations for rural community educational development.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2019 Numeracy-project-2019-1 A comprehensive project proposal outlining the theoretical foundation and methodology for the Numeracy Project. The… ▸ more
A comprehensive project proposal outlining the theoretical foundation and methodology for the Numeracy Project. The document defines numeracy as application of mathematics across life domains, presents the Conference Board of Canada's assessment that Canada earns a "C" grade in numeracy, and proposes a structured approach to identifying essential numeracy competencies (estimating, counting, patterns, fractions, spatial reasoning, statistics, measurement, money management, time management, chance). The workplan includes six implementation tasks from initial analysis through adoption of assessment criteria and desired profiles for citizenship, employment, and postsecondary entry.

2019 2019Committee members List of Education 20/20 Awards Committee members for 2019 dated November 29, 2016 (likely a template or misdated… ▸ more
List of Education 20/20 Awards Committee members for 2019 dated November 29, 2016 (likely a template or misdated document). Members include Sharon Cameron (President), Donald DesRoches (College de l'isle President), David McCabe (School Superintendent, Retired), Peter Russell (Investment Adviser, RBC Dominion Securities), and Jeniene Peake (College Administrator, Retired). Notably absent from this list is Don Glendenning, though he is identified as President in other 2018 documents, suggesting organizational changes or committee rotation.

 Read · Download
2019 9 Treatment o unequals Inspired by a quote from John Terry, founding Director of the Eastern Nova Scotia Institute of Technology, Don… ▸ more
Inspired by a quote from John Terry, founding Director of the Eastern Nova Scotia Institute of Technology, Don critiques age-based classroom grouping. He observes that individuals possess different capacities, learn at different rates, and have varying experiences and interests, yet schools enroll them in uniform classes expecting identical growth. Don commends New Brunswick's initiative to eliminate grade levels and restructure around student learning needs, expressing interest in monitoring this progressive reform.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2019 8 Nobel omments Don references recent Nobel Economics Prize winners' research on poverty in Kenya and India, emphasizing that improved… ▸ more
Don references recent Nobel Economics Prize winners' research on poverty in Kenya and India, emphasizing that improved instruction (not merely more resources) is key to better educational outcomes. He highlights that half the world's children leave school without basic literacy and numeracy skills, with PEI students also requiring remediation. Don advocates for accountability measures, citing Quebec's strong PISA performance achieved through accountability at "virtually no additional cost," and the Montreal Economic Institute's research supporting this approach.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Dec 18, 2018 71 Souris Open Education No. 71 (December 18, 2018), authored by Don Glendenning reporting findings from the Souris Study… ▸ more
Open Education No. 71 (December 18, 2018), authored by Don Glendenning reporting findings from the Souris Study examining continuing education needs. Key learnings include: employers and learners prioritize hands-on practical training; information provision is an education function separate from instruction; community quality assurance responsibility is poorly defined; education-instruction distinction remains unrecognized; online courses interest learners but internet infrastructure must improve; quality assurance feedback is broken or missing. The article endorses the EdCan Network (75,000+ members advocating student success) and thanks volunteers and donors for sustaining advocacy work. The Souris Study demonstrates Education 20/20's commitment to evidence-based policy recommendations.

Nov 21, 2018 Attachment to second invoive A summary of activities for the Souris Project submitted November 21, 2018, documenting comprehensive community… ▸ more
A summary of activities for the Souris Project submitted November 21, 2018, documenting comprehensive community engagement. Work included survey instrument development, interview guide creation, promotion through print and social media, and distribution to 2,313 households. Of 212 responses received, 189 were validated at 1.7 confidence level. Stakeholder consultations involved business owners, employers, service providers, community organizations, and government. Signed by Don Glendenning as President of Education 20/20 Inc., indicating executive oversight of major community research initiative.

A formal grant application form submitted to Rotary on October 10, 2018, by Education 20/20 Inc., a registered charitable organization. Don Glendenning is identified as President and primary contact. The form establishes the organization's charitable status (CRA registration: 80082 7081 RR0001) and office location in Charlottetown. This foundational document catalogs project details for funding purposes and organizational accountability.

Sep 2, 2018 24 Larner progress Letter to Charlottetown Guardian (September 2, 2018) signed by Don Glendenning, "A long-time student of education."… ▸ more
Letter to Charlottetown Guardian (September 2, 2018) signed by Don Glendenning, "A long-time student of education." Addresses reporting learner progress and proposes rules of thumb for assessment including reference to Australian educator Gonski. Don articulates the problem of institutional silos in curriculum development and advocates for a common "math map" across schools, employers, and postsecondary institutions to enable better communication about competencies. He calls for leadership to unite stakeholders around shared assessment criteria and reporting.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

September 2018 09 A Framework for decision making September 2018 paper presenting "The Road of Life" as a metaphor for educational framework development. Don argues that… ▸ more
September 2018 paper presenting "The Road of Life" as a metaphor for educational framework development. Don argues that quality education provides preparation for successive life stages, from childhood through adult learning. He defines learners as people seeking behavioral change while bringing prior experiences, physical/mental conditions, and imagined futures to learning situations. The paper outlines education services (information, instruction, feedback, counseling, funding, products/technologies, leadership) and positioning education systems within provincial responsibility frameworks. Don's framework emphasizes that education systems exist to support both individual citizen development and community needs for skilled people. This theoretical paper provides philosophical underpinning for his practical reform recommendations.

Aug 20, 2018 77 Sysem is lost Letter dated August 20, 2018, to the Charlottetown Guardian. Don questions whether PEI's education system is "lost,"… ▸ more
Letter dated August 20, 2018, to the Charlottetown Guardian. Don questions whether PEI's education system is "lost," citing lack of clear mandates, guiding principles, and coherent structure. He proposes action to review and broaden departmental mandate, redefine the Department's leadership role, and implement clear learning models. Signed as "A long-time student of education." Reflects his broader critique of PEI's education system and advocacy for systemic change.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

Aug 20, 2018 13 News 2-lt-Bass ackwards Letter to Charlottetown Guardian (August 20, 2018) using a bus transportation analogy to frame education spending and… ▸ more
Letter to Charlottetown Guardian (August 20, 2018) using a bus transportation analogy to frame education spending and accountability. Don argues that while government investment in education (like bus purchases and maintenance) is important, accountability should focus on outcomes—improvements in literacy, numeracy, self-management, and skills—not merely inputs. He expresses concern that recent graduates enrolling in upgrading courses and employer complaints about new hire skills suggest disappointing returns on education investment. This demonstrates his pragmatic, outcome-focused approach to education policy evaluation.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

August 2018 24 News Let-What i the world Letter dated August 2018 from Don to Charlottetown Guardian cataloging emerging educational innovations and reforms he… ▸ more
Letter dated August 2018 from Don to Charlottetown Guardian cataloging emerging educational innovations and reforms he finds noteworthy: gradeless report cards in BC, competency-based education in Canadian medical schools, democratic school models, holistic assessment scales in PEI, and full-service schools in Toronto. His list demonstrates wide reading across North American education systems and reflects his interests in alternative educational models. The tone suggests both curiosity and concern about rapid change.

Jul 27, 2018 8 Reaching our objective Letter dated July 27, 2018, to Charlottetown Guardian. Don states education system's role is helping citizens learn… ▸ more
Letter dated July 27, 2018, to Charlottetown Guardian. Don states education system's role is helping citizens learn functional skills, asserts most people can learn with help, and argues government is responsible and has tools for change. Cites OECD PISA research on school autonomy and accountability. Reflects his evidence-based approach to education reform and belief in achievable systemic change.

Jul 27, 2018 3 Rating scle employment Letter dated July 27, 2018, to Charlottetown Guardian from Don addressing the transition from education to workplace.… ▸ more
Letter dated July 27, 2018, to Charlottetown Guardian from Don addressing the transition from education to workplace. Drawing on historical Federal government leadership in employment training, Don expresses concern that quality assurance functions have shifted to provinces without adequate capacity. He highlights differences between educational achievement reporting and employment assessment needs (which require evaluation of work quality, timeliness, and problem-solving). He advocates for maintaining Canada's post-WWII reputation for excellent employment training.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

 Read · Download
Jul 27, 2018 1-Leadership Editor letter to Charlottetown Guardian (July 27, 2018) arguing that education, particularly public education, remains… ▸ more
Editor letter to Charlottetown Guardian (July 27, 2018) arguing that education, particularly public education, remains in "constant turmoil" with growing gap between needed and provided services. Analyzes three key issues: government education role overly narrowed to school operations (criticizing as equivalent to delivering all health through hospitals); "fear factor" and politicization limiting professional autonomy; and structural misalignment preventing adequate services. Notes structural change unlikely without systemic reorganization, though commends ministerial efforts.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jul 27, 2018 Let-Services rendered A letter to the editor of the Charlottetown Guardian (July 27, 2018) signed by Don Glendenning. The letter addresses… ▸ more
A letter to the editor of the Charlottetown Guardian (July 27, 2018) signed by Don Glendenning. The letter addresses PEI's substantial education budget (approximately $250 million annually, about $12,000 per student) and questions how educational services are organized and delivered. Don contrasts provider-driven versus user-driven systems and notes that PEI self-delivers most services through schools, resulting in a "politicized, bureaucratic, out of date" culture lacking accountability. He suggests alternatives including educational centers that co-locate services in community centers. The letter calls for developing a clear educational philosophy and long-term goals emphasizing a learning culture that fosters continuing education, accountability, self-reliance, and collaboration. The closing lists aspirational goals: "all can learn," "all will learn," "learn together."
EDUCATION

Jul 20, 2018 B MRSB -47 Contract Update Final from MRSB This formal agreement between Education 20/20 Inc. (Don Glendenning, President) and MRSB Consulting Services governs… ▸ more
This formal agreement between Education 20/20 Inc. (Don Glendenning, President) and MRSB Consulting Services governs the Assessment of Continuing Education and Workforce Development Needs in Souris. The contract is effective April 20-July 20, 2018, with a budget not to exceed $32,051 including HST. Services include background research, environmental scans, interviews with government, employers, and education providers, survey design and distribution to ~2,300 households, data analysis, and final reporting. Payment is structured in four phases (30%, 30%, 20%, 20%) based on project milestones. Don is identified as the reporting contact.

This is an early draft offer acceptance/non-disclosure/confidentiality agreement between Education 20/20 Inc. (March 25-July 14, 2018) and MRSB Consulting Services. The agreement establishes confidentiality protocols for proprietary information related to the continuing education project. Standard legal provisions address information ownership, non-disclosure obligations, use restrictions, and enforcement mechanisms. The agreement reflects standard professional consulting practices and the sensitive nature of community needs assessment data.

July 2018 3 Lexicon Club Open Education No. 66 (July 2018), authored by Don Glendenning introducing the "Lexicon Club"—an imagined community of… ▸ more
Open Education No. 66 (July 2018), authored by Don Glendenning introducing the "Lexicon Club"—an imagined community of education stakeholders who communicate precisely about education. Members understand distinctions between schooling and education, learners and students, instruction and education, credentials and qualifications. The article describes the club's jurisdiction extending across Don's farm north of Finnegan's Brook and supporting education quality improvements across Canada. The Souris Study findings are reported (surveying continuing education needs), and the century-long history of federal education support is acknowledged. The piece reflects Don's commitment to precise language as essential to education reform and documents ongoing research initiatives.

July 2018 B MRSB Replacement Appendix B Highlight This is a consulting services agreement (April-July 2018) between Education 20/20 Inc. and MRSB Consulting Services… ▸ more
This is a consulting services agreement (April-July 2018) between Education 20/20 Inc. and MRSB Consulting Services Inc. for conducting an assessment of continuing education and workforce development needs in the Souris area. The contract, signed by Dr. Donald Glendenning as President of Education 20/20, outlines the scope of work including background research, interviews with government representatives, survey design, data collection of 500+ surveys, and comprehensive analysis. The project budget totals $32,051 including HST, with professional consulting fees of $25,000, and survey costs of $4,801. The consultant reports directly to Dr. Don Glendenning.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jun 21, 2018 2 Education for employmennt Open Education No. 1 (June 21, 2018), authored by Don Glendenning addressing federal leadership in education for… ▸ more
Open Education No. 1 (June 21, 2018), authored by Don Glendenning addressing federal leadership in education for employment. The article recounts historical federal initiatives in the 1960s that justified vocational education through industrial need, educational equality, and cost-sharing between levels of government. Don documents federal criteria that drove program effectiveness: programs not courses, local advisory committees, substantial skill training, experienced teachers, and relevant analysis. He expresses concern that newer funding arrangements have lost important safeguards, raising questions about whether contemporary education-for-employment programs maintain the rigor of historical models.

Jun 1, 2018 B MRSB-4 contract A fourth contract iteration (March-June 2018) establishing activities and timelines for the project. Key activities… ▸ more
A fourth contract iteration (March-June 2018) establishing activities and timelines for the project. Key activities include conducting surveys from project signing through June 1, 2018, to identify continuing education and workforce development needs, reviewing collected data with Education 20/20, and disseminating findings to stakeholders in June. The survey targets the Souris workforce and focuses on identifying service gaps and accessibility improvements. Standard budget of $32,051 with interim payments tied to milestone completion. Confirms Dr. Don Glendenning as the authorized company representative.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
May 21, 2018 21-1 News A10 Let-PuzzlerOECD recommend Letter dated May 21, 2018, analyzing PISA (Programme for International Student Assessment) results and OECD… ▸ more
Letter dated May 21, 2018, analyzing PISA (Programme for International Student Assessment) results and OECD recommendations. Don notes Canada and PEI performed well on 2015 PISA tests measuring 15-year-olds' essential knowledge and skills. However, he highlights OECD's 2011 finding that schools with greater autonomy over curriculum and assessment outperform others. References Quebec's success attributed to combined autonomy and accountability (Montreal Economic Institute) and Japan's approach (98% autonomy on evaluation policies, 89% on course content). Concludes PEI principals and teachers have minimal autonomy, calling it a "puzzler" why the province doesn't implement these proven strategies.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

Outlines Education 20/20's work on math education transition, student performance measurement, and continuing education opportunities, seeking support for educational improvement on PEI.

March 2018 07 Quality Education The published March 2018 version of Occasional Paper No. 7, this document presents Don's definition of quality… ▸ more
The published March 2018 version of Occasional Paper No. 7, this document presents Don's definition of quality education and analysis of international frameworks. He distinguishes between "education" as formative life experiences and "schooling" as formal instruction, arguing many educators conflate these terms. The paper examines quality education from perspectives of UNICEF, UNESCO, OECD, and others, emphasizing that quality requires more than test scores. Key themes include the importance of school autonomy, accountability, learner-centered approaches, and professional teacher development. Don's contribution includes critiques of traditional grading systems and calls for independent qualification bodies. The published version refines arguments from the draft revision.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
March 2018 07 Quality Education - Rev This March 2018 draft explores definitions and characteristics of quality education, contrasting historical focus on… ▸ more
This March 2018 draft explores definitions and characteristics of quality education, contrasting historical focus on cognitive development with contemporary emphasis on individual quality of life and sustainable human development. Don synthesizes frameworks from UNICEF, UNESCO, OECD, and the World Bank to define quality education comprehensively. The paper argues that quality education requires healthy learners supported by families, safe environments, relevant curricula, child-centered teaching approaches, and outcomes linked to national goals and social participation. Don advocates for autonomy in schools and independent assessment services, drawing on international research suggesting greater school autonomy correlates with student performance. The document demonstrates his synthesis of global best practices for PEI application.

Jan 31, 2018 6-Souris Fund letter This January 31, 2018 letter from Don Glendenning solicits the PEI Union of Public Sector Employees as lead donor for… ▸ more
This January 31, 2018 letter from Don Glendenning solicits the PEI Union of Public Sector Employees as lead donor for the Souris Education Innovation Fund with a requested $1,500 contribution. Don provides detailed background on Education 20/20 Inc.'s incorporation (2012), charitable status (2015), and activities including awards, newsletters, and consultations. He articulates the organization's expansion from school/organization recognition to supporting innovative educational ideas in specific communities through matching funds. This letter exemplifies Don's fundraising acumen, organizational credibility-building, and strategic partnership development skills.

2018 8 Education services Published Guardian letter reframing education as a service industry with distinct functions (governance, funding,… ▸ more
Published Guardian letter reframing education as a service industry with distinct functions (governance, funding, instruction, HR, technology, counselling, quality assurance). Don argues schools are venue-based delivery points for one service among many, not the totality of education.

2018 90- Don critiques PEI's shift from education-as-service to education-as-product (credentials, degrees, certificates). He… ▸ more
Don critiques PEI's shift from education-as-service to education-as-product (credentials, degrees, certificates). He references a 2018 World Bank report and discusses emerging models like microcredentials. Don advocates for PEI to establish a glossary of educational terms, overarching guidelines, and collaborative framework to move forward. Published June 4, 2020 in Open Education No. 90.

2018 10 Call for action 2018 -updated Formal "Call for Action" document (July 16, 2018) from Education 20/20 Inc. (101 Kent St., Charlottetown) signed by Don… ▸ more
Formal "Call for Action" document (July 16, 2018) from Education 20/20 Inc. (101 Kent St., Charlottetown) signed by Don Glendenning presenting comprehensive education reform recommendations. Documents gaps between Islander needs and education services, citing PISA results, youth surveys, Chamber of Commerce presentations, and parent federation surveys. Proposes six major initiatives: comprehensive vision statement, independent qualification service, school autonomy, professional service delivery model, staff development, and provincial leadership in creating learning culture. Emphasizes student-centered outcomes, criterion-referenced assessment, and professional accountability to clients.

2018 RotaryApplication Formal Rotary Club grant application (2018) for $13,000 funding toward Numeracy Map project. Contact: Don Glendenning,… ▸ more
Formal Rotary Club grant application (2018) for $13,000 funding toward Numeracy Map project. Contact: Don Glendenning, 101 Kent St., Charlottetown. Application describes the challenge: inconsistent approaches to mathematics education across PEI. Proposes convening 10-person panel (tourists, parents, teachers, employers) to map everyday math skills needed by 21st-century Islanders and employment-entry-level profiles. Detailed workplan includes 30-day completion target. Demonstrates Don's systematic approach to education reform through outcomes-based methodology.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2018 88-Going to school Don cites Good's Dictionary definition of education as aggregation of processes developing positive societal value… ▸ more
Don cites Good's Dictionary definition of education as aggregation of processes developing positive societal value abilities. Purpose of education systems is arranging learning experiences. Services include information, counselling, instruction, assessment, educational products, and human resources. While learning is individual, schools serve as convenient gathering places (similar to hospitals or shopping plazas), but learning extends beyond school walls. References 2018 World Bank report criticizing ministries' education definitions. Don argues PEI has shifted from providing individualized services toward "adding education products" (credits, courses, certificates, degrees) to résumés—the opposite of US trend toward institutional memberships enabling on-demand educational access. Recommends PEI needs: educational terminology glossary, overarching guidelines for decision-making, and collaborative operational framework. Discusses microcredentials as short, specific courses enabling employment/upgrading without excessive student debt. Includes references to competency definitions and learning objectives distinctions.
EDUCATION

2018 3 Activities 2018 Activities document from 2018 describing Education 20/20 Inc.'s programming and initiatives. Lists monthly bilingual… ▸ more
Activities document from 2018 describing Education 20/20 Inc.'s programming and initiatives. Lists monthly bilingual newsletters, annual education excellence awards, occasional papers on educational issues, STEAM workshops for young Islanders in science/technology/engineering/arts/math, presentations on education topics, research projects (including community capacity survey in Souris, PEI focusing on out-of-school youth education interests). Includes philosophical statement emphasizing education's formative effect on how we think, feel, and act.

The breadth of ideas demonstrates Don's entrepreneurial approach to educational innovation and his organization's commitment to addressing multiple dimensions of educational improvement across PEI.

(100-200 words each):** Identical accounting ledgers for Education 20/20 Inc. covering early 2018 (January-March). Records opening balance ($884.43), donations from Don Glendenning ($250) and Bill Whelan ($250 as Vice President), and translation service expenses ($105 Sylvie Dauphinaise for three issues). The accounts show the organization maintaining modest but consistent operations. Don's continued personal donations demonstrate his financial commitment to the organization beyond his leadership role. The duplicate filing suggests administrative redundancy or document management practices. These records reveal Education 20/20's ongoing operations with Don actively sustaining the organization through personal financial support.

2018 Minues 0AGM2019 Meeting minutes documenting Education 20/20's AGM held June 18, 2019, with Don Glendenning as President. The… ▸ more
Meeting minutes documenting Education 20/20's AGM held June 18, 2019, with Don Glendenning as President. The president's report highlighted the successful completion of the Souris Research Project and noted that the annual award was not given due to limited applicants. A significant agenda item involved Don's proposed research on "how much math do you need to know to fulfill the obligations of citizenship," advocating for practical mathematics education focusing on financial numeracy and everyday life applications. Directors were elected including Sharon Cameron as new President.

2018 2018 President's report President's report for the year ending December 31, 2018, reflecting significant project expansion. Education 20/20… ▸ more
President's report for the year ending December 31, 2018, reflecting significant project expansion. Education 20/20 secured funding from SkilsPEI to conduct a comprehensive survey of continuing education needs and opportunities in Souris, contracting with MRSB for the research. Glendenning's conclusions emphasized that continuing education represents an important but underrecognized component of the educational landscape in Island communities. The organization continued publishing "Open Education" newsletter (monthly bilingual publication) with translation support. No education award postings were accepted that year. The report identifies mathematics skills development as an ongoing research interest. Glendenning documents the organization's evolution toward substantive research projects addressing real community education gaps while maintaining advocacy and networking activities.

2018 Mtg 36 Note Don's memo to board directors prior to April 4 meeting outlines organizational transition planning and governance… ▸ more
Don's memo to board directors prior to April 4 meeting outlines organizational transition planning and governance structure work. Don proposes "reset" of Education 20/20 to clarify organizational purpose, increase community profile, and regularize operations. Indicates each director will receive a comprehensive package of organizational documents including promotional materials, company information, director list, vision statement, board regulations, bylaws, goal-based plans, and occasional papers. Proposes formal review and confirmation of: role of Secretary, role of Treasurer, role of Awards Committee, role of Souris Project Committee. Notes three-year director appointments with option for single renewal followed by one-year minimum break. Proposes annual executive elections with past president chairing nominating committee. Don expresses willingness to step down as Chair at any time but willing to serve additional months/year to ease transition and indicates desire to delegate operations if re-elected. Proposes setting Annual Meeting for mid-May and offers his cottage in Earnscliffe as potential retreat/planning location with BBQ/social option. Notes need to recruit replacement for Anne Miller given quorum issues. This memo reflects Don's sophisticated understanding of governance best practices and commitment to organizational stability.
