2018 Mtg 35 Lifelong Learning Advisor Proposal This comprehensive proposal details Education 20/20's ambitious Lifelong Learning Advisor program for Prince Edward… ▸ more
This comprehensive proposal details Education 20/20's ambitious Lifelong Learning Advisor program for Prince Edward Island. The initiative proposes hiring a bilingual (English/French with potential Mandarin translation) advisor as single point of contact for all learning inquiries on PEI. Responsibilities include fielding phone/online/in-person inquiries, directing residents to resources, identifying continuing education gaps, creating new opportunities where demand exceeds supply, administering a live-calendar website, and managing website advertising for revenue generation. A partnership with a marketing firm would develop public awareness campaigns utilizing multiple media channels. Budget detailed at $225,000 for three-year pilot including office space ($800/month), advisor wages ($4,000/month), communication/office costs, media ($10,000/year during pilot), and website development ($5,000). Potential revenue streams identified as federal/provincial government, private donors, website self-generation, and organizational fundraising. This ambitious proposal reflects Don's vision for addressing community education gaps through accessible, coordinated services.

2018 Mtg 35 Contd Feb 6, 2018 Detailed minutes from February 6, 2018 meeting document significant organizational and educational developments. Ross… ▸ more
Detailed minutes from February 6, 2018 meeting document significant organizational and educational developments. Ross Reid elected as secretary. Minutes from November and January meetings approved. Don's President's Report covered: a letter requesting meetings with provincial party leaders (Green Party responded positively); meetings with Minister of Education forthcoming; math transition project focus on alignment/consistency of terminology and skepticism about teachers assigning proficiency levels (preferring independent regulatory bodies); new perspective on math skills as clusters of demonstrated abilities. Treasurer's report shows $1,400 account balance. Souris Research Project discussion addressed Skills PEI insurance requirement ($2 million coverage), need for consultant proposals with letters of intent vs. full proposals, deliverable clarification, and project timeline definition. Don and Katherine assigned to sign funding application to SkillsPEI. Board discussion revealed concerns about online education accessibility barriers and identified Souris research as potential pilot for broader community education gap-filling initiatives. Don proposed Education 20/20 could develop and fund its own courses. Board members agreed to defer course development decisions pending data from Souris research. Insurance discussion concluded not immediately necessary given organization size. Fundraising discussion noted Don's willingness to pursue personal fundraising with board support.

2018 2018 Continuing Educ-1 handout This public-facing handout summarizes the Souris continuing education initiative for community distribution. It… ▸ more
This public-facing handout summarizes the Souris continuing education initiative for community distribution. It provides context about Souris's population (3,798), economy (fishing, aquaculture, agriculture, tourism), and identifies barriers to continuing education including lack of opportunities, inability to commute, timing issues, limited internet access, and lack of awareness. The document notes employer challenges and outlines Education 20/20 Inc.'s guiding principles emphasizing information access, collaboration, practical training, and online delivery with learning management. Several implementation options are proposed, including research initiatives, hiring an education organizer, and establishing training facilities.

It proposes moving project discussions up organizational levels and emphasizes reframing discussion around underlying issues from the study. It expresses preference for full board discussion and proposes establishing a continuing education organizer position as central to conversations. The memo convenes directors while accommodating scheduling constraints and establishes need-to-know regarding director availability and willingness to participate.

2018 2018 Media final report A November 23, 2018 press release announcing survey results on Souris training needs. The survey of 2,000+ households… ▸ more
A November 23, 2018 press release announcing survey results on Souris training needs. The survey of 2,000+ households and community institutions found residents want practical, hands-on training with better access to online courses. Interest areas include health, small business, computer studies, and trades. Preferred delivery methods: 59% online, 40% night school, 38% correspondence/self-study. The press release emphasizes the survey's funding through the Department of Workforce and Advanced Learning and identifies Don Glendenning as President of Education 20/20 Inc., with contact information provided.

2018 Budget notes2018 Proposal 2018-B Comprehensive 2018 project proposal for community education needs assessment in Souris. Provides extensive demographic… ▸ more
Comprehensive 2018 project proposal for community education needs assessment in Souris. Provides extensive demographic and socioeconomic context, describes Education 20/20's consultations, identifies continuing education need, and outlines objectives: inventory existing services, assess adult needs/interests, identify employer training needs, and assess organizational capacity. Proposed approach includes forming steering committee, developing interview guides, conducting surveys, analyzing data, and sharing findings. Budget of $13,600 covers professional oversight, guide preparation, interviews, youth engagement, analysis, reporting, meetings, and administration. Shows Don's systematic approach to community research and planning.

2018 PVI-2018 Press release dated February 20, 2018 announcing Education 20/20 Inc. public conversation on quality education for… ▸ more
Press release dated February 20, 2018 announcing Education 20/20 Inc. public conversation on quality education for March 1, 2018, from 12:00-1:00 pm at the Inspire Centre in Summerside, PEI. Features Dr. Don Glendenning, President of Education 20/20, advocating for reframing education as a service industry focused on helping learners acquire coping and thriving skills. Glendenning emphasizes that OECD and UNICEF quality recommendations—though low-cost—are largely ignored. Notes institutional reforms occurring elsewhere: rethinking high-stakes testing, introducing continuous progress, replacing school grades with achievement levels, establishing external assessment bodies, and recognizing school autonomy and accountability as improvement drivers. Suggests that if institutions don't change, people will seek help elsewhere and proposes funding services rather than institutions. Describes Education 20/20 Inc. as an independent, broad-based nonprofit focused on improving education quality for all Canadians. Public contact information provided (Don Glendenning, pei@education2020.ca, 902-892-5859).
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2018 Math 2018-1-E Highlight Formal occasional paper (No. 8, June 1, 2018) addressing comprehensive mathematics education reform framework. Begins… ▸ more
Formal occasional paper (No. 8, June 1, 2018) addressing comprehensive mathematics education reform framework. Begins with Community Foundation of PEI youth survey (2013) identifying preparedness gaps and Education 20/20's subsequent engagement. Emphasizes mathematics as essential citizen-level skill learnable by all Islanders. Details instruction providers: public schools (mandatory annual instruction through graduation with grade-based achievement reporting and streaming), postsecondary institutions (UPEI programs and School of Mathematics and Computational Science), SkillsPEI (federally funded training), private schools (province-aligned), and independent learners. Establishes basic educational beliefs: learning as individual matter, group setting constraints, behavior-change resultants, teacher enablement roles, self-correction lack, education independence from school attendance, achievement over time emphasis, and non-grading educational functions. Details instructional support services including governance, information, learning products, competency maps, assessment criteria, rating scales, profiles, instruction, human resources, and learning opportunities. Documents field developments: MPHEC format changes, competency-based education trends, holistic rating scales, independent field analysis, school ungrading, independent qualification authorities, streaming disappearance, and lifelong education services. Presents ten system conclusions and comprehensive nine-part recommendation set addressing belief statements, competency-based outcomes, curriculum platforms, education term lexicons, profile identification, and learning guides. Details extensive benefits including employer tools, SkillsPEI platforms, job-seeker transcripts, counseling tools, provider communication, instructional relevance, worker upgrade guidance, and professional organization references.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2018 Math 2018-1-D Policy paper addressing mathematics education following Community Foundation of PEI's youth survey (2013) revealing… ▸ more
Policy paper addressing mathematics education following Community Foundation of PEI's youth survey (2013) revealing preparedness gaps in postsecondary and workplace readiness. Documents Education 20/20's six public discussion series responding to survey findings. Frames mathematics as essential citizen-level skill for all Islanders based on Oregon Department of Education principles. Identifies instruction providers spanning public schools (comprehensive Grades 1-12 with testing and streaming), postsecondary (UPEI programs and School of Mathematics), SkillsPEI (federal funding coordination), private schools, and independent learners. Analyzes proficiency determinants: skill number, performance level, and clustering. Distinguishes formative assessment (interactive teacher-student process) from summative assessment (regulatory independent function). Notes competencies as "gradeless" (learnable across all levels with varying achievement). Documents related developments including MPHEC competency adoption, Queens medical program conversion, holistic rating scales, independent field analysis, ungraded schools, separate grading authorities, and streaming disappearance. States eleven system conclusions emphasizing non-school-alone solutions, fragmentation, grading non-educational role, inconsistent teacher authorization, definition barriers, coordination absence, and provider cooperation willingness. References "Taking the Pulse of Island Youth" Community Foundation survey.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2018 2018--5 Recommendations Formal recommendations (2018-5) summarizing the working group's conclusions. Recommends PEI undertake mathematical… ▸ more
Formal recommendations (2018-5) summarizing the working group's conclusions. Recommends PEI undertake mathematical skills analysis for typical citizens and work-entry competencies, establish math profiles for different contexts, create an independent evaluation body for achievement levels, adopt community-aligned rating criteria, and develop a dynamic mathematics rating scale. These recommendations represent the distilled wisdom from months of stakeholder discussions and position an independent external assessment body as central to solving transition problems.

This document demonstrates Don's public role in recognizing educational excellence.

2018 2018 Description Official award description for the 2018 Excellence in Education Award ($2,500). The award focused on collaboration as a… ▸ more
Official award description for the 2018 Excellence in Education Award ($2,500). The award focused on collaboration as a strategy for improving education in PEI public schools. The document outlines that collaboration can take multiple forms—between teachers in the same school, between different schools, with colleges/universities, or with outside organizations. It details submission requirements (maximum 3 pages), application criteria, and contact information for Education 20/20 Inc. headquartered at 101 Kent Street, Charlottetown. This document demonstrates Don's vision for fostering collaborative educational approaches.

2018 2018 Learning path August 2, 2015 Education 20/20 Inc. occasional paper presenting a learning path model developed from youth panel… ▸ more
August 2, 2015 Education 20/20 Inc. occasional paper presenting a learning path model developed from youth panel discussions about effective learning supports. The model identifies five learning process components: entry point, exploration (gathering information, observation, assessment), engagement (instruction, practice, feedback), documentation (credentials, qualifications), and exit point. The framework validates individual learning styles and pacing, presenting learning as cyclical rather than linear, accommodating spiral curricula. Document emphasizes learning broadly (beyond schooling) and represents collaborative development with students, facilitators, and educators. This work directly reflects Don's learner-centered educational philosophy.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Oct 29, 2017 1-A Background Detailed background document from October 29, 2017 establishing the context for proficiency level initiatives. Begins… ▸ more
Detailed background document from October 29, 2017 establishing the context for proficiency level initiatives. Begins with the 2013 Community Foundation of PEI survey identifying youth concerns about preparedness gaps for postsecondary study and employment. Following this report, Education 20/20 organized community discussions and published recommendations. The document catalogs multiple concerns: PEI's unsatisfactory PISA scores, low literacy rates, declining enrollment in adult basic education, employer-reported skill shortages, and parent/grandparent disappointment. Key conclusions state that diplomas/degrees are unreliable achievement measures, grading is not a school function, and current organization likely duplicates adult education services. The document proposes skill-based curriculum development, independent proficiency bodies, community-based criteria, universal skill lists, and holistic growth tracking—all designed to reduce bias, improve consistency, reduce teacher workload, remove conflict of interest, and support independent learning.

Reveals Don's personal warmth, concern for colleagues, and attention to administrative details (newsletter distribution) amid organizational work.

CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Feb 12, 2017 16 News 5 Let Potemkin Letter to Charlottetown Guardian (February 12, 2017) using the historical metaphor of Potemkin villages (portable… ▸ more
Letter to Charlottetown Guardian (February 12, 2017) using the historical metaphor of Potemkin villages (portable facades built to impress Catherine the Great in 1787) to critique PEI education system improvements. Don questions whether education system changes represent genuine quality improvements versus superficial "Potemkin" reforms. He references UNICEF 2000 quality education characteristics (relevant content, autonomous schools, accountable teachers, learning-linked outcomes, learner-focused support) and wonders if measured improvement constitutes authentic system transformation. This demonstrates his skeptical, analytically sharp approach to evaluating education policy rhetoric versus reality.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Feb 12, 2017 14 News 3 Let- Implied contract Letter to Charlottetown Guardian (February 12, 2017) examining implicit contracts between educational institutions and… ▸ more
Letter to Charlottetown Guardian (February 12, 2017) examining implicit contracts between educational institutions and students. Don references student guarantee programs at University of Regina and warranty programs at Canadian colleges, where students can return tuition-free if they lack employment-ready skills. He distinguishes between education as service (teachers helping students learn) versus education as product (institutions granting credentials). The document raises critical questions about institutional accountability and the distinction between credentials and qualifications, reflecting his deep engagement with education accountability frameworks.

2017 12 News 2 Math ProblemNews 2 Math Problem Comprehensive 2017 paper analyzing math education challenges in PEI. Defines education, mathematics, and math… ▸ more
Comprehensive 2017 paper analyzing math education challenges in PEI. Defines education, mathematics, and math education; reviews provincial responsibilities and competency-based outcomes; discusses transition challenges between secondary and post-secondary systems. Includes extensive observations noting curriculum coordination gaps, need for master skills lists, common assessment criteria, and independent assessment bodies. Recommends competency-based instruction, student-paced learning, holistic rating scales, and user-based advisory committees. References current educational reform literature and international models.

Written by Don Glendenning, Editor, Education 20/20 Inc.

2017 48 2017-01-20 - no 48 - Functions English-language newsletter no. 48 (January 20, 2017) edited by Don Glendenning reviewing the functions of education… ▸ more
English-language newsletter no. 48 (January 20, 2017) edited by Don Glendenning reviewing the functions of education systems versus school systems. Lists education functions (leadership, information, counseling, instruction, human resources, technology, governance, feedback) and school functions (assessment, accountability, standards, professional development, autonomy, engagement, safety, discipline). Reports that Maureen Kerr has resigned from the Board and discusses Education 20/20's efforts to formalize structure and operations. Demonstrates Glendenning's analytical approach to systems-level educational organization.

2017 2017-Last call for nominations February 20, 2017 press release announcing $2,500 award for Island community education projects. Education 20/20 seeks… ▸ more
February 20, 2017 press release announcing $2,500 award for Island community education projects. Education 20/20 seeks proposals (max 3 pages) describing education projects that serve communities. Award to be made in May 2017. Proposal guidelines ask: What will be done? Why? Who will be served? Activities can be full-time or part-time; schools or community centers may partner. Emphasizes that education is everyone's business and encourages community collaboration. Nominations due April 30, 2017. Organization described as independent, broad-based, national, not-for-profit, located in Charlottetown, maintaining website, publishing monthly newsletter, offering workshops.

2017 2017-Work plan 4 This planning document summarizes possible initiatives for 2017, reiterating the two primary goals established for… ▸ more
This planning document summarizes possible initiatives for 2017, reiterating the two primary goals established for Education 20/20 Inc. The document presents the goal framework with corresponding voting results for proposed outcomes, condensing the strategic direction previously detailed in File 9. The repetition suggests this was part of an iterative planning process where Don and his team refined organizational priorities and assessed director consensus on key strategic directions for education reform, community engagement, and policy advocacy.

2017 2017-Work plan 3 Highlight This November 2017 document outlines proposed initiatives for Education 20/20 Inc. addressing identified gaps in… ▸ more
This November 2017 document outlines proposed initiatives for Education 20/20 Inc. addressing identified gaps in education: information, counselling, independent grading, coordination, communication, leadership, and accountability. Specific initiatives include continuing education programs, information and counselling services, drop-in education centres, qualification authority development, instructional materials, education pathways, navigator programs, and workshops promoting an ideal school system. Additional priorities include roundtables, discussions, newsletters, assessment services, and operational projects like managing the Souris Garden Club and exploring charitable sector developments. The comprehensive list reflects Don's ambitious vision for systemic educational improvement on Prince Edward Island.

2017 2017 President's report Glendenning's 2017 president's report highlighting expanded organizational activities and impact. The organization… ▸ more
Glendenning's 2017 president's report highlighting expanded organizational activities and impact. The organization awarded $2,500 to STEAM PEI for innovative math instruction combining science, technology, engineering, and mathematics education. Glendenning maintained ongoing education policy discussions with provincial government officials. The report documents participation in the Canadian Education Association's second regional workshop in Halifax, informal discussions addressing mathematics education challenges, and exploratory work on educational service gaps in Souris, PEI. The organization received a significant WISEAtlantic grant for the Project STEAM initiative. Glendenning's report demonstrates his focus on practical educational problems and collaborative problem-solving across government, nonprofit, and institutional sectors.

2017 Mtg 34 minutess Official minutes of Meeting 34 held November 23, 2017 document Don's welcoming leadership and organizational… ▸ more
Official minutes of Meeting 34 held November 23, 2017 document Don's welcoming leadership and organizational development work. Don welcomed new directors (Tess Miller, Ross Reid, Ronnie McIntosh) with special acknowledgement and noted Alice Taylor's withdrawal due to personal commitments. Don led discussion reviewing a list of potential projects which he emphasized as personally important and part of his transition planning. Extended conversation addressed potential organizational projects, public awareness campaigns, advocacy roles for public service awareness, partnerships with various stakeholders, and research capabilities. Don thanked participants for contributions. Board approved new directors unanimously. Decisions made include: postponing WISE Atlantic decision to December; Don to create poster/press release for Excellence in Education Award; newsletter ready for publication; Christmas reception confirmed December 13, 4-6 pm; Don and Ross assigned to represent Education 20/20 on Learning Partners Advisory Council. Discussion touched on research questions and data collection as potentially valuable initiatives.

2017 Mtg 34 Discussion question This document presents Don's discussion questions on school standards for Meeting 34, revealing his sophisticated… ▸ more
This document presents Don's discussion questions on school standards for Meeting 34, revealing his sophisticated thinking about educational assessment and structure. Topics addressed include: confusion about grade-level outcomes versus universal outcomes; the basis for grade-level differentiation (number of skills demonstrated, achievement levels, clustering extent); and critical questioning of why uniform criteria shouldn't apply across all educational levels including community and employment contexts. Most provocatively, Don challenges the role of teachers in sorting/stratifying students, suggesting this function creates teacher-student conflicts and should be reserved for regulatory bodies rather than classroom practitioners.

2017 Skill Development 2017 poster Promotional poster for a facilitated discussion on skill development for Prince Edward Island held April 5, 2017 from… ▸ more
Promotional poster for a facilitated discussion on skill development for Prince Edward Island held April 5, 2017 from 7:00-8:30 pm at the Southport Room, Stratford Town Hall. The event was organized by Education 20/20 Inc. to gather Islander perspectives on provincial budget speech initiatives, including advanced manufacturing, agri-food, clean technology, digital industries, health biosciences, and clean resources. The poster highlights support for vulnerable youth skills development and integrated post-secondary learning opportunities. Views expressed at the event were to be forwarded to both PEI and Canadian governments. The contact information indicates Don's leadership role with Education 20/20 Inc., headquartered in Charlottetown.

2017 2017 March Notes March 23, 2017 Don Glendenning convenes initial discussions about the perceived gap between student skills at graduation and those… ▸ more
Don Glendenning convenes initial discussions about the perceived gap between student skills at graduation and those needed for post-secondary education and employment. He frames the issue using Council of Ministers of Education Canada (CMEC) terminology as a "transition" problem rooted partly in communication failures. Drawing on conversations with students, parents, employers, and grandparents, Don proposes exploring a curriculum map or master list of competencies across institutions. He invites stakeholders to a 90-minute working meeting on April 6, 2017, at Royalty Centre to explore systemic solutions. The document reflects Don's systematic, collaborative approach to identifying education system gaps.

2017 Potential Awards-1 Strategic document outlining the rationale for expanding Education 20/20's award program. Don reflects on education's… ▸ more
Strategic document outlining the rationale for expanding Education 20/20's award program. Don reflects on education's lack of incentives compared to other sectors, noting growing evidence that awards improve results. Discusses the need to encourage systemic change benefiting all citizens. Lists multiple expansion ideas including awards for non-teaching staff, journalism students, teachers-in-training, and regional/national expansion with an annual Charlottetown finale.

2017 Media release 1 Media release announcing a "new direction" for the Education 20/20 Excellence Award in 2017, shifting focus from… ▸ more
Media release announcing a "new direction" for the Education 20/20 Excellence Award in 2017, shifting focus from schools to community organizations. References previous recipients (Kinkora Regional High School 2014, Prince Street Elementary 2015, Grace Christian School 2016) and explains that the 2017 award will recognize community organizations addressing educational needs. Includes Don Glendenning's quote: "It takes a community to educate a citizen, so we want to hear from communities."

2017 Announcement STEAM August 2, 2017 press release announcing STEAM PEI as the Excellence in Education Award winner for their "Math Magic"… ▸ more
August 2, 2017 press release announcing STEAM PEI as the Excellence in Education Award winner for their "Math Magic" program reducing math anxiety through entertainment and engagement. The program features comedy, mathematical magic, and applied geometry/physics at Confederation Centre and Summerside libraries during Global Math Week 2017. The document explicitly credits Dr. Glendenning as President of Education 20/20 for announcing the award and thanking donors Regis and Joan Duffy.

2017 2017 coSolve Press release dated August 23, 2017, announcing coSolved Consulting as 2017 Excellence in Education Award winner for… ▸ more
Press release dated August 23, 2017, announcing coSolved Consulting as 2017 Excellence in Education Award winner for their "Math Magic" initiative combining instruction and entertainment to reduce math anxiety. Program showcases mathematical wonders outside standard curriculum through comedy, mathematical magic, applied geometry, physics, and real-world examples using basketballs, Rubik's cubes, mobius strips, and DNA knot theory. Interactive audience participation format. Developed by Amber Jadis (practicing engineer, STEAM advocate) and Nellie Keating (entertainer, Halifax Circus School co-founder) in consultation with UPEI School of Mathematical Science and PEI Department of Education. Dr. Glendenning (Education 20/20 President) announced award, thanking Regis and Joan Duffy for education support. Notes award's evolution from prior focus on engagement and technology to community group recognition.

2017 2017 Description-9 Program description for 2018 Excellence in Education Award ($2,500) specifically recognizing educational collaboration… ▸ more
Program description for 2018 Excellence in Education Award ($2,500) specifically recognizing educational collaboration as strategy for school improvement. Award targets collaboration between teachers within schools, across schools, between schools and higher education, and between schools and other organizations. Emphasizes collaboration's documented contribution to teacher performance, student achievement, and systemic school improvement. Applicants address underlying issues, objectives, educational principles, activities, participant numbers, and timeframes (one-time or ongoing). Limited to PEI, applicants bear proposal costs, 3-page maximum, group-generated documentation. April 30, 2018 deadline. Award reflects Education 20/20's strategic focus on collaborative approaches as key to educational advancement, evolving award themes annually to highlight different excellence dimensions.

2017 2017 Committee members List of Education 20/20 Awards Committee members as of November 29, 2016, including contact information. Members:… ▸ more
List of Education 20/20 Awards Committee members as of November 29, 2016, including contact information. Members: Donald DesRoches (College Acadie President, 436-4881), Don Glendenning (College President Retired, 892-5859), David McCabe (School Superintendent Retired, 569-5349), Peter Russell (RBC Dominion Securities Investment Adviser, 628-4854), and Jeniene Peake (College Administrator Retired, 368-2635). Demonstrates Don's recruitment of experienced, respected education professionals from diverse sectors (post-secondary, public schools, business, community) to guide award program, reflecting institutional commitment to broad stakeholder engagement.

2017 2017 Committee Selection Notes from Education 20/20 Awards Committee meeting on May 17, 2017, at 8:30 am at Casa Mia in Charlottetown. Committee… ▸ more
Notes from Education 20/20 Awards Committee meeting on May 17, 2017, at 8:30 am at Casa Mia in Charlottetown. Committee members: Jeniene Peake, Donald DesRoches, Peter Russell, Don Glendenning, and Dave McCabe (notes provided). Documents evaluation of three proposals: Reading Program (Learning Disabilities Association serving 61 students across 11 PEI locations with $25 fee-based teacher-led training), Community Youth Justice Camp (Community Legal Information Association offering three-day experience for ages 13-15 including courtroom visits and justice system education), and Math Magic (coSolved Consulting with UPEI partnership presenting interactive mathematical demonstrations). Committee selected Math Magic for its innovative approach to changing math perception, engaging education sector, leveraging existing initiatives, and serving diverse audiences.

2017 2017 Award announcement Highlight Press release announcing the 2017 Excellence in Education Award focus and program details, authored and released by Dr.… ▸ more
Press release announcing the 2017 Excellence in Education Award focus and program details, authored and released by Dr. Don Glendenning as President of Education 20/20. Release summarizes award history (2014 Kinkora, 2015 Prince Street, 2016 Grace Christian) and announces 2017 focus on technology applications. Don discusses various technology uses in education (flipped classrooms, student homework platforms, curriculum broadening, diagnostic assessment). He outlines evaluation committee criteria: ease of student access, curriculum relevance, and engagement levels. Document emphasizes Don's educational philosophy and understanding of pedagogy, including hope for novel technology applications. Contact information provided includes Don's home phone.

2017 3 Elevator speech Don advocates for educators to develop and consistently use coherent "elevator speeches"—brief, essence-capturing… ▸ more
Don advocates for educators to develop and consistently use coherent "elevator speeches"—brief, essence-capturing statements about their work. He references John Robinson's Community Foundation work and the importance of capturing shared purpose in a sentence or two. Don proposes educators collectively articulate how they're helping people develop skills, knowledge, and attitudes enabling them to manage life's obstacles and thrive. He emphasizes that consistent key terminology across educators signals unified direction, and invites colleagues to develop their own language variants while maintaining core coherence about education's transformative purpose.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2017 2 Philosophy Don critiques the small school closure strategy as contradicting evidence, then pivots to the urgent need for updating… ▸ more
Don critiques the small school closure strategy as contradicting evidence, then pivots to the urgent need for updating PEI's 28-year-old Philosophy of Education. He proposes a short, clear, crisp statement starting with definitions (education, schools, schooling, graduation, grades, pass/fail, government role, employment relationship, parental role) followed by guiding principles: education for democratic participation, learner/parent responsibility, individual learning differences, government's equity-ensuring leadership role, workforce development responsibility, education as profession, developmental process, and schools as educational service delivery. He argues this framework must precede curriculum, standards, and facility decisions.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2017 1 Chief Supt Inspired by a presentation by Dr. Heather Morrison, Chief Health Officer for PEI, Don proposes establishing a Chief… ▸ more
Inspired by a presentation by Dr. Heather Morrison, Chief Health Officer for PEI, Don proposes establishing a Chief Education Officer position focused solely on improving education quality. He notes historical precedent: New Brunswick's Department of Education once had separate Deputy Minister (administration) and Chief Superintendent (programming) roles; PEI had a Chief Superintendent until at least 1930. He recommends "Director" over "Superintendent" to reflect education's breadth beyond schools, aligning with modern educational scope.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2017 2017 Premier's handout Promotional materials for Education 20/20 Inc. presented to provincial leadership, repeated three times (likely for… ▸ more
Promotional materials for Education 20/20 Inc. presented to provincial leadership, repeated three times (likely for distribution). Describes organization's vision of quality education for every Canadian and mission to strengthen culture of learning. Outlines learner model incorporating genetic makeup, prior learning, and aspirations. Identifies life roles (individual, family member, citizen, learner, consumer) and types of help learners need (information, counseling, instruction, encouragement, guided practice, feedback, funding, products, technology). Lists board members including Don as President and Vice President Bill Whelan. Provides website and contact information. Reflects mature, established organizational framework.
EDUCATION SPEECH

 Read · Download
Dec 17, 2016 D-1 Innovations Open Education No. 68 (December 17, 2016), authored by Don Glendenning documenting emerging education innovations… ▸ more
Open Education No. 68 (December 17, 2016), authored by Don Glendenning documenting emerging education innovations globally: British Columbia gradeless report cards; Ontario teacher math competency requirements; Canadian medical schools adopting competency-based education; university student advocates (especially for international students); tech companies hiring without degree requirements; single-student schools in NYC; school-without-walls models; independent qualification authorities (most developed countries except Canada/USA); democratic schools (Hanover High, NH); holistic rating scales; work colleges; full-service schools; independent student models. Don solicits additional Island innovations from readers, positioning Education 20/20 as a knowledge clearinghouse for education reform ideas. This demonstrates his commitment to learning from global experiments and adapting promising models to Canadian contexts.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Dec 17, 2016 7 Assessment Open Education No. 2 (December 17, 2016), authored by Don Glendenning analyzing provincial assessment practices. He… ▸ more
Open Education No. 2 (December 17, 2016), authored by Don Glendenning analyzing provincial assessment practices. He advocates for comprehensive assessment review beyond provincial exams, distinguishing between formative tests (identifying learning gaps for adjustment), summative tests (measuring achievement levels), and competitions (ranking students). Don argues schools should not conduct summative assessment or competitions, proposing instead independent qualification authorities like most developed nations employ. He acknowledges PEI's improved Pan-Canadian Assessment Program (PCAP) results while questioning whether standardized testing adequately measures readiness for employment or post-secondary education. The article welcomes translator Desmond Bernard and acknowledges reader correspondence, creating community dialogue.

Includes Education 20/20 directors list with Glendenning as President. Emphasizes the post-screening discussion as integral to community learning, inviting continued civic engagement.

He acknowledges missing their partnership and extends warm personal regards.

Jun 11, 2016 Hambly-1 This June 11, 2016 letter to Wayne Hambly, President of Hambly's Home Furnishings, reflects Don's views on education… ▸ more
This June 11, 2016 letter to Wayne Hambly, President of Hambly's Home Furnishings, reflects Don's views on education transformation. He argues for shifting from an inward-looking, bureaucratic system to an outward-looking, nimble organization focused on developing responsible citizens. Don notes some progress through the Premier's commitment to consultation but emphasizes that seven additional items in the Education 20/20 "Call for Action" remain on the agenda. He describes Education 20/20's activities (information gathering, newsletter, workshops, award programs) and announces plans to increase public advocacy, lobby for alternative delivery and assessment models, and refocus the education award from schools to community-led initiatives. The letter solicits potential financial support without obligation.

Comprehensive thank you and progress report dated June 1, 2016, to Roger Birt. Don thanks Birt for remembering initial conversation about young people's education and future, emphasizing alignment of purposes. Describes education system needing "outward looking, nimble organization" focused on developing mature adults. Reports increased education dialogue frequency, growing bilingual newsletter addressing identified niche, improved school awards program with planned expansion to Atlantic provinces, webinar under development, and emerging focus on educational standards. Notes Education 20/20 received charitable status from Revenue Canada this year. Credits Birt's support as essential to establishing independent organization working for education change.

Read · Download

March 2016 About Educ Dated March 2016, this document presents Don's evolving personal framework for understanding and changing education. It… ▸ more
Dated March 2016, this document presents Don's evolving personal framework for understanding and changing education. It opens with clear definitions distinguishing learners, education, schooling, learning, and teaching. Don articulates his operating beliefs, including that each person is responsible for their own education, the home is the major contributor to education, and institutions' importance in acquiring education is declining. He identifies specific tools for educational change (instruction, opportunity, role models, counseling) and barriers (politicization, bureaucracy, inertia). Notably, he asserts that awarding credentials and qualifications is not an educational function and creates conflicts of interest. The framework emphasizes characteristics of quality education systems: accessibility, affordability, flexibility, relevance, accountability, transparency, and focus on helping individuals change.
EDUCATION

Feb 19, 2016 Goodine acceptance This February 19, 2016 letter is Don's gracious acceptance of Brenda Goodine's resignation as a Director of Education… ▸ more
This February 19, 2016 letter is Don's gracious acceptance of Brenda Goodine's resignation as a Director of Education 20/20 Inc. Goodine, who has relocated to Alberta, resigns to allow local representation on the board. Don thanks her for her foundational support during the organization's formation and expresses appreciation that the organization's growth and impending charitable status represent validation of her early confidence. He acknowledges the unique nature of Education 20/20 in the education sector and notes the challenge of engaging teachers as active partners. The letter demonstrates Don's diplomatic relationship management and his understanding of organizational transitions.

Jan 6, 2016 Dunphy Mayor Film In this January 6, 2016 letter, Don invites Stratford Mayor David Dunphy to attend the "Most Likely to Succeed" film… ▸ more
In this January 6, 2016 letter, Don invites Stratford Mayor David Dunphy to attend the "Most Likely to Succeed" film screening and solicits the City of Stratford as a sponsor ($100). The letter describes the film's project-based learning approach and its coverage in major U.S. newspapers. Don reserves seating for the mayor or a representative and invites participation in post-film discussion. This demonstrates Don's engagement of municipal government in educational advocacy and his use of cultural events as platforms for advancing reform ideas.

Jan 6, 2016 Meeting 2 Agenda Agenda for the January 6, 2016 second stakeholder meeting held at Stratford Town Hall, continuing the Preparedness-2… ▸ more
Agenda for the January 6, 2016 second stakeholder meeting held at Stratford Town Hall, continuing the Preparedness-2 initiative. This meeting narrowed focus to numeracy/mathematics after determining the initial scope was too broad. The agenda emphasizes a "planning framework" for identifying key mathematical skills, introducing participants' roles, and determining next steps. The document reflects adaptive project management—the group pivoted from examining all preparedness dimensions to concentrating on mathematics as the foundational competency. This demonstrates Don's pragmatic approach to large reform initiatives, working within realistic constraints to achieve measurable progress.

Jan 4, 2016 Premier film Dated January 4, 2016, Don invites Premier Wade MacLauchlan to a screening of "Most Likely to Succeed," a documentary… ▸ more
Dated January 4, 2016, Don invites Premier Wade MacLauchlan to a screening of "Most Likely to Succeed," a documentary produced by education philanthropist Ted Dintersmith. The film premiered in the United States and received positive reviews from both the New York Times and Washington Post. Don describes the film's focus on project-based learning at High Tech High in San Diego and its argument for emphasizing relational skills over pure content delivery. The screening is scheduled for Sunday, January 17, 2016, from 2-4:00 pm at The City Cinema, Charlottetown. Don offers to provide two complimentary tickets at the door and extends the invitation as "our guest," suggesting this was part of Education 20/20's ongoing advocacy strategy. The letter demonstrates Don's commitment to introducing innovative educational approaches to decision-makers.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

2016 D Priorities@2016-01-02T16;12;41 Don proposes an alternative education budget approach for 2016 emphasizing priorities and school autonomy. He advocates… ▸ more
Don proposes an alternative education budget approach for 2016 emphasizing priorities and school autonomy. He advocates freezing the budget, prioritizing basic skills (math, science, communications, computer programming), allowing principal discretion over other offerings in consultation with communities, and creating an innovation fund. This approach would align with OECD recommendations for school autonomy while maintaining government control and enhancing community engagement.

2016 2016 Green partyoEducation Act Highlight Notes on the PEI Education Act (duplicate variant) providing Glendenning's critical analysis for the Green Party. He… ▸ more
Notes on the PEI Education Act (duplicate variant) providing Glendenning's critical analysis for the Green Party. He identifies the Act's limitations: narrow school-focused scope, excessive ministerial centralization, lack of provisions for adult/lifelong learning, and insufficient educator professional autonomy—reflecting his broader vision for comprehensive, inclusive, and professionally-driven education systems.

2016 2016 Education and schooling Argues for distinguishing education from schooling, noting that departments of education often focus only on school-age… ▸ more
Argues for distinguishing education from schooling, noting that departments of education often focus only on school-age children despite education being lifelong. Uses analogies (health vs. hospitalization, religion vs. church) to clarify the distinction. Advocates that this separation improves communication, expands learning opportunities, supports independent learning, and better accommodates personal skills like problem-solving and entrepreneurship.

2016 2016 Account (100-200 words):** Financial accounting ledger for Education 20/20 Inc. covering 2016, documenting all transactions… ▸ more
(100-200 words):** Financial accounting ledger for Education 20/20 Inc. covering 2016, documenting all transactions with dates, descriptions, and account balances. Initial accounts held by Community Foundation of PEI, later transferred to Provincial Credit Union. Notable entries include donations from Don Glendenning ($100 for film), RBC ($500), and other supporters; expenses for film production ($1,089.81), translation services, and operational costs. Final year-end balance: $1,684.73. The ledger demonstrates Don's attention to financial transparency and disciplined management of the nonprofit organization, with detailed record-keeping suitable for auditing and stakeholder accountability.

2016 ABE Questions Opinion piece on adult basic education (ABE) gaps and questions about secondary-to-postsecondary transitions in PEI… ▸ more
Opinion piece on adult basic education (ABE) gaps and questions about secondary-to-postsecondary transitions in PEI (appears to be from Education 20/20 newsletter context). Don questions why high school graduates needing remedial coursework cannot retake courses at secondary level, why taxpayers fund redundant services, and whether curriculum committees should include employers. Raises systemic questions about funding structures and communication gaps. Demonstrates Don's continued critical analysis of education policy, advocacy for practical solutions, and engagement with contemporaneous education debates in PEI through 2016 and beyond.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 2016-PC Party February 2016 presentation to Progressive Conservative Party outlining Don's education vision for PEI. Speaking at Rodd… ▸ more
February 2016 presentation to Progressive Conservative Party outlining Don's education vision for PEI. Speaking at Rodd Royalty Inn, he frames education as the most important issue, arguing the province's future depends on citizens' education levels. Don presents his systemic framework: 140,000 Islander learners requiring support across the life journey; providers including families, communities, and institutions; and essential educational services (information, instruction, financing, governance, evaluation, accountability). He introduces Education 20/20's "Call for Action" with seven recommendations: develop clear educational vision for all Islanders, create learner-centered service model, establish government leadership role, delegate instructional provision, establish independent qualification body, adopt professional service delivery model, and encourage innovation. The presentation demonstrates Don's consistent messaging across political platforms and his role as education thought leader in PEI.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
c. 2016 11 Math for transition 7 Problem May 2019 paper addressing the critical role of mathematics education in student transition from secondary school to… ▸ more
May 2019 paper addressing the critical role of mathematics education in student transition from secondary school to post-secondary education and employment. Building on the CMEC 2016 statement that transition success measures education system effectiveness, Don identifies math as essential to citizenship and economic productivity. He documents communication gaps between education providers and receivers, argues that curriculum-based outcomes reflect educator thinking rather than learner needs, and identifies structural impediments including lack of overarching philosophy and no formal coordination among math providers. Recommendations include competency adoption, universal curriculum platforms, independent study options, dynamic rating scales, competency-based reporting, and independent assessment bodies. The paper synthesizes key themes from his earlier work on educational fragmentation.
EDUCATION

 Read · Download
2016 47 2016-12-17 - no 47 - Professional roles Glendenning compiles list of teacher functions (instruction, assessment, material preparation, record-keeping, parent… ▸ more
Glendenning compiles list of teacher functions (instruction, assessment, material preparation, record-keeping, parent engagement, technology, learning styles recognition, practice guidance, homework checking, classroom management, learner support) and questions whether teaching roles have been formally analyzed. He notes absences: non-instructional duties (hall patrol, lunch service, fundraising, counseling, playground supervision). Raises questions about role clarity in hiring and professional duties. Acknowledges Education 20/20's supporters and donors. Describes innovative schools as those where teachers are "designers of learning not simply deliverers."

2016 2016 LSA Miller Yan Highlight Press release detailing research findings on large-scale assessment. Results showed Islanders knew of poor PISA… ▸ more
Press release detailing research findings on large-scale assessment. Results showed Islanders knew of poor PISA performance but were unaware of improvements in national PCAP rankings. The research highlighted inconsistencies in provincial assessment reporting and lack of standards transparency. Glendenning, through Education 20/20, used this research to advocate for improved transparency and public understanding of educational measurement. The document shows his focus on evidence-based advocacy and the connection between public knowledge and educational policy.

2016 2016 Assessment Press release announcing Education 20/20 workshop on school accountability featuring research by Lizzie Yan (UPEI M.Ed.… ▸ more
Press release announcing Education 20/20 workshop on school accountability featuring research by Lizzie Yan (UPEI M.Ed. student) and Dr. Tess Miller. The workshop examined knowledge and perceptions of over 500 PEI Islanders regarding large-scale assessments including PISA and PCAP. The event, held at Stratford Town Hall, discussed how schools are held accountable through these international and Canadian measures of student achievement. This reflects Glendenning's commitment to public education dialogue and transparency in assessment practices.

2016 2 Framework 2 brochure single 2016 Educational framework document titled "The Road of Life" presenting Don Glendenning's philosophy on education.… ▸ more
Educational framework document titled "The Road of Life" presenting Don Glendenning's philosophy on education. Framework consists of three components: the learner bringing innate conditions, attitudes, and aspirations; demands of life's road including roles and challenges; and educational services including information, instruction, feedback, counseling, practice and assessment. Lists Don Glendenning as President of Education 20/20 Inc. in this 2016 brochure, with contact information in Charlottetown, PEI.

2016 2016 President's report Glendenning's comprehensive president's report for 2016 detailing the organization's diverse activities. Education… ▸ more
Glendenning's comprehensive president's report for 2016 detailing the organization's diverse activities. Education 20/20 published "Open Education," a monthly bilingual newsletter; maintained active social media presence; hosted educational workshops including presentations on "Literacy for the 21st Century" and large-scale assessment research; awarded $2,500 to Grace Christian School for technology innovation; held a regional workshop with the Canadian Education Association; and achieved official charitable status from the Canada Revenue Agency. Glendenning personally met with the provincial Minister of Education and Premier, led presentations to the Progressive Conservative Party, and facilitated community events. The report demonstrates Glendenning's extensive advocacy network and commitment to advancing educational policy on PEI.

2016 2016-9 This year-end 2016 report shows Don managing complex stakeholder relationships in the Souris Garden Club project. He… ▸ more
This year-end 2016 report shows Don managing complex stakeholder relationships in the Souris Garden Club project. He presented a four-part proposal to private donors for a summer program including a 12-week program for 20 students, indoor green space development at Souris Regional School, promotion of garden clubs elsewhere on PEI, and a Camp Bean competition. Don notes that while donors responded positively without committing funds, Education 20/20's direct involvement would create bureaucratic burden rather than value. This reveals his strategic thinking about organizational scope and the appropriate role of Education 20/20 in community initiatives. He also reports meeting with Sally Coles at the Guardian about media coverage and remaining focused on Canada 150 Fund applications.

2016 1-G FRAMEWORK NOTES colour This is the finalized, color-formatted version of "A Learning Journey" presentation. It contains the complete framework… ▸ more
This is the finalized, color-formatted version of "A Learning Journey" presentation. It contains the complete framework with polished messaging: learners carry conditions they were born with (physical, emotional, social well-being), learning experiences since birth (home life, culture, travel, schooling, relationships), and aspirations. It addresses "Impediments and Detours" including extensive barriers and emphasizes "Roadside Assistance" (help types and helpers). The concept includes building "The Holy Grail: A Learning Culture" with "Continuing Engagement." Credits Education 20/20 Inc., notes the Oregon concept, credits Dr. Don Glendenning as Project Director, and credits artist Louise Carota with copyright 2016.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 Proposal 2-A This early proposal document presents the background and context for education services in Souris, focusing on… ▸ more
This early proposal document presents the background and context for education services in Souris, focusing on demographic and economic challenges. Souris is a declining population centre (1,053 residents as of 2016 census) with aging demographics, lower household incomes than PEI average, and workforce concentrated in seasonal industries. The document outlines Education 20/20's consultation process with residents, employers, and service providers to understand educational needs, particularly for out-of-school youth. It lists existing educational institutions (Holland College, Souris Regional School, Ecole La Belle Cloche) and proposes brainstorming around technology skills training including robotics, IT, and skilled trades.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2016 A Wilmot-2 Detailed letter from Don to Louise and Jim Wilmot describing four separate garden program proposals: Souris Sprouts-2… ▸ more
Detailed letter from Don to Louise and Jim Wilmot describing four separate garden program proposals: Souris Sprouts-2 (repeat of 2016 program with 20 students), Green Spaces (indoor living spaces for school), Program promotion (island-wide presentations), and Camp Bean (competitive challenge for island schools). Don outlines the evolution from direct Education 20/20 operation to fund "flow-through" arrangements with Souris Regional School or town council, citing CFPEI precedents. He emphasizes breaking down school "silos" through broader community engagement. The letter reveals Don's sophisticated understanding of organizational structures, his commitment to community partnership, and his vision for scaling successful initiatives. His personal investment in teachers Sarah and Ilse is evident throughout.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 Minutes-2016 Official meeting minutes from Education 20/20 Awards Committee meeting on May 12, 2016, at BMO Nesbit Burns in… ▸ more
Official meeting minutes from Education 20/20 Awards Committee meeting on May 12, 2016, at BMO Nesbit Burns in Charlottetown. Attended by Peter Russell, Steve MacQuaid, and Don Glendenning (Chair). Minutes document evaluation of four nominations: Grace Christian School (nominated by Natalie MacNeill for comprehensive technology integration), Charlottetown Rural High School (nominated by Rebecca Rioux for impressive wireless technology pilot implementation with strong staff engagement), Down to Earth Child Care (nominated by Ilse Peters-Ching for potential technology use despite current lack of resources). Committee unanimously selected Grace Christian School based on how technology genuinely supported the school's educational philosophy and mission. Discussion included future award directions, recommendations for focused annual themes, donor engagement, and strategic communication about awards.

Media release announcing Grace Christian School as the 2016 Excellence in Education Award recipient, with award focus on effective use of technology in teaching and learning. Document highlights Grace Christian's integration of technology across all school levels (K-12), including Lego WeDo, Scratch, LittleBits, Apple TVs, digital microscopes, and iPads. Includes quote from Principal Jason Biech and Don Glendenning (as Education 20/20 President) emphasizing not just tool availability but meaningful integration into school life. Notes award history (2014 Kinkora Regional High School, 2015 Prince Street Elementary) and provides contact information for Don.

2016 2016 Grace Christian award Press release dated June 8, 2016, announcing Grace Christian School as the winner of the Excellence in Education Award… ▸ more
Press release dated June 8, 2016, announcing Grace Christian School as the winner of the Excellence in Education Award from Education 20/20 Inc. Highlights the school's innovative use of technology in educational practice. The award recognizes excellence in Prince Edward Island schools. Part of a suite of documents including supporting letters from educators endorsing technology integration in teaching (e.g., letter from Rebecca MacPhee from Down to Earth Child Care describing integration of outdoor play with technology use). Related meeting minutes from May 12, 2016 show Don Glendenning serving as Chair of the awards committee, with Peter Russell and Steve MacQuaid also in attendance. Demonstrates Don's continued involvement in education recognition and institutional leadership through Education 20/20 Inc. during his later years.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Download
 Download
2016 2016-9 Small Schools Don defends small schools against closure bias, citing studies showing they improve student achievement, increase… ▸ more
Don defends small schools against closure bias, citing studies showing they improve student achievement, increase attendance and graduation rates, elevate teacher satisfaction, and improve safety—while maintaining lower costs per graduate. A Wisconsin 2000 study recommended increasing small schools, not closing them. He notes Ontario's 2005 definition of small schools (under 200 elementary, 500 high school students). He argues that educational philosophy determines school design, proposing piloting community autonomy with bulk funding to discover innovative small school models rather than defaulting to closure.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 2016-8 Duplication Don identifies apparent duplication in PEI's education system: the Department of Education teaches essential skills… ▸ more
Don identifies apparent duplication in PEI's education system: the Department of Education teaches essential skills (reading, numeracy, writing, communication, thinking, computer use) to school-age learners, yet the Department of Workforce and Advanced Learning must teach identical skills to unemployed youth. He questions whether graduates already possess these capabilities and suggests taxpayers are "paying twice for the same service." He advocates for achieving educational goals effectively the first time rather than remedial spending.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 2016-7 Language of learning Don emphasizes precise language in education discourse, tracing his attention to clarity back to learner-centered… ▸ more
Don emphasizes precise language in education discourse, tracing his attention to clarity back to learner-centered lesson planning, competency-based outcomes, and Ed Macintosh's "fog index" for writing clarity. He questions the Department of Education's phrase "delivering excellence," noting it's ambiguous regarding what is delivered, how, and to whom. He argues that since learning is a personal act only learners can perform, excellence language should clarify whether it applies to learner achievement, teacher delivery, or institutional support, and how it will be measured—essential for accountability and student understanding.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 2016-6 Student grading Don argues that postsecondary institutions and employers should abandon blanket "high school graduation" entrance… ▸ more
Don argues that postsecondary institutions and employers should abandon blanket "high school graduation" entrance requirements in favor of specific skill requirements (communication, algebra, etc.). He identifies grading as a regulatory, not teaching function, noting that teachers certifying achievement while teaching creates conflict of interest. He advocates separating teaching and sorting roles—as done in sports (coaches vs. referees) and professional credentialing—and proposes creating an independent qualification authority to measure and certify achievement levels, improving consistency and reducing teacher workload.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 2016-5 Schoools Act Don critiques PEI's new Education Act, arguing it's misnamed (Schools Act, not Education Act) and focuses on efficiency… ▸ more
Don critiques PEI's new Education Act, arguing it's misnamed (Schools Act, not Education Act) and focuses on efficiency over effectiveness. He identifies multiple deficiencies: no education definition, inflexible teacher/principal credentialing, centralized decision-making contrary to OECD research, and policies contradicting student-centered principles. He advocates for flexibility (noting Australian Catholic systems don't require teacher principals), school autonomy in daily decisions including budget allocation, and student-centered policies like exemptions and remedial support referenced by Dean Goddard and Finnish models.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 2016-3 Signs of an educational spring Don outlines five indicators of genuine educational progress: updated education philosophy clarifying purpose and… ▸ more
Don outlines five indicators of genuine educational progress: updated education philosophy clarifying purpose and goals, community members on curriculum committees, department reorganization based on functional analysis, replacing "grade" terminology with achievement-level language, and restoring high school exemptions. He uses the metaphor of spring robins—one or two small signs suggest change, three or four indicate a new season—emphasizing that transformative improvement requires coherent, multi-faceted reform.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 2016-2 Educational achievement Don critiques the grading system, noting that despite being called "absolutely uncalibrated" since 1913, grades… ▸ more
Don critiques the grading system, noting that despite being called "absolutely uncalibrated" since 1913, grades continue shaping young lives. He distinguishes formative assessment (diagnostic teaching tool) from summative assessment (sorting learners by achievement), arguing teachers shouldn't rate students they teach due to conflict of interest. Standards should be set independently. He separates credentials (what was studied) from qualifications (what can be done), advocating for better assessment aligned with actual learning progress.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 2016-11 PISA While celebrating PEI's improved PISA test results, Don warns against conflating academic achievement with genuine… ▸ more
While celebrating PEI's improved PISA test results, Don warns against conflating academic achievement with genuine education. He defines education as the patchwork of experiences—many outside classrooms—that alter how people think, feel, and act. Drawing OECD parallels to agriculture, fisheries, and justice, he argues government should provide leadership and ensure equity rather than operate schools directly. He cites OECD research showing schools with greater autonomy and accountability through public achievement data perform better, advocating for school autonomy paired with transparency.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 D-2016 Educational achievement This document appears to be a duplicate of File 2, with identical content discussing grading systems as uncalibrated… ▸ more
This document appears to be a duplicate of File 2, with identical content discussing grading systems as uncalibrated instruments and proposing independent assessment bodies rather than teachers conducting evaluations. It distinguishes formative assessment (diagnostic, teaching-focused) from summative assessment (sorting by achievement), arguing this distinction reveals fundamental conflicts of interest in teacher grading. The repeated inclusion suggests this letter was important enough to warrant multiple copies in his records, or may represent the final version kept for documentation alongside an earlier draft.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 Priorities Slightly revised version of the priorities letter with minor wording adjustments (changes in phrasing about "freedom… ▸ more
Slightly revised version of the priorities letter with minor wording adjustments (changes in phrasing about "freedom and accountability" to "need for both freedom and accountability" and "allocate funds" vs. "reserve funds"). The core arguments remain identical: freeze budgets, allocate basic skills funding, allow principal discretion, and establish innovation funds. This iteration reflects editorial refinement of the same proposal.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 Priorities 2 Don proposes an alternative education budget process emphasizing school-level autonomy while maintaining governmental… ▸ more
Don proposes an alternative education budget process emphasizing school-level autonomy while maintaining governmental control. He recommends: freezing education budgets at 2015 levels, reserving funds for basic skills (math, science, communications, computer language), allowing principals curriculum decisions within allocations in consultation with their communities, and establishing an innovation fund for special projects. Don argues this approach provides government necessary control, implements OECD-recommended school autonomy, and meaningfully engages communities—all characteristics of quality education systems. This reflects his commitment to balancing fiscal responsibility with local governance.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 2016-2 Post secondary entrance requirements Don examines the disconnect between high school requirements and post-secondary admission practices. Referencing… ▸ more
Don examines the disconnect between high school requirements and post-secondary admission practices. Referencing Australia's experience where universities admit up to 70 percent of students below minimum ATAR scores, he questions why post-secondary institutions spend resources remediating material taught months earlier in high school. He poses critical questions: What is high school's actual role? Do diplomas mean anything? Why don't under-prepared high school graduates return for upgrading? Should post-secondary institutions develop independent entrance assessments instead of lowering standards? He suggests financial analysis could reveal educational system truths.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2016 Prince St Media release announcing Prince Street Elementary School as 2016 Excellence in Education Award winner from Education… ▸ more
Media release announcing Prince Street Elementary School as 2016 Excellence in Education Award winner from Education 20/20. Award, established last year, includes $2,500 cheque recognizing schools/learning centres providing quality education. Previous year's winner: Kinkora Regional High School. Award emphasizes family engagement, citing National Parent Teacher Association research showing parental involvement improves student achievement, teacher morale, attendance, behavior, and graduation rates. Award focused on school-controlled factors: student engagement, environment, instruction, school-community partnerships, parent engagement. Dr. Glendenning (President of Education 20/20) highlighted collaboration evidence: student recognition, case management meetings, school song, "Garden Buddies" food program, mascot selection, staff efforts improving student spaces, and extensive community engagement. Award open to all schools; three nominations received, reviewed by Awards Committee, recommendation approved by Board June 3. - **Key People**: Dr. Don Glendenning (President of Education 20/20) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Prince Street Elementary School, Kinkora Regional High School, National Parent Teacher Association - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY, FOUNDATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Shows Don's leadership recognizing educational excellence and emphasis on family-school-community partnerships

Media release announcing 2016 Excellence in Education Award from Education 20/20. Award recognizes schools/learning centres using technology to enhance learning and teaching, $2,500 prize. Earlier awards emphasized school-community engagement; 2016 focuses on technology use. Don Glendenning, President of Education 20/20, announces award and thanks Dr. Regis and Joan Duffy for their ongoing education support. Previous winners: Kinkora Regional High School (2014), Prince Street Elementary School (2015). Glendenning discusses varied technology applications including replacing lectures with "upside classroom" approaches, course broadening, and student assessment aids. Media release announcing Education 20/20's Excellence in Education Award for 2016, focused on technology use in schools. The $2,500 award recognizes K-12 schools or learning centres demonstrating effective technology application. Don Glendenning, as President of Education 20/20, announces the award and thanks Dr. Regis and Joan Duffy for their support. Previous award winners mentioned: Kinkora Regional High School (2014) and Prince Street Elementary School (2015). Glendenning discusses various technology applications in education, including replacing lectures, upside-down classrooms, curriculum broadening, and student assessment aids. Dec 28, 2015 Duffy, Regis 4 In this December 28, 2015 reflection, Don provides a status update on Education 20/20's progress and personal… ▸ more
In this December 28, 2015 reflection, Don provides a status update on Education 20/20's progress and personal introspection. Despite age-related health concerns, Don reports that Education 20/20 has sustained debate on education, engaged with elected officials, and gained support from many decision-makers, though actual policy announcements remain disappointing. He expresses frustration that knowing what needs to be done is not the problem—implementation is. Education 20/20's 2016 strategy includes continuing the bilingual newsletter, maintaining the school awards, focusing on basic skills content and standards, and amplifying advocacy efforts. This letter demonstrates Don's perseverance despite limited tangible policy victories and his sustained commitment even as he ages.

Dec 25, 2015 00 Donor letter December 25, 2015 fundraising letter from Don Glendenning to John Robinson requesting $100 sponsorship for "Most Likely… ▸ more
December 25, 2015 fundraising letter from Don Glendenning to John Robinson requesting $100 sponsorship for "Most Likely to Succeed," another education documentary. References positive reviews in New York Times and Washington Post. Film features High Tech High in San Diego using project-based learning with student autonomy and trust. Don explains film shows alternative model where success is not measured by standardized tests and relational skills receive emphasis. Requests donation through Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island pending Education 20/20's charity status. Shows Don's pattern of securing multiple film screenings to advance education reform agenda.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Nov 5, 2015 RBC 2 Highlight Dated November 5, 2015, Don updates Mary McInnis, Manager of RBC Charlottetown, on Education 20/20's progress and… ▸ more
Dated November 5, 2015, Don updates Mary McInnis, Manager of RBC Charlottetown, on Education 20/20's progress and solicits continued financial support. He notes that calls for education system change have become "more frequent, more widespread, and more urgent." While Education 20/20 doesn't claim credit for driving change, Don observes they are helping keep education in the public spotlight. He outlines recent activities: monthly bilingual newsletters, public presentations, workshops, website, media coverage, Excellence in Education Awards ($2,500 annually to innovative schools), meetings with MLAs and education officials, and the "Call for Action" document with seven recommendations. Don details future plans: a working group exploring gaps between K-12 education and postsecondary/employment readiness, and improved student achievement measurement. He requests ongoing financial support, suggesting $1,000 annually for three years, with contributions directed through the Community Foundation of PEI.

November 2015 22 Learning path November 2015 article documenting Education 20/20's initiative to map learner pathways through consultation with… ▸ more
November 2015 article documenting Education 20/20's initiative to map learner pathways through consultation with students and educators. Don reports students identified diverse learning needs: overview, context, instruction, assessment, practice, and reflection. He emphasizes that students require varied approaches and that schools must accommodate individual learning preferences. The panel included Tanya Craig (chair), Callen Cudmore, Ryan Rioux, Iain Cudmore, and Stephanie Mayne, with results to be presented in flowchart form.

November 2015 Webster-1 A letter (date approximately November 2015) from Don to the Community Foundation of PEI regarding film screening of… ▸ more
A letter (date approximately November 2015) from Don to the Community Foundation of PEI regarding film screening of "Most Likely to Succeed." Don reports that Education 20/20 Inc. has observed increasing calls for education system change in recent months and notes the organization's visibility in keeping education issues public, though systemic change remains elusive. He outlines Education 20/20's activities including monthly newsletters, public presentations, workshops, website, media exposure, and the Excellence in Education Award (won by Kinkora Regional High School in 2014, Prince Street Elementary in 2015). Don proposes screening "Most Likely to Succeed" on February 7, 2016, at City Cinema and seeks $775 CAD to cover screening license, rental, and shipping costs.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
October 2015 2 Proficiency levels Education 20/20 Inc. proposal from October 2015 proposing nationally recognized math proficiency levels to replace… ▸ more
Education 20/20 Inc. proposal from October 2015 proposing nationally recognized math proficiency levels to replace age/grade-based systems that have "lost much of their value." Argues that level-setting is not a school function and that teaching and assessment functions should be separated. Proposes independent service certifying individual proficiency levels regardless of age or formal education. Cites existing Canadian models (Red Seal apprenticeships, Red Cross swimming, Royal Canadian Conservatory music exams) as precedents. Benefits include independent assessment reducing bias, improved consistency, reduced teacher workload, and support for independent learning.

September 2015 occasional paper synthesizing Alfie Kohn and Douglas Reeves' research on grading effects, documenting Don's arguments against grades as instruments that undermine learning motivation and student relationships.
