EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL SPEECH
Read · Download
 Read · Download
August 2015 31 Math in Quebec (1) August 2015 article comparing mathematics performance in Canada, highlighting Quebec's superior PISA scores. Don… ▸ more
August 2015 article comparing mathematics performance in Canada, highlighting Quebec's superior PISA scores. Don attributes this to three factors: increased formal mathematics instruction, improved teacher quality, and classroom technology use. He compares Quebec's skills-based, arithmetic-and-algebra-focused curriculum with PEI's outcomes-based approach organized around patterns, space, and probability. Don presents this as pedagogical comparison material for readers, noting potential differences while avoiding prescriptive recommendations, illustrating his empirical approach to educational analysis.
EDUCATION INSTITUTIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jul 27, 2015 D Depoliticize Education This is essentially the same argument as File 18 (July 27, 2015), with minor wording variations. Don reiterates that… ▸ more
This is essentially the same argument as File 18 (July 27, 2015), with minor wording variations. Don reiterates that provincial governments control all aspects of education, creating a political system incapable of self-regulation. He emphasizes that trustees, principals, and teachers lack control over important decisions, all made by government employees under government regulations. He argues this eliminates checks and balances that ensure quality in other sectors and calls for government to delegate meaningful decision-making authority. The repetition of this core message in multiple letters over time demonstrates Don's conviction about this fundamental systemic problem and his belief that emphasizing it through multiple published pieces could drive policy change.
BIOGRAPHICAL

Jul 10, 2015 Taylor, Alice Highlight A July 10, 2015 nomination letter supporting Alice M. Taylor for the PEI Senior Islander of the Year Award. Don praises… ▸ more
A July 10, 2015 nomination letter supporting Alice M. Taylor for the PEI Senior Islander of the Year Award. Don praises Taylor's 35-year career in early childhood education at Holland College, her program's quality and national recognition, and her continued professional development. He highlights her guest speaking, board service including the Kindergarten Transition Team, leadership in the Early Childhood Development Association, and co-authorship of "The Dance of Bullying." Don emphasizes her role as Education 20/20 Inc. founding member and Secretary-Treasurer, her commitment to the Handle with Care mental health program, and her breadth of community engagement. He characterizes her as a "Wise Woman" embodying lifelong learning and community dedication.

Jul 10, 2015 Early signs of change A field report document from Education 20/20 Inc. conducting a survey of early signs of educational change in PEI,… ▸ more
A field report document from Education 20/20 Inc. conducting a survey of early signs of educational change in PEI, based on Don Glendenning's letter to the Charlottetown Guardian (July 10, 2015). The survey tracks five specific changes: appointment of community members to curriculum committees, expansion of exemptions and credit-by-challenge opportunities, release of updated philosophy of education for all Islanders, stakeholder collaboration on basic skills, and new measures of autonomy and accountability for school boards. The document includes blank fields for respondents to record date, time, and notes on observing these changes—representing Don's effort to document and track educational reform movements on the island.

Dated July 8, 2015. High school focused survey questions addressing three main areas: ranking school roles (citizenship preparation, employment preparation, childcare), employer assessment of recent graduate preparedness with year-over-year comparison, and skill deficiency concerns (math, writing, reading, communications). Includes proposed newsletter questions about education value, exam exemptions, coding instruction, and external examination reinstatement. Represents multi-stakeholder approach to curriculum and workforce alignment. - **Tags:** high-school, survey-design, workforce-alignment, PEI-education, 2015 - **Eulogy Relevance:** HIGH - **Don Authored:** Likely (Education 20/20 project)

July 2015 30 Recent Reading July 2015 newsletter synthesizing recent educational literature. Don reports on four key sources: Obama's 2014 teacher… ▸ more
July 2015 newsletter synthesizing recent educational literature. Don reports on four key sources: Obama's 2014 teacher lunch identifying child-centered teaching as priority, an article emphasizing teacher autonomy as reform strategy, New Zealand's finding that half of children inadequately prepared for school due to rigid systems, and calls for schools to adapt to children rather than vice versa. Don applies insights to PEI, arguing for teacher autonomy, educator-public dialogue, and progressive school organization. He suggests graduate students partner with principals to design "greenfield" schools.

Dated May 22, 2015, Don congratulates Hon. Hal Perry on his election to the PEI Legislative Assembly and assumes his role as Minister of Education. Don emphasizes education's critical importance to young people and to PEI's economic and social future, arguing that the province has the capacity to become "a world leader in providing education." He encloses Education 20/20 materials and particularly directs Perry's attention to "A Call for Action," which identifies seven priority recommendations for education improvement in PEI. Don offers to meet to discuss education issues in detail and welcomes Perry to the Education 20/20 mailing list. The letter is signed "Don Glendenning, C.M." (indicating his Order of Canada honor), reflecting his standing in the community when making education advocacy appeals.

ADMINISTRATIVE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
May 2015 28 Career education - Bruner May 2015 article redefining career education beyond vocational courses. Don argues the distinction between career and… ▸ more
May 2015 article redefining career education beyond vocational courses. Don argues the distinction between career and academic studies lies not in content but in learner purpose and performance standards. Career education emphasizes qualification (demonstrated competence) versus credentials (studied content), with graduates proving they can produce quality work within acceptable timeframes with minimal supervision. This distinction challenges conventional curriculum organization and emphasizes competency-based assessment over knowledge-based credentials.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
May 2015 D 2 Assessment A May 2015 proposal from Education 20/20 Inc. for establishing an independent certification service for subject… ▸ more
A May 2015 proposal from Education 20/20 Inc. for establishing an independent certification service for subject proficiency. Don identifies problems with public school reliance on social promotion and age-based grading, proposing instead a third-party assessment system for subjects like mathematics. The service would operate independently from government, open to individuals of all ages, certifying competency levels aligned with employer needs and postsecondary entrance requirements. Key characteristics include identifying competency levels, providing unbiased assessment, and supporting both educational providers and users. This innovative approach demonstrates Don's focus on transparency, standards-based accountability, and removing institutional barriers to accurate skill recognition.
EDUCATION

Apr 18, 2015 Education 20202020 Inc A brief organizational note dated April 18, 2015, with file management instructions for Education 20/20 Inc. materials.… ▸ more
A brief organizational note dated April 18, 2015, with file management instructions for Education 20/20 Inc. materials. Directs that Jemiene (likely assistant/family member) should manage organization documentation. Lists location of files: top drawer of filing cabinet, Word folder, backup flash card (mid-April 2015), binder, basement box. Notes personal files in bottom drawer; desktop folders belong to organization; three-ring binders designated for PEI archives. Indicates floor papers are draft materials from CRA (Canada Revenue Agency) registration application to be discarded post-registration. References ongoing paper sorting and archive recommendations. This administrative note reveals Don's organizational practices and his establishment of Education 20/20 Inc. as a formal educational advocacy organization. Original note by Don.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL

Apr 14, 2015 00 -Description Comprehensive project framework document dated April 14, 2015, establishing the mathematics education initiative within… ▸ more
Comprehensive project framework document dated April 14, 2015, establishing the mathematics education initiative within Education 20/20 Inc. Frames the problem using PISA results and CFPEI surveys showing low basic skills among recent graduates. Explains deliberate choice of Grade 9 as the intervention point before academic streaming and commitment to learner-centered perspective. Outlines PEI mathematics education goals (confident problem-solving, mathematical communication, appreciation, real-world connections, lifelong learning, mathematical literacy). Identifies key gaps: inadequate transcript descriptions for employers, lack of comprehensive outcome lists, absence of quality control procedures, and missing spiralling evidence. Proposes actions including consultant consultations, master outcome lists, qualification levels, assessment instruments, external qualification mechanisms, and math roundtables.

Mar 21, 2015 D 1 A blurred vision Article titled "A vision void" referencing New York Times (March 21, 2015) report on Connecticut superintendents'… ▸ more
Article titled "A vision void" referencing New York Times (March 21, 2015) report on Connecticut superintendents' school reform manifesto. Poses four reform questions: what are worthy education outcomes, are students prepared for post-graduation world, is system designed for continuous improvement versus ranking/sorting/punishing, do laws increase conformity over innovation? Notes PEI adopted Philosophy of Education in 1990 (25 years outdated) and argues updating must encompass: all Islanders' education, all educational experiences (not just schools), preparation for life (not just postsecondary), and education as developmental process. Invited article submissions. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (Guest Editor) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., New York Times - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Advocacy for comprehensive educational philosophy update reflecting Don's systems thinking
CORRESPONDENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
March 2015 00 Alignment An occasional paper by Don Glendenning (March 2015) using a car alignment metaphor to explain the need for school… ▸ more
An occasional paper by Don Glendenning (March 2015) using a car alignment metaphor to explain the need for school system alignment across learning outcomes, assessment criteria, reporting standards, and available study time. Represents his clear, accessible communication style for public education on systemic issues.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL SPEECH

March 2015 00 Invitation March 2015 call for contributions to Education 20/20's occasional papers series. Invites public to share educational… ▸ more
March 2015 call for contributions to Education 20/20's occasional papers series. Invites public to share educational views in 1,000-2,500 word pieces on ideas, innovations, best practices. Promotes collaborative, inclusive approach to educational thinking. Emphasizes writing as learning activity aiding clarification of thinking, challenging assumptions, building vocabulary, and exploring alternatives. Demonstrates Don's vision of Education 20/20 as forum for diverse educational discourse and community engagement.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
February 2015 25-In the beginning February 2015 article emphasizing the foundational importance of early childhood education and home-based learning. Don… ▸ more
February 2015 article emphasizing the foundational importance of early childhood education and home-based learning. Don defines education broadly as experiences with formative effects on thinking, feeling, and action. He advocates for delivering educational services to homes through visits, parent information, training, and practical tips, acknowledging the challenge of individualization. The newsletter promotes "Handle with Care" - an interactive program supporting mental health of children birth to age 6, coordinated by Alice Taylor.
EDUCATION

Jan 21, 2015 3 (B) Virtual Island tour@2014-12-08T16;21;48 Detailed planning document for Education 20/20's "Virtual Tour through Island Education" (January 21, 2015) at… ▸ more
Detailed planning document for Education 20/20's "Virtual Tour through Island Education" (January 21, 2015) at Stratford Town Hall, facilitated by Don Glendenning and team. The 2-hour interactive program guides participants in small teams to examine PEI education documents, compare definitions of learning/teaching/education, evaluate the Department of Education's completeness, and discuss teacher/principal roles, lifelong learning, and the "preparedness gap" identified in the Community Foundation's Vital Signs report.
CORRESPONDENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jan 20, 2015 1 Running notes 1 Planning document dated January 20, 2015 recording Don Glendenning's notes on Education 20/20's investigation of… ▸ more
Planning document dated January 20, 2015 recording Don Glendenning's notes on Education 20/20's investigation of mathematics preparedness for youth employment. Identifies context: widespread concern about low literacy among Island adults (PISA results, CFPEI youth survey, Chamber of Commerce advocacy, PEI Home and School Federation data). Documents working group meeting (January 9, 2015) with participants Duffy, Miller, White-Hassler, Greyborn, and Glendenning. Outlines analytical framework emphasizing life roles (individual, citizen, student, producer, consumer), learning sources (self-study, instruction, online, tutoring, on-the-job), assessment methodology, and documentation approaches. Notes follow-up outreach to Lori Johnston at Workplace Learning PEI for expertise on employer math skills requirements.

A comprehensive glossary of education terminology (credentials, competencies, assessment, learning outcomes, etc.) dated January 2015. Demonstrates Don's systematic approach to clarifying education concepts and the distinctions between credentials and qualifications. Reflects his deep engagement in education reform work and commitment to clear definitions for policy work.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL REFERENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
January 2015 24-Eight Year Study Biling January 2015 article analyzing the Eight-Year Study (1933-1941), in which 30 schools experimented with outcome-based… ▸ more
January 2015 article analyzing the Eight-Year Study (1933-1941), in which 30 schools experimented with outcome-based curricula organized around "problems of living" rather than traditional course sequences. Don reports that experimental schools produced equivalent academic results but superior college outcomes, supporting his contention that myriad credential requirements impede rather than improve education. He recommends readers research the study to form independent judgments, reflecting his evidence-based approach.

The document shows Don's organizational management approach and commitment to education advocacy work.

 Read · Download
2015 2015 Changes to school system @2015-11-16T20;54;20 Don analyzes the Premier's announcement on learning and prosperity, observing that government is broadening its… ▸ more
Don analyzes the Premier's announcement on learning and prosperity, observing that government is broadening its educational vision beyond schooling to encompass all Islanders. He identifies the Premier as the de facto "First Minister of Education" with delegated responsibilities to different ministers. Don notes the elimination of the English Language School Board will reduce flexibility but likely have minimal impact, and cautions that partnerships can obscure accountability while the Province retains sole operational responsibility for schools.

2015 D 2015 Premier Letter to editor by Don arguing government should not directly run schools to avoid politicizing all issues. Outlines… ▸ more
Letter to editor by Don arguing government should not directly run schools to avoid politicizing all issues. Outlines government's appropriate role: provide leadership, ensure quality, provide funding, manage human resources, monitor performance.

2015 D 2015 Reform step 1@2015-02-27T17;11;44 Don advocates for PEI to develop a comprehensive written philosophy of education that applies to all ages and learning… ▸ more
Don advocates for PEI to develop a comprehensive written philosophy of education that applies to all ages and learning contexts, not just schools. He argues this would provide direction, consistency, and help narrow expectations gaps, proposing it as a key first step in educational reform.

2015 2015 This I believe@2015-01-13T00;32;40 A powerful statement of Don's core educational beliefs, including that most students can learn most content with… ▸ more
A powerful statement of Don's core educational beliefs, including that most students can learn most content with support, teaching is simply helping others learn, families need education advisors, schools should not rank credentials, and government should fund but not operate education. He challenges educators to publish their own beliefs, encapsulating his lifelong philosophy.

2015 2015 It's a puzzler@2015-02-12T16;06;26 Duplicate of the February 2015 Guardian letter articulating Don's central education paradox: despite government… ▸ more
Duplicate of the February 2015 Guardian letter articulating Don's central education paradox: despite government investment, schools fail to teach basic skills effectively because they neglect learner-centered support. He advocates for outcome-based education, competency frameworks, and challenges the conventional age-grading model used in public schools.

Occasional paper analyzing school engagement, examining relationships between students, teachers, parents, and communities. Presents research showing that positive outcomes occur when families, schools, and communities collaborate, improving student achievement and teacher morale. Discusses the importance of engaging students in meaningful learning and establishing welcoming school environments that foster critical thinking and community partnerships.

2015 Motions Email notification from Bill Whelan regarding continuation of Education 20/20 Inc.'s 2016 Annual General Meeting held… ▸ more
Email notification from Bill Whelan regarding continuation of Education 20/20 Inc.'s 2016 Annual General Meeting held July 20 in Charlottetown. Five members were present but lacked quorum, so two motions were submitted for electronic vote by deadline July 26, 2016: approval of 2016 budget and retention/modification of current officers. Message requests members vote FOR, AGAINST, or ABSTAIN on each motion and respond to all. Don Glendenning's role as President continues through this governance procedure.

2015 2015 Temporary minutes 12 Minutes from reconvened meeting of Education 20/20 Inc. held June 28, 2016 at Haviland Club due to lack of quorum at… ▸ more
Minutes from reconvened meeting of Education 20/20 Inc. held June 28, 2016 at Haviland Club due to lack of quorum at initial June 15 meeting. Two motions were conducted via electronic email poll: approval of 2016 budget (moved by B. Whelan, seconded by T. McRoberts) carried unanimously; and retention of current officers with modification splitting the Secretary-Treasurer position, with Alice Taylor as Secretary and Tanya Craig as Treasurer, carried with one abstention. Don Glendenning remained President, Bill Whelan Vice President.

Also profiles seven other accomplished educators and community leaders (Alice Taylor, Tim McRoberts, William Whelan, etc.) who served as directors, revealing Don's network and collaborative approach to education reform leadership.

2015 PEI -2 Educ Facts Compilation of PEI Department of Education's official statements, purpose, goals, and priorities from 2015-2023.… ▸ more
Compilation of PEI Department of Education's official statements, purpose, goals, and priorities from 2015-2023. Glendenning's analysis notes the department's focus on youth in school rather than comprehensive education services, highlighting a persistent gap between the department's mission and broader educational needs.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 95 Board of Education Don expands on structural impediments to educational improvement, drawing again from public education discussions he… ▸ more
Don expands on structural impediments to educational improvement, drawing again from public education discussions he convened on PEI and World Bank research. He identifies political embedding of education delivery within government departments as problematic, notes PEI's narrowing view of education (conflating school attendance with genuine education), and cites OECD/PISA evidence that students perform better in schools with operational autonomy. He reiterates that accountability reporting focuses on school operations rather than demonstrable learning outcomes, and restates Education 20/20's 2015 call for a "clear and compelling" vision of education as the critical starting point for systemic improvement.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 94 Structural Don identifies systemic barriers to educational improvement in PEI, including political interference, limited… ▸ more
Don identifies systemic barriers to educational improvement in PEI, including political interference, limited professional autonomy for principals and teachers, outdated organizational structures, and confusion between schooling and education. He cites OECD/PISA research showing students perform better when schools have operational autonomy, and references the World Bank's distinction between education and school attendance. He notes the "fear factor" constrains open discussion of educational change on PEI and criticizes the loss of vocational training programs (PVI and PCVHS), calling for a clear vision of education informed by 2015 Education 20/20 principles.
EDUCATION

Brief letter dated December 3, 2015 from Don to Ms. Baksh regarding resubmission of Education 20/20's application for charitable registration. References the original application submitted January 8, 2013, withdrawal on July 16, 2013, and resubmission in March 2015. Notes administrative details about board membership and compliance awareness (90% charitable use requirement). Primarily procedural correspondence regarding application status.

Includes details about the "Learning Path" initiative, "A Bridge to New Careers" presentation, "Teaching and Learning for a Complex World" by Dave Cormier (2+ hours, no handouts), and screening of "Most Likely to Succeed" film on January 17, 2016. Mentions presentation to the Minister of Workforce and Advanced Learning on November 23 covering qualification authorities, part-time courses, and first-line supervisor training. Shows Don's engagement with provincial education policy and innovation in educational programming.

2015 35 En 2015-12-15 - no. 35 - Basic Skills Gap Initiates investigation into basic skills gaps among high school graduates unable to enter employment or postsecondary… ▸ more
Initiates investigation into basic skills gaps among high school graduates unable to enter employment or postsecondary education. Don notes lack of comprehensive data about gap nature and affected populations. Discusses distinction between citizenship skills (critical thinking, active participation, collaborative working, negotiation, communication) and employment-specific skills. Reports Education 20/20's exploratory meetings and announces government's newly established consultative bodies: Principals' Council, Family of Schools District Advisory Councils, and Learning Partners Advisory Council. Encourages community engagement in voluntary advisory roles. Announces "Most Likely to Succeed" film screening (January 17, 2016) showcasing project-based learning at High Tech High, San Diego. Includes holiday greetings and end-of-year reflections.

2015 D 2015-1 Hubley-Little Press release documenting Education 20/20 dialogue with Dr. Tammy Hubley-Little, English Language School Board… ▸ more
Press release documenting Education 20/20 dialogue with Dr. Tammy Hubley-Little, English Language School Board director. Discussion focused on support for struggling students, early identification of learning difficulties, and equity and opportunity. Reflects Glendenning's collaborative leadership style, convening educators and public for knowledge exchange. Shows his belief in dialogue as mechanism for educational improvement. The format of organized discussions became hallmark of Education 20/20's approach under his leadership.

2015 D 2015- School lunch Opinion piece on school lunch programs and nutrition. While acknowledging diet's importance, Glendenning argues… ▸ more
Opinion piece on school lunch programs and nutrition. While acknowledging diet's importance, Glendenning argues nutrition is primarily a health-wellness issue, not a school responsibility. He positions nutrition within broader health system context, noting schools should participate but not lead such initiatives. This demonstrates his clear thinking about institutional boundaries and his resistance to expanding school mandates beyond core educational functions. Shows his advocating for appropriate role definition in education policy.

2015 2015 Prince St award June 8, 2015 announcement of Prince Street Elementary School as the 2015 Excellence in Education Award winner ($2,500).… ▸ more
June 8, 2015 announcement of Prince Street Elementary School as the 2015 Excellence in Education Award winner ($2,500). Award recognizes schools for quality education efforts. National PTA research cited: family-school-community collaboration improves achievement, teacher morale, communication, attendance, behavior, and graduation rates. Award focuses on school-controlled factors: student engagement, environment, instruction, community partnerships, parental involvement. Dr. Glendenning highlighted specific evidence: student accomplishment honors, case management meetings, school song development, "Garden Buddies" food program, mascot selection, staff effort to improve student spaces, and extensive community engagement. Three nominations received; committee recommended Prince Street; Education 20/20 Board approved June 3.

2015 Key Planning document for a five-session "Issues in Education" series limited to 20 participants, led by Don Glendenning… ▸ more
Planning document for a five-session "Issues in Education" series limited to 20 participants, led by Don Glendenning (892-5859) and a co-leader. Sessions cover educational overview/basics, curriculum development (with Derek McEwen, Director of English Curriculum), and three participant-determined topics. Encourages participants to bring iPads/smartphones, planned for 2015, offered in multiple communities by demand. Reflects Don's philosophy of participant-centered learning and flexible program design.

2015 2015 Notes-1 Notes from January 9, 2015, documenting Education 20/20 Inc.'s exploration of basic math skills needed for modern… ▸ more
Notes from January 9, 2015, documenting Education 20/20 Inc.'s exploration of basic math skills needed for modern economies. Cites concerns from PISA results, CFPEI surveys, Chamber of Commerce presentations, and Home and School surveys regarding low basic skills, especially mathematics. Proposes a four-element framework examining life roles, learning opportunities, assessment approaches, and documentation methods. Outlines first step of identifying employer expectations and required skill levels.

2015 0 2015 Discussion paper-2 Comprehensive policy analysis document examining Education 20/20 Inc.'s awards program criteria evolution from 2014 to… ▸ more
Comprehensive policy analysis document examining Education 20/20 Inc.'s awards program criteria evolution from 2014 to 2015. Detailed discussion of prior year feedback ("purpose not clearly defined," "excessive documentation," "favored early childhood"), then presents refined 2015 criteria focusing on student engagement, school environment, instruction, and community partnerships. Document also analyzes external frameworks like "Schools of Opportunity," independent school hallmarks, and quality education characteristics. This strategic thinking demonstrates Don's evidence-based approach to educational program design and continuous improvement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Two sides- Don distinguishes between professional and organizational problems in school systems, arguing that education typically… ▸ more
Don distinguishes between professional and organizational problems in school systems, arguing that education typically addresses professional issues (resources, training, pilots) while ignoring organizational ones. He advocates for organizational solutions: flexible scheduling, alternative delivery models, after-school tutoring, extended school years for struggling students, challenge-for-credit options, online courses, school autonomy, and self-directed study. Without addressing organizational barriers, professional interventions lose effectiveness.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Signs of change Don outlines five low-cost indicators of educational improvement requiring only administrative change: appointing… ▸ more
Don outlines five low-cost indicators of educational improvement requiring only administrative change: appointing community members to curriculum committees, restoring student exemptions and challenge-for-credit options, updating education philosophy beyond school-age focus, addressing basic skill deficiencies across stakeholders, and granting schools and boards greater autonomy with accountability measures. He emphasizes these changes need no significant budget impact, demonstrating his pragmatic approach to systemic improvement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 School closings Don defends small schools against closure recommendations, citing research showing they foster cooperation, improve… ▸ more
Don defends small schools against closure recommendations, citing research showing they foster cooperation, improve attendance, strengthen student engagement, and build self-reliance. He argues that while rural schools are often targeted for closure, evidence suggests small schools provide superior educational outcomes. He proposes giving small schools autonomy in scheduling, grouping, staffing, and technology access rather than eliminating them, and suggests prioritizing educational services by their impact on student learning while eliminating less essential offerings.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Kudos Don praises the Summerside Rotary Club for establishing a Learning Centre and Murphy's Community Centre for the… ▸ more
Don praises the Summerside Rotary Club for establishing a Learning Centre and Murphy's Community Centre for the Stratford After-School Program. He commends these initiatives for recognizing that education extends beyond schooling and that communities play vital educational roles. He particularly notes how schools' "care function" became evident during severe winter weather, appreciating community efforts to fill gaps schools cannot address.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Accountability Don examines the Department of Education website to analyze accountability structures. He finds the Minister's role… ▸ more
Don examines the Department of Education website to analyze accountability structures. He finds the Minister's role clearly defined (defines, provides, assesses, establishes, approves, prohibits) while the Deputy Minister and Superintendent lack clear function descriptions, principals exercise vague "leadership" responsibilities, and teachers' instructional roles are undefined. He concludes the organization is "out of sync" with form and function misaligned, issues parachuted up to ministerial decision-making, and focus absent from accomplishment.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 D 2015 Role of government Don argues that PEI has a school system lacking purpose, service orientation, value, worth, and direction, rather than… ▸ more
Don argues that PEI has a school system lacking purpose, service orientation, value, worth, and direction, rather than a true education system. He advocates for expanding beyond classroom delivery to include tutoring, study centres in libraries, a separate qualification authority, continuing education, and support for self-directed learners. He critiques box schools for their inability to cater to individual needs and calls for educational diversity including specialized schools. The letter emphasizes that implementing these changes requires bold government action and premier-level leadership. This reflects his inclusive vision of education as serving all learners across the lifespan, not just youth in traditional classroom settings.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 D 2015 Conspiracy Don contemplates writing a novel about educational reform, framing systemic change as a bureaucratic "conspiracy to… ▸ more
Don contemplates writing a novel about educational reform, framing systemic change as a bureaucratic "conspiracy to control." The document distills his conclusions from recent travel, newspaper reading, and previous discussions into actionable recommendations: widespread recognition that education quality is crucial to individual and national futures; acknowledgment that current systems lack capacity for necessary change requiring outside intervention; identification of provincial leadership as key to reform initiation; calls for action over further study; and specific changes including increased choice, defined standards, decentralized decision-making, teacher autonomy, and early childhood investment. This represents his most comprehensive final summary of reform priorities.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015-student staff ratio Don draws from personal leadership experience, noting he once declined a position when the board attempted to dictate… ▸ more
Don draws from personal leadership experience, noting he once declined a position when the board attempted to dictate organizational structure. He argues that student-staff ratios, while useful to administrators for funding allocation, indicate little about school service quality. Effective staffing decisions should occur at school level, accounting for individual staff strengths and school context. Don references research supporting team teaching, focused professional development, and assigning diagnosis and assessment to specialist teachers. He recalls a transformative assignment from Professor Gibson to design a university organization based on Kant, illustrating how intellectual challenge creates lasting learning.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 The myth of grade levels A refined version of his grade-level critique, Don clarifies that while different levels exist within subjects (Grade 9… ▸ more
A refined version of his grade-level critique, Don clarifies that while different levels exist within subjects (Grade 9 math vs. advanced mathematics), these levels should not correspond to age or years in school. He highlights apprenticeship, music, and swimming as better models where levels are set by external bodies and recognized across jurisdictions. Don proposes PEI establish a qualification framework identifying subject levels independent of age, potentially creating national and international portability. He positions this as an opportunity for PEI to "break new ground" in education innovation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 School grades Don distinguishes three purposes of educational testing: diagnostic (to identify support needs), level-setting (to… ▸ more
Don distinguishes three purposes of educational testing: diagnostic (to identify support needs), level-setting (to establish subject proficiency), and ranking (comparing individuals against peers). He argues that while diagnostic testing is integral to teaching, teachers are so consumed with curriculum delivery they cannot effectively use diagnostic results. Ranking conflicts with the teacher's role and should be relegated to external agencies. Similarly, level-setting should be independent, as occurs in music and apprenticeship. Don advocates for refocusing teacher effort on diagnosis and student support rather than summative evaluation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Role of government Don advocates for updating PEI's Philosophy of Education document, noting it is foundational to system decisions but… ▸ more
Don advocates for updating PEI's Philosophy of Education document, noting it is foundational to system decisions but narrowly focused on schools and schooling. He calls for broadened scope to include home and community education across all ages. The letter mentions needed consultation with external facilitators and suggests this update as an appropriate priority for a new premier. The document appears to have formatting issues, suggesting it may be a working draft or outline rather than a finished letter.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Ranking students This letter challenges the fundamental practice of teachers ranking students, which Don views as a conflict of interest… ▸ more
This letter challenges the fundamental practice of teachers ranking students, which Don views as a conflict of interest that distorts education's meaning. He questions why those who teach should award credentials, as this creates incentive misalignment. Don proposes a provocative interim measure—issuing credentials on "evaporating" paper valid only 10 days after graduation—to highlight the absurdity of static credentials. He argues that an independent agency should award all degrees and diplomas, separating teaching from credentialing functions.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Plilosophy of Education Don calls for PEI to develop an updated philosophy of education to replace the 1990 version housed on the Department of… ▸ more
Don calls for PEI to develop an updated philosophy of education to replace the 1990 version housed on the Department of Education website. He argues the existing philosophy focuses narrowly on youth and schooling rather than recognizing education as a lifelong process for all Islanders. Drawing on OECD research, Don emphasizes that schools must balance individual development with preparing citizens for community needs. He positions this philosophical update as an ideal priority for a new government, framing education policy as foundational to governance.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 The myth of grsde levels An early draft of Don's argument that grade levels are administrative conveniences devoid of educational foundation. He… ▸ more
An early draft of Don's argument that grade levels are administrative conveniences devoid of educational foundation. He uses vivid metaphor, calling grade levels "mythical but sacred cows of education"—widely held but unexamined beliefs. Employing mathematics as his example, Don questions why age and achievement level should be linked. He calls for separating subject mastery from chronological age and school years, positioning this as essential educational reform. This is a foundational argument he revisits across multiple letters.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Ossification Don draws on David McLaughlin's essay about federal public service renewal to address "idea ossification" in education… ▸ more
Don draws on David McLaughlin's essay about federal public service renewal to address "idea ossification" in education policy. He observes that fear of failure and political criticism creates barriers to innovation in education. Don identifies a problematic disconnect where educators primarily discuss education with other educators, and the public talks mainly to itself. He calls for reciprocal dialogue, suggesting the public should initiate conversations with educators about educational reform and advocating for program chairs to organize speaker series. This piece emphasizes the importance of critical thinking and public engagement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Graduation requirements Don commends the Department's review of graduation requirements and the Chambers of Commerce for advocating literacy… ▸ more
Don commends the Department's review of graduation requirements and the Chambers of Commerce for advocating literacy standards, but questions whether research supports rigid graduation requirements. He notes that the Secondary Literacy Assessment requires students to write but not pass the exam, uses results for teacher improvement rather than student accountability, and doesn't solicit feedback from employers or postsecondary institutions despite their expressed concerns. The letter shows Don's attention to policy details and his belief that requirements should be evidence-based and stakeholder-informed.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Basic documents Don critiques PEI's Department of Education Philosophy document for being narrowly focused on schooling rather than… ▸ more
Don critiques PEI's Department of Education Philosophy document for being narrowly focused on schooling rather than education, fuzzy in language, and lacking measurable goals. He argues that important learning happens outside institutional settings and that education should encompass online courses, workplace training, and home-based learning. Don recommends that updating this foundational document should be "Job 1" for a new Premier, reflecting his belief that clarity of purpose precedes effective implementation. This letter showcases his demand for philosophical clarity and systemic coherence.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 An opening salvo This more ambitious draft addresses the coming election and education's place in public discourse. Don argues that… ▸ more
This more ambitious draft addresses the coming election and education's place in public discourse. Don argues that government conflates setting rules with running schools, creating inflexibility, reduced innovation, and politicization of professional issues. He outlines options: an independent education board or government delegation of operations while retaining oversight. The document is notably fragmented and shows significant revision, suggesting Don was wrestling with comprehensive education system reform during election season. He emphasizes that consensus exists on needed changes but implementation remains blocked.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2015 2015 Alignment Using a car maintenance analogy, Don explains that school systems also require "alignment checks" across 8-10… ▸ more
Using a car maintenance analogy, Don explains that school systems also require "alignment checks" across 8-10 dimensions. He identifies critical alignments: outcomes with life needs, assessment criteria with later-life requirements, report cards with outcome statements, and time allocation with student needs. The letter provides practical advice to parents: review course outcomes before parent-teacher meetings to focus discussion. This demonstrates Don's ability to translate complex systemic concepts into practical guidance for families.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2015 00 Pro forma Support document Detailed evaluation of three school nominations for Education 20/20's inaugural School Award in 2015. Glendenning… ▸ more
Detailed evaluation of three school nominations for Education 20/20's inaugural School Award in 2015. Glendenning served as ex officio member of Awards Committee. Document analyzes three finalists: Spring Park School, Queen Charlotte Band Program, and Prince Street Elementary School. Spring Park highlighted for innovative practices (literacy, numeracy fairs, 21st century learning, clubs, playground equipment). Queen Charlotte noted for long-established band program with free concerts and community involvement. Prince Street praised for inclusive practices, student recognition, community partnerships, and creative programming. Document shows Glendenning's attention to detailed educational assessment. - **Key People**: Donald Glendenning (Ex officio), Donald DesRoches, Peter Russell, Dave MacCabe - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, Spring Park School, Queen Charlotte Band Program, Prince Street Elementary School - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Glendenning's leadership in educational recognition and assessment

2015 2015- CRA Clarification-1 Notes from telephone conversation with Mezaun Baksh at CRA regarding clarification requests on Education 20/20's… ▸ more
Notes from telephone conversation with Mezaun Baksh at CRA regarding clarification requests on Education 20/20's application. CRA sought elaboration on workshops/webinars structure and materials, employer engagement details, supplemental educational services (robotics), credentials, website information, and budget allocation. Key requirement noted: 90% of resources must go to charitable purposes. CRA set 60-day response deadline (indicating December 6, 2015 deadline). - **Key People**: Donald Glendenning (implied), Mezaun Baksh (CRA Charities Analyst) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Canada Revenue Agency, CFPEI (Community Foundation PEI) - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, CORRESPONDENCE, ADMIN - **Eulogy Relevance**: LOW - Administrative clarification notes

2015 D-9 Learning Path document july 2015 Final published version of learning path paper incorporating all previous consultations. Documents workshop convened… ▸ more
Final published version of learning path paper incorporating all previous consultations. Documents workshop convened "From a Learner's Perspective" with youth panel identifying learning support activities. Discusses evolution from linear to non-linear learning models and five major steps: decide to learn, explore options, attempt task, use help, reach expectations. Includes detailed visual learning path diagram showing various learning activities (gather information, seek counseling, take instruction, observe others, feedback, undertake assessment, attempt task, self-assess) and decision points. Includes connections to credential/qualification framework. Acknowledges thanks to Tanya Craig, youth panelists, Holly Moses, ECE students at Holland College, and Mike Chapman. - **Key People**: Tanya Craig, Callen Cudmore, Ryan Rioux, Iain Cudmore, Stephanie Mayne, Holly Moses, Mike Chapman - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Holland College - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Final version of research project involving Holland College collaboration

2015 D-2015-Seaward Gap fillow After Education 20/20-sponsored presentation by Gerry Seaward on Holland College Adult Basic Education program addressing… ▸ more
Education 20/20-sponsored presentation by Gerry Seaward on Holland College Adult Basic Education program addressing preparedness gaps. Community Foundation of PEI 2013 survey of Island youth identified gaps regarding post-secondary readiness and workplace preparation. Gaps result from dropout, course failure, unmet entrance requirements. Holland College program (funded by Department of Workforce Development and Higher Learning) offers full/part-time study in eight Island centres for students lacking high school credits, seeking mark upgrades, or pursuing PEI High School Graduation Certificate for Mature Students. Presentation at Stratford Town Hall, September 30, 4:30 pm. Seaward currently Program Manager, Prince of Wales Campus. Students with preparedness gaps especially welcome. Education 20/20 coordinating dialogue on education among Islanders; other presentations planned. - **Key People**: Gerry Seaward, Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Holland College, Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, Department of Workforce Development and Higher Learning - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Glendenning's sustained focus on addressing educational readiness and bridging community access to education opportunities

2015 2015- Learning path Education 20/20 working group meeting (22 Islanders: parents, business, educators) discussing draft "learning path"… ▸ more
Education 20/20 working group meeting (22 Islanders: parents, business, educators) discussing draft "learning path" model developed by organization. Learning path visualizes learning as process showing help needed at different stages. Group identified learner needs: information, encouragement, practice, feedback, self-study, instruction, self-analysis. Critical issue: accommodating varied learning paces and styles. Feedback incorporated for revised model. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Haviland Club - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Reflects Glendenning's commitment to systematic, evidence-based learning process design

2015 2015 A call for action Education 20/20 announces seven-point action plan for PEI education improvement. Glendenning critiques existing model… ▸ more
Education 20/20 announces seven-point action plan for PEI education improvement. Glendenning critiques existing model as focused on service delivery rather than people development. Plan calls for Department of Education to increase school/teacher autonomy and accountability while establishing learning culture. Proposes clear vision, learner-centered delivery, delegated instruction authority, separate qualification authority, professional service models, and innovation incentives. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Department of Education (PEI) - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Core policy advocacy reflecting Glendenning's mature educational philosophy and systemic reform vision

2015 Math 2015 Proposal Mathematics gap proposal identifying flawed education organization and proposing comprehensive remedies. Discusses… ▸ more
Mathematics gap proposal identifying flawed education organization and proposing comprehensive remedies. Discusses age-based curriculum, education-based sorting, and batch processes as systemic issues. Proposes establishing independent testing service/authority to award qualifications. Includes extensive discussion of mathematics structure (numeracy through infinite series) and goals of math education. Details a four-step process: comprehensive analysis of math competencies, development of rating scales, establishing identifiable performance levels, and creating testing service. References workplan and project director responsibilities. - **Key People**: Duffy, Miller, White-Hassler, Greyborn, Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Holland College, UPEI, Chamber of Commerce, Government of PEI, Education 20/20 - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's comprehensive educational reform vision and leadership.

2015 9 2015 math proposal Creative conceptual framework presenting "Mathematics as a Mountain" metaphor. Critiques current educational elevation… ▸ more
Creative conceptual framework presenting "Mathematics as a Mountain" metaphor. Critiques current educational elevation system for grades as lacking logic, being subject to interpretation, and having no national standard. Proposes mountain-climbing framework emphasizing mathematics as prerequisite for later-life opportunities. Outlines mathematical structure: numeracy through infinite series. Advocates for complete field analysis before establishing levels. Proposes linkage with PISA or OECD levels and independent assessment service model similar to music and skating certification. Project plan: establish committee, undertake analysis, establish levels, conduct national consultation, distribute widely. Benefits include common standards, mobility support, and reduced curriculum workload. - **Key People**: None specifically named - **Key Organizations**: OECD, PISA, provincial education systems - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's creative metaphorical thinking and national-scope ambitions for educational reform.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Dec 1, 2014 D Changes that make a difference Written December 1, 2014, Don reflects on transformative changes in rural life (electricity, indoor plumbing, water… ▸ more
Written December 1, 2014, Don reflects on transformative changes in rural life (electricity, indoor plumbing, water systems) and argues education needs equivalent systemic changes. His priority list includes: adequate time, fair teacher compensation, criterion-referenced assessment, challenge-for-credit options, school autonomy, competency-based education, and teaching professionalization. The letter is partially incomplete but conveys his conviction that education transformation requires addressing multiple structural factors simultaneously.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
December 2014 A clear vision Dated October-December 2014, this letter responds to the Chamber of Commerce's call for "a clear vision" in education.… ▸ more
Dated October-December 2014, this letter responds to the Chamber of Commerce's call for "a clear vision" in education. Don notes PEI has a published Philosophy of Education but identifies two critical limitations: it addresses only youth education, not lifelong learning, and it focuses narrowly on schooling rather than recognizing learning in homes, workplaces, and communities. He invokes John Dewey's principle that understanding an organization's philosophy reveals its essence, arguing that education policy requires comprehensive rethinking to encompass all citizens and learning settings.

Nov 9, 2014 Parkhouse Marked "DRAFTED BUT NOT SENT" (November 9, 2014), this letter addresses Owen Parkhouse more formally regarding his… ▸ more
Marked "DRAFTED BUT NOT SENT" (November 9, 2014), this letter addresses Owen Parkhouse more formally regarding his inactive participation on the Education 20/20 Board. Don notes that Parkhouse's last Board meeting attendance was the June 2014 planning meeting, with the last correspondence from him dated June 26, 2013. The unsent draft indicates Don's intention to remove Parkhouse from the Director list unless he responds by December 31, 2014. The tone is more formal and administrative than the actual letter sent on November 10, suggesting Don revised his approach to be more considerate of Parkhouse's circumstances. This document is valuable for understanding Don's internal decision-making process and his capacity for diplomatic revision.

Oct 22, 2014 20 Expectations of schools Glendenning addresses changing public expectations for schools, noting confusion over undefined "full potential" as an… ▸ more
Glendenning addresses changing public expectations for schools, noting confusion over undefined "full potential" as an educational goal. He reports findings from Education 20/20 workshops across PEI revealing that islanders want schools to prepare students for work, further education, and citizenship—not just knowledge transfer. He proposes a clarifying statement emphasizing skills, knowledge, and attitudes for coping with and contributing to a full life. Includes advertisement for community workshop event scheduled for October 22, 2014. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (Editor) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Stratford Town Hall - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Glendenning's grassroots engagement with PEI communities and his commitment to clarifying educational philosophy through stakeholder conversation.

Oct 14, 2014 Education should increase opportunity-2 From October 14, 2014, Don recounts a student's life-altering decision to accept a lower-level math course… ▸ more
From October 14, 2014, Don recounts a student's life-altering decision to accept a lower-level math course recommendation, dramatically reducing college/university prospects and likely lifetime income. He argues schools should open doors, not close them. Presented as a concrete case study, the letter shows Don's emotional investment in individual student outcomes and his conviction that well-intentioned teacher decisions can have devastating consequences when they narrow rather than expand student possibilities.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Oct 14, 2014 00 Closing doors Letter to the Editor of Charlottetown Guardian (October 14, 2014) titled "Closing doors," written by Don Glendenning.… ▸ more
Letter to the Editor of Charlottetown Guardian (October 14, 2014) titled "Closing doors," written by Don Glendenning. The letter critiques a school's decision to move a struggling high school math student to a lower-level course, arguing this "closes doors" to college/university options and lifetime employment prospects. Don advocates for schools to expand opportunities through extra instruction and support rather than restrict them through course placement. He emphasizes that school decisions fundamentally shape student futures and expresses concern about institutional practices that limit rather than enable student potential.

This brief bibliography (August 31, 2014) compiled for a 2014 learning workshop includes references on learning science, neuroplasticity, and cognitive development, featuring authors like Barbara Kantrowitz (Scientific American), Doreen Dailey, and Robert Gagné. The document reflects Don's evidence-based approach to education design, his commitment to grounding workshops in contemporary learning science, and his practice of drawing on peer-reviewed research and expert sources to inform Education 20/20 programming.

Aug 1, 2014 B-2 Learning Diagram Education 20/20 working paper (No. B-2, dated August 1, 2014) describing the learning process based on panel feedback… ▸ more
Education 20/20 working paper (No. B-2, dated August 1, 2014) describing the learning process based on panel feedback from young people. Don presents learning as individual change in behavior, knowledge, or attitude. Identifies key learning steps including gathering information, attending lectures, seeking counseling, observing demonstrations, attempting tasks, undergoing assessment, motivating self, reflecting, and obtaining feedback. Notes that learners follow different paths through these steps based on learning style and purpose. Credits Tanya Craig for convening the youth panel and Mike Chapman for design. Includes a visual learner process chart showing planning, engagement, and verification phases. - **Key People**: Tanya Craig (panel convener), Mike Chapman (design), Youth panel members (unnamed) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Don's collaborative approach to understanding learning and his engagement with young people in the education reform process.

Jul 28, 2014 201-Gap Informarion sheets July 28, 2014 proposal for education information sheets addressing parent education about school practices, accessible… ▸ more
July 28, 2014 proposal for education information sheets addressing parent education about school practices, accessible through media and direct distribution. Document outlines methodology for surveying parent information needs, developing 600-1,000 word newspaper-style articles in both official languages, testing with community groups, and using materials as discussion guides. Potential topics include report cards, OBE, math skills, and numeracy. Emphasizes grassroots information dissemination focused on parent engagement as key educators, reflecting Education 20/20 Inc.'s communication strategy.

Jul 28, 2014 200 ProposaL Gap-1 July 28, 2014 proposal from Education 20/20 Inc. (with which Don was involved) addressing perceived gaps between school… ▸ more
July 28, 2014 proposal from Education 20/20 Inc. (with which Don was involved) addressing perceived gaps between school delivery and education quality. Document cites Community Foundation of PEI's youth survey revealing employment concerns, educational deficiencies, and preparedness gaps. Proposes systematic information dissemination through short papers on educational topics, community-level testing, bilingual publication, and wide distribution. Proposal emphasizes parents as key educators and focuses on topics including essential skills, emotional intelligence, social promotion, workplace preparedness, and formative evaluation. Reflects Don's advocacy for community engagement in educational transformation.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Jul 10, 2014 Dthe leading cause From July 10, 2014, Don argues schools face a systemic crisis: they focus on knowledge delivery while parents expect… ▸ more
From July 10, 2014, Don argues schools face a systemic crisis: they focus on knowledge delivery while parents expect educated citizens; institutions matter less; teachers shouldn't award credentials (like coaches vs. referees); public education lacks market forces incentivizing improvement; and time-based progression replaces standards maintenance. He advocates for government ensuring quality education through unbundled service delivery rather than direct school operation. His analysis is systemic: the problem isn't individual schools but the education system's structural misalignment with modern needs.

Reflects Don's emphasis on competency-based assessment independent of school credit systems.

Jun 26, 2014 Greenan, PEI Legislature In this June 26, 2014 letter, Don accepts an invitation from Hon. Gerard Greenan, Chair of the Standing Committee on… ▸ more
In this June 26, 2014 letter, Don accepts an invitation from Hon. Gerard Greenan, Chair of the Standing Committee on Education and Innovation, for Education 20/20 Inc. to present to the committee on July 8 at 10:00 a.m. in the Pope Room at the Coles Building in Charlottetown. Don notes that the 10-15 minute presentation will be led by Tom White-Hassler and Alice Taylor, two of Education 20/20's board directors. This represents a significant opportunity for Don's organization to influence provincial educational policy at the highest legislative levels and demonstrates the credibility Education 20/20 had achieved within government structures by 2014.

Jun 1, 2014 Beliefs Education 20/20 Occasional Paper No. 101 (dated June 1, 2014) presenting Education 20/20's vision and Don's personal… ▸ more
Education 20/20 Occasional Paper No. 101 (dated June 1, 2014) presenting Education 20/20's vision and Don's personal educational beliefs. The organization's vision emphasizes achievement over time served, mutual respect, meaningful assessment, learning-centered focus, teacher accountability, outcomes-based approach, criterion-referenced assessment, and independent learning support. Don's personal beliefs span education as critical social priority affecting health, drugs, crime, and literacy; most people can learn; achievement as constant and time as variable; publicly-funded systems' responsibility to develop capabilities; education's purpose to support life roles; learning as behavior change; education occurring outside school; need for systemic organizational change beyond current education institutions; government leadership without direct school operation; and recognition that current systems reward schooling not education. Emphasizes engagement, community focus, and results orientation. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Core summary of Don's educational beliefs and his vision for transforming education systems.

Public announcement for the O'Leary workshop scheduled for Tuesday, May 6, 2014 at the Access Centre. The announcement publicized the workshop's focus on youth preparedness for work, referencing a Community Foundation study ("Taking the Pulse of Island Youth"). Presenters Steve McQuaid and Katherine MacDonald would present findings, followed by roundtable discussion on preparedness for work. Don Glendenning is listed as the contact person (902-892-2060), indicating his leadership role in organizing these events for Education 20/20 Inc.

A brief personal letter dated May 1, 2014, from Don to Emily Shaw congratulating her on acceptance to the Academie de Paris for art study. Don acknowledges the significance of her initiative but informs her that Education 20/20 Inc. does not have a scholarship program and suggests she consult her school's guidance counselor. This letter demonstrates Don's awareness of individual student achievements and his willingness to encourage educational pursuits, while being clear about organizational limitations.

May 1, 2014 00 - Introductory notes Comprehensive opening remarks for a May 1, 2014 Education 20/20 event, establishing organizational mission and… ▸ more
Comprehensive opening remarks for a May 1, 2014 Education 20/20 event, establishing organizational mission and governance. Don Glendenning listed as one of six Directors (alongside Alice Taylor, Brenda Goodine, Bill Whelan, Tanya Craig, Owen Parkhouse). Organization described as small, independent, nationally incorporated, network-based (not membership-based), broadly inclusive ("big tent"), and financially supported by CFPEI, with sponsorship from R. Birt and Associates, Metro Credit Union, Maritime Electric, and anonymous donors. Core mission emphasizes holistic education concept, not just schools. Initial focus areas: information (website, newsletter), incentives (education awards), and engagement (two workshop series). Defines quality education as emphasizing learner health, safe environments, relevant content, community-linked outcomes, learner-focused support, timely/independent advice, and professional/autonomous teachers. Evening agenda included CFPEI presentation and youth survey findings by Steve McQuaid and Katherine MacDonald.

Dated April 14, 2014, this brief letter thanks Wendy Budgeon for her public advocacy on education issues, particularly referencing the "Taking the Pulse of Island Youth" report and Education 20/20 discussions. Don acknowledges that educators often cannot speak freely about needed changes without career risk, and calls on citizens to voice support for educational reform. The letter reflects his conviction that public engagement is essential to advancing education policy and reveals his collaborative approach to systemic change.

April 8, 2014 press release announcing workshop outcomes and Education 20/20's approach. Apr 6, 2014 D What education should be free Published April 6, 2014, this letter addresses the preparedness gap identified in the Community Foundation's youth… ▸ more
Published April 6, 2014, this letter addresses the preparedness gap identified in the Community Foundation's youth report. Don attributes the gap to social promotion practices and insufficient teaching support time. Rather than accepting school limitations, he proposes two innovations: allowing teachers to open professional tutoring offices (similar to medical or legal clinics) and establishing independent testing centers to certify skill levels outside school grade systems. Both services would be publicly funded, reflecting his belief that educational support is a legitimate public responsibility.

Diagram outlining the education delivery system in PEI, dated April 2014. Don maps the landscape of education providers including public schools, private institutions, postsecondary options, tutoring services, and professional organizations, reflecting his systems-thinking approach to educational reform.

April 2014 15 Quality - English and French April 2014 publication defining quality education systems using frameworks from UNICEF, OECD, and UNESCO. Don… ▸ more
April 2014 publication defining quality education systems using frameworks from UNICEF, OECD, and UNESCO. Don identifies seven characteristics: healthy, well-nourished learners; safe environments; relevant content; community-linked outcomes; learner-focused support; timely information; and professional, autonomous teachers. This comprehensive definition emphasizes that quality education prioritizes learner well-being and learning processes over administrative structures, reflecting Don's philosophical commitment to student-centered pedagogy.

Mar 29, 2014 Media-Announcement Press release announcing establishment of Education Engagement Award. Details: $2,500 award donated anonymously,… ▸ more
Press release announcing establishment of Education Engagement Award. Details: $2,500 award donated anonymously, recognizes PEI school or learning centre demonstrating engagement in daily operations. Award philosophy: student achievement improves, teacher morale rises, communication increases when schools and communities work together. Focus on school-controlled factors: family and community communication, frequency of community-based events, parent/community involvement in curriculum development and planning. Five engagement areas identified: student-to-student, student-to-teacher, student-to-learning materials, student-to-community partnerships, parental involvement. Committee will review nominations and recommend recipient based solely on submitted information. Nominations deadline March 29, 2014; award early May. Primary contact: Don Glendenning, 892-5859. Notes Education 20/20 Inc. as "broad based, independent national, not-for-profit education organization" in Charlottetown with interest in improving education quality for every Islander.

 Read · Download
Mar 27, 2014 D Math clubs Published March 27, 2014, Don observes the absence of math clubs in Canadian schools and proposes establishing them as… ▸ more
Published March 27, 2014, Don observes the absence of math clubs in Canadian schools and proposes establishing them as community-based programs outside school hours, open to students from multiple schools. He notes UPEI's mathematics team competes successfully in national competitions, suggesting student interest and potential exist. His proposal reflects belief in fostering intellectual curiosity and providing enrichment opportunities beyond standard curriculum. The letter demonstrates his vision of education extending beyond formal schooling into community engagement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Mar 21, 2014 D 1-Focus on schools Dated March 21, 2014, Don analyzes emerging shifts in public discourse about education. He identifies two complementary… ▸ more
Dated March 21, 2014, Don analyzes emerging shifts in public discourse about education. He identifies two complementary changes: growing structural concerns about schools (standards, relevance, age-based grouping) and recognition that education extends beyond schooling. He notes that while educators cannot unilaterally drive change, the community is increasingly aware that education involves homes, workplaces, and community settings. The letter demonstrates his systems thinking and understanding that lasting educational improvement requires comprehensive societal engagement rather than school-centric reforms.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Mar 3, 2014 13 Award FR (1) The March 3, 2014 thirteenth issue, edited by Don Glendenning, announces a new $2,500 Education Award offered by… ▸ more
The March 3, 2014 thirteenth issue, edited by Don Glendenning, announces a new $2,500 Education Award offered by Education 20/20 Inc. The award recognizes schools and learning centers demonstrating high engagement in daily activities across five domains: student-to-student engagement, student-to-teacher engagement, student-to-learning-materials engagement, student-to-community partnerships, and parental involvement. Selection criteria focus on the school's direct control areas: family-community communication respecting cultural values, community-based events, and parent/community curriculum development involvement. The announcement appears in both French and English, reflecting Education 20/20's bilingual commitment. Award decisions are made solely on nomination information submitted, with an Awards Committee reviewing nominations and recommending recipients for announcement in early May. The award demonstrates Don's commitment to recognizing and incentivizing schools that prioritize meaningful engagement over standardized metrics.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
March 2014 Pressure for change is mounting 2 Don Glendenning penned a letter to the Charlottetown Guardian editor in March 2014 advocating for educational system… ▸ more
Don Glendenning penned a letter to the Charlottetown Guardian editor in March 2014 advocating for educational system reform. He identifies mounting pressure for change across multiple dimensions: changing marketplace demands emphasizing developmental over content-driven models, escalating costs of schooling, quality concerns requiring remedial courses at Holland College and UPEI, technology underutilization in schools, professional desires for teacher autonomy, and political domain removal from education. Glendenning notes that while officials may address these issues privately, public awareness and involvement remain essential for meaningful reform.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Feb 17, 2014 00 Proforma-Foundations Highlight Fundraising letter dated February 17, 2014, to potential foundation donors outlining Education 20/20 Inc.'s… ▸ more
Fundraising letter dated February 17, 2014, to potential foundation donors outlining Education 20/20 Inc.'s three-pronged strategy: independent information (monthly newsletter, website hub), engagement (workshop series across PEI, community discussions), and recognition/incentives (education awards, innovation encouragement). Requests $22,000 support: $15,000 for information gathering, $2,000 for incentives, $2,500 for workshops, $2,500 operations. Emphasizes system inadequacies in autonomy, innovation, teacher incentives, and parental choice. Demonstrates Don's compelling articulation of educational system deficiencies and solutions.
REFERENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Feb 15, 2014 12 Report cards The February 15, 2014 twelfth issue, edited by Don Glendenning, argues for comprehensive reform of school report cards,… ▸ more
The February 15, 2014 twelfth issue, edited by Don Glendenning, argues for comprehensive reform of school report cards, which he contends have remained largely unchanged despite dramatic changes in the world. Don advocates transforming report cards from traditional grade-listing documents into planning tools and interim progress reports toward learning goals. He proposes that outcomes-based education (OBE) model adoption should logically lead to report cards that summarize pursued outcomes, achieved levels, remaining work, new outcomes, identified cautions or deficiencies with remediation plans, and new instructions for students and parents. Don emphasizes that reformed report cards would meaningfully operationalize "parents as partners" in education. The newsletter announces workshops in Montague (February 18) and Summerside (March 11) continuing Education 20/20's community engagement. Don credits Tom White-Hassler for website development and promotes the newly functioning website at education2020.ca.
EDUCATION SPEECH

 Read · Download
Feb 9, 2014 C-1 System components Framework outline (dated February 9, 2014) identical to File 13, describing education system components across four… ▸ more
Framework outline (dated February 9, 2014) identical to File 13, describing education system components across four categories: Information services (advice, counseling, assessment, referral, advocacy, diagnosis); Instruction services (formal instruction, coaching, tutoring, guided practice, engagement, specialists, social media, demonstrations, group work); Community Support (libraries, bookstores, encouragement, opportunity, access, technology, exposure, travel, transportation, facilities); and Feedback mechanisms (qualifications, competition, research, quality control, awards). Provides systematic approach to designing comprehensive educational support. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: None named - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: LOW - Duplicate framework without personal context.
