Jan 20, 2014 Chtn Announcement January 2014 public announcement for the Charlottetown/Stratford workshop on January 20, 2014, featuring the youth… ▸ more
January 2014 public announcement for the Charlottetown/Stratford workshop on January 20, 2014, featuring the youth survey presentation and roundtable discussion on preparedness gaps. Don's contact information is provided as the primary organizer, highlighting his role as the public face of Education 20/20's initiative on this critical issue.
SPEECH
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 Structural change Don directs readers to the Education Handbook for School Administrators (2014-2015, pages 20-21) where they can find… ▸ more
Don directs readers to the Education Handbook for School Administrators (2014-2015, pages 20-21) where they can find the stated purpose, five basic principles, and sixteen goals of PEI's public education system. He advocates reading this document as an essential starting point for public discussion about education. By making this reference accessible to general readers, Don attempts to democratize educational planning, inviting community engagement in understanding what schools are supposed to accomplish.
ADMINISTRATIVE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 What's ahead A January 2014 draft letter to the Guardian reflecting on education trends and predictions for 2014 PEI. Don observes… ▸ more
A January 2014 draft letter to the Guardian reflecting on education trends and predictions for 2014 PEI. Don observes rising public concern about basic skills gaps, notes increased media coverage of education issues (citing three of six Globe and Mail opinion pieces in December), and predicts growing pressure on schools from online learning, demands for transparency, and rising teacher activism in reform movements.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL SPEECH
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 What's a door-2 A January 2014 Guardian letter where Don uses architectural terminology (inspired by his drafting instructor) to… ▸ more
A January 2014 Guardian letter where Don uses architectural terminology (inspired by his drafting instructor) to explore fundamental questions: What is a school? What is its purpose? He argues schools provide two services—childcare and education—and questions whether combining them is effective. The draft explores competing definitions of school purposes and the ambiguity in what a high school diploma represents.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL SPEECH
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Supposin@2014-12-12T04;27;04 A Guardian letter examining education issues that may influence the next provincial election. Don identifies standards… ▸ more
A Guardian letter examining education issues that may influence the next provincial election. Don identifies standards (especially math, reading, writing), mental and emotional wellness, inflexible delivery models, and inability to respond to individual student needs as key concerns, reflecting broader public anxiety about education system effectiveness.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Essential skills@2014-08-17T13;22;02 A major Guardian letter proposing replacement of the traditional degree/diploma system with a stage-based certification… ▸ more
A major Guardian letter proposing replacement of the traditional degree/diploma system with a stage-based certification model similar to music and swimming, where independent testing services verify achievement levels. Don argues this would improve consistency, reduce teacher workload, enhance fairness, and provide employers with meaningful skill verification rather than age-based credentials.

Duplicate or variant of the curriculum letter, urging parents and learners to examine PEI curriculum documents available on the Department website to become informed about what children are learning and how content differs across grades and career tracks.

2014 D 2014 Basic skills - a chronic problem@2014-12-12T12;10;35 A Guardian letter urging public engagement with PEI's publicly available curriculum documents to understand educational… ▸ more
A Guardian letter urging public engagement with PEI's publicly available curriculum documents to understand educational content and identify skill gaps. Don recommends parents and learners study these materials to track progress, understand grade differences, and distinguish between subject levels for different career paths.

2014 2014 The education payroll An incomplete draft comparing the Minister of Education's extensive control over personnel and delivery to other… ▸ more
An incomplete draft comparing the Minister of Education's extensive control over personnel and delivery to other provincial ministries like Health. Don argues the Minister not only sets curriculum and scheduling but has all education providers on his payroll with direct reporting lines to him. He begins drawing comparisons to Health (which contracts with independent professionals) but the piece trails off incomplete, leaving the full argument undeveloped.
GOVERNANCESTRUCTURE MINISTERIALCONTROL BUREAUCRACY INCOMPLETE

2014 1 Preparedness workshops 2014 Highlight An "Occasional Paper" documenting four public workshops organized by Education 20/20 to address youth preparedness gaps… ▸ more
An "Occasional Paper" documenting four public workshops organized by Education 20/20 to address youth preparedness gaps for post-secondary study and employment. Don convened discussions in Stratford, Montague, Summerside, and Wellington, drawing from a Community Foundation survey of 200+ Island youth to identify essential skills and recommend systemic improvements to close preparedness gaps.

Media release reporting on an Education 20/20 youth panel discussing learning support needs. The panel revealed that students require varied types of assistance (information, assessment, feedback, practice) and that classrooms contain students at different levels of readiness, creating challenges for teachers in providing differentiated instruction.

2014 2014-VS Press Release Press release announcing Education 20/20's workshop on youth preparedness, highlighting the Community Foundation survey… ▸ more
Press release announcing Education 20/20's workshop on youth preparedness, highlighting the Community Foundation survey findings and workshop outcomes. Emphasizes the key theme of "courage" (for youth innovation, educators' decisions, community support) and the consensus that action is needed immediately, not further study. Chaired by Don Glendenning, with additional workshops planned. Provides media contact information and reflects Don's communication strategy for education advocacy.

2014 Education 20 20 2014-presentation to Standing committee-3 Presentation to PEI Legislative Standing Committee on Education and Innovation. Don articulates Education 20/20's… ▸ more
Presentation to PEI Legislative Standing Committee on Education and Innovation. Don articulates Education 20/20's working definitions of education, purpose, and quality systems. Argues education is broader than schooling, emphasizes changing world requires different skills, and calls for community engagement in rethinking education principles. Recommends committee engage community in reviewing guiding principles. Shows Don's public advocacy for systemic education reform and community-centered approach.

August 25, 2014 letter from Don to Ms. Mezaun Baksh (CRA) describing one year of Education 20/20 activities: six community workshops on youth preparedness, school engagement award to Kinkora Regional High School, educator workshops, and invitation to present to PEI Legislative Committee. Shows Don's passion for practical engagement and demonstrates organization's growing credibility. Details new initiatives in occasional papers and educator engagement.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D RBC letter Solicitation letter from Don (President, Education 20/20 Inc.) to Mary McInnis, Manager of Royal Bank of Canada… ▸ more
Solicitation letter from Don (President, Education 20/20 Inc.) to Mary McInnis, Manager of Royal Bank of Canada (Charlottetown), requesting $10,000 lead donation. Written early in Education 20/20's formation (Jan 2014), it articulates the organization's three-pillar approach: (1) information provision via newsletter and website hub, (2) community engagement through workshops (starting in Stratford Jan 20, with planned events in O'Leary, Summerside, Wellington, Souris), (3) incentives for innovation and engagement. Requests total $22,000 ($15,000 info, $2,000 incentives, $2,500 workshops, $2,500 ops). Describes young people's concerns about readiness for education/work. Conveys Don's educational philosophy: education is a community responsibility, not solely a school function.

Demonstrates Don's integration into a collaborative leadership structure working toward educational policy influence in PEI.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 2014 proposal A comprehensive proposal (October 2014 and March 2014 versions) for establishing and maintaining the Open Education… ▸ more
A comprehensive proposal (October 2014 and March 2014 versions) for establishing and maintaining the Open Education newsletter as a sustainable publication for Education 20/20 Inc. The document outlines the newsletter's purpose to inform the public on educational matters, details target audiences (directors, media, elected representatives, and ~200 subscribers), and proposes solutions for bilingual publication, funding, distribution, and editorial governance. The proposal addresses critical issues including circulation growth, sponsor arrangements with CFPEI, and readership surveys. The newsletter was envisioned as monthly in frequency with single-page, two-column bilingual format, demonstrating Don's strategic thinking about educational communication.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 7-2014-Summerside workshop March 12, 2014 workshop report from Summerside addressing education and community needs. "Culture" emerged as a central… ▸ more
March 12, 2014 workshop report from Summerside addressing education and community needs. "Culture" emerged as a central theme, encompassing economic skills, literacy, numeracy, personal finance, and social caring. Attendees identified a disconnect between schools and communities, including low engagement, poor event attendance, voting participation gaps, and limited communication. Workshop opened with Community Foundation survey findings on Island youth concerns (health, education, employment, well-being) presented by Steve McQuaid and Katherine MacDonald. Don Glendenning chaired the session and advocated for CBC Compass to create a regular education slot. Workshop was part of Education 20/20's ongoing community dialogue initiative.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 2014-10 Learner in the spotlight Workshop announcement for October 22, 2014 at Stratford Town Hall featuring a student panel discussing helpful support… ▸ more
Workshop announcement for October 22, 2014 at Stratford Town Hall featuring a student panel discussing helpful support strategies for learning. Format includes student perspectives first, followed by parents, teachers, and community members developing a learning support flowchart and corresponding teaching strategies. The workshop philosophy centers on learner-centric education: what learners actually learn matters more than what teachers teach. Organized by Education 20/20 Inc. and open to the public.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 2014-10 - Wellington Press Release-Eng Report on an Education 20/20 workshop at Centre Goeland in Cap-Egmont (April 10, 2014) focusing on education solutions.… ▸ more
Report on an Education 20/20 workshop at Centre Goeland in Cap-Egmont (April 10, 2014) focusing on education solutions. Workshop participants rapidly moved from problem identification to solution-seeking, discussing how communities need education systems supporting individual and collective potential development. Presentation covered the Community Foundation survey on youth concerns. Don Glendenning, as President of Education 20/20 Inc., presided and clarified that some educational issues stem from system structure while others reflect educational philosophy. The organization's commitment is to improve education quality for every Canadian.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 2014 Annual-Minutes Minutes from Third Annual Meeting of Education 20/20 Inc., June 3, 2015, with Alice Taylor, Maureen Kerr, Katherine… ▸ more
Minutes from Third Annual Meeting of Education 20/20 Inc., June 3, 2015, with Alice Taylor, Maureen Kerr, Katherine McQuaid, and Don Glendenning present. Key decisions include expanded director recruitment targeting students, parents, teachers, and employers. Governance improvements discussed: limiting director meetings to four yearly with executive handling interim business, increased social media presence, and committee structures with director leadership. Significantly, Don expressed his view that "while he plans to remain active, it is time for new leadership for the organization," agreeing to meet with Bill Whelan and Alice Taylor to discuss succession. Directors and officers for 2015 were elected with Don remaining as President.

2014 2014 Annual-Minutes for 2013 Minutes from Education 20/20 Inc.'s Second Annual Meeting held June 2, 2014 at Haviland Club with Alice Taylor, Brenda… ▸ more
Minutes from Education 20/20 Inc.'s Second Annual Meeting held June 2, 2014 at Haviland Club with Alice Taylor, Brenda Goodine, Don Glendenning, and Bill Whelan present. Notable points include approval of the previous year's minutes moved by Don and seconded by Bill. Financial discussion reveals the organization had no bank account; expenses were paid privately or through the Community Foundation of PEI. The $216.60 reimbursement to Glendenning covered postal box costs. Seven directors were elected for the coming year.

Don outlines a cadre-building approach, suggesting taking potential trainers and educators off-island for professional development—a strategic vision for systemic change.

2014 2014-Learning wkshp 1 Don's conceptual framework for a workshop on "A learner's perspective on learning" under Education 20/20. The proposal… ▸ more
Don's conceptual framework for a workshop on "A learner's perspective on learning" under Education 20/20. The proposal emphasizes stakeholder engagement, brainstorming learning supports, and creating flowcharts of learner access to educational resources. It exemplifies Don's pedagogical thinking—moving beyond traditional instruction to understand learner needs holistically.

2014 2014 Steve dates Strategic planning memo from Don (dated January 19, 2014) to Education 20/20 Directors outlining an ambitious… ▸ more
Strategic planning memo from Don (dated January 19, 2014) to Education 20/20 Directors outlining an ambitious multi-location preparedness workshop series. Proposes four presentations by Steve McQuaid and Katherine MacDonald across Souris, O'Leary, Summerside, and Wellington (preferably in French). Don had already scouted venues, assessed capacity and facilities, and coordinated with local organizations. Demonstrates his strategic thinking, resource management, and commitment to island-wide community education engagement despite logistical challenges.

Download

2014 Summary of PR activities This document chronicles Don Glendenning's comprehensive promotional strategy for the inaugural 2014 Education 20/20… ▸ more
This document chronicles Don Glendenning's comprehensive promotional strategy for the inaugural 2014 Education 20/20 Award, spanning February 20 to March 14. Activities include: advising the Saskatchewan Teachers' Society Association, notifying the PEI High School Federation, contacting regional media outlets, circulating newsletters to approximately 115 people (including Department of Education officials and early childhood center directors), emailing journalists and reporters, and coordinating a CBC Morning show interview on March 13 with broadcast on March 14. The systematic approach demonstrates Glendenning's sophisticated public relations and stakeholder engagement methodology.

2014 Selection Committee This brief document lists the 2014 Education 20/20 Award Selection Committee membership, chaired by Eileen… ▸ more
This brief document lists the 2014 Education 20/20 Award Selection Committee membership, chaired by Eileen Conway-Martin. Committee members include Donald DesRoches, Brenda Goodine, David McCabe, Peter Russell, and Wendell Labobe, with Don Glendenning serving as Ex Officio member, reflecting his leadership role as organization president while allowing other educators and community members to lead selection deliberations.

2014 Final 2014-Eng 2 Guidelines for Engagement Highlight Final version of engagement guidelines matching File 6 content. Reiterates Education 20/20's philosophy of engagement… ▸ more
Final version of engagement guidelines matching File 6 content. Reiterates Education 20/20's philosophy of engagement as central to student success across five dimensions: student-to-student, student-to-teacher, student-to-learning material, student-to-community partnerships, and parental involvement. Emphasizes the extensive research base supporting parental engagement's impact on educational outcomes. Includes institutional contact information (101 Kent St., Charlottetown; 902-892-2060; pei@education2020.ca; www.education2020.ca). Document dated 14-02-Eng, indicating February 2014 version.

2014 2014 Public description Comprehensive public description of the Excellence in Education Awards Program for 2014-15, authored under Don's… ▸ more
Comprehensive public description of the Excellence in Education Awards Program for 2014-15, authored under Don's direction as Education 20/20 President. The document synthesizes the program's theoretical foundation, citing research on family-school-community engagement driving achievement, and details the five engagement areas evaluated. Notes that decisions will be based solely on submitted information, establishing transparency in the evaluation process under Don's stewardship.

2014 2014 Description-handout 14-02-D Detailed program description articulating Education 20/20's philosophy on engagement, awards, and incentives in… ▸ more
Detailed program description articulating Education 20/20's philosophy on engagement, awards, and incentives in education. The document references research from the National Parent Teacher Association establishing that family-school-community collaboration improves student achievement, teacher morale, and communication. Outlines the program's five engagement areas and selection criteria, demonstrating Don's evidence-based approach to defining educational excellence and the rationale for recognizing schools excelling in engagement.

2014 1 List of centres Comprehensive listing of all schools and learning centers nominated for the 2014 and 2015 Education Engagement Awards… ▸ more
Comprehensive listing of all schools and learning centers nominated for the 2014 and 2015 Education Engagement Awards under Don Glendenning's Education 20/20 organization. The 2014 nominations represent diverse Island institutions at all educational levels, including early childhood centers, elementary schools, and high schools from Tignish to St. Peter's Bay. Includes contact information and nominator details, providing administrative record of the award program's reach across Prince Edward Island's educational landscape.
REFERENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 9- 2014 Options Don critiques a school's decision to place a struggling math student in a lower-level course rather than providing… ▸ more
Don critiques a school's decision to place a struggling math student in a lower-level course rather than providing extra instruction. He frames schools as places that should "open doors, create opportunities, and help each child find a meaningful place in society." By transferring the student to a lower level, the school created a barrier rather than supporting access. This choice delays postsecondary entry, reduces college/university likelihood, diminishes employment prospects, and contradicts education's stated goal of helping students develop to full capacity.

 Read · Download
2014 7-2014 Sherren letter Brief response affirming columnist Joe Sherren's article on education improvement. Don cites OECD research (School… ▸ more
Brief response affirming columnist Joe Sherren's article on education improvement. Don cites OECD research (School Accountability and Autonomy, Report No. 9) demonstrating that students perform better when schools have autonomy. He characterizes "freedom to act and well trained principals" as a winning combination.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 4-2014 Coach or referee Don argues that teachers cannot fairly perform dual roles of coach (teacher) and referee (assessor) simultaneously. The… ▸ more
Don argues that teachers cannot fairly perform dual roles of coach (teacher) and referee (assessor) simultaneously. The coaching/teaching role suffers when teachers must also rank students. He proposes establishing an independent qualification authority (like the Royal Conservatory or apprenticeship programs) to award credentials separate from instruction. This separation maintains coaching while ensuring fair, objective assessment.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 2 2014 This one for Education Commemorating Confederation's 150th anniversary in 2014, Don proposes using this milestone to establish an educational… ▸ more
Commemorating Confederation's 150th anniversary in 2014, Don proposes using this milestone to establish an educational legacy rather than merely celebrating the past. He views education as central to Canada's future and suggests creating an innovation fund, think tank, national center for public engagement, demonstration projects, or citizenship focus. The letter reflects Don's belief that education transcends institutional change to address fundamental national development. His vision positions education as the determinant of Canada's collective future.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 costly operational policies Don explains why education faces more reform pressure than health or justice services, identifying four key problems:… ▸ more
Don explains why education faces more reform pressure than health or justice services, identifying four key problems: public schools lack market incentives for improvement, operation follows formulas (ratios, hours, salaries) rather than standards, scripted curricula ignore individual needs, and services are bundled through single providers. He articulates government's appropriate roles: providing leadership, funding, access, learning culture, quality monitoring, and accountability reporting—notably excluding direct school operation. This letter synthesizes his governance philosophy, emphasizing market mechanisms and accountability within government-funded systems.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 cost of degrees and diplomas Don questions whether expensive diploma ceremonies represent genuine educational value or primarily serve as rites of… ▸ more
Don questions whether expensive diploma ceremonies represent genuine educational value or primarily serve as rites of passage with declining value. He argues that transcripts adequately convey educational achievement without ceremonial framing, and that structural problems in education delivery—particularly content delivery to captive audiences—have created unsustainable cost structures. He identifies the "cost disease" as affecting education like healthcare, with overhead consuming resources while qualified staff shortages emerge for complex cases. Don proposes business model transformation from content delivery to learner development.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 What does the taxpayer pay for Don critiques education's focus on instructional time rather than learning outcomes, contrasting schools with other… ▸ more
Don critiques education's focus on instructional time rather than learning outcomes, contrasting schools with other professions where service quality matters more than process duration. He notes schools predetermine time availability regardless of individual learning pace, creating boredom for fast learners and discouragement for slower ones. He advocates for flexible timelines allowing students to progress at individual rates—completing material early when ready or receiving additional time as needed—arguing that administrative convenience has replaced learning-centered scheduling.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Sherren letter Don supports professional development while citing OECD research demonstrating students perform better when schools… ▸ more
Don supports professional development while citing OECD research demonstrating students perform better when schools have operational autonomy in daily decision-making. He notes searching for information about principal roles yielded mostly qualification requirements but little about actual duties and responsibilities, leading him to conclude principals have minimal decision-making freedom. The letter reinforces his core argument that teacher and administrator empowerment through delegated authority is essential for educational improvement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Problem solving Don applies systems thinking to education reform, arguing that the public school system lacks normal problem-solving… ▸ more
Don applies systems thinking to education reform, arguing that the public school system lacks normal problem-solving mechanisms. He identifies math skill gaps as an example where students, employers, and post-secondary institutions all report problems but no systematic resolution occurs. He contrasts the current system with other professions (law, medicine, counseling) that employ specialists for problem-solving. Don calls for establishing formal mechanisms to identify, define, and resolve educational problems, noting that historically the system resolved issues by allowing struggling students to drop out—an unacceptable modern alternative.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Preparedness Don addresses reported gaps in student preparation for employment and further education, referencing the Conference… ▸ more
Don addresses reported gaps in student preparation for employment and further education, referencing the Conference Board of Canada's framework of employability skills: fundamental skills (communication, information management, numeracy, problem-solving), personal management (attitude, responsibility, adaptability, safety), and teamwork. He argues these skills are primarily developmental and experiential rather than content-based, making school classrooms poorly suited for their acquisition. Don proposes community-based pilot projects with local leadership involvement, positioning community as the classroom and transforming skill development into participatory experience rather than classroom instruction.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Parents consider leaving Drawing on a Home and School Federation survey of 700 parents, Don reports that one in eight would consider leaving PEI… ▸ more
Drawing on a Home and School Federation survey of 700 parents, Don reports that one in eight would consider leaving PEI for better schools. He contrasts this with Alberta's school choice system, where parents can select among public, private, and charter options without relocating. Don argues that limited school choice constrains PEI's ability to attract industry and retain immigrant families, positioning education access as an economic and retention issue. This letter exemplifies his advocacy for market-based mechanisms in education reform.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Initiating change Highlight Don reflects on a community gathering of 35 people discussing education reform, noting recognition of needed changes,… ▸ more
Don reflects on a community gathering of 35 people discussing education reform, noting recognition of needed changes, the persistence of issues, and rising public frustration. He suggests mathematics as a starting point for systemic reform, advocating for clarity on educational purpose (skill development, economic competitiveness, childcare), identification of required math competencies from multiple stakeholders, and structural changes to accommodate individual learning timelines. He emphasizes that the public possesses knowledge and capacity for reform without waiting for top-down mandates, calling for grassroots engagement and local ownership of solutions.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Improving education This concise letter outlines key structural reforms Don believes necessary for improving PEI education: redefining… ▸ more
This concise letter outlines key structural reforms Don believes necessary for improving PEI education: redefining government's role to policy, evaluation, and funding (not daily operations); granting schools operational autonomy; adopting criterion-referenced rather than norm-referenced assessment; shifting from content delivery to developmental learner support; and clarifying decision-making authority. The piece serves as a policy summary of themes developed more extensively in other letters, establishing the foundational framework underlying his broader reform agenda.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Entrepreneurship Don examines whether entrepreneurship can be taught in schools, drawing on research that identifies entrepreneurial… ▸ more
Don examines whether entrepreneurship can be taught in schools, drawing on research that identifies entrepreneurial students as autonomous, self-reliant, flexible, and tolerant of ambiguity—often appearing rebellious or emotionally aloof. He concludes that entrepreneurial spirit is personality-driven rather than skills-based, and that traditional classroom structures may suppress rather than cultivate entrepreneurial traits. The letter argues for pedagogical approaches that honor entrepreneurial students' psychological needs for independence and flexibility, suggesting that standard teaching methods are poorly suited to this student population.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Employers should This letter calls for replacing high school diplomas with competency-based certification issued by independent bodies,… ▸ more
This letter calls for replacing high school diplomas with competency-based certification issued by independent bodies, similar to driver's licenses or Royal Canadian Conservatory of Music certificates. Don critiques how diplomas serve primarily as screening devices that no longer guarantee skill levels. He references model schools in Calgary and Vancouver that allow competency-based assessment outside traditional school calendars. This piece articulates his vision for decoupling assessment from educational delivery and emphasizing demonstrated competency over credentials.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Business model Dated March 12, 2013, this comprehensive letter argues that current school models are unsustainable due to cost… ▸ more
Dated March 12, 2013, this comprehensive letter argues that current school models are unsustainable due to cost escalation (rising 90% in five years), quality decline, inflexibility, technological limitations, and public dissatisfaction. Don applies business model frameworks (value, resources, processes, revenue) to education, identifying that while PEI has strengthened resources and revenue, values and delivery processes remain outdated. He contends schools must shift from content delivery to learner development and explores whether current institutional structures can support needed transformation. The letter exemplifies his analytical rigor and belief that education requires systemic innovation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 An insight into schooling Published January 25, 2014, this analytical letter deconstructs the school system's structural characteristics and… ▸ more
Published January 25, 2014, this analytical letter deconstructs the school system's structural characteristics and limitations. Don identifies three school functions: skill development for societal participation, workforce development, and childcare. He notes that schools control curriculum delivery for all students over 12 years regardless of progress, offer limited accountability mechanisms, and operate without market incentives for improvement. The letter reveals his systems analysis approach and conviction that structural reforms (not just professional development or technology upgrades) are necessary for meaningful change.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 D 2014 Action expecte -2 Dated January 25, 2014, Don establishes foundational premises for his educational critique: most young people can… ▸ more
Dated January 25, 2014, Don establishes foundational premises for his educational critique: most young people can achieve subject mastery given appropriate support, and schools cannot blame communities or homes for student failure. He documents widespread Islander concern that graduating students lack basic reading, writing, and arithmetic skills. He argues that government, having monopolized education delivery and limited competition, owes Islanders explanation and action plans. This letter encapsulates his fundamental conviction that schools must ensure foundational competencies for all students.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 Unbundling Don's most ambitious structural proposal argues that government should "unbundle" education services, withdrawing from… ▸ more
Don's most ambitious structural proposal argues that government should "unbundle" education services, withdrawing from operating schools while retaining its planning, policy, standards, and funding roles. He compares education unfavorably to health and justice sectors where government funds but doesn't employ practitioners, and identifies three organizational weaknesses: scripted curricula limiting teacher judgment, absence of independent advocates for students, and monopoly provision with no consumer choice. This letter represents Don's most radical proposal for systemic transformation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 The role of schools Don identifies three key roles for schools emerging from an Education 20/20 workshop: developing young people to their… ▸ more
Don identifies three key roles for schools emerging from an Education 20/20 workshop: developing young people to their full potential, helping the Island develop needed human capital, and providing care while parents work. He notes that acceptance of the "care" function may have contributed to social promotion and declining diploma value. This foundational letter clarifies Don's belief that clarity about institutional roles must precede other reforms, reflecting his systematic approach to education policy.

2014 Sherren letter Don responds to columnist Joe Sherren's article on education improvement by reinforcing the importance of school… ▸ more
Don responds to columnist Joe Sherren's article on education improvement by reinforcing the importance of school autonomy with OECD evidence. He succinctly endorses Sherren's combination of "freedom to act and well trained principals" as "a winning combination." This brief letter demonstrates Don's ability to build on others' work and his consistent messaging about autonomy as a key success factor.

 Read · Download
2014 Governance-2 amended Don responds to the School Board's invitation for governance input by strongly advocating for devolution of… ▸ more
Don responds to the School Board's invitation for governance input by strongly advocating for devolution of decision-making authority to schools and teachers. He cites OECD research showing students perform better when schools have autonomy over daily operations. The letter emphasizes that while PEI has quality staff, they are constrained by centralized control. Don argues that freedom to act, combined with accountability, enables teachers to respond to student needs more effectively than top-down mandates.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2014 D 2014 Class size A more developed response to the Minister's statement on class size, Don acknowledges the Minister's correct point that… ▸ more
A more developed response to the Minister's statement on class size, Don acknowledges the Minister's correct point that class size alone doesn't improve achievement while building on it. He references diverse staffing models from Arizona (teacher assistants), Michigan (principal-reduced management), Saskatchewan (differentiated staffing), and national research on teacher mobility. The letter advocates for exploring alternative staffing strategies while commending the Department's upward PCAP trend, balancing criticism with recognition.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 Coach or referee Don argues that teachers should not simultaneously teach and evaluate the same students, as this creates a conflict of… ▸ more
Don argues that teachers should not simultaneously teach and evaluate the same students, as this creates a conflict of interest comparable to a coach also serving as referee. He proposes establishing independent qualification authorities (like those used in music and apprenticeships) to award credentials separately from instruction. This reflects Don's systematic thinking about organizational role separation and his belief that assessment should be divorced from instruction to ensure fairness and maintain teacher focus on learning support.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 Class size Don counters the assumption that small class sizes automatically improve education, citing a school that improved… ▸ more
Don counters the assumption that small class sizes automatically improve education, citing a school that improved dramatically by trading seven teaching positions for fourteen teacher assistants. This evidence-based argument shows that the composition of instructional support matters more than simple class-to-teacher ratios. The letter demonstrates Don's willingness to challenge conventional wisdom with concrete examples and suggests that intervention strategies must be thoughtfully targeted rather than formula-based.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 An implied contract Drawing an analogy to professional relationships with lawyers, accountants, and doctors, Don proposes that schools… ▸ more
Drawing an analogy to professional relationships with lawyers, accountants, and doctors, Don proposes that schools carry an implied commitment to students comparable to the commitment professionals make to clients. He explores what schools might reasonably promise: safe environments, instruction, minimum literacy and numeracy, college-readiness, or employment skills. This foundational letter establishes the contractual thinking that underpins his education advocacy and reflects his belief in accountability and clear institutional commitments.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 6- 2014 Closing doors Don recounts how a college-bound student struggling with math was moved to a lower-level course—a decision he views as… ▸ more
Don recounts how a college-bound student struggling with math was moved to a lower-level course—a decision he views as closing doors rather than opening them. While sympathetic to teaching constraints, he lists alternatives: let student struggle, recommend post-graduation upgrading, provide extra instruction, transfer to lower level, or recommend tutoring. Options 3 and 5 keep doors open, but cost barriers and school culture favor option 4, creating barriers to post-secondary transition, reducing college likelihood, harming employment prospects, and potentially lowering lifetime income. He emphasizes this contradicts educational philosophy about developing full capacity.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 4-2014 An implied contract Don explores the implicit contract between schools and students by analogy to professional relationships (lawyers,… ▸ more
Don explores the implicit contract between schools and students by analogy to professional relationships (lawyers, accountants, doctors). While professional contracts are clear, educational commitments are murky. He poses questions about what schools commit to: safe environment, 190 days of instruction, subject variety, minimum literacy/numeracy, diploma, college/university preparation, or work skills? Given mandatory attendance and heavy investment, he asks what students should expect in return, framing this as a fundamental policy question.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 3Nova Scotia Panel - Halifax Herald Writing to the Chronicle Herald, Don commends Nova Scotia's education review panel and offers three key pieces of… ▸ more
Writing to the Chronicle Herald, Don commends Nova Scotia's education review panel and offers three key pieces of advice: clarify whether studying education (personal development) or schooling (knowledge acquisition); recognize that current government operation differs from other sectors where professionals have independence; and address structural weaknesses (lack of autonomy, inflexibility, knowledge focus, absence of incentives) alongside professional issues. He emphasizes that education's impacts on individual and collective futures make the review critically important.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 2014 School and work Don identifies three components in the school-work debate: education should develop full capacities including work and… ▸ more
Don identifies three components in the school-work debate: education should develop full capacities including work and life skills; disagreement exists on schools' role (public expects work skills, educators resist); and documentation problems (schools provide credentials describing what was taught, not qualifications describing what was learned). He proposes employers move beyond high school graduation to direct skills testing through an employer-operated service, allowing individuals to establish and document skill levels relevant to job requirements.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2014 1-2014 Governance Don responds to the English School Board's invitation for governance policy input, commending their openness. He… ▸ more
Don responds to the English School Board's invitation for governance policy input, commending their openness. He advocates for broad devolution of decision-making authority, particularly to teachers and schools, based on personal experience and OECD research showing that schools with significant operational autonomy achieve better student performance. He emphasizes that teachers are quality professionals deserving freedom to act, and that freedom should be given a chance to improve educational outcomes.
BIOGRAPHICAL

 Read · Download
2014 1 Opening remarks 2014 Presentation notes for Education 20/20 Inc. workshop introducing organization and philosophy. Education 20/20 is… ▸ more
Presentation notes for Education 20/20 Inc. workshop introducing organization and philosophy. Education 20/20 is independent, nationally incorporated, not-for-profit organization focused on quality education for every Canadian. Don served as President with board including Alice Taylor, Brenda Goodine, Bill Whelan, Owen Parkhouse, Tanya Craig. Organization operates without formal membership, employing network model emphasizing learners rather than education providers. Key insights center on learning models and community support. Activities include newsletters, website, workshops, awards. References OECD PISA accountability findings and UNICEF emphasis on child-centered, relevant content beyond knowledge acquisition.

2014 2014 draft to donald2014 Highlight Draft letter to Mezaun Baksh, Charities Analyst at CRA, following up on rejected 2013 application. Documents Education… ▸ more
Draft letter to Mezaun Baksh, Charities Analyst at CRA, following up on rejected 2013 application. Documents Education 20/20's reapplication with revised objectives after a year of operational experience. Highlights that the organization has been instrumental in keeping education issues in public discourse through workshops, public engagement, and award programs. References Kinkora Regional High School education award presented June 20, 2014. Outlines new initiatives including occasional papers on educational topics and mathematics skills improvement project. Signed by Don Glendenning as President. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (President), Mezaun Baksh (CRA Charities Analyst) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Canada Revenue Agency, English Language School Board, PEI Legislative Committee on Learning and Technology - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, CORRESPONDENCE, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, EDUCATION, ADMIN - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Shows Don's persistence and strategic thinking in addressing CRA concerns about charitable status

2014 2014 Objectives and activities-4 Expanded version of T2050 Question 11a notes with refined language and additional details. Maps activities to five… ▸ more
Expanded version of T2050 Question 11a notes with refined language and additional details. Maps activities to five incorporation objectives with more specific language about expected/future activities: (1) Promote education - planning to solicit and publish "one-pagers" on future-oriented education topics, organize electronic public forums on schooling matters; (2) Exercise leadership - presentations to government bodies, school boards, continued public workshops and awards program, establishment of qualification authority; (3) Foster cooperation - hosting discussions with educational organizations (Home and School, Women's Institute, Construction Association, Professional Engineers Association); (4) Support research - partnering with University, Holland College, professional associations, employers on math needs identification; (5) Improve public understanding - monthly newsletter in both languages to 140-person growing mailing list, website maintenance, six-community education and preparedness workshop series, surveys, social media engagement, education think tank, parent engagement initiatives, research dissemination monitoring, organizational collaboration. Shows ambitious vision for education system improvement. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Holland College, University of Prince Edward Island, PEI Home and School Federation, PEI Women's Institute, PEI Construction Association, PEI Association of Professional Engineers - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY, FOUNDATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates scope and ambition of Don's educational reform agenda for PEI.

2014 5-2014-04-28 - School Award-EN Announcement of Excellence in Education Award established by Education 20/20 Inc. with support from an anonymous Island… ▸ more
Announcement of Excellence in Education Award established by Education 20/20 Inc. with support from an anonymous Island family. Award recognizes direct link between community-school engagement and student achievement. Nominated schools/learning centers evaluated on five areas: student-to-student, student-to-teacher, student-to-learning-materials, student-to-community-partnerships, and parental involvement. Dozen nominations received; award value $2,500. References National Parent Teacher Association research showing engagement improves achievement, teacher morale, and communication. Notes Education 20/20 as independent, broad-based, national non-profit offering workshops and monthly newsletter from Charlottetown. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (contact) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., National Parent Teacher Association, Community Foundation of PEI, J. French version of press release announcing an Education 20/20 workshop at Centre Goéland in Cap Egmont. Workshop participants discussed educational challenges and solutions, emphasizing holistic educational needs and community-based learning. First part featured results from Community Foundation of PEI survey of 200+ Island youth on preparedness for work and post-secondary education. Presented by Steve McQuaid (CFPEI Vice President) and Katherine MacDonald (researcher). Glendenning, as Education 20/20 President, thanked participants and promoted the organization's mission to improve education quality for all Canadians. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning, Steve McQuaid, Katherine MacDonald - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, Centre Goéland - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, COMMUNITY, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Glendenning's leadership of Education 20/20 and commitment to community engagement on education issues in PEI

2014 2014 Presentation ELSB Media release describing Education 20/20 presentation to English Language School Board advocating flexible crediting… ▸ more
Media release describing Education 20/20 presentation to English Language School Board advocating flexible crediting for prior learning. Proposes formal evaluation process for course credit challenges without prerequisite enrollment. Cites precedent: schools/colleges/universities grant credit for equivalent coursework. References PEI examples including Dance Umbrella and Royal Canadian Naval Reserve (eight external providers total). Introduces PLAR methodology where students submit portfolios documenting learning experiences; institutions assess and award credit. Notes postsecondary adoption at Holland College, UPEI, and College Acadie I.P.E. Advocates extending PLAR to high school level. Presentation available on Education 20/20 website. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (contact) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., English Language School Board, Holland College, UPEI, College Acadie I.P.E - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Documents Don's advocacy for educational innovation and flexible crediting approaches

2014 10-2014-10 learners weigh in Media release reporting on youth panel discussion organized by Education 20/20 regarding learning support needs. Panel… ▸ more
Media release reporting on youth panel discussion organized by Education 20/20 regarding learning support needs. Panel members (Tanya Craig as chair, Callen Cudmore, Ryan Rioux, Iain Cudmore, Stephanie Mayne) identified helpful learning supports: information with context/overview, assessment and feedback, early skill practice attempts, reflection on performance. Emphasizes heterogeneous classroom composition with students ranging from topic experts to novices with no background knowledge. Highlights dilemma for teachers accommodating diverse learning needs simultaneously. Notes panelists' diverse perspectives on problems and solutions. Demonstrates Education 20/20's commitment to learner-centered perspective in educational design. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (contact), Tanya Craig, Callen Cudmore, Ryan Rioux, Iain Cudmore, Stephanie Mayne - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY, ANECDOTE - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Shows Don's commitment to inclusive education and meaningful youth engagement in educational planning

Dec 1, 2013 Gap - independent information 2 Highlight From December 1, 2013, Don identifies a critical information gap: insufficient independent, practical information for… ▸ more
From December 1, 2013, Don identifies a critical information gap: insufficient independent, practical information for educational decision-making beyond school. He describes conversations with students unable to assess course implications, employers dismissing report cards as useless (proposing independent assessment bodies like Royal Canadian Conservatory of Music as models), and parents and graduates seeking better career information. He argues career counseling should relocate from schools to community access centers open evenings and Saturdays, making services available to post-secondary adults. This reflects systems thinking beyond traditional schooling.

Follow-up communications strategy notes (December 2013) refining Education 20/20's messaging approach. Emphasizes information as fuel for change and outlines specific platforms (website, newsletter, surveys, media) for public education advocacy.

BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Nov 28, 2013 Duffy, Regis 3 This November 28, 2013 letter is a year-end reflective note thanking Duffy for funding the Excellence in Education… ▸ more
This November 28, 2013 letter is a year-end reflective note thanking Duffy for funding the Excellence in Education Award. Don expresses pride that the award represents "the first of its kind in Atlantic Canada" and possibly elsewhere. He articulates his theory of change: systemic improvements won't originate from within the education system itself; change requires public demand and external accountability. Education 20/20 is strategically pivoting toward public engagement through a new website launch, community foundation-organized discussions, and acting as an independent body asking critical questions and disseminating information. This represents Don's mature understanding of institutional change dynamics and his belief in the power of informed public scrutiny.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

Nov 26, 2013 H&S Invitation-final Formal meeting agenda for November 26, 2013 Directors meeting at Royalty Centre, Charlottetown. Don Glendenning… ▸ more
Formal meeting agenda for November 26, 2013 Directors meeting at Royalty Centre, Charlottetown. Don Glendenning provides opening and closing remarks with focus on engaging parents as learning partners. Attendees include Education 2020 Directors (Bernadette Allen, Alice Taylor, Tanya Craig, Don Glendenning, Brenda Goodine, Bill Whelan, Owen Parkhouse), PEI Home and School Federation representatives, and Saskatchewan Teachers' Society Association (SSTA) participants. Includes organization contact information and website reference.

The substantive content remains identical, reiterating Education 20/20's mission to ensure quality education through combined community efforts. The letter emphasizes the organization's openness to broad educational discussions while particularly seeking parent engagement and support mechanisms. This document variant reflects Don's attention to detail and commitment to accurate communication in official correspondence, showcasing the iterative nature of his administrative work.

Nov 1, 2013 PEIHSF-1A Dated November 1, 2013, this letter invites Ms. Pam Montgomery (President of PEI Home and School Federation) and her… ▸ more
Dated November 1, 2013, this letter invites Ms. Pam Montgomery (President of PEI Home and School Federation) and her organization's leadership to a discussion on October 26, 2013 (note: date discrepancy suggests draft revisions). Don introduces Education 20/20 as a new, independent, broad-based organization committed to ensuring quality education for every Canadian. He highlights the Home and School Federation's long history of education advocacy and expresses interest in discussing the role of parents in education and what support would be most helpful to them. The letter projects warmth and genuine interest in partnership with this established community organization.

November 2013 D 34 Stakeholder Engagement Initiative Highlight A comprehensive November 2013 proposal establishing Education 20/20 Inc.'s stakeholder engagement strategy. Don… ▸ more
A comprehensive November 2013 proposal establishing Education 20/20 Inc.'s stakeholder engagement strategy. Don articulates a diagnosis that education systems are failing to prepare citizens for the future due to structural inflexibility and lack of market accountability. His three-pronged solution involves: information provision about best practices and needed changes, stakeholder engagement through conversations and debates, and creating incentives for organizations demonstrating best practices. Specific activities include monthly electronic newsletters, occasional papers, video webinars, media releases, blogs, public forums, speaker bureaus, and surveys. This vision demonstrates Don's belief that systems change requires simultaneously improving information access, fostering dialogue, and recognizing excellence.

November 2013 D 12 Writing A November 2013 document presenting the foundational philosophy and governance model for the "Better Writing"… ▸ more
A November 2013 document presenting the foundational philosophy and governance model for the "Better Writing" organization. Don articulates his belief that reading and writing are foundational competencies for individual and community development. The organization operates through an unaligned volunteer board with expertise in education but without institutional affiliations, ensuring transparency, public service orientation, and evidence-based decision-making. Activities include volunteer coordination, advocacy, research sponsorship, educational materials production, and organizing conferences and discussion groups. This document reveals Don's values around independence, stakeholder cooperation, and systemic improvement through public engagement.

November 2013 8 Education tomorrow Forward-looking outline titled "Characteristics of Education Tomorrow" dated November 2013. Details desired… ▸ more
Forward-looking outline titled "Characteristics of Education Tomorrow" dated November 2013. Details desired characteristics across three levels: Education system (diverse, affordable, evidence-based, learner-centered, flexible, transparent, community-based, results-oriented), School system (includes learner choice, school autonomy, publicly funded), and Teachers (professional autonomy, accountability, independence). Reflects Donald's visionary thinking about education's future direction and values during his active Education 20/20 period. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: None named - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Donald's forward-thinking vision for education transformation and his leadership in educational futures thinking during the 2010s.

Reflects Don's commitment to community and family engagement in education reform.

Sep 30, 2013 PEIWI Dated September 30, 2013, Don introduces Education 20/20 to Cynthia Mitchell, President of the PEI Women's Institute.… ▸ more
Dated September 30, 2013, Don introduces Education 20/20 to Cynthia Mitchell, President of the PEI Women's Institute. He acknowledges his personal connection to the organization through his mother's active membership in the rural Women's Institute of his childhood. Don frames education as "the most important issue of the day" and expresses Education 20/20's belief that public and parental involvement are essential to achieving necessary educational change. He proposes a meeting to share activities, exchange views on educational issues, and explore collaboration opportunities. The letter demonstrates Don's respect for established community institutions and his ability to leverage personal history to build relationships. He offers to meet in late October or November at a mutually convenient time.

Sep 24, 2013 Mtg 14 Minutes Official minutes from Education 20/20 Inc. Board Meeting No. 14, September 24, 2013 at 4:30 pm, Royal Canadian Legion,… ▸ more
Official minutes from Education 20/20 Inc. Board Meeting No. 14, September 24, 2013 at 4:30 pm, Royal Canadian Legion, Charlottetown. Attendees: Eileen Conway-Martin, Bernadette Allen, Alice Taylor, Don Glendenning (President). Regrets: Bill Whelan. Guests: Brenda Goodine. President called meeting to order and welcomed members. Agenda amended to include Bill Whelan's suggestions on Vision statement (though Bill was absent). Approved minutes from Meeting 13. President reported Director invitations extended to and accepted by Brenda Goodine, Tim McRoberts, and Wendell Labobe (formal motion to follow). Workplan copies posted on DropBox but inaccessible; Don tasked with checking on problem. Revised Framework and handout enclosed. Next meeting called at chair's discretion. Meeting adjourned at 6:00 pm. Attachments include Revised Vision Statement, Revised Workplan framework, and Revised Workplan Handout. Shows organization was expanding board membership and refining operational frameworks. **Tags:** #Education20/20 #BoardMeeting #Governance #Leadership #Vision-Development #Workplan **Eulogy Relevance: 4** (Documents Don's active presidency and organizational development) **Don Authored: No**

Sep 4, 2013 Duffy, Regis 2 Dated September 4, 2013, this letter describes Education 20/20's Excellence in Education Award program in detail. Don… ▸ more
Dated September 4, 2013, this letter describes Education 20/20's Excellence in Education Award program in detail. Don explains that unlike the private sector, education rarely recognizes and rewards excellence in community engagement. The award would recognize schools demonstrating strong community-school partnerships, as research shows such engagement directly correlates with improved student achievement, teacher morale, and communication. The committee is chaired by Eileen Conway-Martin, guidelines are finalized, and a $2,500 cash award accompanies the recognition plaque. Don explicitly solicits Duffy's sponsorship, explaining the award's significance in breaking new ground in provincial education practice. This reflects Don's understanding of incentive structures and organizational change.

Sep 4, 2013 Strategy A September 4, 2013 strategic communications plan for Education 20/20 Inc. describing the organization's mission to… ▸ more
A September 4, 2013 strategic communications plan for Education 20/20 Inc. describing the organization's mission to improve Canadian education quality through information and engagement as "twin pillars of change." The document outlines guiding principles (encourage writing, gather local information, survey-based research, public-facing language), proposed communication components (website, blog, Twitter, newsletters, surveys, papers, publications, public gatherings, media releases, wikis, instructional materials), and operational structure including management, communications, editorial committees, and volunteer engagement.

Aug 29, 2013 06 Australian study The August 29, 2013 sixth issue, edited by Don Glendenning, examines the Victorian Competition and Efficiency… ▸ more
The August 29, 2013 sixth issue, edited by Don Glendenning, examines the Victorian Competition and Efficiency Commission's recommendations for greater principal autonomy and accountability in Australian schools. Don references OECD research showing schools with greater autonomy achieved better PISA results, aligning with his recurring theme about decentralization improving education. The issue also addresses early childhood development concerns about excessive academic pressure in young learners' classrooms, noting federal and state mandates pushing testing down to preschool levels at the expense of play-based learning. Don highlights the Canadian Vocational Association's shift to web-based newsletters and research initiatives. This issue reflects Don's interest in comparative international education policy and ongoing concern for developmentally appropriate practices.

Aug 25, 2013 One pager August 25, 2013, Education 20/20 Inc. position paper on "Reading Skills for Citizens." Identifies widespread concern… ▸ more
August 25, 2013, Education 20/20 Inc. position paper on "Reading Skills for Citizens." Identifies widespread concern about declining reading performance in Canada and PEI. Proposes community-based solutions beyond schools, emphasizing development of measurable reading competencies. Outlines plan to convene working groups of parents, employers, and teachers to establish "Reading Skills for Citizens" checklist and website resource.

Aug 13, 2013 Mtg 10 SD 11-01 Strategic Plan Comprehensive strategic planning document for Education 20/20 Inc. dated August 13, 2013, presented as draft.… ▸ more
Comprehensive strategic planning document for Education 20/20 Inc. dated August 13, 2013, presented as draft. Establishes organizational vision: "An organization that supports Canadians in their efforts to improve the quality of education in their respective communities." Mission focuses on improving educational quality by providing a vehicle for interested people to pool efforts toward educational improvement. Mandate emphasizes influencing education system evolution through information, encouragement, and support. Historical context notes July 18, 2012 national incorporation, Charlottetown headquarters, and charitable status application. Documents organization's beliefs including high school completion support, education over schooling focus, clear accountability, stakeholder engagement, outcomes-based assessment, lifelong learning encouragement, and flexibility. Identifies priorities: information for stakeholders, engagement, independent/lifelong learning, networking, and organizational governance/funding. Document shows Don's philosophical leadership in education transformation. **Tags:** #StrategicPlanning #Vision-Mission #EducationalPhilosophy #Governance #Organizational-Development #Canada **Eulogy Relevance: 4** (Articulates Don's educational vision and values) **Don Authored: Yes**

Jul 6, 2013 Purdy thanks Dated July 6, 2013, this warm, personal letter thanks Henry Purdy for his contribution to Education 20/20's letterhead… ▸ more
Dated July 6, 2013, this warm, personal letter thanks Henry Purdy for his contribution to Education 20/20's letterhead design. Don recounts a humorous parking lot anecdote about visiting the Royal Bank, seeing Purdy vacating a parking space, and playfully commenting on Purdy's banking deposits versus his own withdrawals. The letter expresses deep gratitude for "your friendship and support for yea these many years" and wishes Purdy a great summer. The informal, affectionate tone reveals Don's capacity for personal warmth and his ability to build long-standing friendships outside formal professional structures. The letter provides a glimpse of Don's social life and his appreciation for those who supported his various endeavors over the years.

July 2013 Bridge Charitable status Don writes to Richard Bridge, a barrister and solicitor, requesting pro bono legal assistance for Education 20/20 Inc.… ▸ more
Don writes to Richard Bridge, a barrister and solicitor, requesting pro bono legal assistance for Education 20/20 Inc. to gain charitable status with Revenue Canada. The organization had previously withdrawn its application in July 2013 due to questions about whether their educational objectives qualified as charitable. With a year of operations completed, they developed new objectives and supporting documentation, and now seek Bridge's expertise in navigating the charitable status process. Don demonstrates confidence in the organization's mission to improve education and its unique national scope.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

May 22, 2013 4 Reading Opinion piecel-1 Dated May 22, 2013, this letter to Charlottetown Guardian editor expresses Don's public advocacy for reading… ▸ more
Dated May 22, 2013, this letter to Charlottetown Guardian editor expresses Don's public advocacy for reading improvement as key skill. He articulates concern about reading's state through parents paying both taxes and private tuition, children reading below grade level, employers seeking skilled workers, and seniors endangered by inability to read medicine labels. Don challenges complacency, noting 42 percent of Canadian adults lack sufficient literacy for modern employment. Rather than assigning blame to systemic causes (literacy silos, staffing, resources, curriculum), he advocates for expert problem-solving, citing British Columbia's appointment of a Superintendent of Reading. Don calls reading a pandemic problem and literacy "the most valuable of school subjects," emphasizing most people can learn to read with proper support. He positions himself as inviting feedback (standards2020@gmail.com) and advocates trusting educators' expertise while addressing coordination gaps among providers (school system, post-secondary, community organizations). The piece reflects Don's public engagement on education issues and practical problem-solving orientation.

May 18, 2013 10 Bibliography Brief bibliography compiled May 18, 2013, listing three key texts: Fleming's "Worlds Apart: British Columbia Schools,… ▸ more
Brief bibliography compiled May 18, 2013, listing three key texts: Fleming's "Worlds Apart: British Columbia Schools, Politics and Labour Relations before and After 1972," Coates and Morrison's "Campus Confidential," and Vollmer's "Schools Cannot Do It Alone." These citations suggest Don's research into comparative education systems (BC context), institutional dynamics, and the principle that schools are only one component of educational ecosystems. Limited bibliography indicates early stage of research organization or selective list for specific project. - **Key People**: Fleming, Thomas; Coates; Morrison; Vollmer, Jamie - **Key Organizations**: British Columbia schools - **Tags**: BIBLIOGRAPHY, EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: LOW - Brief reference document showing research interests but limited substantive content for biographical purposes.

May 5, 2013 PEI Mutual Highlight A compelling fundraising letter dated May 5, 2013, to PEI Mutual seeking financial support for Education 20/20 Inc. Don… ▸ more
A compelling fundraising letter dated May 5, 2013, to PEI Mutual seeking financial support for Education 20/20 Inc. Don articulates his educational philosophy: education is "the most important issue of the day" and will determine individual and collective futures. He identifies systemic weaknesses including lack of autonomy, accountability, and mismatch between taught and needed skills. The letter describes Education 20/20's activities (workshops, publications, website development, school awards) and emphasizes that the public must demand change since traditional reform efforts have failed. Don notes the organization is federally incorporated and seeking charitable status, with administrative support from the Community Foundation of PEI. He requests $25,000 in total support and invites a meeting to discuss solutions.

Apr 25, 2013 Aliant Letter dated April 25, 2013, to Bruce Howatt, Vice President of Bell Aliant, describing Education 20/20 Inc. as a… ▸ more
Letter dated April 25, 2013, to Bruce Howatt, Vice President of Bell Aliant, describing Education 20/20 Inc. as a national not-for-profit organization dedicated to quality education. Solicits funding for an online course delivery workshop featuring visiting instructor Professor White-Hassler. The letter explains MOOCs (Multiple Open Online Courses) and their importance for educators, requests $350 sponsorship for the May 14 workshop. Demonstrates Don's forward-thinking approach to technology in education and his ability to secure guest experts for educational events.

Apr 23, 2013 01-Learning (Rev) The inaugural April 23, 2013 issue of Open Education, featuring Don Glendenning's foundational essay on learning and… ▸ more
The inaugural April 23, 2013 issue of Open Education, featuring Don Glendenning's foundational essay on learning and education. Opening with Plutarch's quote about kindling fire in minds, Don defines learning as a personal, lifelong process involving attitude, skill, and knowledge changes. He emphasizes that learning transcends schooling and begins before children enter formal education. The article establishes Education 20/20 Inc. as a national not-for-profit organization governed by volunteer directors focused on quality education. Notably, Don scheduled a May 7 conversation with himself about education, demonstrating his leadership role and vision for community dialogue. The issue includes announcements about future conversations with Dr. Tom White-Hassler and organization contact information for this nascent educational initiative.
EDUCATION

Apr 20, 2013 4 Reading Occasional-2 Dated April 20, 2013, Education 20/20 Inc. document exploring reading from learning perspective. Don defines… ▸ more
Dated April 20, 2013, Education 20/20 Inc. document exploring reading from learning perspective. Don defines education's purpose as developing individual potential and preparing for life roles (individual, family member, learner, citizen, producer, consumer). He emphasizes reading as foundational, enabling access to life's challenges and treasures. Documents widespread concern about reading through Islander discussions, noting it's a community problem unsolvable by schools alone. The paper provides multiple reading definitions emphasizing meaning-making, independence, comprehension, fluency, and mental text engagement. Includes extensive statistics on literacy challenges: 40 percent of Islanders lack adequate literacy/numeracy for high school completion, PEI students rank below national average internationally, 30 percent of Islanders cannot deal with common printed materials. Details Atlantic Canada Grade 12 English Language Arts curriculum expectations for reading and viewing, including text selection, diverse literature experience, comprehension strategies, evaluation skills, and critical response. Proposes reading level frameworks and discusses strategies (scanning, skimming, underlining, highlighting, summarizing) with resources for learner support.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Apr 19, 2013 Skills From April 19, 2013, Don defines skill training comprehensively: attitude, skill, and knowledge development for… ▸ more
From April 19, 2013, Don defines skill training comprehensively: attitude, skill, and knowledge development for workplace function, including supporting academics. He distinguishes skill training from course reconfiguration, emphasizing occupational analysis as the starting point. He argues for workplace-aligned assessment criteria (quality, timeliness, safety) confirmed through demonstration rather than exams. He distinguishes credentials (what was studied) from qualifications (what someone can do) and suggests external qualification authorities may better serve skills training than educational institutions.

An April 5, 2013 discussion paper addressing newsletter development for Education 20/20 Inc., proposing "Open Education" as the publication name. The document discusses committee structure and recommends assigning newsletter leadership to specific individuals (Eileen mentioned as potential committee chair, with Don offering interim chair role until schedules ease). Notes the upcoming website launch and discusses newsletter format (one to two pages with electronic distribution), proposed fresh weekly content items, and plans for occasional papers on focused educational topics.

April 2013 D-19 Grading April 2013 Open Education newsletter from Don distinguishing three types of grading based on Robert Paul Wolff's… ▸ more
April 2013 Open Education newsletter from Don distinguishing three types of grading based on Robert Paul Wolff's framework: criticism/formative assessment, evaluation/criterion-referenced levels, and ranking by competition.

Mar 22, 2013 Reading-1 Highlight Don Glendenning's personal notes from March 22, 2013 on reading, framing literacy as central to education and lifelong… ▸ more
Don Glendenning's personal notes from March 22, 2013 on reading, framing literacy as central to education and lifelong learning. Don emphasizes that reading is "the golden skill" and a "tool for lifelong learning," not merely a school responsibility but a community responsibility rooted in early years. He compiles multiple definitions of reading and presents PEI literacy statistics identical to those in the broader Education 20/20 paper. Don outlines reading competencies (interpreting prose, graphs, manuals, computer printouts, etc.) and establishes key performance criteria. The notes reflect his systematic approach to understanding educational problems.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Feb 1, 2013 MOOCs Highlight A letter to the Editor of the Guardian (dated February 1, 2013) titled "MOOCs in Education." Don expresses concern… ▸ more
A letter to the Editor of the Guardian (dated February 1, 2013) titled "MOOCs in Education." Don expresses concern about the "tsunami" of online education, drawing parallels to Japan's actual tsunami. He distinguishes between technical knowledge (printable, lectureable, rote) and practical knowledge (wisdom, judgment, skill) that cannot be taught through online formats alone. Quoting David Brooks and Sheryl Sandberg, Don advocates for in-person instruction in critical thinking, communication, and practical skills. He criticizes low public expectations for communication skills, particularly in reading and writing, and challenges citizens to demand accountability from educators. A passionate and prescient argument against viewing education as purely technical delivery.

Shows Don's systematic approach to education policy development and his collaboration with government, educational institutions, and employers.

Triggered by a University of Moncton professor controversy, Glendenning argues transcripts inadequately assess citizenship/employability skills and proposes redesigned transcripts or gold seal endorsements reflecting basic skills competency needed for modern economic participation.

Identifies systemic barriers (lack of professional freedom, obscured accountability) and enabling activities (information, innovation, public engagement). Core statement of Don's reform vision.

2013 Murphy, Ray-2 Highlight Follow-up letter to Ray Murphy updating him on Education 20/20's progress and requesting sustained support for 2013… ▸ more
Follow-up letter to Ray Murphy updating him on Education 20/20's progress and requesting sustained support for 2013 activities. Don reiterates that meaningful change requires rethinking education fundamentals and system structure. He reports activities underway: early childhood education workshops with recognized practitioners, school-community engagement software testing (recognizing research linking engagement to achievement), school award program development, educator dialogue on reading skills gaps, and public information initiatives to address education's communication deficit. Don sets a $25,000 budget for 2013 initiatives and requests either one-time or three-year commitments from supporters. Community Foundation of PEI administers funds and issues tax receipts.
