2013 2013 Annual Pres. Report Don Glendenning's President's Report for the year ending December 31, 2013, highlighting Education 20/20 Inc.'s… ▸ more
Don Glendenning's President's Report for the year ending December 31, 2013, highlighting Education 20/20 Inc.'s expanding influence and activities. The organization continued broad consultation with stakeholders across PEI (parents, educators, employers, volunteers, government officials). Formal 2013 activities included planning sessions with external facilitators yielding a vision statement, launch of a monthly newsletter, and a major workshop on "Learners and Learning" at the Quality Inn, Charlottetown (October 21, 2013). Meetings were held with high-level representatives including the Premier, Minister of Education, Deputy Minister, PEI Teachers Union President, and professional associations (Engineers, Construction Association, Home and School Federation, Women's Institute). Glendenning emphasizes that the organization's leadership role demonstrates public interest in education improvement and confirms education's fundamental importance.
EDUCATION SPEECH
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-16 A Response to Pisa results. Highlight Responding to low PISA results, Don argues these reflect community issues beyond schools' sole responsibility. He… ▸ more
Responding to low PISA results, Don argues these reflect community issues beyond schools' sole responsibility. He proposes a comprehensive approach to reading improvement: shifting from outcome-based to competency-based curriculum, developing master reading competency lists with community input, establishing rating scales and benchmarks, and organizing competencies by real-world application. He emphasizes that "what gets measured gets taught" and advocates for transparent competency frameworks visible to students, parents, and employers.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-15-03 Grade Level A Myth Don challenges the validity of grade levels as meaningful measures of student achievement, noting that within any grade… ▸ more
Don challenges the validity of grade levels as meaningful measures of student achievement, noting that within any grade students may be several "grade levels" ahead or behind. He proposes replacing age-based grades with a competency-based system using clear exit outcomes and on-demand testing (similar to the Royal Conservatory of Music model). Students would progress based on demonstrated mastery regardless of age, with diplomas reflecting completed competencies rather than time served.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-13 To start the discussionx Highlight Synthesizing concerns about reading proficiency as a foundational community problem, Don reframes reading as a… ▸ more
Synthesizing concerns about reading proficiency as a foundational community problem, Don reframes reading as a learnable, teachable, measurable skill accessible to most with support. Success requires information, instruction, materials, and practice alongside readiness, encouragement, and feedback. Don advocates recognizing early childhood's unique developmental needs rather than extending school models downward, giving early learning equivalent status to colleges and universities. He proposes replacing traditional graduation requirements with a single reading proficiency standard; students achieving it receive diplomas and pursue interests. Referencing a school with differentiated language arts and math placement enabling flexible progression without grade repetition, Don envisions systems prioritizing readiness over batch processing.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-05 Exemptions Supporting Keith Hogg's suggestion that high school students successfully challenge examinations could be exempted from… ▸ more
Supporting Keith Hogg's suggestion that high school students successfully challenge examinations could be exempted from taking courses, Don recalls similar exemption policies during his university studies. Exemptions would free students to concentrate on challenging subjects, explore new interests, or graduate early, eliminating wasted time re-learning previously covered material. Don identifies only positive impacts (student motivation, personalized pacing, exposure to new learning) and no downsides. He frames this as a practical incentive encouraging student achievement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-03 Remedial Math Critiquing the label "remedial" in educational contexts, Don argues the term implies student fault and carries… ▸ more
Critiquing the label "remedial" in educational contexts, Don argues the term implies student fault and carries stigmatizing effects potentially lasting throughout life. Drawing on personal medical experience where receiving corrective treatment didn't result in labeling, Don questions whether remedial math instruction differs fundamentally from regular instruction or merely employs different teaching methodology for different learner needs. He contends careful labeling practices—especially for young students—protect long-term potential. The letter demonstrates Don's attention to psychological and social impacts of educational language.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-02 Principal While reaffirming principal importance in school success, Don calls for shifted emphasis toward greater autonomy.… ▸ more
While reaffirming principal importance in school success, Don calls for shifted emphasis toward greater autonomy. Supported by OECD and New Zealand research linking school-level autonomy and accountability to student performance, Don advocates for principals' freedom to allocate operating funds uniquely, organize and fund professional development, select and assign staff matching school priorities, and lead outcome identification and program implementation. The letter balances recognition of principal leadership with conviction that greater autonomy—not constraint—maximizes effectiveness.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-01 Golden Skill Addressing widespread concern about reading proficiency, Don cites alarming statistics: PEI 15-year-olds ranking below… ▸ more
Addressing widespread concern about reading proficiency, Don cites alarming statistics: PEI 15-year-olds ranking below other provinces in reading/writing, 30% of Canadian Grade 6 students unable to read adequately, 30% of PEI adults lacking functional literacy. He notes interventions show promise and calls for sustained public engagement. Rather than treating reading as a discrete subject, Don suggests establishing independent reading clinics operating outside schools. He emphasizes public engagement as key to change, urging conversations with principals, school trustees, MLAs, and community members.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 D 2013-Reading Don identifies inadequate reading instruction as a critical PEI education problem, citing low literacy levels despite… ▸ more
Don identifies inadequate reading instruction as a critical PEI education problem, citing low literacy levels despite improvements. He proposes five specific changes: increase reading attention, update and specify outcomes, clarify assessment criteria and levels, distribute accountability clearly, and improve report card accuracy for reading performance. He suggests employers and community organizations (Chambers of Commerce, Rotary Clubs) take leadership roles in documenting literacy gaps and advocating improvement. The letter combines diagnostic analysis with concrete recommendations and stakeholder engagement strategies.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 D 2013-Failure A lengthy, exploratory draft examining whether schools should teach students to deal with failure. Don distinguishes… ▸ more
A lengthy, exploratory draft examining whether schools should teach students to deal with failure. Don distinguishes between failure as a life experience and schools' instructional role. He argues that test results are diagnostic information for teaching improvement (formative), not measures of student failure. He critiques schools taking on ranking functions alongside teaching, proposing three metaphors: sport (with coaching and umpiring), race (with judges), and journey (with guides). This philosophical piece reflects Don's mature thinking about systemic purposes and the distinction between learning support and competitive ranking.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 D 2013-Exemptions Don supports Keith Hogg's proposal allowing students to exempt courses through successful exam performance, drawing on… ▸ more
Don supports Keith Hogg's proposal allowing students to exempt courses through successful exam performance, drawing on his own university experience. He argues exemptions create incentives, allow customized learning paths, and prevent repetition of already-mastered material. The letter advocates for individual flexibility within school systems and positions exemption policies as having no downside, worth implementing as an experiment. It reflects Don's student-centered perspective and belief that educational systems should accommodate individual learning needs and pace.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 D 2013-2 Should schools sort Don distinguishes between formative testing (to improve learning) and summative testing (to rank and sort students),… ▸ more
Don distinguishes between formative testing (to improve learning) and summative testing (to rank and sort students), arguing these are fundamentally incompatible functions. He proposes separating teaching from ranking roles, analogous to how sports divide coaching from refereeing. His argument emphasizes that ranking inherently contradicts the teacher's role of helping students learn, and this dual responsibility creates systemic unfairness. The position reflects Don's systematic thinking about organizational roles and his commitment to pedagogically sound practices.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 D 2013-01 Curriculum Don articulates his curriculum philosophy using Oregon State Department of Education's life roles framework… ▸ more
Don articulates his curriculum philosophy using Oregon State Department of Education's life roles framework (individual, learner, family member, citizen, consumer, producer). He argues that education should prepare people for these multiple roles in contemporary society, not recreate yesterday's educational model. He advocates for outcomes-based education with clearly stated graduation requirements. The systematic framework reflects Don's organizational thinking and his belief that clear philosophical foundations should guide curriculum design rather than historical precedent.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 D-2013-01 Pre-school Don advocates for reframing early childhood education as development-focused rather than school-preparation-focused. He… ▸ more
Don advocates for reframing early childhood education as development-focused rather than school-preparation-focused. He cites research suggesting that preschool focus may actually interfere with development of critical social skills. Don argues early childhood education deserves the same organizational independence as postsecondary education, not as a downward extension of schooling. He proposes three organizational options: an Early Childhood Commission, integration with Health or Social Services (already serving this age), or delegating school operation to boards to allow the Department to focus on all educational needs. Don emphasizes early years as a distinct life stage requiring customized approaches and autonomy from traditional school regulations and structures.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 D-2013-01 How do you know you learned Don defines learning as behavioral change across cognitive, affective, and psychomotor domains, emphasizing that… ▸ more
Don defines learning as behavioral change across cognitive, affective, and psychomotor domains, emphasizing that learning manifests as new or improved knowledge, skills, and attitudes. He explains that learning cannot be measured directly but is evidenced through observable competencies (reading, machinery repair, design, communication). Don advocates for outcomes-based education (OBE) starting with clearly defined competencies and measurable performance levels, using physician decision-making as a model that combines objective data with professional judgment. He emphasizes this approach helps parents, teachers, and planners understand student progress and plan next steps. This letter showcases his sophisticated understanding of educational measurement and outcome-based systems.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 D 2013-11 Culinary model Dated November 21, 2013, Don draws parallels between culinary education's evolution and needed educational… ▸ more
Dated November 21, 2013, Don draws parallels between culinary education's evolution and needed educational transformation. He recalls PEI's shift from quantity cooking (for institutional food service) to refined culinary arts with professional chefs, driven by changing market demands and entrepreneurial vision. He argues schools similarly need to evolve from delivering standardized content to fostering creative, rewarding learning experiences with teachers as skilled craftspeople. The letter reveals his belief that education, like the culinary sector, benefits from industry leadership, professional autonomy, and responsive innovation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-11 Quality Education Don calls for shifting education measurement from "time in seat" to quality outcomes. He defines learning as developing… ▸ more
Don calls for shifting education measurement from "time in seat" to quality outcomes. He defines learning as developing attitudes, skills, and knowledge to navigate life roles (individual, family member, learner, citizen, consumer, producer). Using UNICEF's 2000 quality education framework, he notes progress on healthy learners and safe environments but identifies content relevance, child-centered processes, and holistic outcomes as needing attention, suggesting these may not yet be on the provincial agenda.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-07-07 School Credits A complex, lengthy piece arguing that schools conflate teaching and sorting functions, which creates inherent… ▸ more
A complex, lengthy piece arguing that schools conflate teaching and sorting functions, which creates inherent conflicts. Don distinguishes between testing as a teaching tool (confidential, diagnostic) versus testing for administrative control and credentialing. He proposes separating these functions: schools should teach while external qualification authorities (like a proposed Atlantic Qualification Authority) handle certification and sorting. He critiques the control exercised by the Department of Education over scheduling, curriculum, and staffing as incompatible with teaching responsibility.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-06 Schools and skills In response to student Danielle Phelan's concerns about education and employment, Don argues that each educational… ▸ more
In response to student Danielle Phelan's concerns about education and employment, Don argues that each educational level should equip students either for the next level or for entry-level employment. He cites Conference Board of Canada research showing that employability skills are everyday competencies (literacy, numeracy, personal management, teamwork) rather than technical expertise requiring expensive facilities. He contends schools must shift from academic focus to life-relevant skills while maintaining rigor.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 2013-06 A Family educator Don proposes establishing independent educational advisors separate from school counselors. Drawing on Jan Hodges'… ▸ more
Don proposes establishing independent educational advisors separate from school counselors. Drawing on Jan Hodges' Manchester Guardian article, he argues that just as families have doctors, accountants, and lawyers, they need educational advisors who can provide independent guidance to students, parents, and teachers on career and educational pathways. This would address a gap between school-based counseling and the broader lifelong learning needs of people of all ages.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2013 2013-05 What we want our schools to do An unpublished piece responding to Walter Wilkins' question about school purpose. Don reframes the discussion by asking… ▸ more
An unpublished piece responding to Walter Wilkins' question about school purpose. Don reframes the discussion by asking first "What kind of education do we want?" before defining school roles. He notes that much important education occurs outside schools and advocates for starting a community conversation. He organized a May 7 meeting at Sports PEI to discuss these fundamental questions with interested community members.

2013 2013-04 Skill Training A detailed exploration of what skill training actually means versus superficial program reconfigurations. Don… ▸ more
A detailed exploration of what skill training actually means versus superficial program reconfigurations. Don distinguishes between credentials (what was studied) and qualifications (what can be done), arguing skill training requires workplace-aligned assessment criteria rather than traditional exams. He emphasizes the importance of work habits, teamwork, and safety practices alongside technical skills, advocating for external qualification authorities rather than having schools award credentials for employment preparation.

2013 1-Description Comprehensive description of Education 20/20's Preparedness 2 initiative addressing skills of citizenship. Based on… ▸ more
Comprehensive description of Education 20/20's Preparedness 2 initiative addressing skills of citizenship. Based on Community Foundation of PEI's 2013 survey of 200+ island youth identifying preparedness gaps for post-secondary study and employment. Document identifies core issues: math gaps, low basic skill levels, economic drag from low skills, lack of master list for skills, absence of coordinating education body on PEI. Proposes identifying skills required for citizenship, employment, and further education through systematic analysis. Reflects Glendenning's systematic educational approach to problem identification and solution development. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning, CFPEI researchers - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, Holland College, UPEI - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, PROPOSAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Core educational initiative reflecting Glendenning's vision and values

Budget proposal for Education 20/20 Inc. for 2013. Projects total revenue of $27,500 from corporate donations ($10,000), individual donations ($2,500), Community Foundation of PEI ($5,000), and sponsorships ($10,000). Major expenditure categories include administration ($7,200), open education newsletter ($1,200), occasional papers ($5,000), workshops ($3,600), dialogues ($2,500), and school engagement awards ($6,000). Total projected expenditures are $25,500. - **Key People**: Donald Glendenning (as administrator) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Community Foundation of PEI - **Tags**: FINANCIAL, ADMIN, PROFESSIONAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Donald's leadership in founding and managing Education 20/20's early financial operations and strategic direction

2013 3-4-3-g Windsor proposal docx Windsor Foundation proposal for developing basic education skills curriculum map. Education 20/20 Inc. addresses… ▸ more
Windsor Foundation proposal for developing basic education skills curriculum map. Education 20/20 Inc. addresses preparedness gap and challenges simplistic "poor teaching" explanations. Suggests examining curriculum role clarity, standards relevance, alignment degree, assessment/evaluation criteria, and inter-institutional communication. Proposes developing basic competencies curriculum map serving teachers (identifying learning objectives), students (tracking progress), curriculum developers (field analysis), employers (new employee expectations), and credentialing bodies (assessment foundation). Identifies persistent PEI education silos including public schools, university, private schools, colleges, literacy training, and NGO projects with minimal coordination. Emphasizes curriculum alignment requiring clear mission, attainable/measurable goals, relevant curriculum, appropriate instructional methodology, unbiased assessment, accurate reporting. Notes subject-centered (vs. learner-centered) education limiting customization. References DACUM process and Bloom's taxonomy. Seven-step process: establish steering committee, gather background information, develop master skills list, develop/adopt criterion-referenced rating scale, identify profiles, develop/test assessment, prepare report. Budget $13,775. Includes Appendix A on preparedness gaps from 2013 CFPEI Island youth survey. - **Key People**: Donald Glendenning, steering committee members - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Windsor Foundation, Holland College - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, CORRESPONDENCE, PROPOSAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Glendenning's systemic thinking about education reform.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 3-4-3-J Windsor proposal docx Highlight Windsor Foundation proposal for creating a mathematics curriculum map. Education 20/20 Inc. addresses gap between basic… ▸ more
Windsor Foundation proposal for creating a mathematics curriculum map. Education 20/20 Inc. addresses gap between basic skills taught in public schools and skills needed for postsecondary/employment access. Proposes consulting employers, postsecondary institutions, and community to identify desired skills for mathematics curriculum map. Seeks funding to develop competency-based curriculum map in mathematics, identify assessment level criteria, develop criterion-referenced rating scale transcending student ages/grades/boundaries, and establish assessment processes ensuring fair consistent standards. References 2013 CFPEI youth survey showing preparedness gaps, PISA results, and chamber of commerce presentations. Notes vulnerable youth lacking basic skills and duplication in postsecondary remedial services. Proposes starting with existing practical mathematics analysis from Holland College, using DACUM methodology pioneered by Holland College. Three-stage approach: develop master competencies list (curriculum map), develop externally-referenced assessment criteria aligned with outcomes-based education principles, establish externally-referenced benchmarks. Emphasizes separating teaching from assessment functions. Budget section incomplete in extraction but indicates major cost items for project leadership, analysis preparation, rating scale development, profile identification, assessment development, materials/supplies, graphics, and community engagement volunteer hours (450 person-hours noted). - **Key People**: Donald Glendenning (President), community stakeholders, employers, educators - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Windsor Foundation, Community Foundation of PEI, Holland College - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, CORRESPONDENCE - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Glendenning's sophisticated understanding of educational standards and his practical approach to curriculum development.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2013 3-4-3-D Windsor proposal docx Further refined Windsor Foundation proposal addressing the "Preparedness Initiative." Frames the core educational… ▸ more
Further refined Windsor Foundation proposal addressing the "Preparedness Initiative." Frames the core educational problem: low level of basic skills in high school graduates impacting transition to employment and postsecondary studies. Cites PISA results, 2013 CFPEI youth survey, chamber of commerce presentations, and Education 20/20 workshops across PEI. Criticizes the silo nature of schooling, curriculum misalignment, and inflexibility. Proposes solutions including establishing steering committees, searching relevant literature, conducting DACUM-based competency analysis, developing Bloom's-taxonomy-aligned rating scales, identifying profiles reflecting citizenship, work entry, and postsecondary gaps, benchmarking, testing the model, and reporting. Describes features such as common curriculum maps for teachers and learners, multiple profiles from single analysis, engaging broad stakeholder participation, and fostering collaborative education teams. Appendix A includes detailed background on CFPEI's "Preparedness gaps" finding from Island youth survey. - **Key People**: Donald Glendenning, Community Foundation of PEI leadership - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Windsor Foundation, Community Foundation of PEI, CFPEI, PEI Department of Education - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, CORRESPONDENCE, PROPOSAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Glendenning's leadership in addressing provincial education challenges.

Includes learning models and pedagogical frameworks. Reflects Don's articulate vision for systemic educational improvement and his ability to mobilize community participation.

Notes from Don's facilitation of Education 20/20 Workshop #1 on April 4, 2013, at Royalty Centre on learning and teaching. Documents lessons learned about workshop moderation, including need to manage discussion length, employ interventions to redirect conversation, and maintain focus on learners rather than system criticism. Reflects on attendance (three people) and includes discussion topics about teacher outcomes and employer concerns regarding student communication and work skills.

Dec 17, 2012 Duffy, Regis 1 This December 17, 2012 letter thanks Regis Duffy for supporting Education 20/20 Inc.'s education reform efforts. Don… ▸ more
This December 17, 2012 letter thanks Regis Duffy for supporting Education 20/20 Inc.'s education reform efforts. Don outlines the organization's progress: successful small-group meetings, federal incorporation, upcoming charitable status, and multiple initiatives including early childhood development workshops, school-community engagement assessment, an education excellence award, dialogue with educators on reading skills, and plans to publish educational materials. The letter demonstrates that Education 20/20 had moved from exploratory phase to operational organization with concrete programs. Duffy is being solicited for ongoing financial support, and the letter invites him to an educational workshop in Stratford. This shows Don's fundraising and donor cultivation skills.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Dec 16, 2012 Scotia O'Hanley-3 Highlight A December 16, 2012 letter updating Robert O'Hanley on Education 20/20 Inc.'s progress and mission. Don expresses the… ▸ more
A December 16, 2012 letter updating Robert O'Hanley on Education 20/20 Inc.'s progress and mission. Don expresses the critical importance of education and articulates his belief in the necessity of fundamental systemic change, including greater school autonomy, reduced bureaucracy, teacher freedom/accountability, preschool attention, expanded choice, and reformed standards. He reports a dozen community meetings held, establishment of a cadre of reform-minded individuals, and federal incorporation achieved. Recent activities include early childhood education workshops, school engagement software testing, innovation awards, educator dialogues (particularly on reading skills), and exploration of public information gaps. Seeking additional funds for implementation, Don solicits ScotiaMcLeod's continued support and early decision-making.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

Thank you letter dated December 16, 2012, to Roger Birt expressing gratitude for his foundational support. Details organization evolution from initial meetings to federal incorporation as Education 20/20 Inc., including logo development, website construction, and Canadian Revenue Agency charitable status application. Lists accomplishments: early childhood development workshops, engagement software testing, school excellence award program, educator dialogue initiatives, and publication planning. Shows transformation from informal initiative to formal charitable organization within eight months of initial contact with Birt.

Don articulates his vision for educational reform, emphasizing the need for fundamental change in education including greater school autonomy, reduced bureaucracy, teacher accountability, and alternative delivery models. Lists specific accomplishments: early childhood education workshop, engagement software testing, school excellence award program, educator dialogue on reading skills, and information dissemination plans. Requests $25,000 program budget and three-year donor commitment.

Foundational letter dated November 9, 2012, to APM Group CEO Tim Banks introducing Education 20/20 Inc. and explaining concerns about Canadian education based on experience and community feedback. Articulates need for systemic change including teacher/principal autonomy and accountability. Notes existing changes fall short of needs. Emphasizes information scarcity in education compared to health sector, advocating for practical educational information (reading problem detection, standards, independent study). Describes Education 20/20 Inc. strategy: identify approaches, engage diverse stakeholders, identify projects, implement activities. Seeks financial and moral support through Community Foundation of PEI.

The letter demonstrates Don's commitment to building evidence-based advocacy and connecting stakeholders.

The organization, newly incorporated as a non-aligned national body focused on quality education, proposes workshops on reading-related matters including outcomes, competencies, learning materials, and teaching strategies. Don requests funding for research assistance ($2,500) and facility rental for ten meetings ($1,500). The proposal demonstrates Don's early education reform efforts before Education 20/20 Inc.'s formation and his strategic focus on reading as the foundational literacy skill. The letter references endorsement by the Community Foundation of PEI, showing early partnership development.

A February 1, 2012 letter to Michael S. Schurman, President of the Schurman Family Foundation, articulating Don's concerns about the state of education in PEI. Don advocates for systemic change addressing autonomy, accountability, and skills misalignment. He describes Education 20/20 Inc.'s newly launched initiatives including consultation with education officials, school engagement awards, engagement software testing, literacy improvement efforts, and publication strategies. Seeking $25,000 support, Don emphasizes that traditional change efforts have failed and innovative measures are needed. He notes the Community Foundation of PEI will administer funds.

Published Guardian letter criticizing time-based rather than performance-based education systems. Don argues schools should be flexible enough to adjust schedules for struggling and advanced learners, using service industry standards as comparison—a cornerstone theme of his reform philosophy.

2012 D-Exemptions@2015-04-06T12;43;58 Letter to the Charlottetown Guardian arguing for the restoration of exam exemptions for high-achieving students, a… ▸ more
Letter to the Charlottetown Guardian arguing for the restoration of exam exemptions for high-achieving students, a practice that existed at Colonel Grey High School until 2012. Glendenning cites evidence that non-traditional credit arrangements (exemptions, online courses, challenge for credit) are widely available across Canada and supported by both educators and parents. He appeals for the Premier to include flexible credit options in future policy announcements as a key student incentive.

Official minutes of the First Annual Meeting attended by Alice Taylor, Eileen Conway-Martin, and Don Glendenning. Minutes record approval of all governance proposals, including Director expansion from 3 to 8, extended terms, committee structure, and membership designation. The President welcomed attendees and noted the "historic gathering" significance. Financial notes indicate Education 20/20 Inc. had no independent bank account; the Community Foundation of PEI paid expenses ($707.43 initially corrected to $2,492.57). Officers elected: Don Glendenning (President), Eileen Conway-Martin (Vice President), Alice Taylor (Secretary).

2012 2012 Annual-Bkgrd paper Support document detailing governance proposals for the First Annual Meeting. Sections address: (A) Directors -… ▸ more
Support document detailing governance proposals for the First Annual Meeting. Sections address: (A) Directors - proposing expansion from 3 to 8 Directors with 3-year staggered terms and re-election provisions; (B) Members - admitting Directors to membership status while postponing external recruitment, recognizing the broader "Education 20/20 Network" of meeting attendees; (C) Committees - establishing board-approved committee structure normally chaired by Directors. These structural proposals demonstrate thoughtful organizational design, emphasizing term limits, succession planning, and community integration.

2012 A Fund 1 Souris UPSE Letter A formal fundraising letter from Don Glendenning to Karen Jackson, President of the PEI Union of Public Sector… ▸ more
A formal fundraising letter from Don Glendenning to Karen Jackson, President of the PEI Union of Public Sector Employees, requesting a $1,500 lead donation to fund innovative educational initiatives in Souris. Don describes Education 20/20 Inc. (incorporated 2012, registered charity 2015) as a volunteer-governed organization. He highlights the organization's involvement with the Souris Garden Club and education-to-work transition issues, proposing the UPSE contribution be matched by Education 20/20 to demonstrate community partnership. The letter showcases Don's fundraising skills and ability to frame educational needs persuasively.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2012 5 Standards Don differentiates between school-based testing for instructional purposes and external certification testing for… ▸ more
Don differentiates between school-based testing for instructional purposes and external certification testing for employment/advancement qualification. He argues schools should assess learning progress to inform teaching strategies, while society needs separate external assessment confirming skill levels for hiring, licensing, and advanced study entry. Proposing an independent provincial qualification authority to assess individual achievement separately from school grading, Don notes such models exist (Apprenticeship, International Baccalaureate). External testing would improve consistency, reduce teacher workload, minimize cheating, and increase system flexibility.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2012 1 An Education Windfall Contemplating hypothetical million-dollar educational investment, Don contrasts conventional spending approaches (more… ▸ more
Contemplating hypothetical million-dollar educational investment, Don contrasts conventional spending approaches (more teachers, computers, aides, professional development days) with systemic reforms he believes would create lasting quality improvements. His priority list includes rewriting school legislation and labor agreements to empower teachers, establishing external innovation funds, increasing school operational freedom, creating independent qualification authorities, enabling credit-by-challenge, establishing separate skill training centers, expanding best-practice information sharing, developing educational navigators, enhancing public engagement, and implementing outcomes-based teacher certification. The letter consolidates his core reform vision.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2012 D 2012 Acceptance Don uses a restaurant analogy to explore how consumers—especially employers—can respond to unmet educational… ▸ more
Don uses a restaurant analogy to explore how consumers—especially employers—can respond to unmet educational expectations. He argues that public education's monopoly status removes market incentives, but citizens retain political power through communication with leadership. He advocates for employers and the public to voice dissatisfaction with reading and writing standards directly to government decision-makers (Premier and cabinet). The draft suggests that unclear hiring specifications and low community expectations perpetuate low performance, requiring active stakeholder intervention.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2012 D 2012 Schools Disappeared Published September 5, 2012, this letter references Don's memory of Patrick Watson's 1969 keynote at the PEI Teachers'… ▸ more
Published September 5, 2012, this letter references Don's memory of Patrick Watson's 1969 keynote at the PEI Teachers' Federation convention titled "The Day the Schools Disappeared," which explored hypothetical scenarios if communities lost school infrastructure. Don poses a more provocative question: what would change if schools lost connection to the School Board and departmental oversight? He asks whether the loss of bureaucratic layers would affect student numbers, instruction quality, achievement, operations, or costs. The letter reveals his conviction that institutional structures often hinder rather than help educational effectiveness.

2012 4 Proposals- 2012 short list Draft outline of multiple proposed initiatives under Education 20/20 umbrella: Awards program (school focus with… ▸ more
Draft outline of multiple proposed initiatives under Education 20/20 umbrella: Awards program (school focus with community engagement), Information dissemination (public-oriented media and papers), Enabling Change framework (island-wide, 3-5 years), Leaders Club ("Forty Under Forty" emerging leaders with annual Charlottetown gathering and national expansion), and Credentials for Independent Learners (competency-based recognition for technical professionals). Emphasis on information, engagement, awards, and innovation support to drive systemic educational change. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows breadth of Glendenning's educational reform agenda and strategic thinking

Read · Download
 Read · Download
Dec 12, 2011 Reading Clinic Don submits a letter to Charlottetown Guardian editor (December 12, 2011) proposing public reading clinics modeled on… ▸ more
Don submits a letter to Charlottetown Guardian editor (December 12, 2011) proposing public reading clinics modeled on specialized medical clinics like Calgary's knee clinic. Inspired by an article on reducing wait times and unnecessary tests, Don applies the clinic concept to reading instruction. He identifies reading as a key skill and primary parental concern, proposing mainstream clinics (not research-focused) staffed by reading specialists who would assess problems, identify needs, and create learning plans addressing fluency, grammar, comprehension, spelling, and vocabulary. Don envisions fee-for-service operation open to Islanders through direct access or referral, distinguishing this from university research clinics. He identifies himself as "a long-time student of education" and invites reader commentary at an email address.

2011 X 2011-8-30 culture@2014-12-23T00;07;17 Letter examining how school culture fails to model real-world expectations for work and life. Glendenning critiques… ▸ more
Letter examining how school culture fails to model real-world expectations for work and life. Glendenning critiques schools for operating on rigid time schedules, lacking service mentality, mimicking outdated industrial organizations, and obscuring accountability. He advocates for cultural changes that emphasize self-direction, collegial operations, and transparent accountability rather than merely adding new courses.

2011 D2 2011 Interventions Don's open letter to Guardian proposing immediate, low-cost education interventions: parents-as-consumers dialogue with… ▸ more
Don's open letter to Guardian proposing immediate, low-cost education interventions: parents-as-consumers dialogue with teachers, teacher outcome clarity, reading as separate subject, exit interviews for non-graduates, employer hiring by skills rather than subjects.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL SPEECH
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 21-2-C RESTRUCTURING Version examining Islander educator reluctance/fear regarding educational reform. Don attributes resistance to system… ▸ more
Version examining Islander educator reluctance/fear regarding educational reform. Don attributes resistance to system structure: political embedment determining who teaches, subject matter, scheduling, and methodology via "head office." Repeats international reform calls (OECD 2011, World Bank 2018, UNESCO, Education 2020 Inc. 2015) and references "fear factor." Redefines education as umbrella term including all learning that produces observable changes in thinking/feeling/acting, contrasting with narrow focus on credentials. Argues two-fold problem requires overhaul: broadening education vision and removing military-precision bureaucratic delivery. Advocates Legislative committee restructuring initiative.
EDUCATION

 Read · Download
2011 21-2 RESTRUCTURING Comprehensive working draft proposing PEI education restructuring. Don defines education as umbrella concept… ▸ more
Comprehensive working draft proposing PEI education restructuring. Don defines education as umbrella concept encompassing all learning experiences, distinguishing it from schooling. References calls for reform from PEI trustees, OECD (2011), World Bank (2018), Montreal Economic Institute, UNESCO, Education 2020 Inc. (2015), and educators. Identifies problems: government's narrow vision conflating education with schooling, political system embedment limiting flexibility. Proposes solutions including independent qualification service, chief educator role, micro-credit system, government-funded education service identification, individual profiles, Department role redesign, and PEI Education Association. Advocates for Legislative committee educational overhaul.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-9 Another voice Don proposes creating stand-alone educational organizations modeled on independent health advocacy groups (Heart and… ▸ more
Don proposes creating stand-alone educational organizations modeled on independent health advocacy groups (Heart and Stroke Foundation, Diabetes Association). He specifically advocates for a reading improvement association operating independently from schools but in collaboration with them. Such organizations could provide public awareness, early detection support, research promotion, service lobbying, information clearinghouses, and policy influence. Open membership would include teachers, parents, employers, and community members. Don envisions these as complementing institutional support, extending reach beyond schools to libraries, workplaces, and homes.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-8 Elephant Using the parable of blind men describing an elephant, Don identifies the underlying "elephant in the room" as the… ▸ more
Using the parable of blind men describing an elephant, Don identifies the underlying "elephant in the room" as the absence of market forces and competition in public education. While others blame teachers' unions, home support, or low standards, Don argues the core issue is monopolistic government control lacking accountability, choice, and transparency. He contends the system prioritizes schooling over education, operates without clear student outcomes, discourages growth in favor of conformity, and fails to treat teachers as professionals. The letter demonstrates Don's market-oriented thinking about systemic improvement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-7. Culture This letter diagnoses fundamental cultural misalignments between school practices and real-world functioning. Don… ▸ more
This letter diagnoses fundamental cultural misalignments between school practices and real-world functioning. Don identifies six structural problems: task completion timing (schools interrupt; work requires task completion), self-direction (schools restrict autonomy; society needs self-starters), service mentality (schools lack accountability; society demands it), collegial organization (schools remain hierarchical), accountability obscurity (both students and teachers lack clear responsibility), and compensation based on credentials rather than performance. Don contends these are cultural, not curricular issues requiring systemic redesign rather than course additions.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-5 Professional Freedon Following international education conferences emphasizing teacher importance, Don calls for expanded professional… ▸ more
Following international education conferences emphasizing teacher importance, Don calls for expanded professional autonomy for educators. He argues teachers should control key instructional elements—content, time on task, textbook selection, assessment methods, and reporting—which he categorizes as professional rather than administrative matters. Granting teachers similar freedoms afforded other professionals could dramatically improve instruction quality. The letter reflects Don's consistent theme that systemic constraints rather than teacher capacity limit educational quality.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-4 Palmer Park Inspired by the Detroit-based Palmer Park Preparatory Academy, a school without traditional principal hierarchies, Don… ▸ more
Inspired by the Detroit-based Palmer Park Preparatory Academy, a school without traditional principal hierarchies, Don advocates for teacher-led school management models. He references historical education innovations like the Trump Plan for differentiated staffing and Schools without Walls (Philadelphia), suggesting modern education could benefit from similar distributed leadership approaches. Don argues that teacher-led schools better address educator concerns and create less stressful, more positive work environments while genuinely prioritizing learners. His reference to visiting Detroit to observe such innovations demonstrates serious engagement with best practices.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-3 Twenty Responding to coverage of Grade 3 math difficulties, Don advocates for summer instruction programs targeting the 20… ▸ more
Responding to coverage of Grade 3 math difficulties, Don advocates for summer instruction programs targeting the 20 percent of students struggling with mathematics. He contends that timely intervention prevents cumulative learning gaps and suggests minimal-cost summer sessions could provide crucial remediation. The letter illustrates Don's commitment to equity and early intervention, arguing that preventing failure is more cost-effective than addressing compounded deficiencies later. His practical tone reflects experience with both budget constraints and student learning needs.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-2 Challenge This foundational piece proposes replacing PEI's batch graduation system with a continuous-flow credential model. Don… ▸ more
This foundational piece proposes replacing PEI's batch graduation system with a continuous-flow credential model. Don argues that students learn at different rates and should be able to challenge for credit at any time rather than waiting for cohort graduation dates. He notes that schools already have examination frameworks, assessment instruments, and processes in place twice yearly, requiring only administrative restructuring. The proposal would allow students to complete requirements flexibly through work, employment, additional coursework, or travel while potentially reducing costs and foregone earnings. Don emphasizes that achievement of standards should be the goal, not time-serving compliance.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-17 Credential Don distinguishes credentials (academic documents certifying program completion) from qualifications (demonstrated… ▸ more
Don distinguishes credentials (academic documents certifying program completion) from qualifications (demonstrated skills, knowledge, and attitudes for role performance). He notes diplomas and degrees rarely get used after earning and explores why they're issued. Don argues employment advertisements list both credentials (e.g., high school diploma) and qualifications (training, experience), and observes this distinction applies to teaching (degree = credential, teaching license = qualification). He identifies public concern about standards partly stemming from conflating these concepts, with schools awarding credential "folded papers" that public assumes represent qualifications. He argues clarifying this distinction would improve standards discourse.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-14 West Prince Don welcomes educational planning for West Prince but criticizes institution-based approaches where schools, colleges,… ▸ more
Don welcomes educational planning for West Prince but criticizes institution-based approaches where schools, colleges, and universities plan independently according to their mandates, leaving gaps. He references a 1969 PEI Teachers' Convention presentation by Dr. Patrick Watson imagining a community without schools, asking how education needs would be met. Don advocates for comprehensive community-wide educational planning identifying citizen needs rather than institutional offerings, proposing this approach for West Prince or all Islanders. He argues such planning could begin with the Department of Education or any community organization and framing it as a valuable winter project for engagement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-13 School Reports Don critiques school report cards designed for post-secondary institutions rather than employers, noting that… ▸ more
Don critiques school report cards designed for post-secondary institutions rather than employers, noting that help-wanted ads emphasize skills (problem-solving, communication, teamwork, project management) largely absent from academic transcripts. He observes schools organize instruction around disciplines while colleges/universities do likewise, creating university-focused reporting systems. Don proposes schools and employers collaborate with colleges/universities to design comprehensive report cards including both subjects and transferable skills. He argues employer engagement would be valuable even without format agreement, advancing dialogue among stakeholders about educational deliverables.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-12 Doctors Don draws parallels between healthcare and education systems, questioning whether education has equivalent to doctors,… ▸ more
Don draws parallels between healthcare and education systems, questioning whether education has equivalent to doctors, nurses, and technical specialists. He explores whether teachers function as doctors or nurses, whether principals are instructional leaders or administrators, and where specialists fit in organizational structures. Don notes healthcare has referral pathways while education appears more rigid, and proposes examining whether separate "before-school" and "after-school" educational services exist. He calls for education to adopt healthcare's "model of care" redesign approach, suggesting systematic review of how education cares for all learners throughout their lifespan.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-11 Graduate Don addresses complaints from parents about graduates' reading levels, noting both positive improvements in elementary… ▸ more
Don addresses complaints from parents about graduates' reading levels, noting both positive improvements in elementary instruction and concerns about overall performance. He examines how reading ability is measured (fluency, range, comprehension, independence, speed, vocabulary) and notes the lack of clear standards for high school graduates. Don proposes a simple standard: "In order to obtain a high school graduation diploma, a person must demonstrate the ability to read a range of printed materials with independence, fluency and ease." He argues such clarity would improve stakeholder communication and invites suggestions for better articulations.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2011 2011-1 Repairs to the rosd Don uses infrastructure metaphor to argue education needs major systemic repairs beyond incremental improvements. He… ▸ more
Don uses infrastructure metaphor to argue education needs major systemic repairs beyond incremental improvements. He identifies two critical areas: educational outcomes must be clear, unambiguous, and measurable (arguing many PEI language arts outcomes fail this test), and teacher certification should be skills-based rather than credential-based. Don notes that PEITF agreements mention methodology and management but should include diagnosis, assessment, project management, counseling, and materials selection. He argues skills-based certification would have clarified kindergarten teacher qualification debates the previous year and contends needed reforms can occur at minimal cost without operational disruption.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Dec 1, 2010 D focus on learning and teaching From December 1, 2010, Don articulates his educational philosophy by examining three variables at the learning-teaching… ▸ more
From December 1, 2010, Don articulates his educational philosophy by examining three variables at the learning-teaching interface: learners with varied readiness, teachers with unique personalities and professional skills, and circumstances (resources, scheduling, testing) largely beyond teacher control. He identifies the core improvement lever: increasing successful learning experiences for every student. He emphasizes that real improvement occurs only when the essential teacher-learner interaction improves, dismissing administrative tinkering as insufficient.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Dec 1, 2010 D School Report Cards From December 1, 2010, Don critiques traditional school report cards as communication failures. Parents want to know… ▸ more
From December 1, 2010, Don critiques traditional school report cards as communication failures. Parents want to know what children can do (reading, writing, social skills), but cards report what was taught (A in English, B in History). He questions the meaning of letter grades and their inconsistency with how performance is rated outside schools. He argues for clarity: defining what A/B/C mean and aligning school rating scales with real-world workplace standards. Improving communication is his proposed first step to improving schools.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Dec 1, 2010 D Educational improvement Dated December 1, 2010, this substantive letter distinguishes education from schooling and argues improvement must… ▸ more
Dated December 1, 2010, this substantive letter distinguishes education from schooling and argues improvement must focus on individual learning at the teacher-student interface. Don contends schools teach subjects while learners need skill development (communication, social, analytical). He critiques school grades as administrative conveniences lacking real meaning. He argues work habits should be rated on report cards and advocates allowing students to challenge courses for credit once standards are met, reducing the role of time-based progression.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Nov 10, 2010 D Education From November 10, 2010, Don addresses postsecondary funding and student attitudes. He proposes recognizing high school… ▸ more
From November 10, 2010, Don addresses postsecondary funding and student attitudes. He proposes recognizing high school graduation as significant by awarding cash prizes alongside diplomas, regardless of further study intentions. He advocates for measuring and reporting student attitudes on report cards, believing measurement drives teaching focus. His core insight—"What gets measured, gets taught"—reflects his data-driven approach to educational improvement and belief in explicitly valuing non-academic outcomes.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Sep 18, 2010 D Paying students From September 18, 2010, Don proposes a thought experiment: if school is "work," should students be paid? He questions… ▸ more
From September 18, 2010, Don proposes a thought experiment: if school is "work," should students be paid? He questions the basis for payment (attendance vs. achievement) and proposes tying compensation to accomplishments—credits earned, courses completed, diplomas awarded. He further suggests eliminating attendance requirements entirely, allowing students to challenge any course via examination with a fee, and awarding credit upon success with potential refund as reward. This radical proposal reflects his challenge-for-credit advocacy.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Sep 6, 2010 D Making and Fixing Things From September 6, 2010, Don reviews Matthew Crawford's "Shop Class as Soulcraft," noting Crawford earned a PhD in… ▸ more
From September 6, 2010, Don reviews Matthew Crawford's "Shop Class as Soulcraft," noting Crawford earned a PhD in political philosophy but operates a motorcycle repair shop. Don endorses the book's argument that tangible, hands-on work provides measurable accomplishment and problem-solving satisfaction. He recommends the work to educators, arguing practical skills and troubleshooting ability transfer to life problem-solving. This reflects his emphasis on skills-based, practical education over purely theoretical knowledge.

Nearly identical to FILE 13 (11-2). August 20, 2010 letter advocating systemic education reform, professional leadership independence from government, and public conversation on education purposes and structures. Demonstrates Don's sustained focus on governance issues and the need for broader educational vision beyond school operation.

[Duplicate of File 5] Addresses PISA findings regarding parental vs. school expectations, focusing on the teacher-learner interface as the critical intervention point.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2010 3 Teacher pay Don argues that quality teachers are underpaid and that compensation should reflect the diverse and complex work… ▸ more
Don argues that quality teachers are underpaid and that compensation should reflect the diverse and complex work teachers perform—coaching, instructing, diagnosing, counseling, assessing, and developing materials. He criticizes grid-based salary systems using credentials and years of service rather than performance and effectiveness. Don advocates for competency-based compensation reflecting actual work contribution, arguing that professional remuneration should reward excellent teachers more than average ones. He contends that education systems constrain teacher professionalism by dictating what, when, where, and how teachers work, suppressing individual creativity and accountability, and proposes that enabling teacher professionalism would increase high performance.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2010 2 Aftermarket Don addresses gaps between parental expectations and school delivery as identified in PISA results, arguing that… ▸ more
Don addresses gaps between parental expectations and school delivery as identified in PISA results, arguing that improvement requires changes at the critical teacher-learner interface. He identifies two categories of problems: those within teacher control (diagnosis, teaching techniques, communication) and those external to teachers (curriculum materials, time allocation, technology, unclear outcomes). Don emphasizes that systemic issues often create barriers even for competent teachers, and advises against blaming students for achievement gaps. He recommends comprehensive diagnosis identifying patterns of failure before implementing reforms, maintaining focus on the classroom interaction point.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
2010 D 2010 Dec 8 First steps Don proposes six low-cost, immediately implementable interventions to improve education: adding communication as a… ▸ more
Don proposes six low-cost, immediately implementable interventions to improve education: adding communication as a separate subject, publishing clear performance standards, shifting teacher licensing criteria from coursework to demonstrated skills, reviewing teaching-learning models, allowing course challenge-for-credit, and encouraging teacher-led innovation. His emphasis on minimal disruption and cost demonstrates his understanding of institutional constraints and political feasibility, positioning reform as achievable within existing budgets and structures.

Document format version of the High School for the Arts proposal letter. Glendenning congratulates young artists, references 30 similar schools across Canada, and advocates for a collaborative governance model involving government, community, private sector, and educational institutions to establish arts training facilities on closed school properties.

Glendenning argues the arts contribute significantly to quality of life and economic development, and suggests a collaborative public-private model similar to other provincial specialty schools.

Comprehensive bibliography of selected references on Outcome-Based Education, compiled from internet sources. Includes academic publications, institutional guides, and policy documents on OBE theory and practice. Key works include Kenny and Desmarais's guide to developing learning outcomes at University of Guelph (2007) and South African Management Development Institute materials. Reflects research by Brockmann and others on OBE implementation in higher education institutions including University of Newcastle and University of Guelph.

2005 2005-5 OECD [Identical content to File 2] Read · Download
2004 2004- 7 Skill training Undated working draft establishing educational definitions and exploring skill training components. Don outlines… ▸ more
Undated working draft establishing educational definitions and exploring skill training components. Don outlines distinctions between learning, education, teaching, and "good education," then discusses how educational offerings should serve two purposes: personal knowledge development and community benefit. References Oregon's "life roles" framework (individual, citizen, student, family member, consumer, employer) as a useful planning model. Raises concerns about curriculum context disconnection from learners' real circumstances and advocates for advisor roles analogous to doctors and lawyers.

A proposal document for a training program to certify facilitators of "Handle With Care," a program promoting mental health and early childhood development. Glendenning outlines program history (initiated 2002), structure built on building blocks of trust, self-esteem, emotional expression, and relationships, and workshop logistics for training facilitators in PEI as part of a national initiative.

2000 2000-12-16 y-34 Lengthy letter to the Charlottetown Guardian arguing against automatic school closures due to weather. Glendenning… ▸ more
Lengthy letter to the Charlottetown Guardian arguing against automatic school closures due to weather. Glendenning distinguishes between schooling and education, emphasizing individual responsibility for learning. He proposes keeping facilities open, allowing teachers and parents individual decision-making authority, and rejecting administrative convenience as rationale for closure.

2000 2000-1-34 Don challenges the assumption that school closures due to weather are necessary, arguing instead that schools should… ▸ more
Don challenges the assumption that school closures due to weather are necessary, arguing instead that schools should remain open with participation being a choice. He distinguishes between schooling and education, noting that groups don't learn—individuals do. The piece proposes that schools remain available as resources, teachers decide individually whether to attend, students/parents choose daily attendance, and bus operators determine route safety. Don criticizes the administrative convenience of closures as pedagogically disruptive and advocates for distributed decision-making rather than blanket institutional closures.
BIOGRAPHICAL

2000 11-E Engagement-notes Highlight Detailed notes on public engagement in education addressing institutional-citizen disengagement. Discusses widely… ▸ more
Detailed notes on public engagement in education addressing institutional-citizen disengagement. Discusses widely recognized importance of quality education to individual and societal futures, but acknowledges education systems inadequately preparing students for current needs. Documents calls for public engagement in educational development and delivery. Analyzes divide between education service providers and users, noting public cynicism about consultation processes. Examines institutional-citizen estrangement evidenced by urban occupations. Provides examples of public engagement models: Kentucky's education reform, Birmingham University's public engagement, Manhattan's Lower Manhattan future discussions. Proposes engagement requires three components: information, discussion, policy-making. Advocates enhanced public participation in PEI education. - **Key People**: Donald Glendenning (author/analyst), Islanders engaged in education discussions - **Key Organizations**: State of Kentucky, Birmingham University, UNICEF (2000 report) - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Donald's engagement with critical education policy issues, institutional reform, and public participation in governance.

Read · Download

2000 Quality Characteristics of a Quality- Education System Don's summary of quality education characteristics drawn from 2000 UNICEF report supplemented with OECD and UNESCO… ▸ more
Don's summary of quality education characteristics drawn from 2000 UNICEF report supplemented with OECD and UNESCO sources. Key elements: healthy, nourished learners; safe, respectful environments; relevant content for modern society; outcomes linked to personal/community objectives; learner-focused support; timely, independent information; professional, autonomous, accountable teachers. Don argues these characteristics, with their focus on learner and learning, provide a consistent framework for decision-making at all educational levels. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author); UNICEF; OECD; UNESCO - **Key Organizations**: UNICEF, OECD, UNESCO - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Articulates Don's philosophy of quality education; relevant to institutional leadership values

A shorter, refined glossary from November 1998 containing eight key definitions (CBE, Competence, Competency, Outcome, Performance, Performance assessment, Performance standard, Rating Scale, Standard, Task). This version appears to be a condensed, perhaps more practical reference that Don personally refined, as evidenced by his signature and date.

1997 1997-1 Challenge Formatted version of the 1997 Journal Pioneer letter on challenge for credit. Glendenning argues that educational… ▸ more
Formatted version of the 1997 Journal Pioneer letter on challenge for credit. Glendenning argues that educational institutions should enable learners to demonstrate competency through examination rather than course attendance, citing language placement testing as precedent. He envisions this approach expanding to all educational levels including arts degrees.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
1997 1997 06 13 Letter to the Editor of Moncton Times (June 13, 1997) from Don Glendenning addressing school closings in Maritime… ▸ more
Letter to the Editor of Moncton Times (June 13, 1997) from Don Glendenning addressing school closings in Maritime communities. Don critiques government plans to close small schools, arguing the closure debate focuses on confrontation and money rather than learning quality. He challenges the assumption that the current educational delivery model is the only viable option, suggesting governments pursue alternative delivery models. Don proposes schools use site-based management to examine operational efficiencies, asking principals to explore cost-saving measures working with teachers and communities. He questions whether small schools using different approaches might deliver quality education cost-effectively compared to large schools, advocating for innovative solutions before accepting closures.
REFERENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Oct 8, 1996 1 Atlantic Don's first published letter to the Guardian (October 8, 1996) responding to an Atlantic Canada education study,… ▸ more
Don's first published letter to the Guardian (October 8, 1996) responding to an Atlantic Canada education study, commending its timeliness while questioning its scope. He advocates for schools to address three dimensions: citizenship, work preparation, and further education, noting the study emphasized only academic achievement. Critiques the apparent abandonment of schools' responsibility in work preparation and calls for reassessment of this role. Questions whether data on technology course participation exists and challenges statistics about student destinations beyond graduation, arguing that tracking the 70% not attending university would improve program planning. Demonstrates his early emphasis on comprehensive education addressing multiple student pathways rather than university-only focus.

1996 Contents Table of contents for "The Glendenning Letters" manuscript documenting Don's published letters to editors from… ▸ more
Table of contents for "The Glendenning Letters" manuscript documenting Don's published letters to editors from 1996-2014. The extensive list shows 62 published letters organized chronologically by year, covering topics including education in Atlantic Canada, labour training, school closings, bullying, funding, graduation requirements, OECD reports, teacher pay, curriculum standards, reading clinics, skills development, and education governance. The breadth of topics demonstrates decades of sustained engagement with education policy issues and public advocacy through editorial correspondence.

1994 Graduates of the keyboard campus - The Globe and Mail Ira Nayman's article examining online education through his experience as first online graduate student (1994-1996)… ▸ more
Ira Nayman's article examining online education through his experience as first online graduate student (1994-1996) under Paul Levinson at New School for Social Research. Discusses advantages of online learning: cost-effectiveness, accessibility for working adults and disabled students, inversion of student-teacher roles requiring active participation, and flexibility. Compares online education structures to in-person teaching, noting that online classes shift from teacher-centered to student-centered communication. Warns against scaling online education without maintaining quality through careful course design.

1994 00 Discussion Masthead Highlight Occasional paper No. 1 examining charter schools in Canada, specifically Alberta's experience. Provides historical… ▸ more
Occasional paper No. 1 examining charter schools in Canada, specifically Alberta's experience. Provides historical context (legislation passed 1994), operational characteristics, and comparative analysis between supporters and opponents. Notes 22 charter schools operated by 13 authorities in Alberta, addressing perceived inflexibility in traditional public education. Presents balanced conclusions that charter schools are neither panacea nor disaster, provide viable alternatives, but may not create competitive improvements across entire systems. Published by Education 20/20 Inc. (Charlottetown, PEI). - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Alberta schools, provincial government - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, PUBLICATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Don's consulting work on education policy and his capacity to synthesize complex educational issues
ADMINISTRATIVE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
1991 Mission statement Don's mission statement for "Education 20/20," an occasional newsletter addressing education at all levels, directed to… ▸ more
Don's mission statement for "Education 20/20," an occasional newsletter addressing education at all levels, directed to the general public. He opens with John Dewey's principle: "Relate the school to life, and all studies are of necessity correlated." Don frames education around six life roles (Oregon Education Act 1991) and argues schools should prepare students for acceptable performance in each role. He emphasizes that the clearer schools specify exit performance expectations, the more likely learners achieve them. Schools should look to communities—not disciplines—when planning programs. Don values schools as safe environments for experimentation while questioning society's clarity about educational expectations.

1990 Abt Education and Schooling@2014-11-08T04;06;07 A comprehensive essay distinguishing between education and schooling, defining education as any experience with… ▸ more
A comprehensive essay distinguishing between education and schooling, defining education as any experience with formative effect on attitudes, knowledge, or skills. Drawing on the Oregon 1990 life roles framework, Don argues for lifelong learning beyond formal schooling and discusses the five levels of educational achievement. Reflects his philosophical approach to human development and institutional leadership.

1990 PEI Purposes (old version) PEI Department of Education's official education philosophy and goals adopted in 1990, documenting the stated purpose:… ▸ more
PEI Department of Education's official education philosophy and goals adopted in 1990, documenting the stated purpose: providing child development so students take meaningful place in society. The document outlines 13 educational goals including critical thinking, literacy, science understanding, cultural appreciation, self-worth, workplace skills, mental/physical health, bilingualism, and gender equity. Reflects the provincial educational framework that Don Glendenning often referenced and critiqued in his work with Education 20/20.

1990 11 xx Learning support system Educational framework document titled "Elements of a Learning Support System" from Education Series. Presents… ▸ more
Educational framework document titled "Elements of a Learning Support System" from Education Series. Presents comprehensive learning support model viewing every person as lifelong learner on "road of life" from birth to death. Outlines five life roles: individual, learner, producer, citizen, consumer, family member (Oregon Educational Act, 1990). Defines learning as behavior change across three domains: attitudes (affective), skills (psychomotor), and knowledge (cognitive). Identifies conditions needed: wellness (physical, mental, emotional, social) and opportunity (transportation, facilities, personal funds, advocate). Lists support elements: information (public health-style resources), professional advice (counseling, assessment, referral, advocacy), instruction (formal, tutoring, coaching), recognition (credit, credentials, feedback), and engagement (school culture, specialists, role models, funding). - **Key People**: Not specified - **Key Organizations**: Oregon Educational Act (1990 reference) - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Donald's comprehensive, holistic approach to education supporting the whole person across lifespan, reflecting his educational philosophy and practical frameworks for educational support.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
1989 D-18 Management problem Glendenning asserts that PEI's educational challenges are fundamentally management problems, not resource problems—more… ▸ more
Glendenning asserts that PEI's educational challenges are fundamentally management problems, not resource problems—more teachers, higher salaries, or technology won't resolve them. He applies organizational principles to education: "form follows function," requiring functional analysis and organizational alignment. He identifies education's functions as governance, financing, delivery, human resources, and information. The Department lacks clear, measurable purpose—its 1989 philosophy statement is outdated with unmeasurable goals. Leadership needs a short, clear statement repeated consistently. Additionally, the Department masquerades as serving "education" while focusing solely on schooling, limiting students to opportunities it conceives and manages rather than fostering broader learning opportunities.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
1988 Education Act Comparative analysis document examining definitions of "education" and "school" from PEI's Education Act across… ▸ more
Comparative analysis document examining definitions of "education" and "school" from PEI's Education Act across different time periods (1988, 2024). Documents the evolution and consistency of legislative definitions, noting that "education" itself is not defined in the Act while "school" is described as a structured learning environment through which education programs are offered by an education authority. This gap in defining the core concept is significant to Don's larger critique.

Reflects Glendenning's evidence-based approach to education policy, including historical reference to his 1978 collaboration on Practical Mathematics.

1970 20 - Future of schools@2014-09-18T08;30;46 Newsletter article (Open Education No. 20) by Editor Don Glendenning reflecting on the future of schools, prompted by… ▸ more
Newsletter article (Open Education No. 20) by Editor Don Glendenning reflecting on the future of schools, prompted by remembering Patrick Watson's 1970 conference presentation about a community without schools. He argues that schools' traditional role as certifiers and knowledge providers is being challenged by social promotion, online learning, and employer reliance on assessment centers rather than diplomas.
