1969 2 Intro Highlight Don's personal introduction explaining his unique educational trajectory—a "sandwich education" spanning 20 years… ▸ more
Don's personal introduction explaining his unique educational trajectory—a "sandwich education" spanning 20 years combining teaching and study. He details his credentials as elementary/secondary teacher, principal, teacher trainer, and federal training specialist, alongside advanced degrees. He credits this diverse background as preparation for founding Holland College in 1969. The piece articulates his conviction that educational change must come from public demand rather than from within the system. He published his first Guardian letter in 1995 and compiled approximately 62 published letters over 18 years, viewing this collection as stimulus for public discussion and debate about educational reform. Emphasizes community engagement and citizen demand as catalysts for systemic change.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
1969 D-4 Student assessment Analysis of student assessment purposes based on Robert Paul Wolff's 1969 framework identifying three functions:… ▸ more
Analysis of student assessment purposes based on Robert Paul Wolff's 1969 framework identifying three functions: Formative criticism for designing learning strategies and feedback; Evaluation establishing achievement levels (criterion-referenced); and Ranking showing student comparison. Glendenning argues formative assessment is legitimate school work but ranking and grading represent conflict of interest for teachers. Proposes separating teaching and ranking functions like sports do with coaches and referees, suggesting schools should not handle ranking/grading of their own students. - **Key People**: Robert Paul Wolff (cited), Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Core theme of Glendenning's educational philosophy on separation of teaching and assessment
CORRESPONDENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
1960 OBE Outcome Based Educatio1-closson Comprehensive analysis of Outcome-Based Education written by Don Closson. Reviews historical context of education… ▸ more
Comprehensive analysis of Outcome-Based Education written by Don Closson. Reviews historical context of education reform, noting that despite 225% spending increases since 1960, SAT scores fell 8%. Explains OBE philosophy that "all students can learn and succeed, but not on the same day or in the same way." Contrasts traditional content-based curricula with OBE's focus on student success and customized learning. Details implementation: establishing desired outcomes, designing learning experiences, testing mastery, and remediation. Discusses "Transitional" vs. "Transformational" OBE—the latter more controversial as it subordinates traditional content to key concepts and processes. Addresses debates about learner outcomes, worldview implications, and concerns about values-based education objectives.
REFERENCE

1933 02 Eight year study @2015-03-28T02;34;05 Occasional Paper No. 2 examining Ralph Tyler's Eight Year Study (1933-1941) demonstrating that innovative high school… ▸ more
Occasional Paper No. 2 examining Ralph Tyler's Eight Year Study (1933-1941) demonstrating that innovative high school curricula organized around student learning principles produced college graduates with superior outcomes. Glendenning uses this historical precedent to support his arguments for educational flexibility, outcome-based learning, and autonomy from rigid subject requirements, noting the study's findings deserved greater attention in educational reform.
EDUCATION INSTITUTIONAL PROFESSIONAL REFERENCE

1933 D-1 Eight year study 2 An analysis of Ralph Tyler's landmark Eight Year Study (1933-1941) at Ohio State University examining innovative high… ▸ more
An analysis of Ralph Tyler's landmark Eight Year Study (1933-1941) at Ohio State University examining innovative high schools freed from conventional college-preparatory requirements. The study found graduates from these 30 innovative schools outperformed comparison groups in critical thinking, intellectual curiosity, and demonstrated greater resourcefulness. Glendenning reflects on why this influential study did not receive broader attention.

1933 02 Eight year study 2 @2015-03-22T12;29;01 An occasional paper examining the Eight Year Study (1933-1941) led by Ralph Tyler, which challenged conventional high… ▸ more
An occasional paper examining the Eight Year Study (1933-1941) led by Ralph Tyler, which challenged conventional high school requirements and found that graduates from progressive schools outperformed peers in college. Glendenning discusses the study's findings on intellectual curiosity and resourcefulness, lamenting that the results were overshadowed by WWII and deserved more attention.

1933 Z 00 Eight year study An occasional paper analyzing Ralph Tyler's landmark Eight Year Study (1933-1941), which freed schools from rigid… ▸ more
An occasional paper analyzing Ralph Tyler's landmark Eight Year Study (1933-1941), which freed schools from rigid college-prep curricula and followed students through college. Don highlights the study's findings that innovative, learner-centered schools produced graduates with superior critical thinking, curiosity, resourcefulness, and civic engagement, using this as evidence supporting his education reform agenda.

1933 24 Eight Year Highlight Glendenning discusses the Eight Year Study (1933-1941), experimental program allowing 30 secondary schools autonomy in… ▸ more
Glendenning discusses the Eight Year Study (1933-1941), experimental program allowing 30 secondary schools autonomy in curriculum design around "problems of living." Study found no significant difference in college achievement between experimental and traditional schools, but experimental students succeeded better in other college life aspects. Glendenning supports findings based on experience; critiques excessive course/grade/credential requirements as impediments to quality education. Includes Excellence Award call ($2,500 recognition for K-12 schools demonstrating engagement) and basic skills assessment services listing (Holland College, Workplace Learning PEI, College Acadie IPE, Joanne McCabe). - **Key People**: Goodlad (epigraph), Joanne McCabe - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Holland College, UPEI, College Acadie IPE, Workplace Learning PEI - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Reveals Glendenning's grounding in progressive educational history and his use of research to validate alternative approaches to schooling.

1924 5 Meaning Highlight Don's comprehensive examination of education definitions from literature and international sources, emphasizing that… ▸ more
Don's comprehensive examination of education definitions from literature and international sources, emphasizing that education is a service, not a product. He notes the critical shift in PEI's 1924 Education Act from "education" to "school," marking a dangerous narrowing at a time when education's importance is growing. Discusses how education happens across all life roles and contexts, advocating for conceptual clarity.

French newsletter (No. 65, date unspecified) celebrating century of federal technical education leadership. Don traces Canadian technical training from William Lyon Mackenzie's 1912 Industrial Education Commission through post-WWII success. Notes 1960s federal funding for secondary schools and community colleges. Highlights Bluefield High School receiving Education 20/20 Excellence Award for "Ag for Life" collaborative initiative involving agriculture, hospitality, and culinary programs with 200+ evening meal attendees. Credits teachers Jason Campbell, Emily Perry, and Terry Nabuurs.

Undated D-1 Whither bound A letter to editors (Charlottetown Guardian, Journal Pioneer) prompted by a 1950s memory of a booklet titled "Whither… ▸ more
A letter to editors (Charlottetown Guardian, Journal Pioneer) prompted by a 1950s memory of a booklet titled "Whither Bound?" in a landlady's home at an American university. Don questions PEI's educational direction, noting the $600 million government investment lacks clear purpose. He advocates for the state to clarify why it educates citizens, how it should do so, and who determines when someone is educated. He emphasizes learning as behavioral change distinct from school attendance and calls for public conversation on education.

Undated D-3 who came first-2 Don reflects on his one-room schoolhouse experience with Christmas and June closing ceremonies where exam results were… ▸ more
Don reflects on his one-room schoolhouse experience with Christmas and June closing ceremonies where exam results were publicly posted on blackboards. He questions the purpose of ranking students and argues that assessment should improve teaching-learning, not rank performance. He acknowledges not being against awards but believes student ranking interferes with teaching and may not serve educational purposes as supported by literature.

Undated D-5 Education services A blog post identifying educators as service providers with seven key service categories. Don argues education occurs… ▸ more
A blog post identifying educators as service providers with seven key service categories. Don argues education occurs anywhere (home, church, traveling, school) and schools are purpose-built facilities. He raises post-Covid questions about school operations and suggests considering the health model where doctors (not administrators) control service selection, reflecting his ongoing interest in improving institutional accountability.

Undated D-5 Right to education A blog post (Blog D-5) responding to "People for Education," an Ontario organization launching a Canada-wide initiative… ▸ more
A blog post (Blog D-5) responding to "People for Education," an Ontario organization launching a Canada-wide initiative to define young Canadians' education rights. Don proposes that rather than mandating school attendance until age 18, provinces could require demonstrated education competencies (literacy Level 3, numeracy, self-care, interpersonal relations, work entry) before citizens can own cars or open bank accounts, applying the six life roles model.

Foundational chapter from Don's education work defining education systems comprehensively. Outlines key operating beliefs, education branches (Science, Math, Arts, Technology, Social Science), provider roles, learner needs, and emerging changes (micro-credentials, autonomy, learner tracking). Includes detailed system framework diagrams and recommendations for organizational structure at provincial and institutional levels.

Undated Assessment Don's detailed educational philosophy on assessment, drawing on Wolff's framework distinguishing formative assessment… ▸ more
Don's detailed educational philosophy on assessment, drawing on Wolff's framework distinguishing formative assessment (feedback), summative evaluation (achievement levels), and ranking (comparative measurement). Argues assessment and grading serve different functions and should be separated, with ranking not constituting an education function but rather quality assurance.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 1-3-8-6 Assessment Proposes independent assessment service to certify proficiency in selected subjects and fields. Provides historical… ▸ more
Proposes independent assessment service to certify proficiency in selected subjects and fields. Provides historical context tracing grading practices from guild-degree systems through Yale College (1785) adoption of numerical grades. Argues that modern schools serve broader social functions beyond academics, creating tension with community expectations and declining value of diplomas. Central thesis: teaching and student ranking are conflicting functions that should be separated. Details characteristics of proposed service: identify subject levels, certify applicants, serve individuals and organizations, remain independent of government, assess any age, issue certificates (not credentials), employ outcomes-based methods. Lists 13 potential committee members. - **Key People**: Regis Duffy, Linda Lawlor, Joan MacDonald, Steve McQuaid, Tess Miller, Bill Whelan, Tom Connor - **Key Organizations**: None specifically named beyond general education sector - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Don's committee-building skills and systematic approach to education reform initiatives.
BIOGRAPHICAL

Undated 2 Assessment Duplicate of File 3, proposing independent assessment service. Includes historical context on grading practices from… ▸ more
Duplicate of File 3, proposing independent assessment service. Includes historical context on grading practices from guild-degree systems through Yale College (1785) and modern education. Central argument: teaching and ranking functions are inherently conflicting. Proposes independent assessment service with 10+ specific characteristics including independence from government/institutions, age-irrelevance, outcomes-based methodology. Lists benefits and identifies existing models in apprenticeship, swimming, and music. Includes 13 potential committee members. - **Key People**: Regis Duffy, Linda Lawlor, Joan MacDonald, Steve McQuaid, Tess Miller, Bill Whelan, Tom Connor - **Key Organizations**: None specifically named - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Duplicate content; demonstrates persistent focus on this reform initiative.

Undated 1-3-8-2 Math levels A proposal by Education 20/20 Inc. addressing the limitations of traditional grade-level assessment systems in… ▸ more
A proposal by Education 20/20 Inc. addressing the limitations of traditional grade-level assessment systems in education. The document proposes establishing nationally recognized proficiency levels in mathematics, separating teaching and assessment functions. It argues that age and formal education should not be sole criteria for achievement levels and proposes an independent certification body to assess individual mathematical proficiency. The proposal references existing models like the Apprenticeship Red Seal program and Canadian Red Cross Swim Program as precedents for recognized standards across jurisdictions. - **Key People**: None specifically named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Apprenticeship Red Seal program, Canadian Red Cross, Royal Canadian Conservatory of Music - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL, ADMINISTRATIVE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Don's continued work on educational innovation and assessment reform after his Holland College presidency, showing sustained engagement with education policy development.

Employer survey instrument to assess which of 56 employability skills are important when hiring new employees. Uses a "Have/Like to Have" rating scale across fundamental skills, personal management skills, and teamwork skills categories. Designed to capture employer preferences for entry-level positions by sector. Notes indicate it should be revised to use three-column format: "Must Know," "Should Know," "Nice to Know." Demonstrates Education 20/20's methodical approach to gathering employer input on workforce readiness. - **Key People**: Tiffany (internal contact for formatting) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Conference Board of Canada - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL, ADMINISTRATIVE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's systematic approach to educational assessment and employer engagement in curriculum development.

Undated Job seeker Alpha Self-assessment survey for job seekers to identify current employability skills and those they wish to develop. Uses a… ▸ more
Self-assessment survey for job seekers to identify current employability skills and those they wish to develop. Uses a "Have/Like to Have" two-column format across all 56 Conference Board of Canada skills. Accompanies employer surveys as part of Education 20/20's comprehensive approach to understanding skills gaps and development needs from both demand (employer) and supply (worker) perspectives. The twin surveys form the basis for community employability profiling and targeted skill development interventions. - **Key People**: None specifically - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Conference Board of Canada - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Don's dual-perspective approach to workforce development, engaging both employers and job seekers in skills assessment.

Undated Math Stages Education 20/20 proposal to develop math ladder and establish independent assessment service for certification of… ▸ more
Education 20/20 proposal to develop math ladder and establish independent assessment service for certification of mathematics performance levels. Addresses concerns about PEI graduates lacking basic skills for post-secondary or employment, inadequate report cards and diplomas, and employer difficulty in assessing applicant competency. Proposes fee-based independent testing service (open to any age, voluntary, no school credit) that provides certificate of achievement level. Outlines characteristics: independent, individual-based, results confidential, optional employer/school notification. Includes philosophical framework on competency-based assessment and institutional coordination. Service model emphasizes agency and independence. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., PEI Literacy Alliance - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM-HIGH - Demonstrates Don's commitment to independent assessment, institutional bridging, and practical solutions to education-employment connection.

Proposal 20-01 for establishing certification and testing services in mathematics. Proposal 1 calls for developing a comprehensive list of math competencies, establishing identifiable achievement levels, and offering testing/qualification service on a fee-for-service basis, independent, open to individuals and companies, with results available to test-takers and, on request, employers. Proposal 20-04 for mathematics assessment and certification service. Offers math assessment on fee-for-service basis, independent operation, open to companies (for employee testing) and individuals of any age, by application. No school credit offered, but test-takers informed of achievement level attained. On request, records forwarded to employers. Service includes comprehensive competency list development and identifiable achievement level establishment. - **Key People**: Not named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows systematic approach to educational assessment and competency measurement

Undated 20-05 Math mountain Highlight Detailed proposal for "Math Mountain" (alternative name for Math Ladder) to help more students reach higher mathematics… ▸ more
Detailed proposal for "Math Mountain" (alternative name for Math Ladder) to help more students reach higher mathematics levels. Identifies school system deficiencies: ranking students over assessing levels, conflict between teaching and ranking roles, lack of identified math levels, rejection of difficulty-based grouping, and transcripts that don't identify achievement levels. Proposes undertaking competency/outcomes analysis, establishing levels (similar to music/skating ratings), developing rating scales and benchmarks, and creating independent math testing service. Service would be individual-based, voluntary, self-supporting, fee-for-service, and open to any age without school credit. Elements include information/advice, assessment, instruction, tutoring, clubs, and competitions. Includes conditions for participation, pilot project ideas, and funding approaches involving fundraising, Canadian Math Society, and local sponsors. Identifies potential sponsors including engineers. - **Key People**: Not named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Canadian Mathematics Society, Holland College, Teachers PEI (TPEI) - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Represents comprehensive, well-developed vision for transforming mathematics education with clear philosophical grounding

Undated 3-4-3-C Windsor proposal docx Another iteration of the Windsor Foundation proposal, now framed as the "Preparedness Initiative." Education 20/20 Inc.… ▸ more
Another iteration of the Windsor Foundation proposal, now framed as the "Preparedness Initiative." Education 20/20 Inc. addresses the foundational issue of low basic education skills in youth, evidenced by PISA results, CFPEI youth surveys, and presentations to the PEI Legislative Assembly. Proposes engaging stakeholders to narrow the preparedness gap for post-secondary study and employment. Identifies three core problems: educational silos (separate systems with poor coordination), curriculum alignment issues, and system inflexibility. Proposes establishing common curriculum maps and reducing inter-institutional fragmentation. Features include creating shared learning maps, single analysis with multiple profiles, separating teaching from assessment functions, and fostering collaborative teacher teams. DACUM methodology and Bloom's taxonomy referenced throughout. - **Key People**: Donald Glendenning, steering committee members - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Windsor Foundation, PEI Department of Education, Holland College, Community Foundation of PEI - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, CORRESPONDENCE, PROPOSAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Glendenning's persistent focus on education quality and systemic improvement in PEI.

Community-based engagement initiative to improve education quality through stronger school-community connections. Identifies communication gaps between schools and communities revealed through Education 20/20 workshops. Proposes providing information, facilitating parent engagement sessions, teaching best practices, and supporting community groups. Activities include engagement awards ($2,500 per award), electronic newsletters with volunteer coordinators, occasional papers (electronic, no charge), videos/webinars (8-video learning series), media releases, social media activities, public presentations, speaker lists, and surveys. A brief proposal to link pre-service teachers with parents through an information-sharing project focused on reading. Objectives include providing parents with relevant information and connecting teachers-in-training with parents. Mathematics Gap proposal addressing flawed education organization and proposing remedies. Educational definitions document for Education 20/20 Inc. materials. Defines core education-related terms: education (experiences with formative effect on thinking, feeling, acting), schooling (teacher-directed learning), purpose of education (gaining lifelong skills and attitudes), role of schools (developing potential and community skills), learning, teaching, learner, and standards. Document serves as philosophical framework for organization's quality education principles. Undated 2 Definitions Document establishing key definitions for Education 20/20's educational philosophy. Defines education as "any… ▸ more
Document establishing key definitions for Education 20/20's educational philosophy. Defines education as "any experience that has a formative effect on the way we feel, think or act." Provides parallel definitions for schooling, learning, teaching, and related concepts. Emphasizes education's purpose in helping people gain attitudes and skills for life, and schools' role in developing full potential and community skills. Defines standards as measurable performance levels. Reflects comprehensive approach to education beyond traditional schooling. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's educational philosophy and involvement in Education 20/20's conceptual framework

Undated 00 Learning path Media release announcing Education 20/20's initiative to diagram and understand the learning path. Reports that 22… ▸ more
Media release announcing Education 20/20's initiative to diagram and understand the learning path. Reports that 22 Islanders (parents, business community, educators) met at Haviland Club to discuss a draft learning path model. Describes learning path concept as visual representation of learning as process, developed from learner perspectives and input. Notes that learners identified helpful support elements including information, encouragement, practice, feedback, self-study materials, instruction, and self-analysis. Acknowledges challenge of accommodating different learning styles and paces. Details Education 20/20's intention to refine model by incorporating affective domain learning, learner interests, discovery learning, and motivation. Plans to distribute findings via newsletter and website. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (contact) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Haviland Club - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT, SPEECH - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Don's innovative approach to understanding and visualizing the learning process; core educational research initiative
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Eight year study Media release on Eight Year Study (1930s-1940s US research on high schools). Study followed students from 30 secondary… ▸ more
Media release on Eight Year Study (1930s-1940s US research on high schools). Study followed students from 30 secondary schools (public and private) through four years of college with 250 colleges suspending normal entrance requirements. Found students from non-traditional programs performed as well or better in college than traditional-program graduates. Study concluded music was only subject where high school coursework difference mattered. Glendenning advocates examining study findings as many Canadian high schools remain traditional. Notes study recently resurfaced in New York Times. Education 20/20 provides description and references on website. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Glendenning's interest in historical education research supporting flexible, non-traditional learning approaches
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download

Announcement of Education 20/20 presentation by Dave Cormier on "learning is a messy business" at Stratford Town Hall, November 25, 6:30 pm. Cormier is educational activist, researcher, and Project Lead for Student Relations Management at UPEI. Published on open education, Rhizomatic Learning, MOOCs, technology impact on higher education. Travels internationally (USA, Spain, Fiji, India) promoting educational change. Glendenning notes presentation timely given expected PEI educational changes. Session open to public. Contact information and Education 20/20 address provided at end. - **Key People**: Dave Cormier, Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., University of Prince Edward Island - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Glendenning's curation of cutting-edge educational thought and commitment to public dialogue on education innovation

Undated D- quality Education Comparative framework distinguishing between characteristics of quality education systems and school systems. Education… ▸ more
Comparative framework distinguishing between characteristics of quality education systems and school systems. Education system requires: accountability, choice, relevant content, learner-centered approach, independent information access, and accommodation of all learners. School system adds: autonomy, outcome-based focus. Reflects philosophical approach to educational structure. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: None named - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: LOW - Abstract educational philosophy with no personal content.

Undated 21 Improving achievement in Math Glendenning proposes solutions for improving mathematics achievement: establish math ladder based on subject difficulty… ▸ more
Glendenning proposes solutions for improving mathematics achievement: establish math ladder based on subject difficulty rather than age level; develop common outcomes across public schools, Holland College, and UPEI; create standardized math testing center (modeled on Royal Conservatory of Music); provide students with outcome lists for self-tracking; report granular achievement data per outcome. Includes volunteer call for newsletter translation. - **Key People**: Jose Mujica (epigraph), Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Holland College, UPEI, Royal Conservatory of Music - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Concrete example of Glendenning's practical problem-solving approach and institutional collaboration vision across PEI's post-secondary sector.

Undated 25 Full capacity Glendenning critiques "full potential" language as incomplete without specifying what potential becomes. Notes debate… ▸ more
Glendenning critiques "full potential" language as incomplete without specifying what potential becomes. Notes debate over education's purpose (preparation for next level vs. work preparation vs. community improvement). Proposes "life-roles" framework: individuals navigate multiple roles (learner, individual, consumer, producer, citizen, family member) along life's trajectory. Education prepares for, helps cope with, and enables contribution to events encountered in these roles. Integrates OECD perspectives on community improvement. - **Key People**: Glendenning (author), OECD (reference) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., OECD - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Presents Glendenning's mature educational philosophy integrating life-course perspective and multiple social roles.

Undated D 00 Alignment Article using vehicle alignment metaphor to discuss education system alignment. Identifies four alignment areas to… ▸ more
Article using vehicle alignment metaphor to discuss education system alignment. Identifies four alignment areas to check: relevance of outcomes to life needs, clear assessment criteria, outcomes reflecting basis for reporting, willingness to adjust time as needed. Addresses school principals as instructional leaders with authority to adjust variables. Provides guidance for parents if children struggle: review outcomes, check report cards for alignment, request assessment criteria, discuss additional study time. References "learning path" consultation with students about helpful study supports. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Practical guidance reflecting Don's systematic approach to educational alignment and parent engagement

Undated D-2 Qualifications Glendenning explores the distinction between credentials and qualifications in education. He argues that credentials… ▸ more
Glendenning explores the distinction between credentials and qualifications in education. He argues that credentials (diplomas, degrees) document completion of studies, while qualifications represent actual skills and competencies. Glendenning advocates for separating credentialling from qualification assessment, suggesting employers should focus on competencies rather than paper credentials. He proposes independent certification bodies to assess qualifications, particularly relevant for immigrant workers seeking employment in Canada. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Reflects Glendenning's philosophical stance on education reform and his concern for practical skill assessment over traditional credentials.
CORRESPONDENCE

Undated D-30 Recent reading Glendenning curates media references on education under "Media scan," citing Washington Post account of teachers… ▸ more
Glendenning curates media references on education under "Media scan," citing Washington Post account of teachers meeting the President, emphasizing nothing is wrong with kids but rather about teaching quality and teacher autonomy. References Learning Shore article on school reform stressing teacher autonomy, and New Zealand Herald study showing half of NZ children inadequately prepared for school. Notes the key is parent-teacher communication and schools adjusting to children rather than demanding children be "ready for school." Comments on PEI education issues: autonomy importance, need for educator-public dialogue, and proposes graduate education students work with principals on organizational design. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning, Carla Thompson - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Washington Post, Education Review Office (NZ), English Language School Board (PEI) - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, CORRESPONDENCE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Reflects his engagement with educational thought and local education policy.

Undated D-31 Math better in Quebec Glendenning analyzes PEI vs. Quebec math performance through PISA (Program for International Student Assessment) data.… ▸ more
Glendenning analyzes PEI vs. Quebec math performance through PISA (Program for International Student Assessment) data. Notes Canadian math scores generally fell except in Quebec. Attributes Quebec success to formal math instruction, increased teacher quality, and classroom technology. Compares curricula: Quebec based on skills/arithmetic-algebra vs. PEI based on outcomes/number-patterns-shapes-probability. Asks readers which model Grade 9 students prefer. Lists upcoming Education 20/20 presentations on curriculum development, Adult Basic Education "Bridging the Gap," and "Handle with Care" parenting program. Invites readers' views on education's purpose. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning, Derek McEwen, Gerry Seaward, Thomas B. Gregory - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Holland College - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates comparative educational analysis and focus on improving student outcomes.

Undated D-35 Qualifications-1 Article examining "achievement levels" and the dual meaning of "Grade" in schools - both as age-based cohort grouping… ▸ more
Article examining "achievement levels" and the dual meaning of "Grade" in schools - both as age-based cohort grouping and as achievement level. Notes students learn at different rates creating gaps of 4-8 years within an age group, causing boredom for advanced students and discouragement for struggling learners. Proposes replacing "Grade" terminology with "Level" allowing flexible subject-level combinations (e.g., Grade 11 student taking Level 7 Math, Level 4 Physics, Level 6 Literature). Cites International Baccalaureate program and Red Cross swimming levels as models. Announces film screening and discusses basic skills exploration findings. - **Key People**: Fiona MacDonald (quoted), Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., International Baccalaureate program, Canadian Red Cross - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates innovative thinking about educational structures and assessment
CORRESPONDENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-4 Full capacity Philosophical piece on education's purpose. Questions the common phrase that education should help people develop their… ▸ more
Philosophical piece on education's purpose. Questions the common phrase that education should help people develop their "full potential." Argues the concept is incomplete without defining what "something" people should become. Rejects traditional views that education prepares for next educational level or work. Cites OECD position that schools should help students maintain and improve their communities. Proposes "life-roles" perspective: education prepares people for roles as learners, individuals, consumers, producers, citizens, and family members, helping them prepare for, cope with, and contribute to life events. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., OECD - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Glendenning's philosophical framework for education and community contribution
CORRESPONDENCE

Undated D-9 Education for work Addresses school business models and education quality. Refutes assumption that comparing schools to business models… ▸ more
Addresses school business models and education quality. Refutes assumption that comparing schools to business models implies privatization. Cites Forbes' four business components: value (goods/services), resources (educated workforce, facilities, technology), processes (curriculum, testing, teaching strategies), revenue (financial support). Notes schools are resource-rich despite declining enrollment. References educational model testing at college/university level through online courses, suggests similar testing coming for public schools. Includes lengthy section on defining quality in education from UN Children's Fund (UNICEF) emphasizing learner development capacity, evidence-based change, and diverse stakeholder perspectives. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning, Jerome Bruner (quoted) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Forbes, UNICEF - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Discusses business models and quality in education systems
CORRESPONDENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Qualifications Glendenning distinguishes between credentials (certifying completion of study programs) and qualifications (attesting… ▸ more
Glendenning distinguishes between credentials (certifying completion of study programs) and qualifications (attesting to ability to perform in roles). Using teaching as example, credentials are university degrees while qualifications are teaching licenses. He discusses three assessment purposes: formative (helping learning), summative (establishing achievement level), and ranking. Argues teachers should focus on formative assessment (coaching role) but summative testing creates conflict of interest, as teachers serve both as coaches and referees/judges of their own students. Suggests roles should be separated professionally. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (Editor, implicit authorship) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's principled approach to professional ethics and role separation in education.
CORRESPONDENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download

Similar to File 15 with additional sections on PEI-specific education issues. Includes media scan of international education articles plus "Around PEI" section discussing autonomy (criticism of moving positions to Department of Education), communications (calling for inclusion of both educators and public in education discussions), and school organization (suggesting graduate students work with principals on "greenfield" school projects rather than reading Kant). Emphasizes importance of both educators and public dialogue for meaningful change. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (Editor) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., English Language School Board, Department of Education - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Illustrates Don's commitment to public engagement in education and collaborative problem-solving.

Undated D-3 learning framework Another version of the learning framework paper (similar to Files 2 and 4), providing foundation for understanding… ▸ more
Another version of the learning framework paper (similar to Files 2 and 4), providing foundation for understanding education through the lens of learner characteristics and learning processes. Explains how genetics, past experience, and imagined futures shape learning. Introduces Oregon Life Roles concept and discusses support mechanisms needed for personalized learning including instruction, opportunity, role models, encouragement, information, advice, and recognition. - **Key People**: Robert Gagne, Karl R. Wirth, Dexter Perkins, Robert Plomen, Charles DeFries, Jonathon Flint, Mark Henderson - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates recurring theme of learner-centered approach in Don's educational thinking.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-4 System change Highlight Comprehensive call for education system reform in PEI, arguing education is essential to personal quality of life and… ▸ more
Comprehensive call for education system reform in PEI, arguing education is essential to personal quality of life and community sustainability. Identifies gap between Islanders' expectations and actual education provision due to limited educator-community engagement, lack of comprehensive education philosophy, government focus on young/schooling only, and politicization of decisions. Proposes five recommendations: 1) develop overarching public education statement; 2) create learner-centered service model with flexible scheduling; 3) reserve government's leadership role in creating learning culture; 4) delegate instruction delivery beyond schools; 5) establish separate qualification authority. Advocates professional service delivery model similar to health/justice sectors with closer client-professional relationships and professional autonomy. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Government of PEI - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, PEI-specific - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Encapsulates Don's vision for comprehensive education system transformation emphasizing learner-centered approaches and professional autonomy.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-4-1 Educ Framework Framework paper defining education's role in developing citizen capacities. Discusses education as accumulated bit by… ▸ more
Framework paper defining education's role in developing citizen capacities. Discusses education as accumulated bit by bit through learning experiences, complicated by individual uniqueness in physical/mental/emotional/social makeup, prior experiences, and learning pace/style. Provides definitions: Education as experience with formative effect; Learning as engagement in formative experiences; Education purpose as helping develop capacities for community participation. Outlines education system components: independent information/counselling/advice services; institutions for formal instruction; community-based services; certification/qualification services; governance structure; resource materials; specialists. Discusses clientele spanning infants to adults with various skill needs (attitudes, skills, knowledge). References Oregon Life Roles and Canadian Health Care System as analogous models. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author), Aman Sharma - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., World Health Organization - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's systematic approach to conceptualizing education system components and integration.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-5 A Learning framework Learning framework paper examining factors influencing learning and education. Establishes quality education as major… ▸ more
Learning framework paper examining factors influencing learning and education. Establishes quality education as major focus for citizens and government investment. Explains learning as personal process influenced by genetics, past experience, and imagined future. Discusses learner characteristics: home/school experience, travel, wellness, age, ambition, interests, culture, learning styles. Introduces Oregon Life Roles: individual, family member, consumer, producer, citizen, learner. Education becomes series of learning experiences preparing for life roles. Learning process involves changing behavior (attitudes, skills, knowledge). Customized support needed through instruction, opportunity, role models, encouragement, information, advice, and recognition. Framework provides common language for field collaboration and increases decision consistency. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author), Robert Gagne, Karl R. Wirth, Dexter Perkins, Robert Plomen, Charles DeFries, Jonathon Flint, Mark Henderson - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Reiterates fundamental learning framework central to Don's educational vision.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-5 B A Learning framework Learning framework emphasizing education as experiences with formative effect on thinking, feeling, and behavior.… ▸ more
Learning framework emphasizing education as experiences with formative effect on thinking, feeling, and behavior. Purpose is acquiring skills, knowledge, and attitudes for life journey. Examines learner composition through prior conditions (physical/mental/emotional/social well-being), past experience (home, school, travel, wellness, age, ambition, interests, culture, learning styles), and imagined future (life roles and self-perception). Learning involves change in behavior through experience. Identifies support needed from many sources. Lists help types: instruction, information, opportunity, role models, encouragement, advice, recognition, practice, feedback, self-evaluation, independent study, independent resources. Notes learners need different support types, sequences, and timing. Discusses how to identify, organize, and deliver customized support. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's systematic understanding of learner needs and support mechanisms.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-5 Handle with Care Description of "Handle with Care" program for parents/caregivers promoting children's and families' mental health and… ▸ more
Description of "Handle with Care" program for parents/caregivers promoting children's and families' mental health and social-emotional well-being. Funded by Public Health Agency of Canada Innovations Fund. Program paradigm emphasizes positive everyday interactions, healthy emotional environments, and family-community connections. Targets all economic/social strata. Consists of four building blocks: 1) Building Trust and Attachment; 2) Building/Enhancing Self-Esteem; 3) Expressing Emotions; 4) Building Relationships. Each block includes key messages, research, self-care, activities, bringing it home, and bringing it together components. Woven through with acceptance, caring, honor, respect, trust, understanding, and encouragement. Benefits include children's improved self-esteem, confidence, focus, learning, healthy relationships, mental/physical health. Parents report confidence growth and community involvement. Guest editor Alice Taylor. Goals include program sustainability in PEI and expansion to Atlantic provinces. - **Key People**: Alice Taylor (Guest Editor), Eileen (contact), Don Glendenning (associated) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Public Health Agency of Canada - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY, FAMILY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Don's engagement with holistic child development beyond traditional academics, including social-emotional health.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-5-A Math Problem Highlight Duplicate of File 17 (D-5 Math Problem), providing complete analysis of mathematics education reform needs in PEI.… ▸ more
Duplicate of File 17 (D-5 Math Problem), providing complete analysis of mathematics education reform needs in PEI. Addresses persistent gap between curriculum goal (mathematically literate adults) and achievement outcomes. Lists school system control variables and proposed systemic changes. Advocates for qualification authority separation from teaching function. Discusses mathematical study's importance through Paulos' framework. Proposes comprehensive competency analysis with rating scales and independent assessment. - **Key People**: John Paulos, Bertrand Russell, Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., UPEI, College of PEI - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, PEI-specific - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Reinforces Don's sustained focus on mathematics education as critical Islander competency.

Undated D-6 Math Problem Analysis of improving mathematics education in PEI, addressing the gap between provincial curriculum goals and student… ▸ more
Analysis of improving mathematics education in PEI, addressing the gap between provincial curriculum goals and student achievement. Argues for increased priority on math education with specific recommendations including higher time allocation, quality instruction, clear standards, and competency-based assessment. Proposes establishing independent assessment services, separation of teaching from summative assessment/grading, and creation of a qualification authority. References John Paulos on why mathematics matters (useful, important, interesting). Advocates for systems thinking approach rather than isolated reforms, emphasizing teacher autonomy and appropriate resource allocation. Concludes with four-step process for comprehensive math improvement. - **Key People**: John Paulos (mathematician, quoted) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., UPEI, PEI schools - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's commitment to systemic educational improvement and his sophisticated understanding of assessment and curriculum design
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-6 learning Path Early draft exploring how learners conceptualize their own learning process. Convened workshop "From a Learner's… ▸ more
Early draft exploring how learners conceptualize their own learning process. Convened workshop "From a Learner's Perspective" with youth panel to identify learning support activities and steps. Generated 13 key activities including gather information, obtain feedback, take instruction, self-evaluate, coach others, practice, observe others, attend lecture, seek counselling, observe demonstration, attempt task, and undergo assessment. Found students followed different learning paths rather than linear progression. Identified five major steps: decide to learn, explore options, attempt task, use help, reach expectations. Acknowledges learning purposes vary and paths are non-linear. Includes visual learning path diagram. - **Key People**: Tanya Craig (convener/chair), Callen Cudmore, Ryan Rioux, Iain Cudmore, Stephanie Mayne (youth panel members), Mike Chapman (facilitator) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Holland College (Early Childhood Education class) - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Don's interest in understanding learning from students' perspectives and collaborative educational research
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download

Undated D-7 learning Path Refined version of learning path paper following extensive consultations. Documents workshop outcomes identifying 12… ▸ more
Refined version of learning path paper following extensive consultations. Documents workshop outcomes identifying 12 key learning support activities. Discusses youth panel findings and subsequent consultation with Early Childhood Education class at Holland College. Reports on final discussion with 25+ experienced educators which focused on two major themes: purpose of developing learning path (summarize current thinking, model learning process, explain to others) and addressing motivation, incentives, affective domain, collaboration, learning styles. Acknowledges path remains incomplete and notes next steps include charting paths for educators/helpers. - **Key People**: Tanya Craig, Callen Cudmore, Ryan Rioux, Iain Cudmore, Stephanie Mayne, Holly Moses, Mike Chapman - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Holland College - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's commitment to collaborative research and Holland College partnerships

 Read · Download
Undated D-7 statement Highlight Foundational policy paper proposing comprehensive educational system reform for PEI. Identifies gap between what… ▸ more
Foundational policy paper proposing comprehensive educational system reform for PEI. Identifies gap between what Islanders want and what province provides in education, citing issues including limited community engagement, lack of comprehensive philosophy, organizational barriers, and politicization. Recommends six major changes: develop overarching public education statement, create learner-centered service model, establish government leadership role in quality and culture, delegate instruction delivery beyond schools, establish independent qualification authority (separate from teaching/grading), and implement professional service delivery model. Emphasizes separation of teaching (formative assessment) from qualification/sorting (summative assessment). Advocates for learner-centered outcomes, flexible scheduling, and teacher autonomy. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (implied primary author) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., PEI Government - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Core policy position paper showing Don's vision for PEI education system transformation

Undated D-7-A post institutional Brief conceptual paper on emerging post-institutional education paradigm. Outlines shift from traditional institutional… ▸ more
Brief conceptual paper on emerging post-institutional education paradigm. Outlines shift from traditional institutional models to broader ecosystem including family educators, school focus on social-emotional health, separate qualification authority, and community education centres. References Kevin Carey's "The End of College" and Walter Gordon Symposium discussion. Explores how education is transitioning beyond institutional boundaries. Bibliography indicates engagement with contemporary educational policy literature. - **Key People**: Kevin Carey (cited author) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's forward-thinking perspective on educational system evolution

Undated D-8 Qualification Authority Revised and expanded version of qualification framework proposal. More extensive discussion of labour mobility patterns… ▸ more
Revised and expanded version of qualification framework proposal. More extensive discussion of labour mobility patterns and how mobility may be hampered by lack of portable qualifications. Deeper analysis of credential vs. qualification distinction with emphasis on output vs. input measures. Discusses international models and apprenticeship/Red Seal as Canadian exceptions. Argues qualification authority would improve consistency, ease mobility, improve communications, encourage self-study, and reduce grade inflation. Emphasizes authority should assess individuals directly, not approve courses or institutions. Includes detailed proposal for independent structure accepting direct applications and issuing certificates based on demonstrated performance. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., apprenticeship programs - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Core policy platform showing Don's innovative approach to educational credentialing

Letter to Tim Banks at APM Place requesting support for Education 20/20. Expresses Don's concern about Canadian education based on experience and islander feedback. Education 20/20 Inc. survey on goals of public education in PEI. References PEI Department of Education and Early Childhood Development philosophy and Education Administration Handbook. Respondents rate clarity and importance (1-14). Includes demographic questions asking respondents to identify as parent, employer, student, or teacher. Comprehensive proposal to Windsor Foundation for "Defining the Preparedness Gap" project. Glendenning served as President and primary contact. Proposal addresses low basic education skills in young people including high school graduates. Identified problems: educational silos, curriculum misalignment, subject-centered instruction, lack of recognized standards. Proposes developing curriculum map identifying basic skills needed for citizenship, employment, and further education. Innovative features include single analysis with multiple profiles, broad stakeholder engagement, and team approach. Included detailed timeline, budget considerations, and implementation steps. Undated 00 Quotations Curated collection of 50+ educational quotations reflecting Glendenning's philosophical values and educational… ▸ more
Curated collection of 50+ educational quotations reflecting Glendenning's philosophical values and educational perspective. Includes quotes from Plutarch, Machiavelli, C.S. Lewis, Benjamin Franklin, Albert Einstein, Mahatma Gandhi, Desmond Tutu, George Bernard Shaw, Goethe, and others. Themes include learning as self-organizing system, importance of treating people with respect, role of mistakes in learning, education as equalizer, freedom in learning, and dangers of standardized approaches. Collection reveals Glendenning's deeply humanistic educational philosophy emphasizing individual development, creativity, and personal potential. - **Key People**: Plutarch, Machiavelli, C.S. Undated D 34 Significance of time Glendenning's thoughtful reflection on distinction between academic standards and workplace time requirements. Argues… ▸ more
Glendenning's thoughtful reflection on distinction between academic standards and workplace time requirements. Argues standards can be defined independent of time for academic purposes, but workplace performance requires both quality and speed/efficiency. Uses example of cabinetmaking: student hobbyist and professional carpenter producing identical quality piece would receive different grades based on time/cost considerations. Raises important curriculum design question: Should education prepare students for both academic achievement and occupational realities? Includes announcements of upcoming initiatives including educational support services, teacher role discussion, and "Handle with Care" program. Shows Glendenning's nuanced thinking on education-to-work transitions. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning, Derek MacEwen - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Department of Education, Early Learning and Culture - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Glendenning's sophisticated educational thinking

Undated 25 Change - Strategies Strategic framework for educational change under "Education First Canada" initiative. Outlines six goals for achieving… ▸ more
Strategic framework for educational change under "Education First Canada" initiative. Outlines six goals for achieving quality education for all Canadians: providing relevant information as catalyst for change, engaging community in decision-making beyond consultation to genuine participation, encouraging and supporting innovation with professional freedom to fail, recognizing institutional and individual leadership in education improvements, supporting research into teaching and organizational methods, and developing organizational capacity for service delivery. Emphasizes information as "fuel of change" and public engagement as "grassroots democracy in action," demonstrating Don's belief in stakeholder involvement and evidence-based reform. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: Education First Canada - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's strategic approach to educational change and commitment to community-engaged reform

Undated 4 Reading cost Research document on reading instruction economics and comprehensive reading improvement strategy. Analyzes per-student… ▸ more
Research document on reading instruction economics and comprehensive reading improvement strategy. Analyzes per-student schooling cost ($10,000/year) as insufficient metric without understanding cost breakdown. Notes research suggesting 35-40 hours tutoring needed to raise reading level one grade at $2,000 cost per level. Cites statistics on magnitude of problem: 42% of adults below level 3 literacy, Canadian students performing below national average on reading tests, 30% of Grade 6 students unable to read adequately, community college students requiring remediation. Proposes comprehensive multi-stage initiative to improve reading through public engagement, educator training, standards development, system support (reading clinics, qualification authority), and community information. Identifies reading as "golden skill" foundational to all learning and key to individual opportunity and community development. - **Key People**: Jessie Lees (reading advocate); Don Glendenning (author) - **Key Organizations**: Kingston reading clinic, Brock University, Wilson Reading (Moncton), Bermuda reading services, Department of Education, schools, libraries, communities - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Shows Don's focus on reading as foundational to education equity and economic opportunity; demonstrates his strategic thinking about institutional change; reflects his advocacy for evidence-based, systematic improvement initiatives

Undated 4 Reading criteria Extensive document detailing reading skill assessment and improvement framework. Defines reading as "ability to use… ▸ more
Extensive document detailing reading skill assessment and improvement framework. Defines reading as "ability to use printed information as meaningful language" with key assessment criteria (range of material, comprehension, fluency, independence, speed, vocabulary, flow). Establishes seven-level performance scale with benchmarks (e.g., Level 3 = reading daily newspaper with comprehension). Identifies reading issues (program emphasis gaps, funding continuity, specialist availability) and intervention points (standards setting, rating scale development, assessment training, reading clinics, specialized teacher roles). Comprehensively addresses reading competency components (phonemic awareness, fluency, vocabulary, comprehension), teaching approaches (phonics, rime-based instruction), and evidence-based instruction strategies (previewing, predicting, skimming, context guessing). Includes detailed statistics on literacy crisis and recommendations for systematic reading improvement including outcome identification, benchmark setting, teacher training, specialist support, and community engagement. Proposes establishment of reading organizations, societies, and support structures. Demonstrates Don's systematic, evidence-based approach to addressing a major educational need. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author); National Reading Panel (referenced); Kotter (change management); various literacy researchers - **Key Organizations**: Department of Education, schools, libraries, reading clinics, teacher organizations, parents groups, communities - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Comprehensive demonstration of Don's analytical and strategic approach to educational problems; shows his commitment to evidence-based, systematic reform addressing real community needs; includes innovative institutional proposals

Undated Quality Education 3 Highlight Extensive framework for quality education systems prepared for Education 20/20 Inc. Defines education, education… ▸ more
Extensive framework for quality education systems prepared for Education 20/20 Inc. Defines education, education system, and quality. Discusses two philosophical approaches: humanist/progressive (emphasizing whole-child development and social change) and economist (emphasizing efficiency and outcomes). Details quality education characteristics: healthy learners, safe environments, relevant content, outcomes linked to objectives, learner-focused support, timely/independent information, professional/autonomous/accountable teachers. Includes substantial section on criterion-referenced assessment, quality assurance frameworks, and recommendations from OECD and UNICEF. Extensive discussion of internal/external evaluation, quality management, and tertiary education specific guidance. Shows Don's deep engagement with contemporary quality assurance theory. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author); Robert Glaser; Sherren (PEI columnist); OECD; UNESCO; UNICEF; World Bank; Deming; Juran - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., OECD, UNESCO, UNICEF, World Bank, QAA (UK), EQAO (Ontario) - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY, FOUNDATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Comprehensive articulation of Don's educational philosophy emphasizing learner-centered quality systems, relevant to both Holland College and foundation work

Undated 01 Personal public statement-1 Speaking notes presenting recommendations to public audiences on education reform. Provides accessible explanations of… ▸ more
Speaking notes presenting recommendations to public audiences on education reform. Provides accessible explanations of five main reform initiatives: developing public education vision statement; implementing learner-centered service model with flexible scheduling and challenge-for-credit; establishing government leadership role in learning culture; delegating instruction provision; and establishing independent qualification authority. Notes emphasize conflict of interest when teachers both teach and sort students, cite apprenticeship and music conservatory models, reference family education advisers and essential skills centres. Undated 03 Alignment Occasional paper exploring "alignment" concept in education systems. Discusses alignment meanings including… ▸ more
Occasional paper exploring "alignment" concept in education systems. Discusses alignment meanings including curriculum-assessment coherence (common definition) and broader alignment between education system design and community needs/goals (Don's focus). Examines alignment areas: policy, strategy, standards, assessment, curriculum, professional development, school-life integration, reporting, and management. Provides extensive examples of alignment applications in school improvement, curriculum design, teacher preparation, and standardized testing. Argues school principals, as designated instructional leaders, should have authority to adjust alignment variables. Offers practical advice for parents whose children struggle: review course outcomes against child's needs, check report card-outcome alignment, request progress criteria, and discuss school support with principal. Published under Education 20/20 Inc. masthead. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Great Schools Partnership - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Don's engagement with specific educational concepts and parent advocacy.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 10 School Autonomy-2 Occasional paper No. 114 examining relationship between school autonomy and student performance based on OECD PISA… ▸ more
Occasional paper No. 114 examining relationship between school autonomy and student performance based on OECD PISA research. Establishes direct link: schools with greater autonomy over curriculum and student assessment tend to perform better. Notes autonomy effectiveness depends on accountability mechanisms - schools with autonomy plus public accountability show better performance than those without accountability structures. Defines autonomy as freedom to allocate resources, hire/dismiss teachers, formulate budgets, make curriculum/assessment decisions. Examines PEI principals' limited autonomy despite Schools Act designation as educational leaders. Presents examples of schools exercising autonomy (Arizona's teacher assistant model reallocation, alternative student grouping). Recommends schools have autonomy for individual student decisions, establish student learning accountability, communicate with community, delegate to lowest level, and engage teachers. - **Key People**: No specific individuals named - **Key Organizations**: OECD, Education 20/20, PEI Schools Act - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Reflects Don's consistent advocacy for school autonomy as educational leader
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 11 Engagement-notes 2 Comprehensive occasional paper on student and public engagement in education. Distinguishes between consultation… ▸ more
Comprehensive occasional paper on student and public engagement in education. Distinguishes between consultation (viewed as manipulative) and true engagement (grass-roots democracy with transparency and shared decision-making). Details benefits including improved student achievement, teacher morale, communication, and community trust. Identifies components: student-to-student relationships, student-to-teacher partnerships, student-learning material engagement, parent involvement, and school-community partnerships. References Education 20/20 Inc. framework and includes extensive bibliography of engagement research (Willms, Fredricks, Jimerson, etc.). Advocates for enhanced public participation in PEI education. - **Key People**: Education 20/20 Inc. (referenced), Willms, Fredricks, Jimerson, Sobel - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., Johns Hopkins University, OECD, UNICEF, PTSA organizations - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Shows Donald's scholarly approach to education policy, his commitment to grassroots democratic engagement, and his advocacy for transparent, inclusive decision-making in education. Reflects his educational philosophy and research interests post-Holland College.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 11 Engagement Short reference notes on student engagement drawing from Willms and OECD research. Defines engagement as students… ▸ more
Short reference notes on student engagement drawing from Willms and OECD research. Defines engagement as students feeling they belong, accepting societal values, and participating in school affairs. Notes engagement measures include student feelings and attendance, varies with age, and associates with higher achievement. Lists characteristics of schools with higher literacy: strong disciplinary climate, good teacher relations, high expectations. Notes engagement is integral to instructional design and school culture (reflecting principal and teachers). Documents that engaged students more likely to continue education and find employment, contributing to health, wellbeing and quality of life. Lists components: strong core program, elimination of tracking/streaming, parental involvement, strong discipline, autonomy, authentic evaluation, and curriculum reform. - **Key People**: Willms, OECD researchers - **Key Organizations**: OECD - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Reference notes showing Donald's focus on research-based educational practices and the importance of engagement in school effectiveness.

Undated 11-A-1 Engagement-paper Another variant/revision of engagement paper with minor editing differences. Maintains core thesis that student… ▸ more
Another variant/revision of engagement paper with minor editing differences. Maintains core thesis that student engagement (feeling of belonging, school work interaction, participation, positive attitude, persistence) represents positive school indicator and correlates with achievement. Notes engagement flourishes with strong discipline, good teacher relations, high expectations. Documents school reform outcomes improving engagement: autonomy, parental involvement, strong core programs, curriculum reform, authentic assessment. Lists benefits: achievement, morale, communication, relevant content, feedback, broadened viewpoints, informed community, idea generation, public trust, student wellbeing, employment readiness. Describes engagement framework: student peer relationships, student-teacher relationships, student-learning material engagement, parent involvement, school-community partnerships, and school engagement strategies. - **Key People**: Same researchers referenced - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Working draft showing editing and refinement of engagement frameworks.

Undated 11-F Engagement Brief reference notes on student engagement drawing from Willms and OECD research. Defines engagement as students… ▸ more
Brief reference notes on student engagement drawing from Willms and OECD research. Defines engagement as students feeling they belong, accepting broader societal values, and participating in school affairs. Notes measures include student feelings and attendance, varies by age, associates with higher achievement. Notes schools with higher literacy show strong disciplinary climate, good student-teacher relations, and high expectations. Identifies engagement as integral to instructional design reflecting school and teacher culture. Documents engaged students more likely to continue education and find employment, contributing to health, wellbeing, and quality of life. Lists factors supporting engagement: strong core programs, elimination of tracking/streaming, parental involvement, strong discipline, autonomy, authentic evaluation, curriculum reform. - **Key People**: Willms (OECD) - **Key Organizations**: OECD - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Reference notes on engagement research supporting educational practice.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download

Undated 2-2-1-4 qualifications 1 pager Condensed summary highlighting tasks and benefits of proposed qualification framework. Lists primary tasks (analyses,… ▸ more
Condensed summary highlighting tasks and benefits of proposed qualification framework. Lists primary tasks (analyses, levels, criteria, assessment, reporting) and benefits (reduced assessment burden, consistency in reporting, credential comparison, worker mobility, stakeholder communication). Notes that system would not organize competitions or rank students. Briefly references other countries' frameworks and Canada's CICIC (Canadian Information Centre for International Credentials). Designed as concise reference document for education group exploring PEI education issues. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (implied author/organization member) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., CICIC - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Glendenning's ability to synthesize complex policy into actionable summaries. Demonstrates collaborative work on education reform initiatives with specific PEI focus.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 2-2-3 qualifications and credentials Educational newsletter article distinguishing credentials from qualifications using accessible language. Credentials… ▸ more
Educational newsletter article distinguishing credentials from qualifications using accessible language. Credentials are institutional documents (diplomas, degrees) indicating completion of programs; qualifications reflect demonstrated attitudes, skills, knowledge for task performance. Uses practical example: teaching requires both credential (university degree) and qualification (teaching license). Argues public confusion about school standards stems from conflating credentials with qualifications. Presents Glendenning's eight key views on the distinction and proposes need for separate certification body/qualification authority. Suggests credentials focus on "what one knows" while qualifications address "what one can do with what one knows." Advocates for Atlantic qualification authority while emphasizing need to clarify measured skills first. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author/editor, "Open Education" newsletter) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc., immigrant assessment organizations - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Shows Glendenning's skill in communicating complex education policy to general audience. Demonstrates his commitment to public education dialogue and accessible policy discussion. Evidence of leadership in "Open Education" newsletter.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 2-2-4 Assessment and grading Focused examination of assessment, grading, and their purposes in education. Defines assessment as integral to teaching… ▸ more
Focused examination of assessment, grading, and their purposes in education. Defines assessment as integral to teaching process, with results informing instructional strategies. Structures assessment around Robert Paul Wolff's framework: criticism (feedback about current learning), evaluation (criterion-referenced level establishment), and ranking (competitive comparison). Identifies core problem of conflating teaching with sorting functions. Schools should help learners learn; separate bodies should handle certification. Discusses problem of lacking defined qualification levels and separation of teaching from assessment/ranking. Proposes AQUA authority removing barriers to certification, focusing on demonstrated performance rather than time served, and enabling self-directed learning. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author), Robert Paul Wolff (education theorist) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Glendenning's sophisticated understanding of assessment and educational theory. Shows systematic thinking about fundamental problems in education systems.

Defines key terms for education systems and outlines essential components: Information services (advice, counseling, assessment, referral, advocacy), Instruction (formal instruction, coaching, tutoring, guided practice, demonstrations, group work), Community Support (libraries, bookstores, encouragement, technology access), and Feedback mechanisms (qualifications, competition, research, awards).
