Undated 34 AQUA Proposal for AQUA (Atlantic Provinces Qualification Authority), an independent, private-sector driven certification… ▸ more
Proposal for AQUA (Atlantic Provinces Qualification Authority), an independent, private-sector driven certification body. Would operate on fee-for-service basis, accept applicants directly or by referral, and issue certificates based on demonstrated performance. Would remove barriers to certification, focus certification on actual performance rather than study time, and allow educational providers to focus on teaching while certification bodies focus on assessment. Implementation proposed in steps: feasibility study, business plan, pilot program, then full implementation. Reflects Don's philosophy of separating educational delivery from credential issuance. - **Key People**: Not identified - **Key Organizations**: Educational institutions, proposed AQUA authority, Atlantic Provinces - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Concrete policy proposal embodying Don's core education reform philosophy; likely significant for his professional legacy.

Earlier version of the preparedness report. Addresses youth facing high debt, low incomes, temporary employment, and emotional stress. References CFPEI's "Taking the Pulse of Island Youth" survey reporting high school/postsecondary completion rates but concerns about readiness for next life stages. Education 20/20 organized four public discussions to explore these issues. Occasional paper outlining comprehensive education system components. Distinguishes education (any experience with formative effect) from education system (all services meeting citizen educational needs). Undated 400-1 A learning framework-1 Foundational paper outlining comprehensive learning framework. Begins with premise that future depends on citizen… ▸ more
Foundational paper outlining comprehensive learning framework. Begins with premise that future depends on citizen education quality. Distinguishes learning (process of changing behaviour in attitudes, skills, knowledge) from education (all formative experiences). Identifies five key framework elements: Learner (diverse individuals differing in age, ambition, interests, health, culture); Life Context (Oregon Life Roles model); Learning Process (all experiences are learning; outcomes are observable and measurable); Learner Support (wellness, instruction, opportunity, role models, encouragement, information, advice, recognition); and philosophical foundation (belief systems influence educational decisions). References John Dewey and emphasizes that understanding learning is prerequisite to understanding and improving education. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning, John Dewey, Robert M. Gagne, Karl R. Wirth, Dexter Perkins - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20, State of Oregon - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Foundational document showing Don's theoretical framework and systematic approach to education, building on educational research and philosophy.

Undated 500-1-B Educ System comp Comprehensive educational philosophy document addressing approximately 140,000 islanders (PEI population context).… ▸ more
Comprehensive educational philosophy document addressing approximately 140,000 islanders (PEI population context). Discusses how education determines citizen quality of life and community development. Critiques conflation of "education" and "schooling" across different sectors. Provides definitions, organizes clientele by age cohorts and needs (early childhood through leisure and personal fulfillment), outlines education functions, and details system components (instruction, counseling, community services, certification, governance, private sector resources). Emphasizes gap-filling, retooling, advancement, leisure, and personal fulfillment as educational needs beyond schooling. - **Key People**: Aman Sharma (referenced author) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, COMMUNITY - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Reflects Donald's community-focused educational philosophy for PEI

Undated 51 Conflict Explores the fundamental conflict between schools' teaching and sorting (ranking) functions. Argues that schools should… ▸ more
Explores the fundamental conflict between schools' teaching and sorting (ranking) functions. Argues that schools should help learners learn but shouldn't also rank/sort students, citing the distinction between roles in sports (coaches vs. referees) and other professions. Discusses confusion between credentials and qualifications, credentials vs. qualifications, and the tension between formative assessment for learning versus summative assessment for sorting. Core argument: these incompatible roles place teachers in conflict and ultimately harms education. - **Key People**: Teachers, learners, policymakers - **Key Organizations**: Schools, educational institutions - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Demonstrates Glendenning's core philosophical concern about education system design and his advocacy for separating teaching from certification functions.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 55 D 002 Teaching and sorting-2 Extended exploration of incompatible roles in schools: education vs. training, general vs. vocational, credentials vs.… ▸ more
Extended exploration of incompatible roles in schools: education vs. training, general vs. vocational, credentials vs. qualifications. Core argument: schools have dual conflicting mandates—teaching/learning and sorting/ranking students. Distinguishes: learning (behavioral change), education (sum of formative experiences), schooling (government-funded formal instruction), credentials (what was taught), and qualifications (what one can do). Proposes independent qualification body separate from schools. Concludes schooling/credentialing and teaching are fundamentally incompatible roles; recommends schools focus on learning, external bodies handle certification. Extensively documented draft with multiple revisions showing refinement of ideas. - **Key People**: Teachers, learners, employers - **Key Organizations**: Schools, educational institutions - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT, ANALYSIS - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Central to his lifelong education reform philosophy; shows systematic thinking about role clarity and institutional design.

Framework document examining education system components and service organization. Redefines education and education systems for clarity. Identifies six key system components: information systems (technologies, records, HR, data management), providers (institutions and individuals delivering educational services through instruction, coaching, assessment), community agencies (libraries, bookstores, offering access and resources), feedback mechanisms (quality control, awards, research), industry partnerships, and leadership/governance (including regulatory and comparative functions). Emphasizes coordination among system components to support learner-centered education. Undated A4 vision Comprehensive statement of Education 20/20 Inc.'s institutional vision and philosophy. Describes organization as… ▸ more
Comprehensive statement of Education 20/20 Inc.'s institutional vision and philosophy. Describes organization as broad-based national not-for-profit, PEI-based, governed by volunteer Board representing education interest (not institutional constituencies). States vision: "A quality education for every Canadian"; mission: strengthen learning culture; mandate: influence education evolution through learner-centered approaches. Articulates ten core beliefs: education supports life roles functioning; includes social-emotional growth; shapes community futures; broader than schooling; lifelong journey; community endeavor; teachers facilitate learning; culture of learning enables quality; results from multiple meaningful experiences; is 24/7 activity. Defines quality system characteristics and educational processes emphasizing achievement, mutual respect, meaningful assessment, learner-focused development, outcomes orientation, and evidence-based practice. Lists initial priorities: focus on learners, community information access, and broad engagement. - **Key People**: None named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, FOUNDATION, POLICY - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Definitive statement of Don's educational vision and institutional philosophy through Education 20/20; core document for understanding his educational leadership and reform agenda.

Undated C-1Education and Schooling Seminal document defining the distinction between education and schooling. Education is defined as any formative… ▸ more
Seminal document defining the distinction between education and schooling. Education is defined as any formative experience developing abilities, attitudes, and behaviors of positive social value (farm work, philosophy courses, backpacking in Europe, international consulting projects). Schooling refers to formal institutional training. Donald argues these terms are confused in contemporary discourse. Uses Oregon's life roles model (individual, family member, learner, citizen, consumer, producer) to frame education's ultimate purpose: helping people function better in life roles. Examines consequences of blurring these definitions—discouraging lifelong learning, creating dependence, and limiting learning to formal institutions. - **Key People**: Not specified in document - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: BIOGRAPHICAL, EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Core to understanding Donald's professional philosophy and expertise in education systems and institutional leadership

Undated D 002 Outcomes model Highlight Comprehensive analysis of education outcomes and outcome-based education (OBE) models. Discusses the complexity of… ▸ more
Comprehensive analysis of education outcomes and outcome-based education (OBE) models. Discusses the complexity of educational issues including curriculum, qualifications, and accountability. Proposes upgrading OBE models and establishing clear, measurable educational outcomes developed in consultation with communities. Critiques current system as administrative convenience-driven rather than learner-focused, lacking transparency and professional decision-making at school level. Addresses systemic weaknesses including time-based rather than performance-based models, batch processing, lack of learning culture, and poor credit for prior learning. - **Key People**: Virginia Satir (theorist referenced) - **Key Organizations**: PEI Department of Education, Education 20/20 Inc - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, HOLLAND_COLLEGE, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Core document showing his systematic approach to education reform and intellectual rigor in analyzing institutional problems

EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated OBE-3 paper Glendenning's detailed analysis of Outcomes-Based Education (OBE) as educational reform movement. Explains historical… ▸ more
Glendenning's detailed analysis of Outcomes-Based Education (OBE) as educational reform movement. Explains historical shift from content-focused teaching to learner-focused outcomes-based approaches. Attributes OBE development to William Spady (sociologist, University of Toronto and Ontario Institute for Studies in Education). Details Spady's three premises (all students can learn; success promotes more success; schools control learning conditions) and four power principles (clarity of focus, expanded opportunity and support, high expectations, design down from outcomes). Identifies strengths (consistency, accountability, accessibility) and weaknesses (lack of implementation standards, confusion between outcomes and levels, difficulty separating assessment from teaching). References Saranac Lake Central School District exit outcomes example and Atlantic province cooperative outcomes development. Commends provincial OBE commitment while calling for model updates. - **Key People**: William Spady (Outcomes-Based Education founder), Bertrand Russell (quoted) - **Key Organizations**: Ontario Institute for Studies in Education, Saranac Lake Central School District (NY) - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Shows Glendenning's scholarly engagement with major education reform models.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated OBE-4 Outcomes model Glendenning's detailed examination of outcomes-based education implementation and reform proposals. Reiterates… ▸ more
Glendenning's detailed examination of outcomes-based education implementation and reform proposals. Reiterates foundational education philosophy: education is lifelong and involves self, home/family, schools, and community. Key issues: curriculum should start with outcomes; qualifications and education certification are separate functions; most implementations emphasize schooling narrowly rather than lifelong learning. Proposes OBE model upgrades addressing: principal administrator/educator conflicts; transportation as school responsibility (inappropriate); bureaucratic rather than professional decision-making; lack of learning culture; insufficient credit for prior learning. Recommends: clearly defined outcomes (UNICEF domains), community consultation, broad stakeholder understanding, and examples of exit outcomes. Reflects Glendenning's push for comprehensive reform beyond incremental OBE adjustments. - **Key People**: None specifically named - **Key Organizations**: UNICEF - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: HIGH - Shows Glendenning's comprehensive approach to education system reform and his synthesis of multiple reform frameworks.

Summary conclusions that education sector has a school system posing as an education system, widespread concerns about quality (especially literacy), system cannot self-reform requiring external intervention, widespread support for change, teachers lack influence/control, system is bureaucratic and top-down, and minimal public engagement in policy-setting. Advocates for meaningful systemic change rather than incremental improvements. - **Key People**: None - **Key Organizations**: None - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL, MANUSCRIPT - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Summarizes Don's critical assessment of education system status quo.

Introduction to "Learning for Life" miniseries of educational videos produced by Education 20/20 Inc. Uses metaphor of life's road to frame lifelong learning. Commentary supporting the "Learning for Life" concept with focus on what drives learning. References Maslow's five-level hierarchy of basic needs as motivational foundation. Identifies learning as not a one-time event but an ongoing spiral curriculum involving addition of new competencies. Lists six core life roles derived from Oregon educational framework: Individual, Family Member, Citizen, Learner, Consumer, and Producer. Undated A-4 Levels commentary Detailed commentary on Bloom's Taxonomy as revised by Lorin Anderson. Defines "levels" as points on a scale indicating… ▸ more
Detailed commentary on Bloom's Taxonomy as revised by Lorin Anderson. Defines "levels" as points on a scale indicating amount, quantity, extent, or quality. Establishes Don as a student of Bloom's taxonomy. Explains six hierarchical levels of learning from lowest to highest: Remembering (recall), Understanding (comprehension/translation), Applying (use in new situations), Analyzing (separation into components), Evaluating (making judgments about value), and Creating (building new structures/meanings). Uses mountain climbing metaphor to illustrate progression. Emphasizes levels measure depth of learning, not subject matter complexity. - **Key People**: Bloom (educational theorist), Lorin Anderson (taxonomy reviser), Don Glendenning (student of taxonomy) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: EDUCATION, PROFESSIONAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: MEDIUM - Demonstrates Don's deep engagement with educational theory and adoption of established pedagogical frameworks in his work.

Questions whether current education system serves students' actual learning needs versus bureaucratic requirements. Reflects his systematic questioning of educational assumptions.

Undated AB Learn AvisorAN Learn Advisor Proposal -1 Formalized proposal for Education 20/20 to establish Lifelong Learning Advisor service on PEI. Details roles: fielding… ▸ more
Formalized proposal for Education 20/20 to establish Lifelong Learning Advisor service on PEI. Details roles: fielding inquiries about learning goals, identifying learning opportunities, building calendar/website, creating awareness campaigns. Specifies bilingual English/French requirement and ideal Mandarin capability. Outlines revenue model through website advertising. Provides detailed three-year budget totaling $225,000 including staff ($4,000/month), office rental ($800/month), media campaign ($10,000/year), and website development ($5,000).
ADMINISTRATIVE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated AB-Learn-Beliefs This document, labeled "No. 88," presents Don Glendenning's key beliefs about learners and education. Authored as… ▸ more
This document, labeled "No. 88," presents Don Glendenning's key beliefs about learners and education. Authored as Editor of Education 20/20 Inc., Glendenning articulates his core convictions including that learning is personal, most people can acquire necessary skills and knowledge, teaching time is variable, and education's purpose is developing citizens. Notably, he believes grading is not an educational function and that credentials and qualifications should be separate. He emphasizes that every learner needs an advocate and that governments should invest in education both to develop individual capabilities and serve community needs.

Undated Awards and incentives Comprehensive proposal for Education 20/20 school awards program recognizing achievements in school improvement and… ▸ more
Comprehensive proposal for Education 20/20 school awards program recognizing achievements in school improvement and public engagement. Contrasts outcomes-based incentives (distortive, minimal benefits) with process-based incentives (supported by research) and proposes awards recognizing achievement rather than competition. Emphasizes Education 20/20's independence enables external role inappropriate for schools. Recommends awards for public engagement, leadership, literacy, community partnerships, and transition to work. Includes notes from conversation with Tom Wilkinson discussing award structure ($2,500 cash plus banner/plaque), committee composition, and independence. References Masters' research on effective school characteristics spanning leadership, learning, teaching, learning environments, and partnerships. Extensive examples from U.S. schools and PTA national standards for family-school partnerships. Demonstrates Glendenning's commitment to recognizing improvement efforts and elevating education as community priority.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated C How learners differ An opinion piece by Don presenting a learning framework centered on understanding learner diversity. He explains that… ▸ more
An opinion piece by Don presenting a learning framework centered on understanding learner diversity. He explains that learners differ in home experience, travel, wellness, age, ambition, interests, culture, and learning styles. Don posits that education supports six life roles: individual, family member, consumer, producer, citizen, and learner. He emphasizes that learning is a personal behavioral change process influenced by past experience, imagined future, and current wellness states. The document outlines learning support tools (instruction, opportunity, role models, encouragement, information, advice, recognition) and explains why frameworks are necessary for consistent, effective educational decision-making.

Undated Curriculum-6 Workplan1 Proposal Project proposal outlining implementation steps for universal curriculum platform focusing on mathematics competencies.… ▸ more
Project proposal outlining implementation steps for universal curriculum platform focusing on mathematics competencies. Six-task workplan includes: conducting DACUM-style analysis of math competencies with 10 representative Islanders and experienced facilitator (2-day session); developing or adopting dynamic rating scale; creating holistic rating scale with local panel and community/employer input; identifying citizen skill profiles; developing competency descriptions with rationale and performance expectations (led by experienced math teachers); and developing learning guides (not included in initial project scope). Deliverable is single-sheet learner-friendly competency map adaptable to IT systems. Project originated from Education 20/20 Inc.
PROFESSIONAL SPEECH
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Purposes of educ Don Glendenning's editorial from "Open Education" newsletter addressing purpose of schools. Argues schools should help… ▸ more
Don Glendenning's editorial from "Open Education" newsletter addressing purpose of schools. Argues schools should help citizens develop across multiple life roles: individual, citizen, consumer, family member, learner, and producer. Proposes that education should be more specific in articulating outcomes and that contract between schools and society requires review. Emphasizes education includes formal and informal learning from home, community, church, and schools. Cites John Dewey's principle to relate schools to life so studies become correlated. Advocates for clear statement of educational roles to improve consistency in decision-making.
REFERENCE
Download
 Download
Undated Silos in Education This is a letter to the editor of The Guardian addressing educational silos. Don Glendenning explains how professional… ▸ more
This is a letter to the editor of The Guardian addressing educational silos. Don Glendenning explains how professional autonomy, government policies, and institutional monopolies create isolated systems. He references BC appointing a Superintendent of Reading and uses the farm silo metaphor to critique the system's lock on education. The document discusses OECD research linking school autonomy to performance, noting direct relationships between school autonomy and student achievement in reading and resource allocation. Concludes by urging readers to contact MLAs about school autonomy while new regulations are being written.
ANECDOTE BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Writing-Proposal This proposal establishes "Better Writing," a national not-for-profit organization to improve writing for all citizens.… ▸ more
This proposal establishes "Better Writing," a national not-for-profit organization to improve writing for all citizens. Glendenning argues that education is foundational to individual and community futures, with reading and writing as complementary key competencies. Better Writing would be governed by volunteer directors with education expertise but without current positions in the field, ensuring unaligned, transparent, evidence-based governance. The organization would provide volunteers, advocate for writing improvement, undertake research, produce educational materials, organize conferences and seminars, facilitate discussion groups, and foster cooperation among interested parties. The proposal positions Better Writing as a public, user-friendly organization distinct from institutional education systems, focusing on improving writing practice across Canadian demographics.

Undated OBE-10 Outcome-Based Education Has It Become More Affliction Than Cure _ Center of the American Experiment Critical analysis of Outcome-Based Education from the Center of the American Experiment, a policy research… ▸ more
Critical analysis of Outcome-Based Education from the Center of the American Experiment, a policy research organization. Takes skeptical view of OBE as an educational reform, questioning whether it has become harmful rather than beneficial. Discusses concerns about OBE implementation in American schools and provides conservative/traditional education perspective on the reform movement's viability and effects.

Undated OBE-7 Glatthorn Outcome-based education research or policy document providing guidance on educational outcomes and effectiveness… Download
Undated 13 Interventions This document outlines strategic steps for improving education systems, organized into three categories: conceptual… ▸ more
This document outlines strategic steps for improving education systems, organized into three categories: conceptual clarity, system creation/modernization, and operations. It emphasizes publishing key definitions to differentiate education from schooling, promoting research dissemination, and clarifying system purpose. The implementation section addresses establishing operating principles, identifying services, restructuring based on those services, and clarifying roles. It calls for providing in-service training, salary incentives for advanced degrees, and addressing the "fear factor" in education systems. For schools, it discusses teaching/learning models, competencies, holistic rating, self-assessment, and ranking frameworks for accountability.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL

Undated OBE vs conventional Comparative framework contrasting Outcome-Based Education (OBE) with conventional education across multiple dimensions:… ▸ more
Comparative framework contrasting Outcome-Based Education (OBE) with conventional education across multiple dimensions: learning climate (self-directed vs. teacher-directed; formal vs. informal; mutually respectful vs. authority-oriented), planning (participatory vs. teacher-directed), diagnosis (mutual vs. teacher assessment), goal-setting (negotiated vs. teacher-determined), learning design (projects vs. content units), activity types (inquiry vs. transmission), and evaluation (mutual vs. teacher assessment). This systematic comparison reveals Don's clear preference for learner-centered, collaborative OBE approaches and his critique of traditional authoritarian models.
REFERENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 5 Clarity Comprehensive examination of conceptual clarity problems in PEI education system. Identifies terminology… ▸ more
Comprehensive examination of conceptual clarity problems in PEI education system. Identifies terminology inconsistencies, unclear purpose, unidentified services, organizational structure misalignment, and accountability gaps. Argues that education deserves public conversation with communities rather than top-down implementation. Connects to OECD findings about decentralization improving outcomes. Emphasizes that schools are facilities, not education itself, and that effective service organizations delegate autonomy to frontline staff. Notes fear factor among educators preventing honest dialogue. Recommends establishing shared definitions, clarifying department purpose, and engaging community participation in education policy development.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Principles of education A comprehensive manifesto of educational principles addressing definitions, purpose, learners, teachers, curriculum,… ▸ more
A comprehensive manifesto of educational principles addressing definitions, purpose, learners, teachers, curriculum, facilities, organization, and evaluation. Core beliefs include that learning should be emphasized over teaching, instructors should assess and diagnose rather than solely convey content, programs must be individualized, and colleges should operate year-round with resources scheduled around learners—not vice versa. The document emphasizes performance-based rather than time-based education, credits for proven performance regardless of source, and systematic continuation of learning after college. A lengthy second section appears to be Alberta education policy articulating principles of excellence, talent development, partnership, and innovation. Don's foundational principles stress learner agency, outcome clarity, practical relevance, emotional well-being, and community partnership—core to his vision.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Teacher-instructor A conceptual exploration of the subtle but critical distinction between teaching and instruction, drawing on multiple… ▸ more
A conceptual exploration of the subtle but critical distinction between teaching and instruction, drawing on multiple sources and real-world observations. Teaching is framed as complex, involving varied techniques, strategies, and approaches to facilitate learning—potentially formal or informal, from school or from parents. Instruction, by contrast, is simpler directional guidance on what to do and how to do it. The document notes that instruction creates learner dependence on the instructor, whereas teaching involves opening doors and enabling independent understanding. Don's inclusion of this distinction reflects his sophisticated pedagogy—understanding that college education must shift from directive instruction to enabling teaching, from dependence-creating to autonomy-supporting approaches.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Education or Schooling system Published as Education 20/20 article, this piece advocates renaming or refunctioning "Departments of Education" as they… ▸ more
Published as Education 20/20 article, this piece advocates renaming or refunctioning "Departments of Education" as they currently operate merely as "Departments of Public Schooling." Glendenning uses the health system as analogy: it delivers services through multiple providers (pharmacies, clinics, home care) beyond hospitals. Similarly, education could benefit from school-external services: diagnosis, assessment, guidance, counseling, and specialized clinics. He urges broadening from schooling to comprehensive education, asking the PEI Minister to expand the portfolio beyond schools. The document reflects Don's systemic thinking and his belief that educational improvement requires infrastructure beyond traditional schools.

 Read · Download
Undated Graduation requirements Highlight In this essay, Don uses an analogy from his childhood—identifying automobiles and aircraft from a distance—to pose a… ▸ more
In this essay, Don uses an analogy from his childhood—identifying automobiles and aircraft from a distance—to pose a central question: How does one distinguish an educated person from an uneducated one without examining credentials? He questions whether the pattern of courses required for diplomas or degrees genuinely produces different outcomes. Don examines the Essential Graduation Learnings agreed upon by Atlantic Provinces, proposing these competency-based outcomes as alternatives to traditional course-based requirements. This reflects his belief that education's value lies in demonstrable skills, not documentation.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Graduation A refined version of Don's graduation philosophy, emphasizing that schools should prepare students to live… ▸ more
A refined version of Don's graduation philosophy, emphasizing that schools should prepare students to live fully—enjoying life, making a living, and contributing to communities. Don contrasts the university-focused orientation of secondary schools with the reality that up to half of graduates pursue work directly. He presents Michigan's outcome-based graduation requirements as superior to traditional discipline-based models, arguing that schools should answer the question: what should graduates be able to do? The essay champions outcome-focused education over subject-centered curricula.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Incubators Don frames schools as "incubators" where students develop skills for adult life roles. He traces education's evolution… ▸ more
Don frames schools as "incubators" where students develop skills for adult life roles. He traces education's evolution from apprenticeship models through the industrial revolution's mechanics institutes to modern public schools. Drawing on Oregon's Education Act, Don identifies six life roles: individual, learner, producer, consumer, family member, and citizen. He argues schools haven't adequately specified graduate expectations, creating confusion between what schools think they should do and what communities expect. He emphasizes the need to establish clear standards by resolving the fundamental question of which life roles schools should focus on.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Independent learner Don draws a parallel between travel and learning. Using his family's travel experiences, he illustrates how travelers… ▸ more
Don draws a parallel between travel and learning. Using his family's travel experiences, he illustrates how travelers start from different points, travel in different ways, and have different interests—yet travel agents provide customized support through maps, schedules, and guides. Don proposes that independent learners need similar "travel documents" for education: curriculum atlases, curriculum maps, learning models, learning management models, learning guides, and learning plans. He argues education industry should better support independent learners through more innovative resource materials and in-service teacher education.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Masthead An introductory masthead for Don's "Education 20/20" publication, explaining his motivation for engaging with… ▸ more
An introductory masthead for Don's "Education 20/20" publication, explaining his motivation for engaging with education. Don identifies education as his lifelong passion and the most important issue facing society—more significant than oil reserves or global warming. He argues the kind of education provided determines the nation's future. Don criticizes the current system as impervious to change, overly bureaucratic, hierarchical, and based on outdated industrial structures. He notes people both inside and outside education are calling for reform, arguing the climate for change has never been better. However, systems are incapable of self-change and require external intervention—the purpose of his remarks.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Operating guidelines A framework document outlining operating guidelines for school system transformation. System-level requirements include… ▸ more
A framework document outlining operating guidelines for school system transformation. System-level requirements include supporting self-directed learning, adopting learning manager roles, separating teaching from certification, implementing performance-based assessment, organizing around competencies rather than disciplines, requiring teacher recent/relevant experience, and removing time as a course descriptor. Individual school, teacher, and learner guidelines follow but are incompletely detailed. The document represents Don's systematic approach to educational reform, establishing concrete structural and operational changes needed to shift from traditional discipline-based systems to competency and outcome-focused education.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Sorting My Rank is My Business A near-duplicate of "Sorting (2).doc" reiterating Don's fundamental opposition to student ranking in educational… ▸ more
A near-duplicate of "Sorting (2).doc" reiterating Don's fundamental opposition to student ranking in educational institutions. Don asserts class standing is personal business and schools should not publicize rankings. He argues educational enrollment differs from competition and should not be conducted as a race. Don identifies problems: achievement variance results primarily from differential time availability; schools limit achievement by constraining time; systems allow only one top student annually, penalizing students not schools. Don supports external educational competitions and recognition but opposes internal school ranking. He questions university admissions using rank despite minimal differences between ranked students and arguments that success depends on qualities beyond class standing. Don emphasizes schools should focus on education, not sorting, and universities should establish independent entrance criteria rather than relying on school rankings.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Technology EDUCATION (169 words):** Don advocates "Technology Education" as modern terminology replacing "Industrial Arts," supporting its… ▸ more
(169 words):** Don advocates "Technology Education" as modern terminology replacing "Industrial Arts," supporting its emergence as curriculum requirement. He positions technology as neutral discipline—like social studies, communications, mathematics—rather than vocational-specific. Don argues a course's vocational character derives from learner purpose (employment-seeking) rather than content; physics becomes vocational when pursued for employment preparation. He advocates secondary schools maintain technology alongside business, visual arts, health sciences, and applied arts courses. Technology clusters could encompass computers, fabrication, electronics, design, mechanics, energy. Don's critical insight: a course's academic or vocational character depends on instructor approach, not content. Physics taught academically differs from vocational physics through methodology and emphasis, not curriculum. This perspective challenged prevailing stigmatization of vocational education and positioned technology as respectable curriculum area accessible to all students regardless of post-secondary intent.
EDUCATION

Undated Testing standardized (145 words):** [Duplicate of File 2 - see above] Read · Download
Undated Unresolved Questions (98 words):** Don distills a lifetime of educational reflection into eight fundamental unresolved questions challenging… ▸ more
(98 words):** Don distills a lifetime of educational reflection into eight fundamental unresolved questions challenging system assumptions. Why are current graduation requirements optimal? Why ignore teacher performance in compensation? What justifies institutional credentialing? Why exclude non-school learning? Why force group learning when learning is individual? Why limit preparation to further education? How justify grade failures when grades serve administrative convenience? Why emphasize unmeasurable outcomes over demonstrable competencies? These questions reveal Don's core concerns: evidence-based policy, performance accountability, holistic learning recognition, individualized pacing, practical life preparation, and measurable assessment. The list encapsulates his career-long systematic critique of educational contradictions between stated goals and operational practices.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Vocational A personal reflection on what makes education "vocational" rather than academic. Don draws on his unique position as… ▸ more
A personal reflection on what makes education "vocational" rather than academic. Don draws on his unique position as one of the few New Brunswick teachers holding both academic and vocational licenses. He argues that vocational education's essence lies not in program naming, duration, or institutional designation, but in the learner's purpose. He introduces the concept of "life roles" (learner, citizen, family member, individual, producer, consumer) and argues that vocational education develops skills for the producer role. He emphasizes that performance standards in vocational contexts measure quality and quantity of work similar to employment standards, making this the defining characteristic that distinguishes vocational from general education regardless of content.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated What standards Don critiques the current grading system and proposes improvements to competency-based occupational standards. He… ▸ more
Don critiques the current grading system and proposes improvements to competency-based occupational standards. He questions what letter grades actually communicate about student capability and advocates for standards that measure individual performance against real-world occupational criteria. He emphasizes that standards should focus on "how well one does it" not just "what one can do," establish multiple performance levels rather than artificial divisions, and incorporate professional judgment rather than seeking mechanical sorting. Don argues standards are separate from training and should be based on actual employment performance criteria like dependability, work quality, and team collaboration rather than credential possession.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Work A four-letter word A revised version of the "Work" essay, presenting similar themes with enhanced clarity. Don emphasizes that while… ▸ more
A revised version of the "Work" essay, presenting similar themes with enhanced clarity. Don emphasizes that while parents still believe schools should prepare students for work, educators have moved away from this objective. He notes the disconnect between school policy documentation and actual employment preparation, uses the term "weasel words" like "career exploration" and "job shadowing" to describe inadequate substitutes for genuine work readiness training. Don appeals to educators to examine their institution's publications and engage school boards and government to reclaim preparing students for productive employment as an explicit educational objective. He expresses confidence that many educators share this view but feel disconnected from policy-making.

Undated Note Draft column critiquing PEI Department of Education's narrow focus on "delivering curriculum" versus developing people.… ▸ more
Draft column critiquing PEI Department of Education's narrow focus on "delivering curriculum" versus developing people. Don contrasts PEI's approach with other provinces like Alberta and New Brunswick, which emphasize lifelong learning attributes and success skills. The piece questions whether the Department's narrow mandate constrains teachers' ability to innovate and argues for aligning educational administration with holistic human development goals. This reflects Don's advocacy for systemic educational reform during his later career.

Read · Download

Undated 3-1 Performance Background Don Glendenning's analytical document on performance levels and grading systems in education. Document distinguishes… ▸ more
Don Glendenning's analytical document on performance levels and grading systems in education. Document distinguishes between testing (standardized achievement measurement), assessment (formative feedback for improvement), evaluation (summative judgment), grading (standardized measurement application), and standards (performance levels worthy of recognition). Don argues for separating administrative grades from performance levels in subject areas and separates teaching functions from ranking/grading functions, citing models from apprenticeships and International Baccalaureate. Document critically examines issues including conflating age-grade levels with performance levels and combining sorting with teaching functions. Published through Education 20/20 Inc., reflecting Don's advocacy for clearer educational assessment frameworks.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 5 Education advisor This document proposes establishing community-based educational advisory services for Islanders outside the formal… ▸ more
This document proposes establishing community-based educational advisory services for Islanders outside the formal school system. Don argues that while schools employ guidance counselors for enrolled students, there is no equivalent "family education advisor" to assist people of all ages in making educational decisions. He draws parallels to family doctors in healthcare and lawyers in legal matters, proposing an independent professional advisor who would provide personalized services including information, counseling, assessment, and referral. The advisor would serve entire communities rather than school districts and operate from accessible locations like libraries or municipal offices. The proposal emphasizes the complexity of education in the modern world and the critical need for individualized support.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Issues 2 A letter from Don Glendenning (signed at end) addressing issues in education to an editor, likely the Charlottetown… ▸ more
A letter from Don Glendenning (signed at end) addressing issues in education to an editor, likely the Charlottetown Guardian. The letter reflects on Don's 50 years on PEI and his observations of how education's meaning has narrowed from a broad developmental process to a focus on acquiring credentials (diplomas and degrees). He notes that PISA results have replaced community standards, and laments the loss of specific institutions (PVI and PCVH). Don advocates for system review addressing: common definitions glossary, stated program purposes, conceptual clarity, assessment methods, autonomy and accountability definitions, collaboration between providers and users, universal rating scales, informative transcripts, and recognition of learning context importance. He proposes two-stage reform: first, public conversation about education needs and development of vision/principles; second, a delivery plan. The letter calls for locally-led processes with outside specialist assistance, emphasizing that "everything should be on the table." This encapsulates Don's reform methodology: vision before structure.

Visual presentation document identifying the target population for education services: 150,000 Islanders in various life roles (individual, family member, citizen, learner, producer, consumer). Highlights that these Islanders need or want to develop and change attitudes, skills, knowledge, and values. The document serves as an infographic-style reference showing the breadth of Education 20/20 Inc.'s potential service population and the comprehensiveness of educational needs across life roles.

Undated 1 General handout Education 20/20 Inc. general handout and organizational information document. Presents the organization's mission ("A… ▸ more
Education 20/20 Inc. general handout and organizational information document. Presents the organization's mission ("A quality education for every Canadian"), vision, mandate, and activities (awards, newsletters, website, research, consultation, workshops). Lists board of directors including Don Glendenning as Treasurer at the time this version was prepared (indicating his leadership changed from President in other documents to Treasurer in this iteration). Emphasizes that quality education requires learners to be healthy, in safe/respectful environments, with relevant content linked to personal/community objectives, focused support, timely/independent information, and professional/autonomous/accountable teachers. References UNICEF standards.

Title page for a major educational publication by Education 20/20 Inc., featuring the central metaphor "Islanders on the road of life." Displays the company information (101 Kent Street, Charlottetown, PEI) and contact details. This cover represents the culmination of Don's educational frameworks and his signature phrase encapsulating his philosophy that education exists to prepare people for life's journey.

It outlines the same major service categories: governance and leadership, instruction, quality assurance, funding, information and counselling, human resources, and learning products. The document includes the same Education 20/20 Inc. contact information, suggesting these are related papers from a sustained education advocacy effort.

Undated 3 Smallchools Written amid debates over closing small rural schools, this piece proposes examining alternative educational delivery… ▸ more
Written amid debates over closing small rural schools, this piece proposes examining alternative educational delivery models rather than accepting school closure as inevitable. Don references emerging pedagogical approaches including learning environments, technology integration, charter schools, and differentiated teacher roles. He suggests that technological access could reduce dependence on traditional classroom instruction while teachers become coaches and assessors. The article proposes pilot charter-style schools as an alternative to closure, positioning small schools within a modernized educational ecosystem.

Undated 2 Labourarket Don responds to federal-to-provincial transfer of workforce training funding and responsibility. While supporting… ▸ more
Don responds to federal-to-provincial transfer of workforce training funding and responsibility. While supporting provincial control in principle, he expresses concerns about politicization, reduced worker mobility, and potential loss of federal support continuity. He advocates for employer and employee groups to lead public discussion on priorities and procedures, emphasizing that training funds must reach actual workforce development rather than administrative purposes. The piece reflects concern that provincial-level decision-making might prioritize local political interests over merit-based worker preparation.

Undated 6 Why school This substantial piece questions the purpose and design of schools, proposing that educational philosophy should… ▸ more
This substantial piece questions the purpose and design of schools, proposing that educational philosophy should address six life roles: citizen, consumer, family member, producer, individual, and learner. Don conducted informal community surveys about time allocation for each role and discovered lack of consensus on school purposes. He argues that communities should define school mandates before criticizing performance, and that schools cannot simultaneously prepare students for higher education and for practical life roles. The article calls for public discussion to establish shared expectations and accountability.

Undated 28 Storage of children Don references a New Zealand Herald article about schools as "storage lockers" for children while parents work, using… ▸ more
Don references a New Zealand Herald article about schools as "storage lockers" for children while parents work, using it to examine schools' evolving role. He proposes that schools must address three mandates: (1) helping Islanders develop citizenship attitudes, skills and knowledge; (2) developing people for community needs; and (3) providing childcare "housed, happy and out of harm's way." Don calls for this multi-dimensional mandate to be explicitly included in future PEI educational philosophy discussions, acknowledging that custodial services now substantially shape how family life is organized.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 29 Alignment Using vehicle alignment as metaphor, Don identifies misalignments requiring attention in school systems: between school… ▸ more
Using vehicle alignment as metaphor, Don identifies misalignments requiring attention in school systems: between school practice and research, outcomes and life roles, assessment and real-world standards, reporting and stated outcomes, timetables and individual learning speeds, and benchmarks and community standards. He advises parents concerned about student progress to review course outcomes with their child before parent-teacher meetings, then bring these outcomes to discussions. Don notes that course outcomes are sometimes provided during course orientation and are available on the Department of Education website, positioning knowledge of outcomes as essential to productive parent-school conversations.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated A Employers mixed messages Don articulates his foundational premise that most young people can learn most school content, though some require… ▸ more
Don articulates his foundational premise that most young people can learn most school content, though some require additional time. He argues schools must shift from "delivery mode" to "development mode"—focusing on individual needs, interests and plans rather than standardized content pacing. Schools must adjust time and resources to learner needs; failure to reach standards cannot be blamed on home or community but indicates insufficient school services. Don expresses concern that graduates lack basic literacy and numeracy for further study or employment. He argues that while government runs schools and restricts competition, it owes Islanders explanation and action plans regarding educational quality.

Identical content to File 18. This appears to be a version with a different title, or a duplicate filing suggesting Don was working with multiple versions or titles for this piece.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D 3 Report cards Don reflects on his old report cards and proposes that report cards should focus on future-oriented information… ▸ more
Don reflects on his old report cards and proposes that report cards should focus on future-oriented information exchange between school and family, similar to a follow-up doctor's visit. Rather than merely reporting past achievements, report cards should identify what needs to happen next to help learners meet their objectives. He advocates for parents to access course outcomes from the Department of Education website and suggests students should receive copies of learning outcomes. The letter addresses parent concerns about jargon and proposes that criterion-referenced reporting, with proper explanation, can serve families better than simple grades. His example of doctor-patient communication reflects his inclination toward professional service models.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D About Time-2 Don contrasts how service industries allocate time based on customer needs with how education allocates time regardless… ▸ more
Don contrasts how service industries allocate time based on customer needs with how education allocates time regardless of learner needs. In other sectors, providers estimate required time, book resources, deliver service, and complete. Education does the reverse: allocates fixed time regardless of whether students need more or less, penalizes early completion, and makes students repeat entire courses if they need additional time. He critiques this fundamental inefficiency and notes that education is unique in this dysfunctional approach to time allocation. The letter reflects his service management perspective and his observation that educational systems lag behind business practices in customer-responsive operations.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Accountability Don analyzes role descriptions from the Department of Education website, finding that while the Minister's… ▸ more
Don analyzes role descriptions from the Department of Education website, finding that while the Minister's responsibilities are clearly defined with measurable actions, the Deputy Minister and Superintendent roles are vague and lacking specific accomplishments. He concludes the organization has misaligned form and function, with decisions parachuted up to ministerial level rather than resolved at operational levels. This accountability deficit, he argues, is comforting for those seeking bureaucratic cover but frustrating for dedicated professionals. The analysis demonstrates his systems-thinking approach: examining actual organizational documentation to identify dysfunction. His critique reveals how government control creates lack of accountability at operational levels.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D BC Court decision Don discusses a British Columbia Court of Appeal decision that removed restrictions on class size and staffing… ▸ more
Don discusses a British Columbia Court of Appeal decision that removed restrictions on class size and staffing patterns, noting that such flexibility should reduce teacher stress and encourage innovation. He cites examples of schools that improved dramatically through non-traditional approaches: one Michigan school operated without a principal, and an Arizona school improved rankings by adding teaching assistants rather than reducing class size. He notes the BCTF appeal to the Supreme Court and suggests that if upheld, the decision could apply nationally. The letter shows his interest in evidence-based alternatives to conventional educational structures and his recognition that flexibility in staffing patterns enables innovation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Box Stores of Education Don uses a retail metaphor to critique schools as "box stores of education" that, while efficient at accommodating… ▸ more
Don uses a retail metaphor to critique schools as "box stores of education" that, while efficient at accommodating large numbers of learners, lack ability to cater to individual needs. He notes that box schools employ missionary-like zeal to capture all learners and provide babysitting services. While acknowledging their role, he advocates for educational diversity including specialized schools (basic skills, sciences, arts) and alternative settings (home learning, workplace). He notes Nova Scotia's Junior Achievement credit system and advocates for similar credit for experiential learning. The metaphor demonstrates his ability to make complex arguments accessible and his belief that educational diversity and local control serve learners better than monopolistic systems.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Changing market place Don observes that credentials are losing their "magic" and employers increasingly value actual education alongside… ▸ more
Don observes that credentials are losing their "magic" and employers increasingly value actual education alongside formal credentials. He cites the University of British Columbia's shift to "broad-based admissions" considering volunteer work, extracurricular activities, study abroad participation, and student engagement. Don notes that UBC seeks students likely to remain enrolled and contribute meaningfully. This letter reflects his understanding that education's value extends beyond credential accumulation and that selective institutions increasingly recognize personal development, engagement, and practical application of learning. His observation presages current employer and university concerns about skills, character development, and demonstrated competence beyond grades.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Children visiting the library Don reflects on observing children and adults at the Confederation Centre library engaged in welcoming, warm reading… ▸ more
Don reflects on observing children and adults at the Confederation Centre library engaged in welcoming, warm reading and storytelling activities. He contrasts this with schools, which he finds less welcoming, requiring children to separate from parents at the school entrance on day one. He proposes that libraries should play a significant role in transitioning young children from home to full-time school. The observation demonstrates his attention to the child's emotional experience and institutional welcomingness. The comparison suggests libraries may be more developmentally appropriate for young children's introduction to structured learning environments than traditional schools. This reflects his humanistic approach to education.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Cookie Cutter learners Don provides a concrete action plan for stakeholders to implement immediate, low-cost reforms: Students/Parents should… ▸ more
Don provides a concrete action plan for stakeholders to implement immediate, low-cost reforms: Students/Parents should communicate in depth with teachers about specific academic concerns; Teachers should review outcomes to ensure clarity, ambiguity-free language, and measurability; Department should identify reading as a separate subject on report cards; Trustees should conduct exit interviews with students who leave without graduating; Employers should base hiring on needed skills rather than subjects studied; Don will continue writing letters. He frames these as "baby steps" toward significant positive change. The tactical, achievable approach and multi-stakeholder framing demonstrate his practical leadership skills. His self-aware humor about his own role shows humility.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Cost of fixing Education Don catalogs the comprehensive government control of education: provincial governments appoint trustees, build schools,… ▸ more
Don catalogs the comprehensive government control of education: provincial governments appoint trustees, build schools, develop curriculum, set standards, hire teachers, measure achievement, limit competition, provide instruction, and issue credentials and grades. He argues this level of control far exceeds government involvement in any other sector, and consequently government has lost regulatory capacity. Because government operates schools, criticism of results becomes political criticism of government itself, making all educational change political. He argues the system has lost checks and balances that ensure quality. Don proposes government must delegate meaningful decision-making authority to school boards, schools, and teachers. This systematic analysis of how government monopoly creates political dysfunction represents his most comprehensive structural critique.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Cross country Check-up Don responds to a CBC Radio "Cross-Country Checkup" discussion of math skills, noting Quebec's strong PISA performance… ▸ more
Don responds to a CBC Radio "Cross-Country Checkup" discussion of math skills, noting Quebec's strong PISA performance may relate to "student-friendly" math outcomes. He expresses frustration at the absence of national analysis comparing math competencies and emphasizes the need for a "qualification framework" like those used in other countries. He advocates for a separate qualification authority to certify achievement in math, similar to apprenticeship, Swimming Canada, Conservatory Canada, and the Canadian Mathematical Society models. The letter shows his comparative knowledge of international education systems and his consistent proposal for independent assessment authorities. His public engagement with national radio shows his thought leadership.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Disconnect Don identifies what he calls "the great disconnect" in education—the disconnect between outcomes-based education theory… ▸ more
Don identifies what he calls "the great disconnect" in education—the disconnect between outcomes-based education theory and actual school practice. He notes that while extensive educational outcomes are published, report cards don't reflect performance on individual outcomes. Teachers cannot realistically assess and report on every outcome, creating a gap between stated educational philosophy and institutional practice. This letter reflects his attention to practical implementation challenges and the importance of alignment between policy rhetoric and classroom reality.

 Read · Download
Undated D Easier to get in A brief but provocative letter proposing that schools should focus on making it easier for students to enter rather… ▸ more
A brief but provocative letter proposing that schools should focus on making it easier for students to enter rather than imposing barriers. This reflects Don's student-centered philosophy and belief that education should be inclusive and accessible. The brevity and directness of the piece suggest a carefully crafted editorial comment designed to prompt reflection on student access and school responsiveness to learner needs.

 Read · Download
Undated D Educators and the education debate Drawing on a New Zealand Herald article, Don highlights how schools sometimes expect children to be "ready for school"… ▸ more
Drawing on a New Zealand Herald article, Don highlights how schools sometimes expect children to be "ready for school" rather than schools adapting to meet children where they are. He argues for child-centered approaches emphasizing the critical importance of parent-teacher communication for successful school transitions. This piece reflects his belief that institutional inflexibility represents a systemic failure, and his openness to international best practices and evidence-based approaches.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D In Defence of teachers Don defends teachers against widespread criticism, arguing that teachers are constrained by bureaucratic systems rather… ▸ more
Don defends teachers against widespread criticism, arguing that teachers are constrained by bureaucratic systems rather than inherently inferior. He catalogs restrictions: curriculum control, standardized testing schedules, prescribed texts, and undefined additional duties beyond teaching. He argues teachers are enveloped in "a cocoon of bureaucracy" that only employers and unions can change together, yet neither group demonstrates commitment to improvement. He advocates for professional development structures separate from union negotiations, as he observed in other provinces. This letter shows his empathy for teachers and focus on systemic constraints rather than individual blame.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Let dollars follow the sudent Don proposes specialized education clinics modeled on healthcare delivery (dental clinics, knee clinics), particularly… ▸ more
Don proposes specialized education clinics modeled on healthcare delivery (dental clinics, knee clinics), particularly for reading instruction. He advocates for clinics that would assess reading problems, create learning plans, and operate on fee-for-service bases. This letter shows his tendency to draw analogies across sectors and his interest in market mechanisms and specialization. He extends the concept to other skill areas, reflecting belief that education could benefit from medical model approaches to diagnosis and treatment.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Life long learning Based on extensive conversations across PEI about education, Don identifies reading as the most critical educational… ▸ more
Based on extensive conversations across PEI about education, Don identifies reading as the most critical educational concern parents raise. He critiques BC's appointment of a Superintendent of Reading as bureaucratic bloat rather than effective reform. Instead, he proposes making reading a distinct subject with assigned teachers, reporting on all levels, and developing common outcomes and assessment scales across all educators. He calls reading a "vital sign" of educational health and encourages public participation in education debate. This demonstrates his data-driven approach (gathering real concerns) and preference for structural clarity over administrative hierarchy.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Maintenance or improvement Don outlines a comprehensive reform platform emphasizing teacher focus on learning interactions, increased choice in… ▸ more
Don outlines a comprehensive reform platform emphasizing teacher focus on learning interactions, increased choice in schooling, and reduced school fixation. He argues teachers should accept learners as they find them (like medical doctors) rather than blame prior experiences. He advocates for staffing flexibility allowing specialists and paraprofessionals, greater student choice in pacing and course challenge opportunities, and developing community learning alternatives beyond schools. He notes PE has few unaligned education organizations serving learners. This piece synthesizes many of his recurring themes into a coherent reform agenda.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D New Model of Education Don proposes operating principles for education systems: all students should meet graduation requirements, principals… ▸ more
Don proposes operating principles for education systems: all students should meet graduation requirements, principals should be instructional leaders, exit standards must be measurable/attainable/relevant, time should adapt to student learning styles, reports should include skills development, programs should be individualized per resources, family education advisors should be available, and students should challenge courses for credit. He argues these principles create clarity for operational decisions. This letter presents a systematic framework for education design and demonstrates his ability to distill complex philosophy into actionable principles.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Opinion - AQUA This is Don's most comprehensive articulation of his qualification authority proposal. Using passport/visa analogy, he… ▸ more
This is Don's most comprehensive articulation of his qualification authority proposal. Using passport/visa analogy, he distinguishes credentials (what has been studied) from qualifications (what has been learned/can do). He argues these serve different purposes and shouldn't be combined. He proposes an independent qualification authority separate from schools to certify demonstrated competencies, operating fee-for-service. Such authority would reduce teacher-sorting conflicts, focus schools on learning, support lifelong learning, and could serve all Atlantic Canada. This represents his signature contribution to education reform thinking.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Parents need a say in Schooling Comparing education to healthcare, Don argues schools suffer from system-centered rather than client-centered culture.… ▸ more
Comparing education to healthcare, Don argues schools suffer from system-centered rather than client-centered culture. Parents feel excluded from meaningful dialogue about their children's learning. Unlike healthcare where patients receive individualized attention, education treats students as batch-processed. He notes public discussion focuses on schooling logistics (bussing, schedules, storm days) rather than learning outcomes. He contrasts this with doctors' question "What can I do for you?" which schools never ask. This piece captures his frustration with institutional inflexibility and client-unresponsiveness.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Partners This appears to be draft or outline material synthesizing Don's reform conclusions. It lists system criteria… ▸ more
This appears to be draft or outline material synthesizing Don's reform conclusions. It lists system criteria (collegial, flexibility, individualized learning), key conclusions (system lacks means for change; Premier must lead; action needed), and reform priorities. Categories include early childhood (family advisors, library-based), public education (decentralization, choice/markets, standards, innovation fund), and postsecondary (student-centered funding, performance-based payment). Despite formatting issues with incomplete items, it demonstrates his comprehensive approach to categorizing reforms across all education levels.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Qualifications Don identifies a fundamental mismatch: government invests over $200 million annually in schools, yet employers report… ▸ more
Don identifies a fundamental mismatch: government invests over $200 million annually in schools, yet employers report skill gaps and jobs go unfilled. Schools issue credentials describing what was studied; employers want qualifications indicating what was learned. He notes many countries (excepting US and Canada) have established qualification frameworks administered by independent authorities with standardized, nationally-recognized qualifications. He calls for Canada to establish similar framework, starting with basic skills standardization. This demonstrates his evidence-based approach and willingness to learn from international comparative practices.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Quality control Don uses restaurant quality control as analogy: customers vote with feet, regulators enforce standards, poor performers… ▸ more
Don uses restaurant quality control as analogy: customers vote with feet, regulators enforce standards, poor performers lose licenses. He contrasts this with education, a monopoly system where students and parents have no recourse for poor service, cannot access alternative suppliers without paying twice, and have limited choice. Schools are not client-centered or consumer-friendly, yet funding is identical regardless of quality. He calls for quality monitoring and consumer protection mechanisms in education comparable to other sectors. The piece (though containing some rough drafting) illustrates his consumer-choice orientation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Questions Don raises fundamental questions teachers cannot adequately answer: How can a student graduate unable to read? He… ▸ more
Don raises fundamental questions teachers cannot adequately answer: How can a student graduate unable to read? He distinguishes schooling from education and notes communication problems in school reporting. Report cards describe what was taught (subjects/grades) rather than what was learned (reading ability, writing skills, social competence). He critiques vague rating scales (A/B/C) undefined outside school contexts. He argues these communication gaps obscure actual learning and calls for improved reporting mechanisms aligned with learner outcomes. This piece demonstrates his attention to communication clarity and practical feedback systems.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Rethink standards This letter presents a brief but significant argument that educational standards should be reconsidered. Don critiques… ▸ more
This letter presents a brief but significant argument that educational standards should be reconsidered. Don critiques the practice of labeling students by years studied and proposes starting fresh with standards development. He defines standards as distinguishable levels of performance worthy of recognition, independent of time spent in school. The letter suggests that Canada's approach to schooling standards lacks the flexibility and competency-based focus needed for true educational advancement. Though brief, it encapsulates his broader philosophy of performance-based rather than age-based assessment.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Reverse thinking Don references New Zealand education research showing that half of children aren't adequately prepared for school… ▸ more
Don references New Zealand education research showing that half of children aren't adequately prepared for school transitions due to rigid institutional requirements. He highlights a critical finding: successful transitions depend on school-family communication rather than child compliance. The letter demonstrates his use of international best practices to support his argument that educational systems must become more flexible and responsive. He emphasizes the paradigm shift from "children must be ready for school" to "schools must be ready for children"—a cornerstone of his educational philosophy.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Small schools Don frames the small schools debate in philosophical terms, arguing that school size preferences reflect underlying… ▸ more
Don frames the small schools debate in philosophical terms, arguing that school size preferences reflect underlying educational philosophies. Large schools emphasize courses and standardized testing; small schools prioritize social-emotional development alongside academics. He advocates for schools with autonomy in operations, technology access, scheduling flexibility, and differentiated staffing. The letter positions Alberta's charter school system as a successful model and notes that educational philosophy should precede operational decisions. Don calls for updating PEI's educational philosophy, arguing current policies derive from outdated frameworks.
BIOGRAPHICAL
