 Read · Download
Undated D Superintendent of Reading Don questions the language of educational failure, noting that we don't label people as failures in other life… ▸ more
Don questions the language of educational failure, noting that we don't label people as failures in other life contexts—religion, medicine, or mortality. He distinguishes between education (skill and attitude development) and schooling (knowledge acquisition), arguing schools focus too narrowly on the latter. He critiques the importance society places on credentials while ignoring broader educational outcomes. The letter invites public engagement on reading improvement and suggests that how we frame success and failure significantly impacts educational outcomes. It challenges the deficit-based language prevalent in educational discourse.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Switch in our thinking A brief letter proposing a fundamental shift in educational focus from "faults in the teaching system" to "faults in… ▸ more
A brief letter proposing a fundamental shift in educational focus from "faults in the teaching system" to "faults in the grading system." Don notes that grading practices originated at Yale in the late 1700s, suggesting their historical basis may not match contemporary educational needs. The letter advocates for redirecting reform energy toward assessment systems rather than solely targeting teacher improvement, reflecting his conviction that grading structures are the real barrier to educational progress.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D The education label Don critiques both employers and the school system for their approaches to hiring and credentialing. He argues… ▸ more
Don critiques both employers and the school system for their approaches to hiring and credentialing. He argues employers spend insufficient time defining job requirements and evaluating actual competencies, instead relying on vague credentials. He suggests employers learn to "read the label" by consulting school principals and understanding transcript categories rather than blindly accepting degrees. The letter proposes a collaborative approach where employers specify needed skills upfront and schools align curricula accordingly, challenging the disconnect between education and workforce needs.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D attendance Don argues that poor school attendance is a symptom rather than the primary problem within educational systems. While… ▸ more
Don argues that poor school attendance is a symptom rather than the primary problem within educational systems. While acknowledging the link between attendance and achievement, he notes that making attendance compulsory doesn't address root causes. He identifies underlying causes in home environments (health, income, food insecurity, transportation) and school contexts (lack of engagement or advocacy). Best practices for improving attendance include collaboration, incentives, family involvement, personalization, and support—all addressing systemic rather than compliance issues. The letter reframes attendance as a diagnostic indicator requiring investigation of deeper structural problems.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D- School Autonomy Don advocates for school autonomy based on PISA test evidence showing students in autonomous schools outperform those… ▸ more
Don advocates for school autonomy based on PISA test evidence showing students in autonomous schools outperform those in centrally controlled systems. He proposes specific autonomy provisions: principals should control staffing decisions (recruitment, hiring, assignment, supervision), budget allocation reflecting local priorities, and professional development tailored to school needs. He argues autonomy improves not just test performance but school culture, engagement, and spirit. Don's position reflects his conviction that educational improvement requires devolving decision-making authority from central bureaucracies to school-level professionals closest to student needs.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D- Teacher pay Don challenges the basis of teacher compensation, arguing that paying teachers by years of formal study and experience… ▸ more
Don challenges the basis of teacher compensation, arguing that paying teachers by years of formal study and experience lacks logical foundation. He contends people should be compensated for actual services rendered—the quality and impact of their work, not the credentials or seniority they possess. The letter advocates for performance-based rather than credential-based compensation, though the piece is incomplete. Don's argument suggests teachers should be evaluated and rewarded based on educational outcomes and student learning rather than inputs like degrees and years on the job.

Undated D-2 Communications Don addresses a different aspect of alignment: the coherence between learning outcomes, curriculum, assessment, and… ▸ more
Don addresses a different aspect of alignment: the coherence between learning outcomes, curriculum, assessment, and reporting. He defines outcomes as a contract between teacher and student, each holding a copy. He outlines specific alignment challenges: curriculum disconnected from assessment, assessment disconnected from life outcomes, and reporting misaligned with actual student learning. Don provides practical advice for parents to use learning outcomes as discussion anchors in parent-teacher meetings, positioning outcomes documentation as a transparency and accountability tool. The letter suggests students and parents often lack access to these critical documents, identifying an institutional accountability gap.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-2 Preparing for school Don challenges the concept of young children "preparing for school," questioning whether 4-6 year-olds should adapt to… ▸ more
Don challenges the concept of young children "preparing for school," questioning whether 4-6 year-olds should adapt to schools or whether schools should adapt to developmental stages. He argues that other institutions (churches, doctors' offices, farms) accommodate visiting children, so why not schools? This letter reflects a child-centered educational philosophy and questions whether rigid school preparation demands are developmentally appropriate. While Don notes this isn't his expertise area, he suggests schools have greater obligation to adapt their practices to childhood development than children have to pre-adapt to institutional structures.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-3 Educational climate Don observes positive shifts in PEI's education landscape, attributing changes to election debates, budget discussions,… ▸ more
Don observes positive shifts in PEI's education landscape, attributing changes to election debates, budget discussions, new leadership (Minister and Deputy Minister), and advocacy from local business chambers and youth. He commends the Department's graduation requirement review and chambers' attention to literacy needs. However, he scrutinizes the Secondary Literacy Assessment policy, noting that students must write but need not pass, results serve teachers rather than students, and business/postsecondary input was not explicitly solicited despite their expressed concerns. This letter demonstrates Don's capacity for balanced critique—recognizing progress while holding institutions accountable to implementation details and stakeholder engagement.
BIOGRAPHICAL

 Read · Download
Undated D-3-B Educational climate Don presents a comprehensive organizational critique arguing PEI's Department should be renamed "Department of Public… ▸ more
Don presents a comprehensive organizational critique arguing PEI's Department should be renamed "Department of Public Instruction" to clarify actual function. He identifies systemic problems: emphasis on school attendance rather than education improvement, limited support for independent/part-time learners, services dominated by youth focus, emphasis on subject delivery over emotional and employment skill development, lack of customization, organizational structure serving schools rather than education strategy, accountability gaps (Minister operates schools but Premier monitors performance), and institutional silos preventing integrated services. This letter represents Don's mature analysis of organizational dysfunction and his conviction that structural reform, not incremental adjustment, is necessary for systemic improvement in PEI education.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-Outside the box Don expresses cautious skepticism about education improvement prospects in PEI, noting "new people bring new ideas but… ▸ more
Don expresses cautious skepticism about education improvement prospects in PEI, noting "new people bring new ideas but I've not picked up any buzz yet" and observing that "educators are still thinking within the box." He discusses charter schools (Alberta model) as a possibility but questions whether adding charters truly improves systems. He then presents more radical alternatives: disconnect specific schools from system control, grant them autonomous trustee boards with staffing autonomy, and operate them as pilot projects (suggesting Murray River and Alberton to remove bureaucratic influence). Don also proposes siphoning resources to Summerside's learning center and opening one school summers for remedial support. The letter reveals both his skepticism about genuine reform willingness and his creativity in proposing concrete alternative structures.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-What's stopping us Don asserts that PEI has excellent educators throughout the system (Department, school boards, colleges, universities,… ▸ more
Don asserts that PEI has excellent educators throughout the system (Department, school boards, colleges, universities, private schools) and asks what prevents progress. The letter then lists obstacles in fragmented form: unanswered questions, lack of debate, bureaucracy, fear, autonomy concerns, formulae, politicization, CEA (union), democracy deficit, and blurred vision. This letter reads as a provocative diagnosis suggesting the barriers to education improvement are political, cultural, and systemic rather than resource or expertise based. The list format emphasizes multiple intersecting obstacles and implies that addressing education challenges requires overcoming institutional inertia, political constraints, and organizational silos—not hiring better educators.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-we have the people Don reports positive news about education in PEI: he has met many great people throughout the province with expertise,… ▸ more
Don reports positive news about education in PEI: he has met many great people throughout the province with expertise, ideas, and willingness to help make PEI an "education Province." He notes that most if not all needed people and ideas already exist within PEI communities; they are waiting for a provincial signal of intent and invitation to join efforts. This letter, positioned at the letter sequence's end, provides optimistic counterweight to earlier skepticism. Don emphasizes that education improvement isn't resource-constrained but leadership-constrained—the province needs to demonstrate commitment and invite community participation. This reflects his belief in collaborative, community-engaged education reform.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D1 Early Education Don responds to Nicholas Kristof's New York Times essay about early childhood education reducing community inequality.… ▸ more
Don responds to Nicholas Kristof's New York Times essay about early childhood education reducing community inequality. Don concurs that early childhood education and reading are education's highest-priority areas but disagrees with organizational approach. He argues PEI correctly recognizes postsecondary/adult education's distinct needs (separate department) and similarly should create specialized early childhood services. Don proposes: early childhood deserves equal consideration with distinct development focus rather than school-preparation focus; early childhood specialists should conduct home visits; school-based early education wrongly models itself on hospital-based pediatrics; early childhood providers need freedom unavailable to traditional teachers. Don emphasizes education is lifelong beginning at birth, making early years most critical, yet questions why this receives minimal attention despite research consensus. This letter shows Don's sophisticated understanding of lifecycle education and organizational design principles.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D1 What Gets Measured Don argues reading is a key skill and proposes high school graduation requires demonstrated reading proficiency at… ▸ more
Don argues reading is a key skill and proposes high school graduation requires demonstrated reading proficiency at specified levels: ability to read diverse printed material including newspaper editorial pages "with independence, fluency and ease." He notes reading ability can be measured using available reading scales and proposes making these scales widely accessible to students, parents, and employers. Don advocates elevating reading's profile by making it a separate required subject with clear performance levels, adjusted school schedules ensuring each student receives needed support, regular feedback to learner and parents, and minimum proficiency as graduation requirement. He also proposes students should challenge for credit at any time. Don concludes by positioning these steps as demonstrating PEI's seriousness about education and reading's significance in learning. This letter shows his practical approach to implementing measurement-based education reform and his conviction that standards, assessment, and feedback must be transparent to all stakeholders.

 Read · Download
Undated D3 An Arab Spring Don observes emerging signs of educational reform, comparing them to springtime harbingers. He identifies teacher… ▸ more
Don observes emerging signs of educational reform, comparing them to springtime harbingers. He identifies teacher frustration as a primary concern, noting that workload and interference with core teaching activities—corridor duty, fundraising, sports absences, administrative burdens—undermine professional satisfaction. The piece advocates for systemic changes that address the conditions preventing effective teaching, recognizing that technical competence without proper working conditions cannot deliver quality education.

Undated D3 Premier This comprehensive proposal outlines Don's vision for educational transformation, positioning the Premier as the key… ▸ more
This comprehensive proposal outlines Don's vision for educational transformation, positioning the Premier as the key decision-maker. He identifies critical changes: increasing choice, establishing clear standards, empowering schools as change agents with autonomy and accountability, improving early childhood education, and restructuring governance. The document contains extensive bulleted recommendations across early childhood, public education, and postsecondary sectors, reflecting Don's systematic thinking and belief that education requires leadership action rather than perpetual study.

Undated D College Ready or Life Ready Don critiques the emphasis on "college readiness," arguing that education's ultimate goal is preparing people for life… ▸ more
Don critiques the emphasis on "college readiness," arguing that education's ultimate goal is preparing people for life beyond school. He reframes college preparation as an interim step, not the end goal, and emphasizes that schools should equip students with diverse skills for multiple life roles. He calls for substantive public debate about educational objectives and expresses frustration at the absence of community dialogue on fundamental educational questions, positioning citizens as stakeholders entitled to voice their perspectives.

Don identifies emerging signs of positive educational change: teacher performance reviews, broadened entrance standards, increased skills emphasis, public engagement recognition, and decentralization calls. He uses seasonal metaphors to suggest these isolated signals indicate a broader warming trend in education. The optimistic piece demonstrates Don's ability to recognize incremental progress toward reform and his belief that multiple actors contribute to systemic change. It reflects his role as observer and cheerleader for educational improvement.

Don supports expanded arts education and proposes a specialized arts school for PEI students pursuing arts careers. He suggests a charter school model might offer greater flexibility than traditional public systems. The brief letter supports Ian Saunders' advocacy for music and extends it to arts generally, reflecting Don's belief that diverse student interests and career paths require specialized institutional options alongside general education.

Undated D Autism Tutors Don observes private schools offering customized post-secondary programs to fill education gaps and questions why… ▸ more
Don observes private schools offering customized post-secondary programs to fill education gaps and questions why public systems don't provide similar services. He identifies an "education aftermarket" need: makeup courses, grade improvements, and non-academic skill development (study skills, problem-solving, communication). Rather than critiquing private schools, he positions gap-filling as a public responsibility and advocates for expanded public sector offerings. The letter reflects Don's belief that education systems should serve diverse learner needs throughout the lifespan.

The filename suggests a focus on vocabulary, but the body addresses governance models and institutional design. This duplicate reflects Don's document management practices during the drafting process.

Undated New premier Highlight Don addresses the incoming premier with constructive proposals for education reform. He encourages updating PEI's… ▸ more
Don addresses the incoming premier with constructive proposals for education reform. He encourages updating PEI's Philosophy of Education document, arguing the current version addresses only K-12 schooling and ignores lifelong learning, early childhood education, upgrading programs, and self-directed learning. He recommends striking a committee with public members to develop a comprehensive, forward-looking philosophy and revision of government's role in education. Don positions education transformation as "Job 1" for the new government, noting that clear educational vision would significantly improve outcomes.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated School shakeup Using the same struggling mathematics student case, Don criticizes how schools handle academic difficulty through… ▸ more
Using the same struggling mathematics student case, Don criticizes how schools handle academic difficulty through structural barriers rather than academic support. When students move to lower-level courses, schools create detours that reduce post-secondary options, delay advancement, decrease employment prospects, and potentially damage lifetime earning potential and personal development. Don emphasizes that education's purpose is to help students develop their fullest capacities, and that alternative options—extra instruction, specialized support, remediation—better serve this goal than institutional detours that effectively limit futures.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Who should operate schools Don argues against direct government operation of schools, proposing instead that while government has an important… ▸ more
Don argues against direct government operation of schools, proposing instead that while government has an important role in education, it should not operate schools. His concerns center on politicization, centralized decision-making that's distant from schools, institutional resistance to change, and government neglect of other essential educational responsibilities. This positions Don as favoring decentralized governance and greater school autonomy while maintaining government financial support and policy oversight.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated oo Kudos Don commends the Summerside Rotary Club for establishing a Summerside Learning Centre and Murphy's Community Centre for… ▸ more
Don commends the Summerside Rotary Club for establishing a Summerside Learning Centre and Murphy's Community Centre for their Stratford After School Program. He praises these initiatives for recognizing education extends beyond schooling and requires community partnership. He notes the "care" function became critical during winter storms, emphasizing schools cannot provide all services alone. The letter celebrates non-governmental educational contributions and affirms that vibrant communities require education partnerships beyond public schools.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 00 Educational drugstore Don proposes creating an "education drugstore"—a physical location where parents, grandparents, and students can browse… ▸ more
Don proposes creating an "education drugstore"—a physical location where parents, grandparents, and students can browse and purchase supplementary educational materials aligned with school curricula. After visiting the Provincial Learning Materials Distribution Centre, he recognized the gap between online availability and tangible access to materials. He envisions a retail-like space where customers handle actual resources before purchasing, potentially staffed by education specialists. Don identifies this as an underserved market niche that could enhance family support for student learning.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-2 New vision-1 Glendenning observes that public education has lost its way through lack of vision, inward focus, inflexibility, and… ▸ more
Glendenning observes that public education has lost its way through lack of vision, inward focus, inflexibility, and remoteness from communities. The system lacks clear focus, measurable goals, community engagement, and internal alignment. He attributes problems to organizational design rather than personnel, tracing issues to poor vision definition and failure to apply "form follows function" principles. He distinguishes between a "Department of Education" and the existing "Department of Public Instruction." He cites declining importance of traditional credentials, referencing companies dropping degree requirements and "Most Likely to Succeed" film showing project-based learning's effectiveness. He proposes project-based learning focused on basic skills, particularly mathematics, as a reform strategy aligned with emerging educational approaches.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-20 Why schools This brief letter articulates four fundamental purposes for schools: providing safe environments for children until age… ▸ more
This brief letter articulates four fundamental purposes for schools: providing safe environments for children until age 18, offering instruction across diverse subjects, preparing students for post-secondary institutions, and ensuring young people learn citizenship skills. The stark simplicity of this list contrasts with the complexity of organizational problems Glendenning discusses elsewhere. This represents foundational thinking about educational purpose before systems become distorted by bureaucracy, political interference, and misaligned incentives. The brevity suggests this may have been submitted as a letter to the editor or draft meant for expansion, serving as a baseline statement of core educational functions.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-22 Measuring one's level of education-1 This concise letter proposes reconsidering how we measure educational attainment. Glendenning makes an analogy: we… ▸ more
This concise letter proposes reconsidering how we measure educational attainment. Glendenning makes an analogy: we don't measure health by hospital stay duration, wealth by years worked, or spirituality by hours in church—so why measure education by time spent in school? This aphoristic approach challenges the fundamental metric of educational success: enrollment duration rather than learning outcomes. The brevity and conceptual elegance of this argument demonstrate Glendenning's ability to distill complex organizational problems into memorable principles. The question suggests education should be measured by demonstrated competence and learning achievement rather than institutional attendance.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-24 Why ask for high school Glendenning confronts the credibility crisis of high school diplomas. He notes that employers require high school… ▸ more
Glendenning confronts the credibility crisis of high school diplomas. He notes that employers require high school credentials, yet articles document rising graduation rates concurrent with falling basic skills, wide subject-matter gaps (6-8 years in some grades), and students in Grade 10 with Grade 6 mathematics levels. He acknowledges conventional arguments: teacher overwork, student homework resistance, test limitations, home environment factors, and social promotion principles. However, he argues it's time to stop pretending. While maintaining diploma issuance if desired, institutions should also grant achievement-based qualifications documenting actual competence. He cites existing models—apprenticeship programs and International Baccalaureate—that successfully separate credentials from qualifications.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-4 Learning partnership Glendenning reviews the newly created Learning Partners Advisory Council's terms of reference with qualified… ▸ more
Glendenning reviews the newly created Learning Partners Advisory Council's terms of reference with qualified enthusiasm. While partnerships can sometimes obscure fuzzy thinking, he sees potential merit. However, he identifies structural concerns. When organizations nominate representatives rather than individuals being selected for their personal expertise, representatives must advocate organizational positions and report back for instructions rather than thinking creatively beyond institutional boundaries. Half the council's members represent organizations, potentially limiting "outside the box" thinking. He questions whether such structures encourage participants to think independently about systemic problems or whether they default to protecting organizational interests. The letter raises fundamental questions about how advisory councils can genuinely function as collaborative problem-solving forums versus becoming extensions of existing bureaucratic structures.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-5 fundammental problrms Glendenning summarizes core educational problems as structural and organizational rather than substantive. Drawing on… ▸ more
Glendenning summarizes core educational problems as structural and organizational rather than substantive. Drawing on insights from a former trustee, he identifies five fundamental issues: lack of clarity about purpose and function, absence of autonomy at operational levels, unclear accountability systems, insufficient freedom to act, and absence of normal market forces that drive quality improvement. He contends these problems cannot be resolved through adding resources—more professional development days, new courses, additional technology, changed graduation requirements, or higher achievement standards. These are matters government controls and should be capable of managing through better organizational practices. The letter synthesizes his systematic analysis, arguing that systemic redesign, not incremental resource allocation, is essential for educational improvement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 11 Debate Don celebrates the increasing public debate about education and calls for continued coverage of educational issues… ▸ more
Don celebrates the increasing public debate about education and calls for continued coverage of educational issues equivalent to business and sports reporting. He responds to specific articles about reading requirements and school responsibility for work preparation, noting that PEI Department of Education literature lacks clear statements about required reading achievement or work-preparation roles. Emphasizes that clear, unequivocal statements from school systems about their purposes and responsibilities would provide necessary direction. Calls for Guardian to publish a full page of responses from students, parents, and citizens about educational expectations. Illustrates his belief in transparency, clear communication, and public dialogue as mechanisms for educational improvement and accountability.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-8 Uniqueness of sector Don references Donald Savoie's book and a New York Times article about French schools' "stifling hierarchy,… ▸ more
Don references Donald Savoie's book and a New York Times article about French schools' "stifling hierarchy, micromanagement, centralized decision-making," noting similar dynamics in Canadian education. He identifies education as uniquely problematic: it is a mandatory monopoly (required participation ages 0-18/20), functions as a formula-driven service-delivery system designed at provincial level, and lacks mechanisms for checking, balancing, or responding to community needs. Lists systemic barriers: focus solely on knowledge, payment based on qualifications, rigid grading systems, insufficient skills emphasis, predetermined learning time, and absence of checks and balances. The letter treats education's structural characteristics as distinctive problems requiring systemic reform beyond typical service-sector issues.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-9 Youth problem Don frames youth employment/continuation challenges as an educational system problem rather than individual student… ▸ more
Don frames youth employment/continuation challenges as an educational system problem rather than individual student failure. Many young people exit the school system lacking credits, knowledge, or skills needed for further education or employment, yet he rejects blame-the-student-or-parents interpretations. Instead, he advocates society has responsibility to increase these young people's chances of success. Based on extensive conversations with educators and stakeholders, he identifies key systemic gaps: absence of clear educational model defining what education is, who it serves, and what outcomes matter; lack of a functioning Department of Education with appropriate mandate; and absence of delivery models matching the educational philosophy. The letter demonstrates his conviction that systemic responsibility precedes individual blame.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-Educational pharmacy During a visit to Royalty Centre and observation of the Learning Materials Distribution Centre (LMDC), Don poses… ▸ more
During a visit to Royalty Centre and observation of the Learning Materials Distribution Centre (LMDC), Don poses critical questions about educational resource distribution and access. He questions whether shelves of materials are only available to teachers, whether differentiated resources exist for students ahead or behind grade-level peers, whether individual student/parent browsing and purchasing options exist (as in college/university bookstores), and whether education product production should be a private-sector function. The letter critiques the centralized, teacher-controlled, standardized distribution model as potentially limiting to student choice, differentiation, and consumer engagement. Reflects his broader concern that monopolistic, centralized systems inherently limit innovation and individual responsiveness.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Criteria Don articulates evaluative criteria for assessing educational system changes, grounded in two foundational purposes:… ▸ more
Don articulates evaluative criteria for assessing educational system changes, grounded in two foundational purposes: (1) help young people develop skills for their futures, and (2) ensure community has skills needed to create desirable community life. He proposes three judgment criteria: (a) Will change increase opportunities for children developing skills needed for their futures? (b) Will change improve the community? (c) Considering everything, is this the best fund allocation? He laments that all three Maritime provinces' education department websites lack clear purpose statements (reviewed pre-writing), containing "wordy" language scoring high on "fog index." He identifies four common purposes (postsecondary prep, employment prep, develop fullest potential, citizenship) plus a fifth: "provide people with skills needed to maintain the community we call home." He calls on citizens to tell government what schools are for, rather than waiting for government declarations.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated d-Math Don addresses confusion from using "grade" to denote both age-based cohorts and achievement standards. Teachers report… ▸ more
Don addresses confusion from using "grade" to denote both age-based cohorts and achievement standards. Teachers report 4-8 year achievement ranges within single grades, creating cascading problems: advanced students become bored, struggling students discouraged, teachers frustrated, parents confused, diploma value declines, public confidence erodes. He notes International Baccalaureate, Red Cross, PISA, P-CAP, and qualification authorities all use "level" terminology for achievement. Renaming would allow students to pursue different subjects at different levels (Grade 11 student simultaneously at Level 7 Math, Level 4 Physics, Level 6 Literature). This proposal directly addresses systemic heterogeneity by replacing age-based lockstep progression with achievement-responsive pathways. Reflects his consistent advocacy for clarity, standards, and flexible personalization within structured frameworks.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 12 Charter Schools Don Glendenning frames the charter schools debate, moving beyond simplistic arguments about public versus private… ▸ more
Don Glendenning frames the charter schools debate, moving beyond simplistic arguments about public versus private education. He identifies five fundamental issues deserving public attention: the distinction between education and schooling, differing stakeholder expectations for schools, roles and responsibilities of various parties, the significance of credentials, and whether teaching and certification should remain separate functions. Rather than advocating for charter schools outright, he calls for thoughtful debate on these foundational questions that affect all educational models.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 2 Labour market Glendenning expresses concerns about the federal-to-provincial transfer of labour market training funds, warning… ▸ more
Glendenning expresses concerns about the federal-to-provincial transfer of labour market training funds, warning against provincial training becoming subject to political patronage and local rather than national workforce mobility. He advocates for employer and employee groups to lead public discussion on appropriate policies and priorities. His analysis reflects concern that without federal oversight, training funds might be misallocated and that smaller provinces like PEI need to train workers for national and international competition, not just local needs. The letter shows his grasp of macroeconomic workforce development.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 3 Small schools Glendenning proposes that the false choice between closing and maintaining small schools misses better alternatives. He… ▸ more
Glendenning proposes that the false choice between closing and maintaining small schools misses better alternatives. He advocates examining successful educational practices elsewhere, including the role of learning environment, teacher expectations, and technological innovation. He suggests pilot "charter-style schools" in affected communities with flexible staffing, expanded computer access, and distance education options. Rather than choosing between status quo and closure, he champions redesigning the system itself to make small schools educationally and economically viable.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 4 Challenge Glendenning argues that students should be able to challenge for school, college, and university credits based on… ▸ more
Glendenning argues that students should be able to challenge for school, college, and university credits based on demonstrated competency through examination, following the model used in language placement testing. He advocates for published course descriptions and the option to study independently and test for credit, freeing time for advanced study. Drawing on his own experience in carpentry, he illustrates how many people possess practical knowledge and skills not reflected in formal credentials and should be allowed to formalize their learning through assessment.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 5 Why school Don questions fundamental assumptions about schools' purpose, conducting informal community surveys to determine what… ▸ more
Don questions fundamental assumptions about schools' purpose, conducting informal community surveys to determine what percentages of school time should prepare students for different life roles (citizenship, consumer, family member, producer, individual, learner). His analysis shows broad community consensus that schools should prepare for multiple life roles, not just college preparation, yet no formal agreement exists. He calls for community dialogue to establish clear school mandates before criticizing results, and identifies the gap between community expectations and educator perceptions as a critical obstacle to improvement.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 7 Choice Drawing an analogy to consumer choice in other services, Glendenning argues parents should be able to select individual… ▸ more
Drawing an analogy to consumer choice in other services, Glendenning argues parents should be able to select individual teachers as easily as they select doctors or lawyers. He proposes restructuring schools with teacher-advisers who work with students for multiple years (similar to medical primary care models), with students referred to specialists as needed. While acknowledging scheduling challenges, he contends that student and parent choice would improve accountability, recognize teaching excellence, and shift responsibility for education appropriately toward families. The consumer-service-provider model reflects his belief in responsive, accountable institutions.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 8 Graduation Glendenning reports on his survey of 40 education leaders (Deputy Ministers, university presidents, college presidents,… ▸ more
Glendenning reports on his survey of 40 education leaders (Deputy Ministers, university presidents, college presidents, superintendents) asking whether current graduation requirements predict success in post-secondary education or employment. Only one respondent affirmed that course patterns matter significantly. He contrasts existing requirements with New Zealand's National Certificate in Employment Skills, which focuses on practical workplace competencies (reading, writing, listening, problem-solving, teamwork, cultural communication). He suggests PEI should adopt competency-based alternatives that better serve the 50% of students entering workforce rather than higher education.
BIOGRAPHICAL

 Read · Download
Undated 9 Change Responding to John Eldon Green's column suggesting systemic school change is impossible, Glendenning disagrees,… ▸ more
Responding to John Eldon Green's column suggesting systemic school change is impossible, Glendenning disagrees, acknowledging real barriers but asserting that change is achievable with strong leadership, clear vision, and commitment. He references scholarly articles on education reform and notes that most teachers would welcome opportunities to teach differently if the system permitted. He advocates for PEI to become a leader in school improvement, developing systems that address documented concerns about current practices. The tone combines idealism with pragmatic recognition of implementation challenges.
BIOGRAPHICAL

Undated 1 School Closings Glendenning proposes separating three distinct decisions conflated in school closure policies: building availability,… ▸ more
Glendenning proposes separating three distinct decisions conflated in school closure policies: building availability, resource accessibility (library, labs), and transportation safety. He argues schools should maintain regular schedules with individual teacher decisions about travel feasibility, and families deciding whether children attend. Rather than administrative convenience closures, students should decide to stay home based on personal circumstances. This reflects his philosophy that learning is individual, not collective, and that institutional policies should support individual choice rather than impose uniform solutions.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 10 Standards Commending PEI's kindergarten program introduction, Glendenning distinguishes between occupational standards (what one… ▸ more
Commending PEI's kindergarten program introduction, Glendenning distinguishes between occupational standards (what one can do) and educational standards (disciplinary knowledge), arguing that standards should be performance-based, not credential-based. He opposes paying people for credentials rather than demonstrated capability and advocates establishing occupational standards based on actual kindergarten teaching tasks. He warns against squeezing out capable teachers lacking degrees, and calls for assessing ability to perform actual job functions—a principled stance on merit-based employment.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 12 Funding Proposing that school funding should mirror post-secondary models—combining base institutional grants with… ▸ more
Proposing that school funding should mirror post-secondary models—combining base institutional grants with enrollment-driven funds reflecting student choice—Glendenning argues this would improve accountability without increasing total spending. He advocates dividing school budgets into a guaranteed portion and an enrollment-contingent portion, such that schools gain or lose revenue based on attracting students. This market-based approach would require schools to respond to community preferences while preserving universal public education. It reflects his consistent theme of introducing accountability through choice.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 2 Bullying Glendenning addresses school violence and bullying by first asserting that schools are not responsible for causing the… ▸ more
Glendenning addresses school violence and bullying by first asserting that schools are not responsible for causing the problem but may have a constructive role. He identifies multiple intervention points: school policies (establishing safe learning environments), curriculum additions (conflict resolution, teamwork, communication), organizational models supporting individual learning and responsibility, and facility design/scheduling. He emphasizes the need to address fundamental questions about schools' role before implementing reactive programs, and calls for attention to environmental factors affecting behavior rather than treating symptoms alone.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 4-OECD Responding to OECD education assessment results, Glendenning advocates not increasing class sizes or changing teacher… ▸ more
Responding to OECD education assessment results, Glendenning advocates not increasing class sizes or changing teacher requirements, but instead clarifying outcome expectations, defining performance levels, distributing standards to all stakeholders, developing aligned materials and teaching strategies, and providing frequent progress reports. He emphasizes that clear, measurable, learner-understood expectations should precede structural changes. His recommendations prioritize clarity and alignment over resource increases, reflecting his philosophy that systemic coherence matters as much as spending levels.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 6 Qualifrication authority Distinguishing education from schooling, Glendenning argues school transcripts inadequately capture learners' practical… ▸ more
Distinguishing education from schooling, Glendenning argues school transcripts inadequately capture learners' practical capabilities—communication, teamwork, problem-solving, technical skills. He proposes an independent regional qualification authority (separate from teaching institutions) to assess actual educational outcomes, preventing conflicts of interest inherent in schools certifying their own students. He references the New Zealand Qualification Authority model and proposes an Atlantic Qualification Authority headquartered in PEI, supporting self-directed learning while providing third-party validation of competence. This represents a sophisticated credential-reform proposal.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 7 Who needs to know Glendenning questions testing's purposes and appropriate audience. Testing serves diagnostic (establishing performance… ▸ more
Glendenning questions testing's purposes and appropriate audience. Testing serves diagnostic (establishing performance levels) and sorting (ranking learners) functions. He argues that learners, teachers, and parents need diagnostic information for instructional improvement, while planners need aggregate data about learner populations needing different support levels. However, he questions whether schools should sort learners, arguing that unlike races where ranking matters, educational success is potentially universal. He contends schools should test to improve instruction but not to publicize individual rankings, suggesting that sorting wastes instructional time while providing no learning benefit.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 8 small schools Reframing the small schools debate, Glendenning argues the question should not be whether to close small schools but… ▸ more
Reframing the small schools debate, Glendenning argues the question should not be whether to close small schools but whether they can deliver quality education cost-effectively. He suggests better questions are "Can we design cost-effective models through small schools?" and "What system changes would make small schools work?" He contends that current system inflexibility may be responsible for small school difficulties rather than size itself, and that educational rather than administrative-convenience decisions should guide closure determinations. This represents his consistent strategy of reframing debates toward system redesign.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 9 Career education Commending new island programs in welding, carpentry, and automotive technology, Glendenning emphasizes that each… ▸ more
Commending new island programs in welding, carpentry, and automotive technology, Glendenning emphasizes that each educational level should prepare for the next level or employment. While schools have emphasized further education preparation, these new courses recognize employment preparation responsibility. He advocates measuring career course achievement against workplace criteria rather than academic standards—quality, supervision level, and quantity of work. He suggests work-based criteria should be added to transcripts and urges employer representatives to participate in program advisory committees. Commending the Minister's leadership, he calls for expanding career programs to non-traditional fields.

Undated Purpose 3 Don provides comprehensive analysis of educational purpose statements, examining how different organizations define… ▸ more
Don provides comprehensive analysis of educational purpose statements, examining how different organizations define their mission and why clarity of purpose drives employee satisfaction and productivity. He surveys various purpose statements from education literature and contrasts them with PEI's existing system purpose, finding them inadequate as guides for implementation. Don argues that meaningful purpose statements must be clear, understandable, and actionable, then argues PEI's current statement lacks sufficient specificity to guide educational reform. He advocates for revising purpose statements and distributing them widely to stakeholders, positioning purpose clarity as foundational to all downstream decision-making in education policy.

Undated 05 Conversation Draft letter offering Don's definition: education comprises all experiences changing what a person knows, feels,… ▸ more
Draft letter offering Don's definition: education comprises all experiences changing what a person knows, feels, believes, values, or can do. He distinguishes schooling as a recognized approach to group learning and schools as buildings for instruction. The piece includes extended sections on education services (information, counselling, management, quality assurance, learning products, technology, funding, human resources), notes that departments don't separately offer these services despite independent learner growth, and advocates for learner-based rather than school-based education in senior grades. Don calls for community participation and suggests local versus consultant-led reform.

Undated 1 About educations Don presents foundational concepts: learning closes the gap between birth knowledge and survival/thriving knowledge;… ▸ more
Don presents foundational concepts: learning closes the gap between birth knowledge and survival/thriving knowledge; teaching helps learners through information, counselling, instruction, funding, technology, and quality assurance. He defines education as the culmination of learning changes and good education as enabling people to handle daily life issues. Emphasizing the World Bank's distinction between going to school and getting education, Don critiques using schooling as "public shorthand" for education, likening it to people calling all snowmobiles "Skidoos." He calls for careful language from education leaders and differentiating between education and schooling.

Undated 2 Purpose Don expresses concern that PEI's public education purpose is unclear. Department statements like "creating… ▸ more
Don expresses concern that PEI's public education purpose is unclear. Department statements like "creating opportunities for student success" and "developing and delivering programs" lack specificity. He argues that education serves life roles (citizen, family member, consumer, producer, student) and that Islanders most often prefer citizen and employment contexts. Don advocates that clear purpose directs organization and provides focus for instruction and assessment. Referencing his Sunday School teacher's phrase "purpose firm," he urges immediate, public articulation of education purpose post-COVID.

Undated 2-B Purpose This is a revised version of File 15, with identical central argument but additional development. Don proposes a… ▸ more
This is a revised version of File 15, with identical central argument but additional development. Don proposes a specific purpose statement: "the purpose of the public education system is to help Islanders develop skills, knowledge, and attributes needed for citizenship." He cites New Brunswick's benchmark that "every child will leave Grade 5 having mastered the tools to learn – reading, writing and numeracy." The revised version emphasizes that clear purpose provides focus for instruction, assessment, and reporting, moving beyond traditional grading to report what has been learned and proficiency level.

Undated 3 Services A Don frames education as services rather than levels or specialties. He catalogs seven education services: Information… ▸ more
Don frames education as services rather than levels or specialties. He catalogs seven education services: Information (relevant to education decisions), Governance and Leadership (vision and monitoring), Instruction (diagnosis, counselling, presentations, assessment), Quality Assurance (community standards), Learning products and technology, Funding (equitable), and Human Resources (teachers, administrators, counsellors). This brief piece establishes the framework that education departments should organize around service delivery rather than client categories, noting he adapted this list from the National Business Council.

Undated 4-Meaning Don notes that PEI education literature lacks a clear definition of education, despite its importance to thinking and… ▸ more
Don notes that PEI education literature lacks a clear definition of education, despite its importance to thinking and communication clarity. He surveys definitions from multiple sources (Good - social process; OECD - organic communication; Anonymous - formative experience; Ontario - act of teaching/receiving). He critiques being asked "where he got his education" as reflecting product thinking and references the World Bank's caution about confusing education with schooling. The piece advocates for PEI establishing its own clear definition to enhance precision and avoid misunderstanding.

Undated Draft Letters This comprehensive compilation contains multiple draft letters exploring education partnerships, education definitions,… ▸ more
This comprehensive compilation contains multiple draft letters exploring education partnerships, education definitions, conceptual clarity, education services, structural changes, and system vision. Key themes include: (1) education is a service requiring skilled, autonomous providers; (2) education and schooling must be distinguished; (3) education services (information, counselling, instruction, quality assurance, products/technology, funding, human resources) should be explicitly organized and universally available; (4) structural issues include communication gaps, unclear purpose, service identification, autonomy/accountability, and reporting student progress; (5) professional development and qualification authorities require attention. Don critiques treating going to school as equivalent to education and advocates for community participation in education governance. He addresses the "service" vs. "product" confusion and proposes structural reforms including delegation, detailed reporting, and qualification authorities.

Undated Sttructurer This comprehensive working document outlines Don's vision for structural reform of Prince Edward Island's education… ▸ more
This comprehensive working document outlines Don's vision for structural reform of Prince Edward Island's education system. The document establishes foundational premises: that future community well-being depends on citizen education quality, that learning is personal, and that education is a service focused on arranging beneficial experiences. Don proposes seven major structural reforms: expanding departmental scope beyond youth to serve all Islanders, establishing clear terminology, articulating explicit educational purpose, clarifying service offerings, restructuring to reflect function rather than age-groups, granting operational autonomy to front-line workers (citing OECD evidence), and implementing accountability frameworks based on clarity, communication, and trust. The document demonstrates sophisticated understanding of organizational design and cites research supporting school autonomy.

Encourages Schult to write more and suggests Home and School Federation feature these topics on future agendas. Shows Don's engagement with education advocacy networks.

Background document for proposed "Journalism Award" recognizing journalism's role in education and community development. Establishes that education is a key factor in determining individual quality of life, and that collective citizen education determines community quality. Proposes journalism as an important educational medium and tool for community development and informed citizenship. Award appears to be proposed as part of Education 20/20 Inc.'s award portfolio, alongside the existing Excellence in Education Award. Reflects Don's belief in journalism's educational value, role in developing informed citizens, and contribution to community improvement through quality information and public discourse.

Undated 3 Journal description Proposed journalism award framework established by Education 20/20 Inc., designed to encourage journalists to… ▸ more
Proposed journalism award framework established by Education 20/20 Inc., designed to encourage journalists to investigate and report on education sector issues. The document outlines eligibility criteria limited to Holland College journalism students, judging criteria emphasizing accuracy, originality, effectiveness, information value, and insight. Submission requirements include completed transmission forms, article copies, 60-word summaries, publication verification, and biographical sketches. Contains contact information for Education 20/20 Inc. in Charlottetown and notes submission alternatives at the Community Foundation of PEI. Multiple questions remain unresolved including closing dates, award amounts, and eligibility periods.

Undated 1 Description Highlight Expanded conceptual framework for achievement levels emphasizing the distinction between age-based grade levels and… ▸ more
Expanded conceptual framework for achievement levels emphasizing the distinction between age-based grade levels and achievement proficiency. Opens with extended discussion of growing recognition that current proficiency assessment systems are fundamentally flawed, citing No Child Left Behind, labour mobility requirements, technology impact, and public school standard erosion. Argues teaching and qualification should separate functions; contrasts education's self-standard-setting with external standard-setting in food inspection, standards associations, and health departments. References examples of separated functions (apprenticeships, Canadian Language Authority, IB Program, music conservatory). Introduces critical insight: Sydney Morning Herald article about 8-year achievement spreads in mathematics classrooms, arguing schools have choice between adjusting time or adjusting learning expectations. Proposes terminology change from "grade" (administrative) to "level" (achievement-based), enabling students to take mixed-level courses within same age cohort.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 2 Description Highlight Policy description addressing public concerns about education quality with emphasis on standards-setting conflict.… ▸ more
Policy description addressing public concerns about education quality with emphasis on standards-setting conflict. Documents that public views education system as flawed due to educator-controlled standard setting (unlike other industries where external bodies establish standards), large-scale assessment results, economic competency concerns, system quality changes (grade inflation, social promotion, report card confusion), awareness of alternative approaches, teaching-grading function conflicts, and technology-aided instruction impact. Identifies nearly 2,000 PEI achievement evaluators creating inconsistency. Distinguishes between grade (age-based administrative grouping) and achievement (learning level), emphasizing confusion from dual-meaning usage. Reviews best practices (apprenticeships, International Baccalaureate, music/swimming, mathematical competitions, credential systems, language levels, qualification authorities). Specifies needed qualification authority characteristics including independence, bias reduction, consistency improvement, workload reduction, and conflict elimination.

Undated 3 Proficiency levels 2 Implementation proposal for Phase One of laddered achievement levels development titled "Constructing the Ladder."… ▸ more
Implementation proposal for Phase One of laddered achievement levels development titled "Constructing the Ladder." Details seven-step implementation approach: secure funding, establish steering committee, undertake literature search, prepare field analysis, develop rating scale, establish levels, establish application profiles. Specifies deliverables: mathematics field analysis, rating scale, minimum five proficiency levels, three application profiles (chemical technology, actuarial science, business), and independent assessment centre proposal. Articulates benefits: prevents grade inflation, removes achievement uncertainty, increases personal mobility, reduces teacher workload, provides curriculum development foundation. Recommends Education 20/20 Inc. convene committee with named members (Kelli, Mike, Tess, Gordon, Tammy, Sweet, Regis, Whelan/DesRoches), seek $10,000 Windsor exploratory funding, and schedule common core workshop.

Undated 4 Proficiency levels This document outlines a proposal for establishing laddered approaches to recognize student achievement independent of… ▸ more
This document outlines a proposal for establishing laddered approaches to recognize student achievement independent of age. Don identifies fundamental flaws in the current public school grading system—specifically that standards are set by educators rather than external bodies. He proposes developing mathematics achievement levels across multiple rungs, establishing a rating scale with minimum 5 levels, and exploring applications in chemical technology, actuarial science, and business. The document emphasizes benefits including prevention of grade inflation, increased personal mobility for students, and reduced teacher workload. Don recommends Education 20/20 Inc. convene a committee, with specific names listed including Kelli, Mike, Tess, Gordon, Tammy, Regis, and DesRoches. A $10,000 grant from the Windsor exploratory fund is sought.
REFERENCE

Undated A-0 Description Foundational description document outlining eight major concerns about PEI's education system. Don identifies a core… ▸ more
Foundational description document outlining eight major concerns about PEI's education system. Don identifies a core conflict of interest: teachers set standards, measure achievement, and determine student levels—contrary to practice in most industries. He highlights issues including grade inflation, social promotion, confusion between age-based grouping and achievement levels, and erosion of public confidence. The document contrasts PEI's approach with international models (apprenticeship, language authorities, IB programs) and articulates why current proficiency level systems are fundamentally flawed due to uncertain outcome origins and lack of external criteria.

The film features High Tech High's approach to preparing students for the innovation age. The invitation notes priority for mixed groups including students, teachers, principals, and parents—reflecting educational research on transformative learning. This document shows Don's ability to distill complex educational philosophy into compelling, accessible messaging for diverse audiences.

Comprehensive master planning document outlining Education 20/20's strategy to use the film as educational vehicle. Undated Financial Procedures Formalized accounting procedures policy for Education 20/20 Inc. establishing internal controls and operational… ▸ more
Formalized accounting procedures policy for Education 20/20 Inc. establishing internal controls and operational responsibilities. Key policies include: cheques require President and Treasurer signatures; bank statements email to both officials; Tanya authorized for Revenue Canada dealings. Revenue procedures: Don collects mail, makes copies, forwards donations to Treasurer; Tanya deposits and maintains records. Expenditure procedures: Don reviews invoices, authorizes payment, forwards to Treasurer; Tanya prepares cheques for Don and Treasurer signature. Other mail handled by Don with copying and filing at Tanya's discretion. This reveals Don's dual role as President and co-signer, with clear separation of duties and financial governance protocols.

Undated 3 Award support staff Detailed program design for recognizing K-12 support staff in Prince Edward Island who demonstrate exceptional… ▸ more
Detailed program design for recognizing K-12 support staff in Prince Edward Island who demonstrate exceptional commitment and positive impact on student lives. Extensive criteria outline five award categories with specific requirements: Inspirational Leadership, Continuous Excellence, Spirit Award, and others addressing service quality, workplace culture, and professional development. The design includes nomination procedures, selection panels, public recognition components, and media engagement. This comprehensive framework reflects Don's belief that support staff deserve public recognition alongside traditional educator accolades.

Second template expresses appreciation to non-winning nominees, acknowledging the breadth of nominations across all educational levels (early childhood through high school) and the diverse engagement activities presented. The letters exemplify Don's commitment to inclusive recognition, appreciation for all participants, and his understanding that award programs strengthen community engagement and educational culture.

Undated 1 Kinkora congratulations Another version of Don Glendenning's congratulatory correspondence to Kinkora Regional High School, emphasizing the… ▸ more
Another version of Don Glendenning's congratulatory correspondence to Kinkora Regional High School, emphasizing the breadth of engagement activities and the school-community partnership evident in the nomination. BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Eng-1 Guidelines for Engagement Comprehensive guiding principles document articulating Education 20/20's philosophy that engagement is key to student… ▸ more
Comprehensive guiding principles document articulating Education 20/20's philosophy that engagement is key to student success. Defines engagement across five dimensions: student-to-student interaction with emphasis on respect and collaboration; student-to-teacher relationships emphasizing safe, welcoming environments and integration of learning; student-to-learning material through active engagement and real-world application; student-to-community partnerships through experiential learning; and parental involvement, citing 30+ years of research demonstrating parental engagement's impact on achievement, attendance, behavior, and graduation rates. Includes references to educational frameworks (AACU high-impact practices, invitational education, multiple intelligences) and academic citations.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Nomination process Internal reflective memo from Don Glendenning analyzing the governance question of whether to request government… ▸ more
Internal reflective memo from Don Glendenning analyzing the governance question of whether to request government distribution of award materials through the Department of Education. Don systematically examines his reasoning through a series of questions: whether requesting distribution represents approval-seeking, cost-saving, courtesy, or endorsement. Considers whether Department distribution ensures wider reach, adds prestige, or fits government guidelines. Reflects on consistency: if awards were in health or justice, would the relevant department distribute? Anticipates future awards in Nova Brunswick or Nova Scotia and whether similar departments would be expected to distribute. Concludes that Education 20/20 should merely inform the Department courtesy while requesting nothing more. Demonstrates Don's thoughtful governance philosophy and commitment to organizational independence.

Undated Press release-3 Another version of press release with similar content to Files 17 and 19, describing the $2,500 Education Engagement… ▸ more
Another version of press release with similar content to Files 17 and 19, describing the $2,500 Education Engagement Award. Maintains core message that engagement and student achievement correlate. Describes diverse engagement examples including Future Local Forums for French students, Junior Achievement in Kinkora, translation services, cross-cultural events, and technology integration. Emphasizes engagement as school-wide activity involving multiple classes, ages, and community collaboration. Award enabled by Island family donation. Education 20/20 identifies five engagement dimensions. Nominations close March 29; award May. Contact: Don Glendenning, 892-5859; email: pei@education2020.ca. Demonstrates iterative refinement of public messaging.

Undated Lifelong Learning Advisor Proposal -1 Highlight Comprehensive proposal for a Lifelong Learning Advisor pilot project on Prince Edward Island. Includes hiring a… ▸ more
Comprehensive proposal for a Lifelong Learning Advisor pilot project on Prince Edward Island. Includes hiring a dedicated advisor, providing office space downtown Charlottetown, creating a live-calendar website for learning opportunities, and launching public awareness campaigns in multiple media. Budget breakdown details: $800/month office (utilities, Wi-Fi), $4,000/month wages, $10,000/year media during pilot, three-year total of $225,000. Identifies potential revenue: federal/provincial grants, private donors, website advertising, and Education 20/20 fundraising. Proposes multilingual capacity (English, French, Mandarin translation). Reflects Don's vision of comprehensive, accessible lifelong learning infrastructure as public good, deeply connected to his educational philosophy emphasizing continuous learning across all life stages.

Undated PEI Numeracy-Pilot An outline for a pilot implementation phase of the Numeracy Project, structured around creating a comprehensive… ▸ more
An outline for a pilot implementation phase of the Numeracy Project, structured around creating a comprehensive literacy support system for Island citizens. Key components include: common master list of competencies, dynamic rating scale, individual learning profiles, external qualifications, common curriculum platform, and competency-based progress reporting with learner self-assessment. The document establishes the framework for moving from theory to practical classroom/training implementation, though the specific steps remain partially undeveloped.

Undated Fund 2 Education Outlines the Souris Education Innovation Fund, a program designed to encourage secondary school innovation through… ▸ more
Outlines the Souris Education Innovation Fund, a program designed to encourage secondary school innovation through competitive grants. The document establishes the fund's goal, objectives (establish fund, identify activities, make awards, monitor results), and approach including local committee formation, proposal solicitation, and award announcements. Preference is given to collaborative, evidence-based projects addressing actual educational issues. Funding details include a five-page proposal requirement, with decisions managed by Education 20/20 Inc. and administrative support through the Community Foundation of PEI. The document demonstrates Don's systematic approach to educational funding and community engagement.

Undated Fund 5 Education Establishes a School Innovation Grant program to increase implementation of best practices and innovation in PEI… ▸ more
Establishes a School Innovation Grant program to increase implementation of best practices and innovation in PEI schools. The program includes objectives to secure funds, identify innovation activities, provide financial support, and monitor results. The three-page proposal process includes preference criteria for collaborative, evidence-based projects addressing actual educational needs. Management through Education 20/20 Inc. with final decisions resting with the organization. Administrative details include cost-bearing by proposers and a two percent administrative fee through CFPEI. This document reflects Don's systematic approach to embedding educational innovation within established institutional frameworks and accountability structures.

Undated Education Services-1 This proposal document presents the concept of a Community Education Service for Souris/Eastern Kings. It describes… ▸ more
This proposal document presents the concept of a Community Education Service for Souris/Eastern Kings. It describes Education 20/20's proposed education service agency to encourage and support local educational services. Governance structure specifies three-person local board with community representation (not provider representatives), plus advisory committee of education leaders. The document identifies potential host organizations, describes ideal manager characteristics (self-starter, mobile, IT knowledgeable, bilingual preferred, contract position), and notes community benefits including increased training, local capacity development, and strengthened social capital.

Undated D-1 The first issue of "Open Education," the newsletter of Education 20/20 Inc., a national not-for-profit organization… ▸ more
The first issue of "Open Education," the newsletter of Education 20/20 Inc., a national not-for-profit organization dedicated to improving Canadian education quality. The document outlines the organization's mission, governance by volunteer board members with educational expertise, philosophy emphasizing lifelong learning across all age groups and settings, and commitment to advocating for quality education. Special focus on reading literacy as the "golden skill" for lifelong learning, with discussion of early childhood development's role in reading readiness and the importance of community engagement in literacy development.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 7 Math levels Highlight An extensive position paper analyzing educational assessment and curriculum development in Canada, authored by Don… ▸ more
An extensive position paper analyzing educational assessment and curriculum development in Canada, authored by Don Glendenning. The document critiques the current grade-level system, arguing that curriculum development lacks input from practitioners and that teaching and assessment should be separated functions. Don proposes establishing independent proficiency levels for mathematics based on field analysis, citing apprenticeship, music, and sports models as precedents. He advocates for age-independent, school-independent competency assessment with an independent certifying body. The proposal includes benefits (reduces bias, improves consistency, reduces teacher workload) and identifies potential models for implementation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 9 Mount Mathematics A metaphorical and conceptual framework presenting mathematics as a "mountain" requiring structured progression. Don… ▸ more
A metaphorical and conceptual framework presenting mathematics as a "mountain" requiring structured progression. Don identifies educational issues (difficulty predetermining appropriate grade levels, lack of national standards, interpretation problems) and proposes treating mathematics as a prerequisite hierarchy from numeracy through calculus. The proposal involves undertaking comprehensive field analysis, establishing PISA-aligned levels, and creating independent assessment services similar to music and skating certifications. Benefits include common standards, improved mobility, reduced curriculum workload, and leveraging existing OECD research. The mountain metaphor emphasizes that learners must progress from base to summit at their own pace.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 1-E FRAMEWORK NOTES Subtitled "Our Education Journey," this document presents the framework for educators and support professionals. It… ▸ more
Subtitled "Our Education Journey," this document presents the framework for educators and support professionals. It emphasizes that "education is intended to help us on the next leg of the journey" and the presentation "provides a framework for people whose responsibility it is to help others along the way." It identifies extensive barriers including physical, emotional, personal, financial, age, language, access, education qualifications, responsibilities, childcare, elder care, work, household, social/cultural factors, peer pressure, family background, discrimination, and poverty. Includes attribution crediting Education 20/20 Inc., the Oregon concept, and noting Don Glendenning as Educational Adviser with artist Louise Carota.

Undated Media 2 Press release reporting on a public workshop on skill development where islanders defined the concept as "being able to… ▸ more
Press release reporting on a public workshop on skill development where islanders defined the concept as "being able to do things" beyond merely knowing. Participants discussed literacy, numeracy, computers, coding, and traditional trades. The document captures community demand for short courses in practical skills (carpentry, welding, auto mechanics), more flexible training timing, and employer involvement in training design. It reports Education 20/20's commitment to compile suggestions and forward them to federal and provincial governments.

Undated Media-1 Skill Delopment Public notice announcing an Education 20/20 session on skill development at Stratford Town Hall, April 5. The document… ▸ more
Public notice announcing an Education 20/20 session on skill development at Stratford Town Hall, April 5. The document provides context about Labour Market Development Agreements (LMDAs) between federal and provincial governments, noting $28 million available annually in PEI for apprenticeships, certification, adult upgrading, and skills training. Don Glendenning is quoted as President of Education 20/20, emphasizing the importance of investing in education and recommending funding for self-study, online courses, part-time instruction, and independent skill testing services. Contact information provided.
