Undated Media-3 Skill Delopment Press release emphasizing that "skill development starts at home" and requires clear definition. The document notes… ▸ more
Press release emphasizing that "skill development starts at home" and requires clear definition. The document notes that foundation skills come from home and K-12 education, distinguishing "skills for citizenship" from employment-specific skills. It references Workplace Learning PEI's practice of providing competency lists to students and notes that most developed countries (except Canada and USA) maintain separate qualification authorities. Suggests PEI establish a testing center for independent learners. References Education 20/20 as the public workshop organizer. Don listed as contact.

Don Glendenning's opening and closing remarks for the Wellington workshop, clearly articulating Education 20/20's mission and philosophy. Opening introduces the organization's founding by learner-centered educators with a vision of quality education for all Canadians, names six directors including Don, and outlines key beliefs about education's role in individual and community development. Closing remarks emphasize continuing the conversation on learner engagement and direct participants to start locally. Lists Education 20/20 board: Alice Taylor, Brenda Goodine, Bill Whelan, Owen Parkhouse, Tanya Craig, and Don Glendenning.

Undated Proposal - 2 Refined proposal for Education 20/20 Inc. session on Massive Open Online Courses (MOOC). Context emphasizes MOOC impact… ▸ more
Refined proposal for Education 20/20 Inc. session on Massive Open Online Courses (MOOC). Context emphasizes MOOC impact on educational institutions, particularly universities. Presenter Tom White-Hassler described as a "cybernostique" with decades of e-learning experience in Alaska, Navajoland, and Connecticut, currently delivering courses from Stratford to Connecticut students. Proposal highlights MOOC challenges: scale, prerequisites, free access, emerging credit options, and state policy requirements for acceptance. Budget replicates File 3 template ($525 total). Demonstrates Don's understanding that MOOC represents a significant institutional challenge requiring informed public dialogue.

Undated 1-Original note Initial concept notes for an educational forum floated in July, which received positive response. Purpose defined as… ▸ more
Initial concept notes for an educational forum floated in July, which received positive response. Purpose defined as keeping education debate alive, bringing together interested people, strengthening stakeholder partnerships, featuring Island leaders, exploring parent views, and identifying expectations. Format options included panel, forum, round table, expert presentations, and discussions. Thematic options ranged from Education 20/20's 7-point Call for Action to future education systems and best practices. Organization involved independent chair/facilitators and partner organizations. Proposed phased approach: (1) Convene Presidents and Executive Directors, (2) Workshop for organizational members, (3) Community organizations workshop, (4) Public conference.

Undated Let-3 Role of Department (100-200 words):** A signed letter to the editor authored by Don Glendenning critiquing PEI's education mandate. Don… ▸ more
(100-200 words):** A signed letter to the editor authored by Don Glendenning critiquing PEI's education mandate. Don argues that the province's role should extend beyond simply delivering school programs to encompassing all lifelong learning experiences. He advocates for a broader provincial mandate including encouraging citizen education, regulating the education service sector, and identifying sectors deserving support. The letter reflects his visionary perspective that education extends beyond schooling, positioning lifelong learning and comprehensive citizen development as essential to provincial prosperity. This document reveals Don's willingness to challenge existing frameworks and publicly advocate for systemic educational transformation aligned with his comprehensive philosophy.

Identifies education system challenges: structural overhaul needed, major issues around mission/structure/autonomy/accountability, gap between Islanders' expectations and system delivery, likelihood system won't self-reform. Acknowledges Education 20/20 Inc.'s need for independence and broad-based participation. This document reveals Don's deepening concern about systemic education issues and mounting organizational challenges.

Undated APM Banks Tim-2 attachment School Engagement Award proposal describing Education 20/20 Inc.'s awards program for schools demonstrating community… ▸ more
School Engagement Award proposal describing Education 20/20 Inc.'s awards program for schools demonstrating community engagement. Outlines five engagement areas: student-to-student, student-to-teacher, student-to-learning materials, student-to-community partnerships, parent involvement. Criteria focus on school-controlled factors: communication levels, event frequency, community-based activities, parent involvement in curriculum/planning, staff community participation. Nomination process outlined with Awards Committee chaired by Eileen Conway-Martin. Draft includes award structure details. Demonstrates Don's innovative approach to incentivizing desired educational practices.

This foundational letter outlines Don's concerns about Canadian education and his vision for reform. He articulates problems including lack of teacher autonomy, insufficient accountability, and inadequate public information about education issues compared to health reporting. Don explains Education 20/20's emerging strategy for change and emphasizes that success requires public demand. He directly solicits Hyndman's partnership and financial support, noting that the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island will administer donations. This letter exemplifies Don's ability to synthesize complex educational issues and communicate them persuasively to business leaders.

Don's opening letter to Mary Jean Irving outlines his concerns about PEI's education system, emphasizing gaps in autonomy, accountability, and alignment between taught and needed skills. He describes Education 20/20's initial projects including school awards for engagement, engagement software testing, a reading improvement initiative, and a plan to publish educational information. The letter articulates a $25,000 short-term funding goal and explains the Community Foundation's role in administering donations. This letter demonstrates Don's comprehensive strategic approach and his focus on data-driven education reform.

Comprehensive funding solicitation letter to Steven Loggie, Vice President of Maritime Electric, introducing Education 20/20's initiatives and philosophy. Don articulates the organization's three core strategies: independent information via monthly newsletters and website, engagement through island-wide workshops discussing education gaps, and recognition of innovative schools through awards and incentives. He details specific workshop dates (Stratford, Montague, Summerside, Wellington) and presents a detailed budget breakdown seeking $22,000 in support. The letter demonstrates Don's vision of addressing systemic education problems through public engagement and institutional change rather than reliance on the education system itself.

Undated McEwen MLA-1 Congratulatory and advocacy letter to newly elected MLA Sidney McEwen. Don emphasizes the critical importance of… ▸ more
Congratulatory and advocacy letter to newly elected MLA Sidney McEwen. Don emphasizes the critical importance of education and appeals to McEwen to champion educational reform in the provincial legislature. He introduces Education 20/20 Inc. and its mission as a national, independent, not-for-profit organization, highlighting their website, bilingual newsletter, school awards program, workshops, and policy papers. Don references "A Call for Action," a document identifying seven priority recommendations for provincial education improvement. He offers to meet and discuss education issues affecting PEI and requests McEwen's support for quality education initiatives.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

Nearly identical to the McEwen letter but addressed to Hon. Alan McIsaac, Minister of Fisheries and Aquaculture. Don congratulates McIsaac on his election and appeals to his leadership role in provincial government. He stresses education's economic and social importance and introduces Education 20/20's national platform, including website, newsletters, school awards, workshops, and occasional papers. Don references "A Call for Action" containing seven priority recommendations and offers to meet to discuss specific education challenges facing PEI and potential collaborative solutions.

Don emphasizes education's critical importance for PEI's future and the need for bold governmental leadership. He introduces Education 20/20 Inc. as a national, independent, not-for-profit organization and describes their activities: website, bilingual monthly newsletter, school awards, workshops, and discussion forums. Don highlights "A Call for Action" containing seven priority recommendations for provincial education improvement and expresses hope to meet Mitchell to discuss education challenges and collaborative opportunities.

Undated Murphy, Mike-3 Highlight Update letter to Michael Murphy on Education 20/20's development following federal incorporation. Don reiterates the… ▸ more
Update letter to Michael Murphy on Education 20/20's development following federal incorporation. Don reiterates the fundamental need for educational system change: autonomy for schools, less bureaucracy, teacher freedom and accountability, early childhood focus, greater choice, and revised standards. He reports progress including: dozens of meetings with educators, a cadre of committed change agents, federal incorporation as Education 20/20 Inc., logo and website development, and charitable status application. Activities underway include early childhood workshops, engagement assessment software testing, school awards program development, educator dialogue on reading skills, and public information initiatives. Don invites Murphy's continued support and updates him on the organization's evolution.

Congratulatory letter to Dr. Alice Collins, Chairperson of the K-12 Education Task Force in Newfoundland and Labrador. Don congratulates her on the appointment and emphasizes that education is the defining issue of the day. He identifies himself as a retired educator still active in the field and describes Education 20/20 Inc. as a recently established organization devoted to influencing education's future. Don offers to share Education 20/20's brochure, "Call for Action" document, and website information (currently being updated), and offers to add Collins to their mailing list if she provides an email address. He extends assistance if needed for her task force's work.

Undated 6-Souris Fund Proposal This formal grant proposal for the Souris Education Innovation Fund establishes criteria and processes for awarding… ▸ more
This formal grant proposal for the Souris Education Innovation Fund establishes criteria and processes for awarding local educational grants. The initiative encourages innovation and best practices through local committee oversight, proposal review, and project monitoring. Preference is given to collaborative, community-issue-addressed, equitable projects reflecting leading-edge research. Documentation limited to three pages ensures accessibility for grassroots educators. The approach emphasizes community agency and shared decision-making, with Education 20/20 providing facilitation and resources. This document demonstrates Don's belief that educational improvement emerges from community-level innovation rather than top-down mandates.

Undated Award support Highlight This expanded version of the support staff award program incorporates multiple institutional award frameworks, mixing… ▸ more
This expanded version of the support staff award program incorporates multiple institutional award frameworks, mixing education-focused criteria with academic/technical institution standards. The document includes three award categories: Inspirational Leadership, Continuous Excellence, and Spirit Award, with detailed criteria for each. It addresses nomination processes, selection panels, documentation requirements, and public recognition components. The complexity suggests Don studied multiple institutional models before developing Education 20/20's approach. The inclusion of diverse recognition criteria reflects sophisticated understanding of institutional culture and human motivation across educational contexts.

Undated D 00 Project Guideline1 This procedural document establishes evaluation criteria for Education 20/20 projects, emphasizing clear focus,… ▸ more
This procedural document establishes evaluation criteria for Education 20/20 projects, emphasizing clear focus, measurable objectives, community support beyond proponents, philosophical consistency, identified competencies with performance levels, solid documentation, stakeholder role clarity, realistic timelines (3-5 years), evaluation components, partnership inclusion, minimal bureaucracy, clear decision-making, and replicability. The document also presents project scenario frameworks based on geography (local to Atlantic Canada), setting (school, library, home, workplace), life roles (consumer, producer, citizen, family, individual), and identified gaps. This framework reflects Don's systematic approach to educational program development and his commitment to rigorous evaluation methodologies.
EDUCATION

Undated D 32 Imagining the future Responding to the Charting the Way report, Don proposes a series of public engagement sessions under the "Education… ▸ more
Responding to the Charting the Way report, Don proposes a series of public engagement sessions under the "Education First" banner to help Islanders shape the future direction of education. The initiative aims to provide information, facilitate discussion, and present policy alternatives in a participatory, learner-centered, future-oriented manner. Sessions would be volunteer-led, held in libraries and community centres, include French-language options, and avoid formal political presence. Agendas incorporate welcome, process explanation, PowerPoint presentations, small group discussions, and reporting. This proposal demonstrates Don's trust in public wisdom, his commitment to inclusive dialogue beyond institutional settings, and his understanding that educational reform requires broad community participation and shared ownership.

Undated D ECE 1-A This document records Don's exploratory notes and brainstorming for early childhood education (ECE) initiatives under… ▸ more
This document records Don's exploratory notes and brainstorming for early childhood education (ECE) initiatives under Education 20/20 Inc. The notes document his consultation process including meetings with Steve McQuaid and research into funding opportunities (McCain Foundation, federal government). Project ideas span diverse approaches: parent email advice, baby-sitter activities, programs for prisoners with young children, weekend camps, infant education workshops, parent-child reading clubs, parent needs surveys, and webinars. The document demonstrates Don's systematic approach to problem-identification and solution-generation, reflecting his commitment to foundational education access.

Undated D Learner series Education 20/20 proposes a series of short educational videos (3-4 minutes each) exploring fundamental learning… ▸ more
Education 20/20 proposes a series of short educational videos (3-4 minutes each) exploring fundamental learning processes. Topics include "What happens when we learn," "The learning process," "What learners bring," "Helping learners learn," measurement of change, and reporting/feedback mechanisms. Don would lead the initial series development, with a steering committee providing oversight and external contractors handling production and evaluation. Videos target parents but would serve teachers-in-training, new teachers, workshop leaders, and presentation professionals. This reflects Don's belief that learning processes deserve attention as central to educational improvement.
EDUCATION

Undated D Roundtable A Highlight Don writes to Metro Credit Union's Bernard Gillis requesting three-year financial support for Education 20/20 Inc.'s… ▸ more
Don writes to Metro Credit Union's Bernard Gillis requesting three-year financial support for Education 20/20 Inc.'s roundtable initiative. He identifies structural impediments to educational change (unclear mandates, outdated philosophy, vague goals, teaching-delivery rather than learner-development models, unanchored standards). Don proposes roundtable sessions—invitational discussions with diverse stakeholders, recommended readings, guided questions, and independent chairs—to examine current issues including attendance, mission statements, governance, early childhood education, standards, and social promotion. He emphasizes that educators themselves hesitate to speak publicly on education matters and that media capability is limited. The initiative seeks to fill information gaps and enable community engagement in educational reform.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

Undated D Sunshine C series Highlight This document appears to be a fuller version of the Windsor Foundation proposal, reiterating Education 20/20's mission… ▸ more
This document appears to be a fuller version of the Windsor Foundation proposal, reiterating Education 20/20's mission to ensure quality education for every Canadian. The organization operates with volunteer leadership, has applied for charitable status, and benefits from Community Foundation administration. The Sunshine Initiative targets disadvantaged and vulnerable youth experiencing preparedness gaps, and post-secondary students struggling with basic skills. Innovative features include unified curriculum mapping with multiple profiles (rather than grade-specific maps), DACUM-model competency analysis, Bloom's Taxonomy-aligned rating scales, and engagement of broad stakeholder ranges. Benefits include clarified basic skills definitions, improved stakeholder communications, and demonstrated components absent from current educational processes.

Education 20/20 proposal establishing a school innovation grant program in Souris, PEI. Goal is to encourage innovation and best practices in Souris schools. Program solicits proposals addressing actual education issues, preferencing collaborative, equitable projects reflecting research-based practices. Documentation requirements specify three-page maximum, grassroots origin (not professional contracts), and supporting letters. Demonstrates 20/20's strategy to localize educational reform through community-based grant-making and local committee structures.

Undated Call for Action-List A concise bulleted action list presenting Education 20/20's core policy recommendations for educational transformation.… ▸ more
A concise bulleted action list presenting Education 20/20's core policy recommendations for educational transformation. The seven-point call addresses: developing a clear educational vision for Islanders, creating learner-centered service models, assuming government leadership in learning culture, delegating instruction provision to multiple providers, establishing independent qualification bodies, implementing professional accountability models, and developing innovation strategies. This distilled format appears designed for easy dissemination and communication. The list is presented twice identically, suggesting preparation for multiple uses (publication, speaking, distribution). This represents the executive summary of Education 20/20's advocacy agenda.

This poster distills Education 20/20 Inc.'s philosophy into actionable components that educators and policymakers should prioritize.

Undated 36 Qualifications Bi Glendenning proposes replacing grade labels with achievement level designations to address the confusion arising from… ▸ more
Glendenning proposes replacing grade labels with achievement level designations to address the confusion arising from using "grade" for both age cohorts and achievement standards. He argues a student could take "level 7 math, level 4 physics, and level 6 literature" rather than being age-locked to grade 11. This model is used by International Baccalaureate and the Canadian Red Cross. He documents problems with current system: bored high achievers, discouraged low achievers, frustrated teachers, and declining public confidence. Education 20/20 explores basic skills definition and identifies gaps in provincial standards.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 40- External Criteria Detailed explanation of criterion-referenced testing as assessment method comparing performance to predefined standards… ▸ more
Detailed explanation of criterion-referenced testing as assessment method comparing performance to predefined standards rather than peers. Glendenning emphasizes transparency, clear outcome statements, defined levels, external benchmarks, and consistent application. He argues teacher-learner discussion about grades is integral to learning. The newsletter announces Grace Christian School's Excellence in Education Award for technology integration, with Glendenning as Education 20/20 president presenting the award alongside Katherine McQuaid, Maureen Kerr, and Jason Biech.

Undated 44- Getting Help in Souris Glendenning reflects on accessing education information in rural communities, using Souris as example. He questions… ▸ more
Glendenning reflects on accessing education information in rural communities, using Souris as example. He questions where non-school residents find education guidance for personal development, workforce transitions, helping children, quality-of-life improvement, or business attraction. He proposes six options: descriptive brochures, toll-free numbers, web pages, education navigators, dedicated education offices, and family education advisors. Photo shows David Smith (RBC Wealth Management) presenting check to Glendenning as Education 20/20 president, demonstrating community financial support for educational initiatives.

Undated 77 Pot Pourria A miscellaneous collection of education news and updates. Announces Sharon Cameron's election as President of Education… ▸ more
A miscellaneous collection of education news and updates. Announces Sharon Cameron's election as President of Education 20/20 Inc. (previously a Deputy Minister in PEI government), with Don serving as Treasurer and other executive members. Notes political changes with new education minister Brad Trivers. Discusses classroom design innovations encouraging collaboration and creativity (Hechinger Report). Highlights Education 20/20's math survey initiative and the eight-year longitudinal study examining college success versus conventional high school course patterns. References PISA results showing that school autonomy correlates with student achievement. Includes Montreal Economic Institute analysis on accountability and autonomy. Reports on BC students' academic gains from music education.
EDUCATION
Read · Download

Undated 81 Transition to work Don reflects on his background as a graduate of New Brunswick's first rural high school (offering gardening, shop, home… ▸ more
Don reflects on his background as a graduate of New Brunswick's first rural high school (offering gardening, shop, home economics, crafts) and as one of few people certified to teach both academic and vocational subjects. He articulates his discovery that "vocationalism" derives not from equipment but from learning purpose. Employment-oriented courses assess differently than academic subjects, using criteria like quality, quantity, problem-solving, leadership, dependability, supervision, and assistance needed. Reports PEI's skilled worker shortage in construction, carpentry, electrical work, and welding, viewing this as a provincial responsibility despite federal funding. References Education 20/20's Souris continuing education study highlighting service gaps. Notes New Brunswick's Green Paper proposing grading structure changes with potential for flexibility and quality improvements.
EDUCATION INSTITUTIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 87 Bishop Carroll High Don reflects on early visit to Bishop Carroll High School in Calgary with Dr. Tom Hall as part of the Canadian… ▸ more
Don reflects on early visit to Bishop Carroll High School in Calgary with Dr. Tom Hall as part of the Canadian Restructured School Plan national study. Recently revisiting the school's website, he finds their approach emphasizing "unique, personalized, self-directed learning environment" where students design customized programs with teacher-advisor guidance. Students progress at individual paces while meeting Alberta Education curriculum requirements. Don praises this clarity of purpose, finding it exemplary and aligned with his previous observations. Notably, Don criticizes PEI for lacking similar clear articulation of educational philosophy and vision. Suggests developing such statements would provide excellent professional development and replace outdated philosophy. Demonstrates Don's ongoing research into exemplary school models and his conviction that clear mission statements drive educational effectiveness.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 92 Government pay for Don proposes applying Canada's healthcare model to education funding. Rather than government providing all services, he… ▸ more
Don proposes applying Canada's healthcare model to education funding. Rather than government providing all services, he suggests selective coverage: essential skills for all residents regardless of age (full cost), entry-level skills training for any occupation practiced in PEI, student/guardian counselling, qualification examinations on instructor recommendation, management training after five years full-time employment, while excluding advanced topics like calculus. This approach would shift focus from school roles to actual learning outcomes. Recent reading highlights emerging trends: learning pods being normalized, renewed interest in continuing education (especially post-pandemic layoffs), and importance of learning context. References Education 20/20's Citizen Math study revealing context matters in all learning—noting four numeracy contexts (citizen, personal, health, career). Observes schools organizing around specialized contexts (arts, sports, health, aviation, technology) and recalls Prince County Vocational High School and Provincial Vocational School serving this function.
EDUCATION

Undated 1 ABOUT EDUCATION First iteration of Education 20/20's foundational educational framework booklet. Introduces the "Road of Life"… ▸ more
First iteration of Education 20/20's foundational educational framework booklet. Introduces the "Road of Life" metaphor—conceptualizing education as preparation for life stages. Defines education as experience with formative effect on thinking, feeling, and action. Presents a comprehensive model including learning paths, essential skills (communications, numeracy, community awareness, self-management, interpersonal relationships, information technology), and typical education services. Includes rating scales for assessment. This represents core educational philosophy developed under Don's leadership as organization President and Editor.

Undated 18-Glossary Comprehensive glossary compiled collaboratively by Education 20/20, with Don as President. Defines 20+ key educational… ▸ more
Comprehensive glossary compiled collaboratively by Education 20/20, with Don as President. Defines 20+ key educational terms (assessment, benchmark, competency, certification, education, learner, learning, outcome, qualification, rating, school, standard, teacher, etc.). Includes Education 20/20 mandate, Board of Directors listing (Don Glendenning as President), and "Call for Action" advocating systemic educational reform including vision development, learner-centered models, government leadership, expanded instruction providers, independent qualification bodies, professional accountability, and innovation incentives. Represents collaborative knowledge synthesis and shared values.
INSTITUTIONAL SPEECH

Undated D-17 Overhaul-2 Occasional paper calling for comprehensive overhaul of PEI's education services, describing them as narrowly focused,… ▸ more
Occasional paper calling for comprehensive overhaul of PEI's education services, describing them as narrowly focused, cognitively based, bureaucratic, and lacking accountability. Glendenning argues that education policy should serve all 150,000 PEI citizens across six life roles (individual, citizen, family member, learner, producer, consumer), not just youth in schools. Identifies 11 key issues including purpose/mission clarity, structure, political embedment, standards, accountability, professional autonomy, and transparency. Emphasizes that public school system conflates attendance with education, echoing World Bank concerns.
EDUCATION

Undated D-17-B Noverhaul-2 Extended analysis titled "A Call For Conceptual Clarity," addressing definitional and structural problems in PEI's… ▸ more
Extended analysis titled "A Call For Conceptual Clarity," addressing definitional and structural problems in PEI's Department of Education. Glendenning identifies confusion about fundamental concepts like "education," "learner," and "benchmark," arguing that Department literature obscures rather than enlightens. Examines purpose clarity, education functions and services, political embedment, accountability, standards, and transparency. Advocates for professional autonomy based on OECD findings about school autonomy and student outcomes. Proposes reviewing recent Health Services restructuring for organizational design insights.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-4-A About Educ Foundational paper titled "About Education" establishing conceptual framework for understanding education systems.… ▸ more
Foundational paper titled "About Education" establishing conceptual framework for understanding education systems. Provides definitions of learner, learning, teacher, teaching, education, purpose of education, education system, and school system. Identifies eight components of education systems: information/counselling, instruction/institutions, community-based organizations, certification and qualification services, governance structure, resource materials, qualified staff, and school days per year. Discusses education domains (cognitive, affective, psychomotor) and role of schools. Examines puzzling education concepts including education levels, subject levels, social promotion, outcome levels, and credentials.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 1 Education and Instruction Blog post introducing Don's online presence and establishing his fundamental distinction between education and… ▸ more
Blog post introducing Don's online presence and establishing his fundamental distinction between education and instruction. He defines education broadly as experiences with formative effect on thinking, feeling, and behavior (occurring anywhere, anytime), while schooling/instruction is more limited, involving teacher-directed learning in schools. Don expresses puzzlement that educators frequently use these terms interchangeably and suspects some deliberately create confusion. He commits to keeping blog posts short and education-focused while inviting reader comments. The post demonstrates his intention to reach broader audiences beyond formal publications and his concern about conceptual clarity in educational discourse. His accessible, conversational tone in this medium contrasts with his more academic occasional papers.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D A different erspective This reflective piece explores a fundamental shift in education's role throughout the past century. Don contrasts… ▸ more
This reflective piece explores a fundamental shift in education's role throughout the past century. Don contrasts historical education (providing answers for industrialized economy) with contemporary needs (developing questioners for knowledge economy). He notes the paradox that while grandfathers once found questioning threatening, today's knowledge workers must be questioners—yet modern education often views them as threatening. The piece invites continued dialogue with readers who share these observations, demonstrating Don's commitment to intellectual discourse and his recognition of education's evolving purpose in society.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

French-language editorial discussing Education 20/20 Inc. study on continuing education gaps in Souris, PEI. Proposes creation of a "Continuing Education College" without internal staff. Includes potpourri of education notes from provinces and references 80th anniversary of Miramichi Rural High School (where Don taught early in his career). Ends with holiday greetings.

Major draft opinion piece examining education transformation in knowledge age. Argues that traditional knowledge-transfer model is obsolete given technology; emphasizes need for problem-solving, personal skills, lifelong learning, and self-directed learning. Signed by Education 20/20 Inc., reflects Don's core belief that education system role must shift from information transfer to capability development for real-world application.

Undated Numeracy -1 "A Switch to Numeracy" proposal articulating Don's educational philosophy that numeracy (practical mathematical… ▸ more
"A Switch to Numeracy" proposal articulating Don's educational philosophy that numeracy (practical mathematical application) better serves citizen needs than traditional mathematics instruction. Distinguishes between math (study of numbers/space) and numeracy (applied ability in contexts). References PEI curriculum goals, Scottish Education definitions, and proposes platform development through community analysis. Shows Don's commitment to shifting educational focus from theoretical to applied competencies.

Letter from Don Glendenning as President of Education 20/20 Inc. to Rotary Literacy Foundation (Kingsley Lewis) requesting funding for numeracy skills analysis. Don articulates the rationale: math skills cannot be improved by schools alone; a systematic analysis of numeracy competencies is needed for multiple stakeholders. References attached Canadian numeracy frameworks. Shows Don's approach to educational innovation through community partnerships.

Undated Description-1 This comprehensive document, titled "About Education: Framework for Education PEI," presents Don's extensive analysis… ▸ more
This comprehensive document, titled "About Education: Framework for Education PEI," presents Don's extensive analysis of Prince Edward Island's education system. It includes key definitions, operating beliefs, identified life roles, typical functions, government mandates, education service providers, and detailed lists of education issues and barriers to change. The document reflects decades of educational leadership philosophy emphasizing learner-centered approaches, flexibility, accountability, and the importance of community engagement. This represents substantial thinking about systemic education reform.

Includes $14,250 budget for facilitator, facilities, printing, and honoraria. Reflects Don's learner-centered pedagogical philosophy.

Undated 1- 3 Issues Third draft of an editor letter refining Don's educational philosophy and critique. Defines learning, teaching, and… ▸ more
Third draft of an editor letter refining Don's educational philosophy and critique. Defines learning, teaching, and education with philosophical clarity, distinguishing between personal development and the economic sector. Observes that during his 50-year tenure on PEI, education has shifted from service to product, from professional practice to credential-focused delivery. Calls for comprehensive system review including glossary of terms, program purposes, institutional autonomy, accountability definitions, and collaborative redesign led by local leaders rather than outside experts.

Undated 1- 4 Issues Fourth draft editor letter analyzing the Department of Education's narrow role statement and its consequences.… ▸ more
Fourth draft editor letter analyzing the Department of Education's narrow role statement and its consequences. Contrasts education with health, noting health maintains patient focus while education focuses on schools rather than learners. Notes education's narrowed focus over 50 years disadvantages non-university-bound youth. Critiques goal statements as misleading and advocates for reconceptualizing education's purpose to encompass all life roles (citizenship, employment, personal development), affecting curriculum selection, assessment, and grading practices.

Undated 1- B Issues Second draft editor letter providing Don's analytical framework for education. Distinguishes learning as individual… ▸ more
Second draft editor letter providing Don's analytical framework for education. Distinguishes learning as individual behavioral change, teaching as helping facilitate change, and education as the cumulative result of all formative experiences. Argues government's role should be "encouraging and supporting" rather than direct operation; notes state must ensure skilled workforce for community sustainability. Lists systemic concerns: narrow role definition, lack of regulatory clarity, accountability measurement, and neglect of adult education—proposing comprehensive public conversation to establish education's nature and services for the coming century.

Editor letter discussing education system fragmentation and bureaucracy, mentioning conversations with students in Souris about continuing education and with employers about entry-level skills. Notes education is "isolated from the community it serves" and often described as politicized. Advocates system overhaul requiring clear beliefs and guiding principles, services configured for individuals and communities, and efficient delivery mechanisms. References election-related timing and encourages voters to raise education issues with candidates; signed as "A long time student of education."

Undated 1-Learning bullets-1 Brief editor letter with ten bullet-point principles about learners and learning reflecting Don's educational… ▸ more
Brief editor letter with ten bullet-point principles about learners and learning reflecting Don's educational philosophy. Emphasizes learning as personal experience, individuals learning within groups, variable learning pace, behavior change as learning marker, teachers' role facilitating learner development, and that teaching effectiveness measured by learner achievement. Notes learning patterns established by age six and offers educational principles suitable for publication in local media. Invites reader comments and dialogue.

Year-end editor letter predicting minimal education improvement with current muddling-through philosophy but noting increasing public frustration and government openness to consultation. Recommends foundational actions: clear directional statement with glossary, principles, and service list; alternative delivery models for each service (government, commission, NGOs); government-funded services specification. Uses Department of Education website mission statement as "barometer of change"—current language emphasizes delivery but should emphasize encouragement, support, and regulation; addresses teacher autonomy and accountability themes.

Year-end outlook letter (duplicate/similar to File 10) forecasting education system stagnation given reliance on outdated 30-year-old philosophy without addressing conceptual clarity between education (universal) and formal instruction (school-based). Notes federal education-for-employment leadership historically provided through federal-provincial agreements but since withdrawn. Discusses postsecondary cost escalation and administrative overhead concerns, particularly regarding graduate student teaching loads. Addresses school board restoration's potential impact contingent on professional autonomy and accountability provisions.

Undated 1-yer end Year-end editorial referenced as "celebrating entrance to new personal decade," offering educational system critiques.… ▸ more
Year-end editorial referenced as "celebrating entrance to new personal decade," offering educational system critiques. Notes government difficulties distinguishing between education (universal, ongoing) and formal instruction (school-based). Advocates government focus on planning, funding priorities, monitoring rather than direct operation. Identifies need for clear philosophical framework, though acknowledges 4-5 year government horizons conflict with education's longer-term requirements. Addresses themes of vision, role clarity, politicization, teacher autonomy, and accountability.

Undated 100 -2 OverhaulI Editor letter addressing "credibility gap" between PEI education and community, describing system as fragmented,… ▸ more
Editor letter addressing "credibility gap" between PEI education and community, describing system as fragmented, cognitively narrow, bureaucratic, lacking accountability and self-correction. Notes government inherited problematic structure but bears responsibility for improvement. Recommends broadening education definition beyond school-to-youth focus, organizing by functions rather than institutions, adopting PISA recommendations (school autonomy and accountability), developing independent qualification authorities, and shifting focus from institutions/programs to learners/learning. Includes supporting outline of current problems and first steps (vision, functional organization, autonomy, accountability).

Undated 100 -3 OverhaulI Nearly identical editor letter variant to File 15, addressing gap between needed and provided education services. Notes… ▸ more
Nearly identical editor letter variant to File 15, addressing gap between needed and provided education services. Notes educators' needs often take precedence over learners', with focus on administrative details (credits, grades, meals, technology) rather than developing knowledge, skills, attitudes, and values. Emphasizes citizens generally support education services but object to irrelevance, poor quality, limited engagement, lack of choice, bureaucracy, and unresponsiveness. Repeats recommendations for narrowing definition (50-year change noted), functional organization, PISA recommendations adoption, qualification authorities, and learner-centered system focus.

Undated 100 -4 OverhaulI Editor letter noting weekly emerging education issues (Ontario teacher math testing, Alberta curriculum overhaul,… ▸ more
Editor letter noting weekly emerging education issues (Ontario teacher math testing, Alberta curriculum overhaul, Manitoba nursing math skills, grade inflation, worker shortages, university costs, poverty's impact on performance). Describes growing gap between desired and provided education services, with conversation focused on administrative matters rather than substantive learning outcomes. Argues system structure—embedding education in government—prevents necessary direction, freedom, and support. Calls for public conversation, simple plan with definitions, guiding principles, service descriptions, governance clarity, and locally-led (not expert-driven) development.

Undated 100 -6 OverhaulI Draft letter distinguishing education as service (developing skills, knowledge, attitudes for thriving) versus product… ▸ more
Draft letter distinguishing education as service (developing skills, knowledge, attitudes for thriving) versus product (MOOCs, courses, diplomas). Notes institutions focus on product delivery while service remains under-served despite community initiatives (community schools, seniors' colleges, night classes). Proposes education service centers as "pharmacy" model offering advice and products, training/upgrading centers, or referral points—potentially separate from institutions given traditional institutions' poor continuing education records. Discusses need for learning-centered materials, experienced teachers, student records, and service management systems, suggesting Souris as potential pilot location.

Undated 102-b Role of Gov Substantial draft paper addressing education system overhaul. Criticizes government's narrow definition conflating… ▸ more
Substantial draft paper addressing education system overhaul. Criticizes government's narrow definition conflating education with schooling, cites OECD and Donald Savoie on government effectiveness, and proposes structural reforms including autonomy, accountability, functional organization, and clear vision. References learner-centered approaches and the principle that early childhood experiences shape personality patterns.

Undated 103-Definiions Letter critiquing PEI's imprecise educational terminology. Don argues that using "Education and Lifelong Learning"… ▸ more
Letter critiquing PEI's imprecise educational terminology. Don argues that using "Education and Lifelong Learning" conflates education with schooling, similar to saying "Department of Agriculture and Farming." He presents his working definition of education as all experiences with formative effect on thinking, feeling, or acting. References Good's Dictionary of Education and criticizes educators for interchangeably using "education" and "schooling."

Letter praising government's consolidation of education services under one department while expressing concerns about workforce training quality. References Good's Dictionary on definitions. Criticizes loss of federal leadership role in training standards and warns that without protection from academic bureaucracy, vocational training will become theoretical with narrowed standards and reduced practice time.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 12 Role of Government in Educ This policy brief (No. 102) argues that PEI's Department of Education has narrowed its mandate over 50 years, now… ▸ more
This policy brief (No. 102) argues that PEI's Department of Education has narrowed its mandate over 50 years, now limited to school-based instruction. Don contends the department should shift to encouraging, supporting, and regulating education services for all Islanders rather than merely delivering school programs. He identifies systemic problems: lack of direction, fragmentation, narrow focus, unmet public expectations, bureaucracy, and politicization. First steps for reform include developing clear vision, functional organization, school autonomy, and accountability structures. This document exemplifies his consistent critique of institutional mission drift and his advocacy for systematic educational reform.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 197 Math pilot Brief paper proposing a math pilot program for PEI education reform. Don notes Alberta's curriculum overhaul shift from… ▸ more
Brief paper proposing a math pilot program for PEI education reform. Don notes Alberta's curriculum overhaul shift from outcomes to competencies, terming this "adulting" of education. He advocates for competency-based frameworks more reflective of community language and life roles. The proposed pilot includes: competency-based structure, self-study platforms, qualification-based certification, independent learning managers, a math hotline, and annual conferences. Don recommends piloting at a small local scale to assess feasibility. This document shows his practical, pilot-based approach to implementing systemic reforms.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 2 Seat time Letter to editor critiquing the use of "seat time" as a proxy for educational achievement. Don argues that since people… ▸ more
Letter to editor critiquing the use of "seat time" as a proxy for educational achievement. Don argues that since people learn at different rates, grade levels should either set achievement targets with flexible time requirements or report achieved levels within available time—not conflate attendance with learning. He notes teachers observe students with same-age peers yet four-to-five years behind in achievement. Don advocates for independent qualification authorities (as in most developed nations) to handle grading/certification, removing this responsibility from teachers. This reflects his consistent position separating teaching from assessment functions.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 20-Editor communication Brief commentary on communication problems in PEI education during pandemic-challenged times. Don identifies three… ▸ more
Brief commentary on communication problems in PEI education during pandemic-challenged times. Don identifies three communication issues: conflating "schooling" and "education" as identical; lack of shared vision about education roles; confusion between credentials and qualifications. He notes seniors ask where one "got their education" when seeking schooling information, and employers misunderstand the distinction between credentials and qualifications. Don argues these terminological confusions raise questions about the Department's leadership and vision clarity. This document shows his concern with precise language and conceptual clarity in education discourse.
EDUCATION

 Read · Download
Undated 21-2-B RESTRUCTURING Revised version of restructuring proposal, expressing surprise at limited PEI interest in educational quality… ▸ more
Revised version of restructuring proposal, expressing surprise at limited PEI interest in educational quality improvement despite international evidence. Don reiterates core thesis: education is umbrella concept including all learning, producing observable changes in thinking/feeling/acting. Emphasizes shift from service to product (credentials) focus. Outlines education as provincial responsibility with governance, funding, instruction, human resources, products, technology, quality assurance, and counseling components. Reiterates two-fold problem: narrow governmental vision confusing education with schooling and bureaucratic delivery with "military precision." Calls for Legislative committee action.

Undated 21-2-D RESTRUCTURING Another restructuring draft emphasizing education's provincial responsibility and various service components… ▸ more
Another restructuring draft emphasizing education's provincial responsibility and various service components (governance, funding, instruction, human resources, products, technology, quality assurance, counseling). Don observes education deeply embedded in government more than other sectors. Identifies multiple structural impediments mentioned by trustees, international organizations, and educators. Outlines key issues: mission clarity, structural organization (hospital administration vs. principal models), accountability specification, autonomy, professional culture/collaboration, and instructional models including curriculum, teacher training, and assessment. Proposes legislative committee as appropriate reform vehicle.

Undated 21-2-E RESTRUCTURING Final restructuring version framing education mandate critique. Don notes widespread recognition that community future… ▸ more
Final restructuring version framing education mandate critique. Don notes widespread recognition that community future depends on citizen education levels. Surveys provincial mandates showing most focus on democratic citizenship, employment skills, and postsecondary preparation; PEI uniquely defines role narrowly as "developing and delivering programs in French and English to Island Children." He advocates both structural and cultural reform, arguing deep government embedment dampens communication, collaboration, autonomy, accountability, and service quality. Calls for structural overhaul, referencing international authority (OECD, World Bank, UNESCO, Montreal Economic Institute) and local stakeholders. Concludes with rallying rhetoric: "Our future lies in our hands. Let's take back our future."
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

 Read · Download
Undated 21-3 Purpose Essay defining education as process helping others develop or change skills, knowledge, and attitudes—an umbrella term… ▸ more
Essay defining education as process helping others develop or change skills, knowledge, and attitudes—an umbrella term encompassing all learning wherever, whenever initiated. Don emphasizes community investment in education for individual and collective benefit through encouragement, regulation, attendance monitoring, and financial support. Lists long-time concerns including government capture of education (embedment, licensing, pay scales, professional/culture conflicts), measuring education by school time, absent program context, shift from service to product, client accountability absence, unclear standards/assessment, and professional status decline relative to health sector. Advocates for clear departmental education definition and invokes John Dewey's maxim that knowing what someone believes is fundamental.

Don lists hoped-for improvements including increased school autonomy, quality emphasis, curriculum updates, and grading system reform. He identifies the lack of a visible change leader as a significant problem and comments critically on government idiosyncrasies that impede educational reform. Undated 99 Math rating scale This document contains the "Universal Rating Scale" and "Citizen Math" assessment tool developed through Education… ▸ more
This document contains the "Universal Rating Scale" and "Citizen Math" assessment tool developed through Education 20/20 Inc.'s community panel process. The six-level scale ranges from "Limited knowledge of math facts" (Level 1) to "Can perform with initiative, adaptability and lead others" (Level 6), with ratings based on community standards and practical daily-living competency. The document appears incomplete with corrupted text fragments, but preserves the core framework Don developed for assessing practical mathematics in real-world contexts, emphasizing accuracy, speed, consistency, and assistance needed.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 99-4 Math rating scale The refined and most complete version of the Citizen Math assessment framework. Don describes the community-led… ▸ more
The refined and most complete version of the Citizen Math assessment framework. Don describes the community-led process: a skilled facilitator worked with islander panels to identify 74 practical math skills organized under six categories (whole numbers, measurement, fractions/decimals/percentages, spatial reasoning, patterns/relationships, statistical information). A second panel refined assessment criteria focusing on accuracy/quality, assistance needed, speed, and consistency. This document documents Education 20/20's participatory approach to developing competency-based assessment aligned with community-valued mathematical skills for lifelong learning.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D 25 Out of Sync A comprehensive letter to Charlottetown Guardian and Journal Pioneer (Draft 25) analyzing PEI's education system as… ▸ more
A comprehensive letter to Charlottetown Guardian and Journal Pioneer (Draft 25) analyzing PEI's education system as "out of sync." Don articulates his philosophy that education encompasses all formative experiences, not just schooling, and notes a major 21st-century shift where schools increasingly must handle social-emotional development as home structures weaken. He diagnoses structural problems (narrow role definition, fuzzy vision, coordination gaps, politicized leadership) and proposes solutions including professional service delivery models, learner-centered approaches, and separation of instruction from credentialing. References personal experience in multiple organizations and calls for clear vision statements developed with public input. This piece encapsulates many of his core education reform ideas.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

 Read · Download
Undated D 27 program changes A brief letter proposing program-level interventions in education including: updating belief statements about… ▸ more
A brief letter proposing program-level interventions in education including: updating belief statements about education, establishing independent qualification bodies separate from schools, standardized curriculum development templates using competencies and rating scales, and introducing "learning managers" as student advisers. Don positions these changes as reducing friction between education system and community.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION

Undated 10 Issues in vocational education A comprehensive analysis identifying twelve critical issues in secondary vocational education: definition, image,… ▸ more
A comprehensive analysis identifying twelve critical issues in secondary vocational education: definition, image, versus general education, graduation requirements, articulation, curriculum, staffing, teacher certification, facilities, counseling, administration, and employment. Don criticizes academia's bias and the degradation of vocational education's image through renaming (technical, applied). He questions why fewer vocational educators occupy leadership roles and why comprehensive schools have lost vocational administrators. He notes the declining labor-intensive job sector requiring corresponding curriculum shifts toward service-sector roles. This article synthesizes decades of Don's practical experience with competency-based and vocational education.

Undated 15 Travel documents for the independent learner Using his family's travel experiences as metaphor, Don proposes "travel documents" for independent learners including… ▸ more
Using his family's travel experiences as metaphor, Don proposes "travel documents" for independent learners including curriculum maps, learning models, learning guides, and learning plans. He contrasts the travel industry's flexibility with education's inflexibility, advocating for documents that help learners navigate the "learning world" independently. Reflects his belief that education should accommodate diverse learner needs.

Undated 16 What standards Don critiques competency-based occupational standards models, proposing improvements: individual focus, separation from… ▸ more
Don critiques competency-based occupational standards models, proposing improvements: individual focus, separation from training, performance-based criteria, outcome focus, performance levels, and assessor judgment. He emphasizes standards must focus on individuals (not groups), that standards are distinct from training, and argues judgment cannot be eliminated—only made more reliable through support systems.

Reflects Don's focus on standardization and measurable outcomes in education.

Written by Don. Letter to editor proposing PEI create comprehensive "education system" (services for all Islanders, not just school-age students). Argues current "school system" insufficient; proposes advisory model (education advisor like family doctor), learning context establishment, competency-based progress reporting. Addresses life roles (individual, family member, learner, citizen, consumer, producer). Encapsulates Don's core educational vision for systemic reform beyond traditional schooling.

Undated Framework 14 no logo circles added Comprehensive "Education Primer" by Don Glendenning, published by Education 20/20 Inc. (PEI-based nonprofit where Don… ▸ more
Comprehensive "Education Primer" by Don Glendenning, published by Education 20/20 Inc. (PEI-based nonprofit where Don served as board director). 400+ page educational framework defining key concepts: learners, learning, quality education, student assessment, Bloom's Taxonomy levels, educational beliefs, essential skills, teaching functions, and life roles. Includes innovative concepts like dynamic rating scales, benchmark standards, and learning paths. References exemplary schools across North America (Calgary, BC, Toronto, Washington, New Hampshire) worth visiting. Represents culmination of Don's career-long education reform thinking with practical implementation guidance.

Undated Structure 4 Brief organizational analysis of education service structure, likely part of a larger series of documents examining PEI… ▸ more
Brief organizational analysis of education service structure, likely part of a larger series of documents examining PEI education system design. Don critiques that PEI's structure does not reflect all services at senior levels, functions are not clearly identified, and organizational form does not follow function. Notes that school autonomy and public accountability are important, and that restricted information flow may result from embedding education in government. Reflects his systems-thinking approach to institutional design.

Undated 100 Clarity - A formal letter from Don to PEI education authorities arguing for conceptual clarity in education terminology and… ▸ more
A formal letter from Don to PEI education authorities arguing for conceptual clarity in education terminology and organization. Don points out critical confusions in the PEI education system, such as the interchangeable use of "education" and "schooling," the lack of a definition of education in provincial legislation, and the failure to organize by function. This document exemplifies Don's role as a constructive critic of education policy.

Undated 100 Definitions Don's carefully crafted definitions of key education terminology, including education, education system, educated,… ▸ more
Don's carefully crafted definitions of key education terminology, including education, education system, educated, learner, life roles, school, school system, and teaching. He notes that PEI no longer has an official definition of education and provides his own definitions based on behavioral change and community support frameworks. This reflects his core concern with precise language in education.

Undated 100 Services Don's analytical essay outlining typical education services that should be available in an education system, including… ▸ more
Don's analytical essay outlining typical education services that should be available in an education system, including information provision, counselling, organizational support, instruction, quality assurance, learning products, technology, funding, specialists, and data management. He criticizes that these services are integrated into schools and therefore unavailable to most Islanders. Reflects his lifelong concern about broadening education beyond formal schooling.

Undated 101 Clarity - Don identifies fundamental confusion in PEI education between "going to school" and "getting an education." He argues… ▸ more
Don identifies fundamental confusion in PEI education between "going to school" and "getting an education." He argues that the Department has narrowed its focus from supporting broad education to delivering school curriculum. This core concern about definitional clarity and the need for a comprehensive education system versus a school system represents a major theme in Don's later writings on education reform.

Undated 11 Adding Education value Don proposes concrete strategies for enhancing the educational value of public schooling, drawing on World Bank… ▸ more
Don proposes concrete strategies for enhancing the educational value of public schooling, drawing on World Bank research distinguishing education from schooling. Recommendations include student self-rating, learning guides, assessment criteria transparency, student engagement, teacher training, school autonomy, and individual student profiles. Reflects his systematic approach to improving educational outcomes.

Undated 13 Imrovements Comprehensive framework for systemic interventions in PEI education across four levels: Education System (terminology,… ▸ more
Comprehensive framework for systemic interventions in PEI education across four levels: Education System (terminology, purpose, principles, accountability), School System (organizational structure, management, autonomy), Classroom (culture, teaching models, assessment), and Teaching/Learning Model (competencies, curriculum mapping, self-assessment). Demonstrates Don's systems-thinking approach to educational reform.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 15 school Don examines the distinction between schooling and education, emphasizing that individual learning is fundamental and… ▸ more
Don examines the distinction between schooling and education, emphasizing that individual learning is fundamental and that education's value depends on preparing people for daily life. He critiques the Department of Education's focus on knowledge delivery rather than holistic education preparation, and notes that learning outcomes lack sufficient specificity.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 17 Role ofDept Don challenges the concentration of educational authority in government, questioning whether a single body should… ▸ more
Don challenges the concentration of educational authority in government, questioning whether a single body should control school attendance, curriculum, employment, assessment, and funding. He proposes separation of powers: government should encourage, support, and regulate; citizens should have choice; an independent body should certify learning; standards should be community-set. Reflects his vision for democratic educational governance.

A comprehensive action agenda for education system reform in PEI, proposing 30+ specific interventions including defining terminology, clarifying purposes, restructuring the Department around education functions rather than schools, increasing school autonomy, replacing outcomes-based education with competency-based, implementing learning guides and student profiles, and establishing community education service centers.

Undated 21 About Education Don outlines fundamental principles about education: learning is personal, education results from experience-driven… ▸ more
Don outlines fundamental principles about education: learning is personal, education results from experience-driven change in knowledge and skills, families and teachers are major contributors, provinces mandate schooling to boost learning. He identifies concerns about narrow curriculum focus, lack of learner choice, weak transcripts, and poor correlation between school curriculum and life needs.

Undated 3 Purpose Highlight Don examines purpose statements across Canadian education systems, comparing PEI's vague goal of helping students "take… ▸ more
Don examines purpose statements across Canadian education systems, comparing PEI's vague goal of helping students "take a meaningful place in society" against clearer mission statements from other provinces. He criticizes PEI's limited focus on children only and lack of specificity for program planning and assessment. Proposes organizing education around six life roles. This document captures his core concern about conceptual clarity.

Undated 6 Help with learning Don outlines nine categories of help available to learners: information, counselling, instruction, assessment, learning… ▸ more
Don outlines nine categories of help available to learners: information, counselling, instruction, assessment, learning products, technology, funding, human resources, and data/reporting. Emphasizes that effective education systems must provide these services equitably and flexibly, recognizing individual learning rates and patterns. Notes that independent learners require system accommodation and will place additional demands on services.

Undated 9 Instruction model Don proposes a competency-based instructional model replacing traditional outcomes-based education. Recommends… ▸ more
Don proposes a competency-based instructional model replacing traditional outcomes-based education. Recommends grounding content in competencies practiced by target populations, establishing performance levels, requiring student self-rating, employing dynamic rating scales, creating learning contexts, and reporting progress by competency. Reflects his systematic approach to making education more relevant and measurable.

Don proposes a comprehensive list of education services (information, counselling, instruction, quality assurance, funding, technology, human resources, data reporting) that should be available to all Islanders. He argues education systems fail to make these services independently available and advocates expanding the education system beyond schools to serve lifelong learners.

Undated Barriers Don identifies twelve major barriers to educational change in PEI: autonomy, funding, time constraints, leadership… ▸ more
Don identifies twelve major barriers to educational change in PEI: autonomy, funding, time constraints, leadership changes, mindset, entrenched traditions, organizational complexity, local control limitations, limited R&D capacity, weak incentives, silo-based organization, and inadequate research and development. This analysis reflects his systems thinking approach to understanding why educational reform has been difficult to implement despite recognized needs for improvement.

Undated Changes This document presents a strategic framework for educational change in PEI consisting of nine sequential steps: clarify… ▸ more
This document presents a strategic framework for educational change in PEI consisting of nine sequential steps: clarify terminology and purpose, identify clientele, promote functions and services, establish an education system (vs. school system), increase school autonomy, clarify accountabilities, institute tracking systems, restructure to reflect functions, and establish functional advisory committees and education hubs. This represents Don's systematic roadmap for comprehensive educational reform in the province.

Letter to editor advocating for clarity in PEI education policy, criticizing vague definitions and mission statements. Don argues the Department needs to define education beyond schooling and establish a full-service system for all ages, demonstrating his late-career advocacy for educational reform.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Clarity 2- Another letter to the editor addressing definitional problems in PEI education. Don questions why departments add… ▸ more
Another letter to the editor addressing definitional problems in PEI education. Don questions why departments add "Lifelong Learning" or "Early Childhood Education" to titles when these are already part of education; criticizes references to only "young people" when the Department serves all citizens; challenges vague phrases like "secure a place"; critiques focus on "developing and delivering programs" rather than helping citizens develop needed competencies; notes Department literature focuses on school matters rather than education. He emphasizes that conceptual clarity is essential to prevent education's concept from becoming diluted.

Includes practical capability components (able to perform daily routines) alongside intellectual achievement.

He advocates for a terminology taxonomy and advocates for renaming the department if necessary.

Undated System 1 Education A concise foundational document defining core education concepts. Don establishes precise terminology distinguishing… ▸ more
A concise foundational document defining core education concepts. Don establishes precise terminology distinguishing learning (changing knowledge/beliefs/values), teaching (arranging experiences), education (sector of helping others learn), school (building with groups), and schooling (pattern of support). This establishes the linguistic foundation for his broader argument that PEI has a "school system" rather than an "education system." The document signals his intention to clarify definitional confusion as central to systemic reform.

 Read · Download
Undated System PEI 1 Don's framework for conversation about PEI's education future. Written from personal experience with education and… ▸ more
Don's framework for conversation about PEI's education future. Written from personal experience with education and commitment to community contribution, this document establishes foundational definitions and life-role theory (individual, family member, citizen, student, producer, consumer) across which education needs arise. Don argues that Islanders recognize education's community importance, contrasts school systems with education systems, identifies key operating beliefs (learners at own pace, education as behavior-change, teachers as experience designers, ranking as non-educational), and catalogs typical services and branches. The document explicitly aims to facilitate community dialogue about transforming school systems into education systems.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated System-6 Highlight Don's detailed educational philosophy emphasizing that provinces confuse school systems with education systems, citing… ▸ more
Don's detailed educational philosophy emphasizing that provinces confuse school systems with education systems, citing World Bank warnings. He articulates comprehensive key concepts, beliefs, and organizing principles for education, proposing that service organizations should be decentralized. This extensive document crystallizes his lifetime commitment to systemic educational transformation.

 Read · Download
Undated 0 Definitions Don provides his standard definitions for education-related concepts, including education, learning, school, college,… ▸ more
Don provides his standard definitions for education-related concepts, including education, learning, school, college, and university. Drawing on the Oregon Department of Education's "life roles" model, he outlines six roles (individual, family member, citizen, student, producer, consumer) and argues education contributes to all. He advocates for the PEI Department of Education to clarify and review its purpose, as clear definitions are essential for maintaining a strong education system.

Undated 2 Purpos2 e Letter to the editor addressing PEI Department of Education's lack of clarity. Don critiques the absence of a written… ▸ more
Letter to the editor addressing PEI Department of Education's lack of clarity. Don critiques the absence of a written definition of education, confusion between branches/fields/levels, and the Department's outdated focus on "delivering" rather than supporting education. He advocates for better public information and a taxonomy of common educational terms.

Undated 3 Devinitions Comprehensive exploration of education definitions and PEI Department's role. Don clarifies distinctions between… ▸ more
Comprehensive exploration of education definitions and PEI Department's role. Don clarifies distinctions between education and schooling, discusses life roles framework, and outlines how other provinces (NB, Alberta) define their education departments' broader missions beyond curriculum delivery. He argues the PEI Department must redefine itself from "delivering curriculum" to "developing people."

Undated 5 Clarity 1 Letter to the Minister addressing public education's clarity problem. Don identifies four specific issues: undefined… ▸ more
Letter to the Minister addressing public education's clarity problem. Don identifies four specific issues: undefined education in policy, confusing department literature, the problematic equation of education with going to school, and understated departmental role. He calls for a dictionary of key terms and emphasizes that education's future depends on clarity in purpose and definitions.

Undated A Beliefs Highlight Comprehensive statement of Glendenning's educational operating beliefs covering learning as personal experience,… ▸ more
Comprehensive statement of Glendenning's educational operating beliefs covering learning as personal experience, individual learner agency, variable time in education, and behavioral change through learning. Twenty-six distinct beliefs address learning philosophy, teaching roles, assessment approaches, institutional limitations, and systemic reform needs. Core beliefs emphasize learners as responsible agents, education's personal nature, distinction between education and schooling, and critique of current institutional inability to implement necessary changes. Argues school system lacks self-correcting mechanisms and external intervention is required for substantive reform.

Undated A Clarity Detailed analysis of clarity problems in PEI education policy. Don exposes three specific examples: the PEI… ▸ more
Detailed analysis of clarity problems in PEI education policy. Don exposes three specific examples: the PEI Administrative Handbook's vague purpose statement limited to children, the Department's understatement of its role, and conflation of education with schooling. He advocates for public discussion of education's purpose and suggests this fundamental issue warrants debate at Cabinet, Caucus, or Legislative Assembly level.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated A Clarity C Don analyzes conceptual clarity issues in PEI education, identifying eight areas needing reform: terminology,… ▸ more
Don analyzes conceptual clarity issues in PEI education, identifying eight areas needing reform: terminology, functions/services, education vs. schooling distinction, purpose, structure, autonomy, accountability, and self-correcting mechanisms. Drawing on World Bank and OECD research, he argues these are easily correctable structural problems that require systemic change to modernize education delivery.

Outline of key education issues organized by category: Clarity (terminology, taxonomy, purpose), Structure (role, services, organization, independent learners), Accountability (clarity and practice), and Workforce (fear factor, in-service training, silos, collaboration, autonomy). This document serves as a roadmap for Don's systematic critique of PEI education system reform needs.

Undated A Key Issues. Comprehensive analysis of nine structural issues in PEI education: unclear purpose, undefined terminology, unidentified… ▸ more
Comprehensive analysis of nine structural issues in PEI education: unclear purpose, undefined terminology, unidentified services, structure not matching function, lack of school autonomy, unclear accountability, insufficient collaboration, curriculum outcomes misaligned with life roles, and understated departmental role. Don argues these interconnected problems require structural reform and public discussion to resolve effectively.

Outline of Don's competency-based mathematics instruction plan emphasizing learner self-rating, universal rating scales, community-based criteria, individual profiles, and student-held competency records. The approach replaces traditional grading with descriptive competency ratings that serve as transcripts, reflecting his broader philosophy of education focused on demonstrated learning rather than institutional assessment.
