Undated 05- Reading matters A focused poster identifying eight key performance criteria for reading: range of material, comprehension, fluency,… ▸ more
A focused poster identifying eight key performance criteria for reading: range of material, comprehension, fluency, independence, speed, word knowledge/vocabulary, flow, and phonics. This practical guide suggests Education 20/20 Inc.'s evidence-based approach to literacy instruction and assessment.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 34 - Significance in Time Newsletter article (Issue 34) edited by Don Glendenning exploring the distinction between academic and occupational… ▸ more
Newsletter article (Issue 34) edited by Don Glendenning exploring the distinction between academic and occupational standards. Don argues that while academic students can take longer to master content, workplace performers must achieve quality work within competitive time constraints. The article challenges educators to differentiate between learning time and performance time, using a carpentry example to illustrate how two students producing equal quality may receive different assessments based on time invested.
SPEECH
Read · Download

Undated 45 - Graduation (1) Newsletter article (Issue 45) edited by Don Glendenning discussing graduation requirements and core skills for… ▸ more
Newsletter article (Issue 45) edited by Don Glendenning discussing graduation requirements and core skills for citizenship and employment. Don advocates for identifying essential skills (communication, mathematics, technological literacy, personal management) that should be taught before other curriculum. He proposes using community input to create a comprehensive skills list linked to citizenship and employment outcomes, which would form the foundation for curriculum development and assessment.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 56 Assigning levels (003) Newsletter article (Issue 56) edited by Don Glendenning on student assessment and grading systems. Don critiques… ▸ more
Newsletter article (Issue 56) edited by Don Glendenning on student assessment and grading systems. Don critiques grading practices, noting they originated at Yale and remain uncalibrated instruments despite determining student futures. He argues that teaching and sorting are conflicting roles and proposes independent qualification authorities (citing New Zealand and Ontario models) to conduct external assessments, suggesting PEI could establish such a service.
SPEECH
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 54- Education services) Newsletter article (Issue 54) edited by Don Glendenning defining education as a service industry. He outlines core… ▸ more
Newsletter article (Issue 54) edited by Don Glendenning defining education as a service industry. He outlines core education functions (information, instruction, diagnosis, tutoring, guided practice, feedback, materials/technology, quality assurance) and school-specific functions. Don argues that grading should not be a school function due to conflicting roles between teaching and sorting, and proposes that schools report progress while independent bodies handle official assessment.

Undated 4 Achiement levels Don's conceptual paper on proficiency levels and assessment in education, arguing for separation of teaching,… ▸ more
Don's conceptual paper on proficiency levels and assessment in education, arguing for separation of teaching, evaluation, and ranking functions (analogous to sports coaching vs. refereeing). Proposes an independent assessment service to certify proficiency in selected subjects, removing bias from schools. Reflects Don's innovative thinking about educational credentialing and assessment methodology influenced by Robert Paul Wolff's taxonomy of assessment purposes.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 6 Proficiency levels Expanded working paper by Don on establishing proficiency levels in education, responding to trends toward social… ▸ more
Expanded working paper by Don on establishing proficiency levels in education, responding to trends toward social promotion, declining credential value, and international testing pressures. Proposes independent assessment service to certify proficiency in math and other fields. Argues the philosophical distinction between formative criticism, criterion-referenced evaluation, and ranking—positions schools and teachers should avoid ranking their own students due to conflict of interest. Demonstrates Don's continuing engagement with educational assessment reform.

Includes consultant proposals, HST estimates, and methodology preferences for surveying the 2,313 residents of Souris, demonstrating Don's professional grant-writing and community development expertise.

Undated AB-Learn 6 Learners Examination of learner characteristics and the conditions affecting education outcomes. Discusses how learners carry… ▸ more
Examination of learner characteristics and the conditions affecting education outcomes. Discusses how learners carry three types of 'luggage': physical/mental/emotional conditions, prior learning experiences, and future aspirations. Frames education as preparation for six life roles (individual, family member, learner, citizen, consumer, producer), emphasizing the personalized nature of education and learning challenges.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated An Education Agenda Critical policy paper arguing that PEI's Department of Education should broaden its mandate beyond schools and youth to… ▸ more
Critical policy paper arguing that PEI's Department of Education should broaden its mandate beyond schools and youth to serve all citizens in lifelong learning. Advocates for systemic change focusing on processes of changing how people think, feel, and act, rather than the current age-based, institution-centric approach. Reflects Don's long-standing views on comprehensive educational reform.
PROFESSIONAL

Undated Our Money's Worth Analysis of educational value and accountability in PEI public schools, examining the $10,000 annual per-student cost… ▸ more
Analysis of educational value and accountability in PEI public schools, examining the $10,000 annual per-student cost and systemic barriers to educational improvement. Argues for systemic reform including reading standards, effective report cards, and increased teacher flexibility. Critical assessment of government-controlled education model lacking market-driven accountability mechanisms.

Undated Redesigning the Eduction System A sophisticated systems-level analysis addressing the confusion between grading and assessment functions in PEI… ▸ more
A sophisticated systems-level analysis addressing the confusion between grading and assessment functions in PEI education. Don argues that assessment should be independent from teaching, proposes separating sorting from instruction, and critiques social promotion. He advocates for competency-based approaches with multiple levels regardless of learner age, reflecting his broader educational philosophy about the conflict of roles in current school systems.

Undated Report cards A background research document analyzing student report card systems, proposing that they should be linked to outcomes,… ▸ more
A background research document analyzing student report card systems, proposing that they should be linked to outcomes, criterion-referenced, and organized by subject difficulty levels rather than age/grades. Don draws from research and policy documents across provinces, advocating for transparency in reporting systems and parent satisfaction through meaningful teacher comments aligned with learning outcomes.

PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Learning-1 (170 words):** Don Glendenning defines learning, teaching, and education with clarity and precision. He argues all PEI… ▸ more
(170 words):** Don Glendenning defines learning, teaching, and education with clarity and precision. He argues all PEI residents are potential learners who seek measurable change in knowledge, skills, attitudes, or values. Learners bring three elements to education: inherent physical/mental/emotional conditions; prior experiences from varied sources; and personal aspirations. Don defines learning as changing what one knows, feels, believes, and can do; teaching as arranging experiences enabling such change; and education as resulting from meaningful experiences. He notes that being "well-educated" means handling everyday life issues competently. Critically, Don rejects the conflation of school attendance with education—the World Bank warns this is problematic. He observes PEI educators lack shared definitions, potentially reflecting mission uncertainty, struggles with contemporary changes, and unclear educational services. He recommends reviewing common terminology, adopting shared definitions, implementing low-key systemic changes, ensuring conceptual clarity, and reconsidering educational goals and lifelong learning integration.

Detailed analysis of mission statements for PEI and other provincial education departments. Glendenning argues PEI's mission is too narrow, comparing it unfavorably with New Brunswick, Newfoundland, and Nova Scotia. He proposes broader language that reflects education's role in developing citizens for the 21st century.

Glendenning critiques the narrow focus on youth and "developing and delivering curriculum" as insufficient.

Undated 2-2 Sorting-Qualifications Brief notes defining credentials and credentialing as distinct from education. Explains that credentials are documents… ▸ more
Brief notes defining credentials and credentialing as distinct from education. Explains that credentials are documents attesting to participation in educational programs, while credentialing is a sorting process carried out by independent bodies based on assessment. Emphasizes that credentialing is not itself a learning function but rather reflects what a person can do and how well.

Don advocates for continuous institutional change management, expanded parent and citizen engagement, increased teacher autonomy, and references Alberta's competitive education model demonstrating how market forces drive performance improvement and innovation in schools.

A brief framework document outlining a learning model with key phases and supporting functions. The model progresses through stages of welcoming learners, providing information and encouragement, assessing skills, providing feedback and awards, and concluding with credentialing and qualification. The framework emphasizes demonstration, modeling, coaching, assistance, and the distinction between awarding credentials and qualifications.

Undated Innovation-1 A proposal to stimulate innovation in PEI's education system through an Innovators Network that would connect educators… ▸ more
A proposal to stimulate innovation in PEI's education system through an Innovators Network that would connect educators working on innovations, provide information about educational advances, and recognize and reward creative contributions. Don argues that education systems are bureaucratic and top-directed (inhibiting innovation) and proposes encouraging innovation through awards, public recognition, promotional campaigns, and competitions. He identifies PEI's historical tradition of innovation in agriculture, pharmaceuticals, and avionics, and proposes systematic support for educational innovators including electronic networking, newsletters, forums, and ongoing professional development rather than periodic initiatives.

Undated Interventions-Long list An extensive working document outlining systemic interventions and reforms for PEI's education system organized into… ▸ more
An extensive working document outlining systemic interventions and reforms for PEI's education system organized into major categories: changers (information, engagement, innovation, recognition, professional development, research), desired system characteristics, enabling changes, and structural recommendations. Don proposes restructuring delivery systems with education advisors, early childhood centers, and special needs clinics; establishing an independent qualification authority; overhauling governance; increasing public engagement; updating curriculum models; encouraging innovation; and implementing market mechanisms. The document reflects his comprehensive vision for transforming education from a school-centered, bureaucratic system to a learner-centered, flexible, transparent system.

Undated Learner A brief framework outlining the characteristics of a learner from Don's educational philosophy perspective. The… ▸ more
A brief framework outlining the characteristics of a learner from Don's educational philosophy perspective. The document identifies three key dimensions: prior experiences (home, school, travel, culture, lifestyle, support), prior conditions (physical, mental, emotional, and social wellness), and imagined future (family, career, community, income, lifestyle). This represents Don's holistic approach to understanding learners as whole people with complex backgrounds and aspirations.

Undated 3-2 Windsor Proposal@2016-05-05T23;34;34 A detailed Windsor Foundation proposal from Education 20/20 Inc. proposing to explore alternatives to current… ▸ more
A detailed Windsor Foundation proposal from Education 20/20 Inc. proposing to explore alternatives to current achievement grading methods, specifically titled "Mapping the Math Mountain." The proposal argues that using "grade" for both age grouping and achievement levels is confusing and proposes establishing criterion-referenced achievement levels in mathematics. It outlines specific steps including establishing a steering committee, developing competency lists, and creating rating scales based on Bloom's taxonomy.

Undated D Sunshine E Bernard Gillis-1@2015-09-28T14;13;03 A fundraising letter from Don Glendenning (as President of Education 20/20 Inc.) to Bernard Gillis at Metro Credit… ▸ more
A fundraising letter from Don Glendenning (as President of Education 20/20 Inc.) to Bernard Gillis at Metro Credit Union seeking financial support for education change initiatives. The letter outlines structural problems in the education system and describes tools for change including newsletters, engagement activities, recognition programs, and awards. It emphasizes the role of independent information as fuel for systemic educational improvement.
CORRESPONDENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated IT Training A proposal for delivering 21st century information technology (IT) skills training to students through Education 20/20… ▸ more
A proposal for delivering 21st century information technology (IT) skills training to students through Education 20/20 Inc. Identifies background challenges: IT skills are critical for modern economy but expensive and difficult for schools to maintain current technology, teachers struggle to keep up, school time is limited, parents cannot keep current, and equipment sits unused after hours/weekends. Proposes training in local communities for children and young adults outside normal school hours and during summer. Options include credit or non-credit offerings, after-hours school facilities, library-based delivery, and fee-based or sponsored funding. Discusses integration approaches: 20/20 could secure funding and hire staff, or find funding and contract with providers. Raises implementation questions about Education 20/20's charitable status, whether IT training aligns with organizational priorities, and whether it conflicts with or supports core mission. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: LOW - While showing Don's future-orientation regarding technology, it's a preliminary concept without substantial development.

Undated Leadership Award A minimal proposal outline for a Leadership Award/Recognition program by Education 20/20 Inc. targeting Island… ▸ more
A minimal proposal outline for a Leadership Award/Recognition program by Education 20/20 Inc. targeting Island educators. Core elements include public recognition of individuals and institutions demonstrating cutting-edge practices, public presentation of award recipients. The document includes Education 20/20 Inc. contact information (101 Kent St., Charlottetown, PEI; Tel: 902-892-2060; email: pei@education2020.ca; website: www.education2020.ca). Represents one component of Don's strategy to incentivize and publicly acknowledge educational innovation and excellence. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (implied) - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 Inc. - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: LOW - Minimal content, though consistent with Don's recognition of educational excellence.

Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Math gap 7 This document outlines the Mathematics Gap Initiative, a steering committee effort led by Don Glendenning to address… ▸ more
This document outlines the Mathematics Gap Initiative, a steering committee effort led by Don Glendenning to address the low level of basic mathematical skills among Islanders. The committee identified the gap as real and having significant economic and social impact, arising from differing perceptions of educational institutions, silo mentalities, and politicization of education. The proposal seeks to establish an independent assessment service certifying proficiency in everyday mathematics skills with multiple performance levels, fee-based access, and employer consultation.
BIOGRAPHICAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Math 6 Independent This proposal recommends establishing a pilot project enabling students to challenge high school mathematics courses… ▸ more
This proposal recommends establishing a pilot project enabling students to challenge high school mathematics courses for credit through independent learning. The initiative recognizes that learners progress at different paces and should be encouraged to meet standards in their own timeframe, with a focus on allowing higher achievement through supplementary instruction and support mechanisms.

Undated Math This document describes Education 20/20 professional services and initiatives emerging from a Community Foundation of… ▸ more
This document describes Education 20/20 professional services and initiatives emerging from a Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island youth survey. It details a working group addressing the transition from secondary school to employment and further studies, identifying four key issues: the mathematics skill gap, varying math proficiency levels, assessment methodologies, and reporting processes for skill documentation.

Undated Math 2 gap This early mathematics gap initiative document frames the problem as a labour market mismatch between available… ▸ more
This early mathematics gap initiative document frames the problem as a labour market mismatch between available workers' skills and employer needs, driven by concerns from PISA results, Community Foundation surveys, and employer feedback. The steering committee, including Don Glendenning, outlined next steps including analysis of practical mathematics competencies, employer surveys, rating scale development, and testing with job applicants.

Undated Math 5@2015-03-18T01;44;05 A comprehensive education proposal critiquing PEI's education system and proposing establishment of an independent… ▸ more
A comprehensive education proposal critiquing PEI's education system and proposing establishment of an independent qualification authority separate from teaching. The document advocates for criterion-referenced assessment, professional teaching model, and establishing standardized mathematics competency levels across schools, colleges, and universities to enable consistent assessment and certification.

This foundational proposal document presents three initiatives: comprehensive analysis of math competencies with identifiable stages and rating scales; establishing competency-based math levels equivalent to high school graduation; and confirming the mathematics skill gap through research and assessment piloting.

Undated Math mountain proposal@2015-02-15T20;07;28 An extensive proposal using the metaphor of Mount Mathematics to advocate for creating a structured math proficiency… ▸ more
An extensive proposal using the metaphor of Mount Mathematics to advocate for creating a structured math proficiency ladder with clearly identified achievement levels. It proposes establishing an independent assessment service, conducting comprehensive competency analysis, developing rating scales, and creating performance-based assessment systems comparable to music or figure skating certification models.

Undated Tutoring service @2015-04-19T09;59;09 This proposal outlines establishing a trial tutoring service at two locations focused on basic skills in both official… ▸ more
This proposal outlines establishing a trial tutoring service at two locations focused on basic skills in both official languages. The service would operate on a fee basis, require organizations to have charitable status, include minimum 40-hour commitments, and involve Education 20/20 oversight of facilities, tutors, and resource materials.

Education 20/20 Inc. advocacy brief calling for systemic education reform in PEI, including learner-centered services, autonomous school operations, independent qualification authority, professional teaching models, and support for innovation. Represents Don's core education philosophy emphasizing flexibility, accountability, and responsiveness to learner needs rather than traditional time-based credentials and centralized control.

Undated 00 New model @2015-05-09T18;01;23 Media release by Don Glendenning critiquing time-based school delivery models and advocating for developmental,… ▸ more
Media release by Don Glendenning critiquing time-based school delivery models and advocating for developmental, outcomes-based education. Argues that schools' current system is ineffective because it assumes students at the same grade level have uniform progress, and proposes using learning paths and technology to provide individualized support based on student achievement of specific outcomes rather than seat time.

Undated D-Coding for Kids @2015-05-09T02;53;37 Media release advocating for computer coding instruction in schools. Don Glendenning emphasizes that coding teaches… ▸ more
Media release advocating for computer coding instruction in schools. Don Glendenning emphasizes that coding teaches different thinking patterns and represents the language of technology. References international examples of coding initiatives and argues that even modest instruction (25-50 hours) provides benefits, positioning schools and libraries as ideal venues for coding education.

Undated D-Quebec math @2015-05-09T18;09;16 Media release analyzing Quebec's superior PISA mathematics scores compared to other Canadian provinces. Don Glendenning… ▸ more
Media release analyzing Quebec's superior PISA mathematics scores compared to other Canadian provinces. Don Glendenning attributes success to formal instruction, teacher quality, and technology use, and hypothesizes that Quebec's more precise curriculum wording for outcomes (arithmetic and algebra categories versus PEI's broader patterns) may facilitate better student understanding and assessment.

Undated 20 Expectationsof schools@2014-09-21T18;46;13 Newsletter article (Open Education No. 20) by Editor Don Glendenning discussing changing expectations of public schools… ▸ more
Newsletter article (Open Education No. 20) by Editor Don Glendenning discussing changing expectations of public schools beyond knowledge acquisition. Drawing on Education 20/20 workshop feedback, he proposes that schools should help students develop skills, knowledge, and attitudes for work, further education, and citizenship, and invites participants to a workshop on learner-centered education.

Undated 25 Alternative credentialling@2015-02-08T02;00;51 Newsletter article (Open Education No. 25) by Don Glendenning examining the decline of high school diplomas as hiring… ▸ more
Newsletter article (Open Education No. 25) by Don Glendenning examining the decline of high school diplomas as hiring criteria and the rise of third-party testing and skills assessments. He argues that schools should abandon ranking functions (which create conflicts of interest), scrap graduation requirements, and instead provide transcripts of learning with the option to help fill gaps later.

Undated 24 fog index@2015-01-03T19;46;10 Newsletter article (Open Education No. 25) by Don Glendenning on implementing educational change, identifying four… ▸ more
Newsletter article (Open Education No. 25) by Don Glendenning on implementing educational change, identifying four essential elements: a change agent with freedom to challenge status quo, an "oasis" or protected space for innovation, patience for implementation, and advocacy from knowledgeable third parties. He emphasizes that systemic issues often prevent teachers from implementing known solutions.

Undated 25 Masthead@2015-02-06T10;46;35 Newsletter masthead/introductory page (Open Education No. 01) articulating Education 20/20's operating beliefs about… ▸ more
Newsletter masthead/introductory page (Open Education No. 01) articulating Education 20/20's operating beliefs about education. Core principles include recognition that education occurs both in and outside schools, that home is the major educational contributor, that parents want education not just schooling, and that educating is a developmental activity distinct from knowledge transfer.

Newsletter article (Open Education No. 25) by Don Glendenning revisiting the issue of credential devaluation and arguing for alternatives to traditional diplomas and degrees. He contends that schools function as learning support institutions and should avoid ranking students (creating conflicts of interest), instead providing transcripts and allowing gap-filling when needed.

Undated 30 - Role of school@2014-08-23T13;17;17 Newsletter article examining the fundamental question of what role schools should play in educating youth. The piece… ▸ more
Newsletter article examining the fundamental question of what role schools should play in educating youth. The piece presents multiple choice options for school functions (guide, provide, support, teach, help, prepare, foster, develop) combined with intended outcomes for students. Draws on dialogue from a Stratford workshop to explore the gap between what schools do and what communities expect them to accomplish.

Newsletter article discussing continuing education as lifelong learning beyond initial schooling. Lists six reasons for continued education (keeping pace with job changes, promotion, career transitions, personal growth, social standing, love of learning) and identifies various delivery mechanisms including employer-sponsored programs, educational institutions, and community agencies.

Undated 30 Myth of grsde levels @2015-07-05T14;13;33 Newsletter article comparing Quebec's strong mathematics performance on international PISA testing to PEI results.… ▸ more
Newsletter article comparing Quebec's strong mathematics performance on international PISA testing to PEI results. Attributes Quebec's success to greater instruction in formal mathematics, increased teacher quality, and technology use. Contrasts Quebec's competency-based curriculum approach with PEI's outcome-based organization and encourages readers to review respective provincial curriculum documents.

Undated 33-B Achievement levels @2015-10-13T00;08;26 Newsletter article addressing wide achievement level ranges within typical classrooms, citing Australian research… ▸ more
Newsletter article addressing wide achievement level ranges within typical classrooms, citing Australian research showing math achievement spreads of up to 8 years within single grades. Argues that grade level is administrative while achievement refers to actual learning reached; proposes that schools choose between fixed time limits with variable achievement or fixed standards with variable time allocation.

Newsletter article presenting systematic conclusions about PEI's education system limitations. Identifies structural problems including focus on schooling over education, institutional rather than lifelong learning, credential preference over qualification assessment, limited services for adult learners, efficiency over effectiveness focus, and teacher-centered rather than learner-centered support.

Details findings that students differ in learning needs and resources, ranging from preferring lectures to self-directed Google research. Proposes creating a learning path flowchart encompassing overview, context, instruction, assessment, practice, and reflection for educational planning.

Undated D Teaching Don defines teachers as change agents who help learners develop new attitudes, skills, and knowledge through modeling,… ▸ more
Don defines teachers as change agents who help learners develop new attitudes, skills, and knowledge through modeling, instruction, feedback, and encouragement. He outlines the diverse roles teachers play in creating learning circumstances, from demonstration and assessment to coaching and project design.

Undated D-00 Powerful Questions Don summarizes Education 20/20 conclusions: the public understands education needs better than political leadership;… ▸ more
Don summarizes Education 20/20 conclusions: the public understands education needs better than political leadership; PEI needs a Department of Education not just Public Instruction; teachers should not participate in ranking (conflict of interest); educational goals must be clear and measurable; problems stem from organizational structure not professional inadequacy.

Undated D-15 Qualifications@2016-01-12T15;36;13 Newsletter article examining confusion arising from dual meaning of the word grade in education. Distinguishes between… ▸ more
Newsletter article examining confusion arising from dual meaning of the word grade in education. Distinguishes between age-based grouping and achievement levels, noting growing gaps cause boredom, public confidence loss, and credential devaluation. Proposes alternative terminology using achievement levels (typically 5-7 per subject) to better reflect student progress independent of age grouping.

Undated D-19 Recent reading@2014-08-17T13;33;41 Newsletter article collecting observations from contemporary education literature and media. Includes insights from… ▸ more
Newsletter article collecting observations from contemporary education literature and media. Includes insights from Marion Brady on student action over teacher instruction, newspaper accounts of presidential teacher meetings, and reflections on standardized testing's limitations. Highlights educator Neil Postman's recommended daily questions for teachers about impact and effectiveness.

Undated D-2 Alignment Newsletter article comparing vehicle alignment to education system alignment. Don argues that education systems need… ▸ more
Newsletter article comparing vehicle alignment to education system alignment. Don argues that education systems need written philosophy statements and measurable goals to maintain consistency across the system, similar to how car manufacturers specify performance standards. The piece advocates for comprehensive framework alignment covering goals, outcomes, assessment, instruction, and scheduling to prevent systems from drifting.
EDUCATION
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-20 Stage based learning@2014-08-27T02;54;59 Newsletter column examining grade-level myths in education, using construction and music training as examples of… ▸ more
Newsletter column examining grade-level myths in education, using construction and music training as examples of competency-based progression. Don contrasts this with age-based classroom grouping and discusses Robert Paul Wolff's framework distinguishing between criticism (feedback), evaluation (proficiency measurement), and ranking (competitive comparison). The piece advocates for moving away from rigid grade levels toward developmental, ability-based instruction.
EDUCATION

Undated D-28-2 Qualifications@2015-05-15T12;20;29 Newsletter article distinguishing between credentials (documents certifying program completion) and qualifications… ▸ more
Newsletter article distinguishing between credentials (documents certifying program completion) and qualifications (demonstrated competency to perform). Don advocates for separate, independent testing authorities to assess student achievement levels rather than having teachers serve as both educators and evaluators, citing successful models in apprenticeships and language acquisition testing.

Newsletter examining what teachers actually do to facilitate learning, noting the difficulty in finding formal position descriptions or outcome statements for teachers in PEI. Don lists typical teaching tasks including coaching, instruction, preparation, counseling, assessment, and motivation, concluding that teaching is fundamentally a process designed to enable learning.

Newsletter critiquing PEI's Department of Education as primarily serving public instruction rather than broader education goals. Don argues for expanded departmental support including tutoring, online courses, qualifications frameworks, part-time learning opportunities, and educational support for disenfranchised youth, proposing the department delegate school operations to focus on systemic education leadership.

Education 20/20 critique of grading systems and proposal for independent assessment bodies. Undated 34 Significance of time @2015-11-21T14;55;28 Educational article examining the role and significance of time in educational planning and student learning outcomes. Read · Download
Undated D-39 - A newsletter article by Don Glendenning and Tom White-Hassler examining issues with curriculum guides, particularly the… ▸ more
A newsletter article by Don Glendenning and Tom White-Hassler examining issues with curriculum guides, particularly the Grade 10 Math guide developed by the Western and Northern Canadian Protocol. Glendenning critiques the lack of clarity in outcome-based education and advocates for providing students with curriculum outcomes. The piece also discusses efficiency vs. effectiveness in education and highlights PEI's performance on adult competency assessments.

A nearly identical newsletter article to the first entry, co-authored by Glendenning and White-Hassler, discussing the confusion between curriculum-based and education-based outcomes. Glendenning argues for providing students with curriculum outcomes and advocates a more education-based approach rather than efficiency-focused curriculum design.

Undated 00 D-8-3 Qualificstion @2015-07-01T01;50;45 Highlight An occasional paper arguing that Canada needs a national qualification framework and independent authority to certify… ▸ more
An occasional paper arguing that Canada needs a national qualification framework and independent authority to certify performance levels, similar to those in other countries. Glendenning distinguishes between credentials (diplomas/degrees) and qualifications (demonstrated capability) and advocates for direct individual assessments rather than institutional credential verification.

Undated 4 System change An occasional paper recommending comprehensive educational system reform in Prince Edward Island. Glendenning calls for… ▸ more
An occasional paper recommending comprehensive educational system reform in Prince Edward Island. Glendenning calls for a clear provincial vision of education, learner-centered service models, delegation of instruction to diverse providers, establishment of a qualification authority, and a professional service delivery model with greater educator autonomy and accountability.

An occasional paper identifying gaps between what Islanders want and what PEI provides in education. Glendenning recommends system reforms including a clear provincial vision, learner-centered models, professional service delivery, establishment of a qualification authority to certify achievement, and encouragement of innovation in educational practice.

 Read · Download
Undated D-00 Math proficiency levels @2015-07-28T15;13;50 An occasional paper published through Education 20/20 Inc. arguing that grade-based assessment in mathematics… ▸ more
An occasional paper published through Education 20/20 Inc. arguing that grade-based assessment in mathematics perpetuates myths about student learning and competency. Glendenning proposes an independent assessment system based on proficiency levels rather than age-based grades, citing models like apprenticeship certification and the Royal Canadian Conservatory of Music as working examples. The paper advocates for separating the teaching function from the ranking/grading function to improve educational outcomes.

Emphasizes the need for learner-centered services, professional accountability, independent qualification authorities, and expanded instructional provision beyond schools to community agencies.

A version of the math proficiency levels paper examining problems with age-based grading systems and advocating for proficiency-level assessment independent of age. Glendenning addresses outcomes quality, age-based determination problems, teacher-grader role conflicts, and social promotion issues, proposing examples from apprenticeship and music certification.

Don provides Education 20/20's framework for systemic change, identifying gaps between what Islanders have and want in education. He analyzes organizational issues: limited community engagement, no comprehensive education philosophy, government focus on youth only, service gaps, lack of market conditions, politicization, and restricted professional autonomy.

An occasional paper on student testing and assessment that distinguishes between testing, assessment, evaluation, grading, and standards, examining the functions of student assessment including formative feedback, summative evaluation, and ranking. Glendenning argues for separating teaching from grading functions and proposes independent assessment services to reduce teacher role conflicts.

Undated D-4-A Educ Framework@2015-03-30T02;59;38 An occasional paper presenting Glendenning's framework for understanding education systems, identifying eight key… ▸ more
An occasional paper presenting Glendenning's framework for understanding education systems, identifying eight key components including information/counselling, institutions for formal instruction, community-based organizations, certification services, governance, resource materials, qualified staff, and defined school days. The paper also identifies several puzzling concepts in current education practice like age-based level assignment and social promotion.

Undated D-4 Math Problem @2015-03-19T15;39;18 An occasional paper addressing the math literacy gap in PEI schools despite stated educational goals. Glendenning… ▸ more
An occasional paper addressing the math literacy gap in PEI schools despite stated educational goals. Glendenning identifies school variables affecting success including time allocation, age-based grading myths, curriculum alignment, educational triage, and assessment practices. He proposes establishing an independent qualification authority and recommends priority attention to basic math skills for all students.
EDUCATION INSTITUTIONAL PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-5 Math Problem @2015-03-28T04;07;56 An occasional paper analyzing challenges in math education in PEI, particularly the gap between goals for mathematical… ▸ more
An occasional paper analyzing challenges in math education in PEI, particularly the gap between goals for mathematical literacy and actual student performance. Glendenning examines variables within the school system's control (time allocation, staffing, resource distribution, teacher autonomy) and proposes establishing a separate qualification authority to assess achievement independently of teaching. The paper emphasizes the distinction between teaching as formative support and assessment as summative ranking, arguing this separation would allow schools to focus on helping students learn.
EDUCATION INSTITUTIONAL PROFESSIONAL REFERENCE

 Read · Download
Undated D-8-2 Qualification @2015-09-07T02;14;11 Highlight Occasional paper proposing establishment of a Canadian qualification framework and independent qualification authority… ▸ more
Occasional paper proposing establishment of a Canadian qualification framework and independent qualification authority to facilitate labour mobility and distinguish between credentials (institutional credentials for course completion) and qualifications (demonstrated competency in performing tasks). Glendenning advocates for separating teaching/formative assessment from certification/summative assessment, citing examples like apprenticeship and music conservatory models that successfully operate independently of educational institutions.

Undated D-6 DACUM Comprehensive overview of DACUM methodology—Don's signature occupational analysis framework. Traces history from Nova… ▸ more
Comprehensive overview of DACUM methodology—Don's signature occupational analysis framework. Traces history from Nova Scotia NewStart to single-sheet skill profiles used in vocational training. Explains how DACUM defines competencies, promotes holistic occupation understanding, and serves as curriculum planning and evaluation instrument.

Undated D-8-5 Qualification @2015-07-04T10;01;10 Highlight Another iteration of Glendenning's qualification framework proposal addressing labour mobility challenges in Canada and… ▸ more
Another iteration of Glendenning's qualification framework proposal addressing labour mobility challenges in Canada and PEI. He distinguishes between credentials (awards for completing courses) and qualifications (proof of demonstrated competency), advocating for independent bodies to assess and certify competence rather than having educational institutions perform this function alongside teaching.

Undated D-8-4 Qualification @2015-09-08T17;21;59 Highlight A detailed proposal for establishing a Canadian qualification framework emphasizing the distinction between credentials… ▸ more
A detailed proposal for establishing a Canadian qualification framework emphasizing the distinction between credentials and qualifications. Glendenning argues that qualification authorities should assess individuals directly based on demonstrated performance rather than relying on institution-based input measures, and should not organize competitions or assign grades—functions that should remain with schools.

Undated Post 2 @2015-04-03T17;43;07 Reflective blog post comparing the historical shift in education's role from providing answers to defining questions.… ▸ more
Reflective blog post comparing the historical shift in education's role from providing answers to defining questions. Don explores how industrial-era grandfathers wanted stable employment for their children, while modern parents seek knowledge-industry careers requiring curious questioners. He proposes examining what people actually need in terms of education in contemporary society.

Undated Confusion in Literacy terms@2016-04-27T15;52;51 Don proposes standardizing literacy terminology and assessment levels across PEI's multiple education agencies and… ▸ more
Don proposes standardizing literacy terminology and assessment levels across PEI's multiple education agencies and programs. He argues that while various literacy initiatives exist in high schools, adult programs, and workforce development, the lack of unified definitions and consistent level frameworks creates confusion and inefficiency. Don advocates for a common provincial framework to improve communication, curriculum sharing, assessment standards, and student transitions.

This planning document outlines criteria and procedures for Education 20/20 to establish partnerships with other organizations. Undated Components Education system Don's structured outline of education system components organized into five categories: Information (advice,… ▸ more
Don's structured outline of education system components organized into five categories: Information (advice, counseling, assessment, diagnosis), Instruction (formal teaching, coaching, tutoring, guided practice), Community Support (libraries, technology, facilities, transportation), and Feedback (qualifications, research, quality control, awards). This framework shows Don's systemic thinking about how quality education operates beyond schools alone, integrating community resources and support mechanisms. - **Key People**: Don Glendenning (author) - **Key Organizations**: None specified - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION - **Eulogy Relevance**: LOW-MEDIUM - Shows analytical approach to education systems but lacks biographical content

This document presents Don Glendenning's personal framework for education reform in Prince Edward Island. Undated 100-2 Bloom-levels of learning Reference document on Bloom's Revised Taxonomy of cognitive learning levels. Presents six levels from lowest to… ▸ more
Reference document on Bloom's Revised Taxonomy of cognitive learning levels. Presents six levels from lowest to highest: Remembering (recalling previously learned information), Understanding (comprehending meaning and interpretation), Applying (using concepts in new situations), Analyzing (separating concepts into component parts), Evaluating (making judgments about value), and Creating (building structures from diverse elements). Each level includes descriptor and brief explanation of learning tasks involved. Represents educational reference material used in Education 20/20 work. - **Key People**: No specific individuals named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: NONE - Standard educational reference
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated 100-3 Rating writing Assessment rubric for evaluating written work using six-level scale. Level 1 (lowest): disorganized, unfocused, many… ▸ more
Assessment rubric for evaluating written work using six-level scale. Level 1 (lowest): disorganized, unfocused, many errors, limited vocabulary. Level 2: generally organized, limited vocabulary, significant errors. Level 3: organized with acceptable structure and grammar. Level 4: organized with few errors in grammar and sentence structure. Level 5: well organized, precise vocabulary, good sentence structure, some creativity. Level 6 (highest): creatively written while maintaining acceptable standards. Represents practical educational assessment tool used in teaching/learning evaluations. - **Key People**: No specific individuals named - **Key Organizations**: Education 20/20 - **Tags**: PROFESSIONAL, EDUCATION, TECHNICAL - **Eulogy Relevance**: NONE - Standard assessment tool

Duplicate/version of the Canadian Qualification Authority paper (D-8), proposing an independent qualification authority (AQUA) to assess and certify performance competencies. Undated 2-2-1-4 Qualifications Framework @2015-06-28T10;10;34 Highlight Argues for a Canadian Qualification Framework and independent authority modeled on international examples (UK,… ▸ more
Argues for a Canadian Qualification Framework and independent authority modeled on international examples (UK, Australia, New Zealand), emphasizing labour mobility and workforce development. Don positions Canada as lagging behind peer nations and calls for private-sector leadership if government will not act, citing Canada's successful apprenticeship model and proposing that qualification authorities assess individuals directly rather than institutions.

Foundational paper distinguishing credentials (awarded for completing courses) from qualifications (certifying competency to perform tasks). Don examines assessment functions (criticism, evaluation, ranking), labor mobility issues, and proposes an independent qualification authority (AQUA) to eliminate teacher-sorting conflicts and support lifelong learning, positioning it as central to educational system reform.

Undated 22 Alignment Don Glendenning authored an article on education system alignment, arguing that schools need periodic evaluation of… ▸ more
Don Glendenning authored an article on education system alignment, arguing that schools need periodic evaluation of outcomes, assessment criteria, instruction, and reporting to ensure they effectively prepare good citizens. Demonstrates his systems-thinking approach to education reform.

Defines key system elements including service providers (schools, colleges, universities), information and counselling services, community agencies, feedback mechanisms, funding structures, and governance. Emphasizes the need for independent information to enable sound decision-making for learners and parents.

Undated 48 Credenrials and qualifications-4 Distinguishes between credentials (documents indicating program completion) and qualifications (abilities to perform a… ▸ more
Distinguishes between credentials (documents indicating program completion) and qualifications (abilities to perform a role). Argues that schools award credentials but not qualifications, yet employers confuse the two, creating credential inflation. Proposes establishing an independent certification body separate from educational institutions to assess and verify qualifications, helping employers identify actual competencies.

Educational philosophy essay using metaphor of life as a road where travelers play six roles: individual, family member, citizen, student, consumer, and producer. Argues education as formative experience is most important factor determining quality of life, more so than schooling alone. Identifies issues arising from self, others, and circumstances; proposes support mechanisms and resource sources for helping people develop as fully functioning travelers on life's journey.

Undated A1 About Education@2016-01-01T17;46;24 Definitional essay establishing core educational terminology, addressing confusion in education discourse by… ▸ more
Definitional essay establishing core educational terminology, addressing confusion in education discourse by distinguishing education (formative experience affecting thinking, feeling, acting) from schooling (learning under teacher direction) and credentials. Argues education is broader than formal schooling, encompassing learning at home, church, community groups, and self-study; emphasizes that formal education represents just one sector of overall learning.

Undated Assessment@2014-10-06T00;56;57 Comprehensive analysis of credentials versus qualifications in education, distinguishing between ranking/sorting… ▸ more
Comprehensive analysis of credentials versus qualifications in education, distinguishing between ranking/sorting (credentials awarded by institutions) and performance capability (qualifications for task/role performance). Proposes establishing independent qualification authority (AQUA) modeled after sports coaching/refereeing separation to assess individual competency. References Wolff's framework of three assessment types: formative criticism, criterion-referenced evaluation, and competitive ranking.

Undated B1 Personal Framework-2 Highlight Comprehensive personal educational philosophy framework articulating definitions, operating beliefs, barriers, and… ▸ more
Comprehensive personal educational philosophy framework articulating definitions, operating beliefs, barriers, and change recommendations for PEI education system. Identifies fundamental organizational problems including lack of written philosophy, school system masquerading as education system, poor decision-making structures, and politicization. Proposes five major recommendations: develop compelling vision, implement learner-centered service model, establish government leadership role, delegate instruction provision, and create independent qualification body to certify achievement levels.

Educational policy paper proposing a pilot program to improve reading and communication skills using competency-based leveling rather than grade-based progression. Don critiques grade levels as poor indicators of actual learning and proposes organizing instruction by demonstrated proficiency levels, drawing on his observation of innovative English schooling practices and his educational philosophy emphasizing learner-centered, competency-driven approaches.

Policy paper proposing an independent mathematics proficiency certification service modeled on music conservatory examinations. Don argues that current school grading creates conflicts of interest and proposes separating assessment from instruction, allowing individuals of any age to be certified at proficiency levels rather than age-based grades—a concrete implementation of his broader educational philosophy.

Undated Proficiency levels Highlight Strategic paper proposing establishment of independent assessment services for certifying proficiency levels in… ▸ more
Strategic paper proposing establishment of independent assessment services for certifying proficiency levels in academic subjects. Don distinguishes three assessment purposes (formative, evaluative, and ranking), arguing that schools should focus on formative feedback while independent bodies handle evaluation and certification, mirroring how sports separate coaching from refereeing roles.
EDUCATION INSTITUTIONAL PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Standards@2015-12-21T19;30;40 An analytical exploration of educational standards that distinguishes between credentials (diplomas/degrees) and… ▸ more
An analytical exploration of educational standards that distinguishes between credentials (diplomas/degrees) and qualifications (demonstrated skills and competencies). Don argues that public confusion between these concepts generates complaints about school standards, advocating for separation of educational and certification functions. He proposes establishing an independent Qualification Authority (AQUA) to assess and certify competencies, allowing schools to focus purely on teaching while a separate body handles qualification assessment.
EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL REFERENCE
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated Time@2014-10-13T07;05;20 A critical analysis of how education systems misallocate learning time compared to service industries, arguing that… ▸ more
A critical analysis of how education systems misallocate learning time compared to service industries, arguing that schools determine time available rather than responding to learner needs. Don contrasts educational practices with other professions that estimate time required and deliver accordingly, highlighting that education's time-based, batch-processing model prevents students from finishing early or taking additional time when needed. He advocates for challenge exams and prior learning assessment to allow students flexible time options.

A detailed analysis of systemic issues in education covering mission and vision gaps, schooling delivery problems, and expectations of schools from multiple stakeholders. Don critiques the age-based versus needs-based system paradigm, advocates for professional autonomy, clear accountability structures, and decentralized decision-making with principals as educational leaders. This document exemplifies his comprehensive critique of educational systems and his vision for reform.

Advocates for schools to adjust controllable variables for educational improvement.

Undated D Faults in our grading system @2015-08-21T08;45;03 Don argues that grades constitute a fundamental conflict of interest when teachers assign them, since formative… ▸ more
Don argues that grades constitute a fundamental conflict of interest when teachers assign them, since formative assessment (diagnostic) and summative assessment (certifying) serve different purposes. He proposes independent bodies for establishing standards and certifying achievement, separating assessment from instruction.

Undated D Ready for School Don argues that early childhood development is critical, with families as first teachers. He proposes family-focused… ▸ more
Don argues that early childhood development is critical, with families as first teachers. He proposes family-focused educational services similar to medical advice for parents with young children. He challenges the focus on preparing children for school, arguing schools should instead adapt to serve children's developmental needs.

Undated D- Alternative to grades @2015-09-01T22;01;20 Don argues that traditional grade-level reporting is unreliable for measuring achievement since students within the… ▸ more
Don argues that traditional grade-level reporting is unreliable for measuring achievement since students within the same grade can vary by 4-8 grade levels in competence. He advocates for defining achievement levels independently of age, pointing to successful models in music conservatory and apprenticeship certification.

Don responds to a New Zealand Herald article about schools' expanding role as childcare during working hours, proposing that schools now have a three-part mandate: education for citizenship, workforce development, and child supervision. He suggests this expanded role should be formally included in PEI's educational philosophy.

CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D achieveement levels @2016-01-22T03;59;27 Don argues that the public school system's grading practices have become confusing and lack integrity, allowing… ▸ more
Don argues that the public school system's grading practices have become confusing and lack integrity, allowing students to graduate with high school diplomas without achieving grade 12 level work. He proposes adopting "level" terminology instead of "grade" to describe achievement, as used by International Baccalaureate, PISA, P-CAP, and qualification frameworks worldwide. This would allow students to progress through subjects at different achievement levels according to their mastery rather than age-based groupings.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Schoools Act @2016-05-06T03;21;07 Don critiques PEI's new Education Act as misnamed because it addresses schools rather than education broadly, and notes… ▸ more
Don critiques PEI's new Education Act as misnamed because it addresses schools rather than education broadly, and notes its definitions of teacher and principal rely on credentials rather than functional roles. He argues the Act overly centralizes decision-making with the Minister when research shows students perform better when schools have autonomy, and observes that restrictions on student exemptions and inappropriate course counseling undermine student motivation and system credibility.
ADMINISTRATIVE CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D Signs of an educational spring @2016-03-28T23;50;35 Don identifies five inexpensive indicators of educational progress: updated philosophy of education, community… ▸ more
Don identifies five inexpensive indicators of educational progress: updated philosophy of education, community participation in curriculum committees, departmental reorganization based on functional analysis, terminology change from grades to levels, and reinstatement of high school exemptions. He uses the metaphor of spring robins to suggest that even one change would signal new thinking, while three or four would indicate systemic transformation.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D- Choice Don argues that choice and autonomy are critical to well-being, yet school systems offer minimal choice compared to… ▸ more
Don argues that choice and autonomy are critical to well-being, yet school systems offer minimal choice compared to other services (doctors, lawyers, stores). He advocates for choice of both schools and individual teachers, noting that finding teachers suited to students' needs is as important as finding appropriate medical or legal professionals.

Don states public education has lost its way due to poor vision and outdated organizational models. He criticizes the Department of Public Instruction as focused on maintenance rather than innovation and strategy. He calls for new mental models of education and delivery systems that create conditions for learning rather than maintaining status quo.
CORRESPONDENCE EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL SPEECH
Read · Download
 Read · Download
Undated D-19 why government... Don questions whether government should directly operate schools, recounting a conversation where inadequate rationales… ▸ more
Don questions whether government should directly operate schools, recounting a conversation where inadequate rationales emerged (historical precedent, provincial reach, patronage). He contends governments should provide governance, financing, leadership, and information while being better served to delegate school operations, pointing to successful alternatives in higher education, private schools, and charter schools where students perform adequately.

Undated Notes based on Objectives proposed for new Non Profit Act (100-200 words):** Policy analysis notes on objectives for proposed non-profit legislation, likely PEI-focused.… ▸ more
(100-200 words):** Policy analysis notes on objectives for proposed non-profit legislation, likely PEI-focused. Document outlines six core objectives: (1) public education and policy advocacy through newsletters, websites, and papers; (2) monitoring education systems and analyzing compliance with research/best practices; (3) engaging parents and communities through workshops on essential skills, learning frameworks, and educational models; (4) supporting learner-centered activities; (5) professional development for educators; (6) organizational growth and sustainability. Detailed budget line items indicate Don's involvement in advocacy organization planning. Workshops mentioned suggest he envisioned Education 20/20 (referenced elsewhere in batch) as platform for community education. Notes reflect Don's philosophy of systematic public engagement, research-based advocacy, and educator professional development - core themes throughout his career.
EDUCATION
